ACKNOWLEDGMENTS

鸣谢

THIS BOOK CAME ABOUT in bouts and breaks over the course of a decade during which I accumulated many intellectual, personal, and material debts. Several institutions subsidized my research trips and leaves from teaching: in 2012–2013, the John Solomon Guggenheim Foundation; in fall 2012, the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton; in spring 2013, the American Academy in Berlin; and, on multiple occasions, the Provost’s Office, MacMillan Center, and Program in Economic History at Yale University. While I made extensive use of digitized rare books, I could not have completed my work without the extraordinary physical repositories on the Yale campus—the Beinecke Library, Sterling Memorial Library, and Lillian Goldman Law Library—and their extraordinary librarians, including Susanne Roberts, Kathryn James, and Michael Widener. I also availed myself of the special collections of the Bibliothèque Nationale in Paris, the Municipal Library in Bordeaux, the Staatsbibliothek in Berlin, and many other storehouses of knowledge across Europe. During the Australian winter of 2016, the Toorak/South Yarra Public Library in Melbourne gave me shelter during many a cold afternoon and reminded me of what we stand to lose when we defund public libraries.

本书是在十年间的阵痛和休息中产生的，在这期间我积累了许多知识、个人和物质上的债务。有几个机构资助了我的研究旅行和教学休假：2012-2013 年，约翰·所罗门·古根海姆基金会；2012 年秋季，普林斯顿高级研究所；2013 年春季，柏林美国学院；以及在多个场合，耶鲁大学的教务长办公室、麦克米伦中心和经济史项目。虽然我广泛使用了数字化的珍稀书籍，但如果没有耶鲁大学校园内非凡的实体图书馆 —— 贝内克图书馆、斯特林纪念图书馆和莉莲·戈德曼法律图书馆 —— 以及它们非凡的图书管理员，包括苏珊娜·罗伯茨、凯瑟琳·詹姆斯和迈克尔·维德纳，我不可能完成我的工作。我还利用了巴黎国家图书馆、波尔多市立图书馆、柏林国家图书馆以及欧洲其他许多知识仓库的特殊收藏。在 2016 年澳大利亚的冬天，墨尔本的 Toorak/South Yarra 公共图书馆在许多寒冷的下午为我提供了庇护，并提醒我，当我们取消公共图书馆的资金时，我们会失去什么。

A number of research assistants, many now scholars and writers in their own right, have helped me at various stages to track down, swiftly search through, and translate material in multiple languages: Cornelia Aust, Aner Barzilay, Veronica Aoki Santarosa, Yemile Bucay, Gijs Dielen, Amanda Gregg, Charlotte Kiechel, Annalena Müller, Jesse Sadler, Miriam Salzmann, Maximilian Scholz, and Tijl Vanneste.

一些研究助理，其中许多人现在是学者和作家，在不同阶段帮助我追踪、迅速搜索和翻译多种语言的材料：Cornelia Aust, Aner Barzilay, Veronica Aoki Santarosa, Yemile Bucay, Gijs Dielen, Amanda Gregg, Charlotte Kiechel, Annalena Müller, Jesse Sadler, Miriam Salzmann, Maximilian Scholz, and Tijl Vanneste.

I am especially indebted to the many friends, colleagues, and passing interlocutors who asked questions, offered suggestions, corrected mistakes, replied to my queries, or simply provided food for thought along the way. In 2010 Caroline Walker Bynum responded positively to a talk in which I sketched out this project before I really knew what it was about, and her reaction gave me the confidence to continue my work. Later, she also gave me the benefit of her insight into a pile of untidy pages. Others were equally generous in reading portions of the manuscript (often in undigested form): Jeremy Adelman, William Caferro, Guillaume Calafat, Giovanni Ceccarelli, Simona Cerutti, Lauren Clay, David Garrioch, Oscar Gelderblom, Lynn Hunt, Ari Joskowicz, Naomi Lamoreaux, Sarah Lipton, Nadia Mantrige, Sarah Maza, Avinoam Naeh, Stefania Pastore, Derek Penslar, Sophia Rosenfeld, Maurice Samuels, Andrew Sartori, Roberto Savelli, Robert Schneider, Silvia Sebastiani, Kenneth Stow, Giacomo Todeschini, and Carl Wennerlind. Maxine Berg and two anonymous reviewers commented on the penultimate version of the book for the press and suggested ways of improving it.

我尤其要感谢许多朋友、同事和路过的对话者，他们提出问题，提供建议，纠正错误，回答我的疑问，或者只是在一路上提供思考的素材。2010 年，卡罗琳·沃克·拜纳姆对我的一次谈话做出了积极回应，在那次谈话中，我在真正了解这个项目之前就已经勾勒出了它的轮廓，她的反应给了我继续工作的信心。后来，她还让我受益于她对一堆乱七八糟的页面的洞察力 。其他人也同样慷慨地阅读了部分手稿（往往是未消化的形式）：Jeremy Adelman, William Caferro, Guillaume Calafat, Giovanni Ceccarelli, Simona Cerutti, Lauren Clay, David Garrioch, Oscar Gelderblom, Lynn Hunt, Ari Joskowicz, Naomi Lamoreaux, Sarah Lipton, Nadia Mantrige,Sarah Maza, Avinoam Naeh, Stefania Pastore, Derek Penslar, Sophia Rosenfeld, Maurice Samuels, Andrew Sartori, Roberto Savelli, Robert Schneider, Silvia Sebastiani, Kenneth Stow, Giacomo Todeschini, and Carl Wennerlind。Maxine Berg 和两位匿名审稿人对该书的倒数第二版进行了评论，并提出了改进意见。

I also wish to acknowledge the exceptional group of women and academics with whom I have shared work in progress on a few treasured occasions over the past several years: Amanda Claybaugh, Patricia Crain, Diana Fuss, Martha Howell, Heather Love, Sharon Marcus, and Judith Walkowitz. They have asked probing questions, put up with my clunky prose, and inspired me with their writing and their example.

我还要感谢一群杰出的妇女和学者，在过去几年中，我曾在一些珍贵的场合与她们分享正在进行的工作。阿曼达·克莱鲍（Amanda Claybaugh）、帕特里夏·克莱恩（Patricia Crain）、戴安娜·福斯（Diana Fuss）、玛莎·豪威尔（Martha Howell）、希瑟·洛夫（Heather Love）、莎朗·马库斯（Sharon Marcus）和朱迪斯·沃科维茨（Judith Walkowitz）。他们提出了一些具有探究性的问题，忍受了我笨拙的散文，并以他们的写作和他们的榜样激励我。

Segments of the book have appeared in print in earlier incarnations: portions of chapters 1 through 3 were published in the Journal of Modern History (2011) and Archives Juives (2015), sections of chapter 4 in Law and History Review (2015) and Tijdschrift voor Rechtsgeschiedenis / Revue d’histoire du droit / Legal History Review (2015), and a version of chapter 6 in French Historical Studies (2016). The readers and editors for those articles improved the project when I most needed advice.

本书的部分内容已在早期的出版物中出现：第 1至3章的部分内容发表在《现代史杂志》（2011）和《档案》（2015），第4 章的部分内容发表在《法律与历史评论》（2015）和《法律史评论》（2015），第6 章的一个版本发表在《法国历史研究》（2016）。这些文章的读者和编辑在我最需要建议的时候改进了这个项目。

At Princeton University Press, Brigitta van Rheinberg and her staff, including her former assistant Amanda Peery, executive editor and editorial director for the humanities Eric Crahan, and senior production editor Leslie Grundfest, were a dream team. Sarah Vogelsong worked tirelessly to copyedit the manuscript, and David Luljak compiled the index. Their kindess and professionalism made all the difference. Brett Savage, academic assistant in the School of Historical Studies at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, lent me his sharp eye while I was reviewing the proofs. Naturally, all errors are mine.

在普林斯顿大学出版社，Brigitta van Rheinberg 和她的工作人员，包括她的前助理 Amanda Peery、执行编辑和人文学科编辑主任 Eric Crahan 以及高级制作编辑 Leslie Grundfest，是一个梦幻团队。Sarah Vogelsong 不知疲倦地编辑手稿，David Luljak 编撰索引。他们的仁慈和专业精神使一切变得不同。普林斯顿高等研究院历史研究学院的学术助理布雷特·萨维奇（Brett Savage）在我审阅校对时借给了我他敏锐的眼光。自然，所有的错误都是我的。

Once again, I owe more to Carolyn Dean than to anyone else.

再一次，我对卡罗琳·迪恩的感激之情超过了其他人。

PREFACE

序言

IT WOULD BE MISLEADING to say that this book “found me.” But the impetus behind it came as much from what was happening around me as from my academic interests. In September 2008 an endless stream of breaking news relayed bleaker and bleaker economic reports on the future of millions of ordinary people. Lehman Brothers collapsed. Home foreclosures became a daily event. Talk of greed resurfaced in public conversation. Even usury and usurious , words that I had not heard uttered outside of the classroom, reentered everyday vocabulary, alongside loan shark and pawnbroker . As financial mogul John Alfred Paulson admitted in April 2010, “We believed that the two-year adjustable rate mortgages made to lower income borrowers with poor credit history, little or no documentation, no downpayment and rates that would shortly reset at usurious interest rates set the stage for significant delinquencies and foreclosures, thus eroding the value of these securities.”1

如果说这本书是 “找到我” 的，那是误导性的。但它背后的动力既来自于我周围发生的事情，也来自于我的学术兴趣。2008 年 9 月，源源不断的突发新闻对数以百万计的普通人的未来转达了越来越暗淡的经济报告。雷曼兄弟公司倒闭了。房屋取消赎回权成为每天都在发生的事情。贪婪的话题再次出现在公众谈话中。甚至高利贷（usury）和高利贷的（usurious），这些我在课堂之外没有听说过的词，也重新进入了日常词汇，与放高利贷者（loan shark）和典当行（pawnbroker）一起。正如金融大亨约翰·阿尔弗雷德·保尔森在 2010 年 4 月承认的那样，“我们认为，向信用记录差、很少或没有文件、没有首付的低收入借款人提供的两年期可调利率抵押贷款，以及不久将以高利贷的利率重置的利率，为大量拖欠和取消赎回权创造了条件，从而侵蚀了这些证券的价值。”1

As a citizen, I was angry and anguished. As a historian of early modern European market organization and market culture, I was intrigued and felt slightly vindicated. Since the fall of the Berlin Wall, scholarly interest in the slow-paced economies of the preindustrial period had waned, and faith in the upward trajectory of modern financial capitalism had become nearly gospel. Now, it seemed, we were back to square one. No easy solution was in sight. In fact, the daily reports did not seem much clearer than seventeenth-century merchant manuals, which were filled with advice on how to make money as well as warnings against avarice and shady dealers.

作为一个公民，我感到愤怒和苦恼。作为一个研究早期现代欧洲市场组织和市场文化的历史学家，我感到好奇，并略微感觉到平反。自柏林墙倒塌以来，学者们对前工业时期的慢节奏经济的兴趣已经减弱，而对现代金融资本主义的上升轨道的信心几乎成为福音。现在，我们似乎又回到了原点。没有看到任何简单的解决方案。事实上，每天的报告似乎并不比 17 世纪的商人手册清晰多少，其中充满了关于如何赚钱的建议，以及对贪婪和黑心商人的警告。

While the global financial system stood on the brink of collapse after years of speculative frenzy, an old excerpt from Warren Buffett’s 2002 annual letter to Berkshire Hathaway shareholders resurfaced and went viral. Sounding like Cassandra amid a cheerful crowd of Wall Street investors, Buffett had described credit default swaps as “financial weapons of mass destruction” carrying “dangers that, while now latent, are potentially lethal.”2 The statement remains controversial. Not everyone agrees with Buffett’s judgment, and this skepticism affects the work of government and private agencies charged with regulating the industry to this day. What is remarkable about Buffett’s warning is that the man who offered it was not a fierce opponent of corporate finance or a future leader of the Occupy Wall Street movement, but the richest man in the world at the time of its writing.

当全球金融系统在多年的投机狂热之后站在崩溃的边缘时，沃伦·巴菲特 2002 年致伯克希尔·哈撒韦公司股东的年度信件中的一段旧摘录再次出现并被传开。在华尔街投资者的欢呼声中，巴菲特像卡桑德拉一样，将信用违约掉期描述为 “大规模杀伤性的金融武器”，带有 “虽然现在是潜在的危险，但却是潜在的致命危险”。2这一说法仍有争议。并非所有人都同意巴菲特的判断，这种怀疑态度至今仍影响着负责监管该行业的政府和私人机构的工作。巴菲特的警告的难能可贵之处在于，提出这一警告的人不是公司金融的激烈反对者，也不是未来占领华尔街运动的领导人，而是在写这篇文章时世界上最富有的人。

I mention these recent events not to suggest that we can link today’s rapid “financialization” to earlier transformations of Europe’s economy in simple terms, but to point out that even those who believe in the positive effects of expanding private and public credit, now as in the past, cannot easily agree on where to draw the boundaries of that expansion and what kind of oversight might best prevent fraud and the emergence of oligopolies. The Promise and Peril of Credit examines key episodes in the West’s millennium-long struggle to delineate the place that finance ought to occupy in the social and political order. It does so by introducing readers to modes of thinking about the morality of credit that have become increasingly alien to us even as the questions that animated those early modern discussions remain as vital now as they were then.

我提到这些最近发生的事件，并不是说我们可以把今天的快速 “金融化” 与欧洲经济的早期转型简单地联系起来，而是要指出，即使那些相信扩大私人和公共信贷的积极影响的人，现在和过去一样，也不能轻易地就如何划定这种扩张的界限以及什么样的监督可以最好地防止欺诈和寡头垄断的出现达成一致。《信贷的承诺与危险》研究了西方千年来为确定金融在社会和政治秩序中应占据的位置而进行的斗争中的关键事件。为此，它向读者介绍了关于信贷道德的思考模式，这些模式对我们来说已经变得越来越陌生，即使那些激发了早期现代讨论的问题现在仍然和当时一样重要。

After decades of retreat from the mainstream, economic history is making its way back to college curricula and scholarly publications. Today as always, present concerns stimulate academics’ choice of subject matter and approaches to historical inquiry. Income and wealth inequality, the connection between slavery and capitalist modes of production and consumption, the impact of cultural traditions on economic performance, and the timing and consequences of globalization top the list of current research topics pursued by economic historians of various persuasions. A sense of urgency infuses this research—a welcome and energizing change after decades during which North American history departments’ interest in economic history lay dormant. However, one should not forget that each of these themes has its own long and distinguished scholarly pedigree; nor should we risk falling into the old trap of searching for the origins of contemporary phenomena—Marc Bloch’s “idol.”3 While I readily admit, and indeed embrace, the influence that present concerns exert on my scholarly work, my aim in this book is to bring back to life ways of thinking about the economy that have become increasingly foreign to the mainstream of the academy and to interrogate the sources of our amnesia about topics and problems that not long ago occupied a central place in debates about the development of European capitalism.4

在从主流中退缩了几十年之后，经济史正在重新回到大学课程和学术出版物中。今天，像往常一样，当前的关切刺激着学者们对历史调查的主题和方法的选择。收入和财富的不平等，奴隶制与资本主义生产和消费模式之间的联系，文化传统对经济表现的影响，以及全球化的时机和后果，这些都是不同观点的经济史学家所追求的当前研究课题的清单。这种研究充满了紧迫感 —— 在北美历史系对经济史的兴趣沉寂了几十年之后，这种变化令人欣喜，令人振奋。然而，我们不应忘记，这些主题中的每一个都有自己悠久而杰出的学术渊源；我们也不应冒险落入寻找当代现象的起源的老陷阱 —— 马克·布洛赫的 “偶像”。3虽然我欣然承认，并确实接受了目前的关注对我的学术工作所产生的影响，但我在本书中的目的是让那些对学术界主流越来越陌生的经济思考方式重新焕发活力，并对我们对不久前在有关欧洲资本主义发展的辩论中占据核心地位的主题和问题失忆的根源进行审问。4

In Anglophone historiography in particular, the demotion of the preindustrial period to second-rank importance in examinations of Europe’s economic takeoff has often been compounded by the enduring legacy of the Protestant Black Legend, according to which Catholic societies after the Reformation eschewed profit and indulged in idleness. This twin tendency has affected even serious scholarship and detracted from the study of economic transformations in Catholic Europe from the medieval commercial revolution to the industrial revolution. To be sure, one can always find staunch enemies of all forms of commercialization among Catholic authors, but more interesting—and, by the sixteenth century, often more influential—were those theologians, lawyers, judges, philosophers, statesmen, merchants turned writers, and polymaths who did not oppose financial dealings as such but disagreed on the written and unwritten rules that ought to govern the marketplace for the benefit of Christian and polite commercial society.

特别是在英语国家的历史学中，在对欧洲经济腾飞的研究中，前工业时期的重要性被降至次要地位，这往往被新教《黑色传说》的持久遗产所加剧，根据该传说，宗教改革后的天主教社会摒弃了利润，沉溺于闲散。这种双重倾向甚至影响了严肃的学术研究，并减损了对天主教欧洲从中世纪商业革命到工业革命的经济转型的研究。可以肯定的是，人们总能在天主教作者中找到所有形式的商业化的坚定敌人，但更有趣的是 —— 到了 16 世纪，往往更有影响力 —— 是那些神学家、律师、法官、哲学家、政治家、商人、作家和多面手，他们并不反对金融交易本身，但对为了基督教和有礼貌的商业社会的利益应管理市场的书面和非书面规则有分歧。

Credit was central to those intellectual debates. Derived from the Latin verb credere , “to believe” and “to trust,” the noun credit and its cognates during this period had economic, legal, political, social, and cultural connotations. Used less frequently, finance referred primarily to government finances. The more capacious and common commerce was adopted by early modern commentators not only in reference to the activities of retail and wholesale merchants, but also to describe the economic policies governing those activities. But commerce had even wider meanings that transcended the economic realm. In the Italian city-states of the fifteenth century, the Latin word commercium denoted the material transactions conducted for the purpose of earthly gain and gratification, but it was used just as often in reference to the relationship between believers and the divine, the exchange of ideas among humanists, the social bonds linking all humans (or at least those men who saw each other as peers), and even prostitution (carnal commerce). Although the word commerce had a somewhat narrower meaning by the eighteenth century, it continued to be applied to the entire gamut of human activities and beliefs. It follows that technical disquisitions about credit instruments, and what might make them go astray, were never abstracted from moral, political, and social considerations.

信用是这些知识辩论的核心。名词 “信用”（credere）源自拉丁语动词 “相信” 和 “信任”，这一时期的信用及其同义词具有经济、法律、政治、社会和文化方面的含义。金融不太经常使用，主要指政府财政。现代早期的评论家们采用了更为宽泛和常见的商业，不仅指零售和批发商人的活动，而且还描述管理这些活动的经济政策。但是，商业具有超越经济领域的更广泛含义。在 15 世纪的意大利城邦中，拉丁语的 commercium 一词表示为了世俗的利益和满足而进行的物质交易，但它也经常被用来指称信徒与神的关系、人文主义者之间的思想交流、连接所有人类的社会纽带（或至少是那些把对方视为同行的人），甚至是卖淫（肉体交易）。尽管到了十八世纪，商业这个词的含义有所收窄，但它仍然被应用于人类活动和信仰的全部范围内。由此可见，关于信用工具的技术探讨，以及什么会使它们误入歧途，从来没有从道德、政治和社会考虑中抽象出来。

Thus framed, the subject of my inquiry would be boundless, since the search for a well-tempered commercial society was at the heart of too many consequential intellectual and political projects in preindustrial Europe to be examined in any depth in a single study. In this book, I turn to one little-known but revealing chapter in these heated debates about the morality of credit: a narrative that for a good 250 years, from the mid-seventeenth to the early twentieth century, attributed to medieval Jews the invention of marine insurance and bills of exchange, two key instruments of European private finance. There is no truth to this tale, since both financial tools emerged slowly out of previous arrangements, and Jews had no special role in the process, yet it proved surprisingly resilient—which is why I believe it warrants the designation of legend . Over time, this unfounded and today largely forgotten origin story punctuated many and varied literatures about commerce. By working with and around this narrative about Jews and credit, I discuss how numerous Christian authors—some famous, some fallen into oblivion—articulated their vision for a morally acceptable and productive commercial society.

这样一来，我的调查主题将是无止境的，因为在前工业化的欧洲，寻求一个有节制的商业社会是太多有影响的知识和政治项目的核心，在一项研究中无法深入研究。在这本书中，我转向这些关于信贷道德的激烈辩论中一个鲜为人知但具有启发性的章节：从十七世纪中叶到二十世纪初的 250 年中，有一种说法将海事保险和汇票的发明归功于中世纪的犹太人，这是欧洲私人金融的两个关键工具。这个故事并不真实，因为这两种金融工具都是在以前的安排当中缓慢浮现的，犹太人在这个过程中没有任何特殊的作用，但事实证明它具有惊人的生命力 —— 这就是为什么我认为它值得被称为传奇的原因。随着时间的推移，这个毫无根据的、今天基本上被遗忘的起源故事成为许多关于商业的不同文学作品的亮点。通过对这个关于犹太人和信用的叙述，我讨论了许多基督教作者 —— 有些很有名，有些已经被遗忘 —— 是如何阐述他们对一个道德上可接受的、富有成效的商业社会的看法。

I take representations of Jews’ economic roles to be symptomatic of larger claims: implicitly or explicitly, they conveyed hard-to-define ideals of a Christian-inflected marketplace rather than describing the actual involvement of Jews in the economy. This approach has been adopted almost exclusively in reference to the Middle Ages because of the widely held assumption that in the mid-seventeenth century, the “science of commerce” began to shed its religious concerns about merchants’ moral integrity.5 Here, I show instead that late medieval representations of Jews and their alleged modes of handling credit, recast in new guises at various junctions, continued to be central to the definition of European commercial society through the French Revolution and that the founders of modern social thought—Karl Marx, Max Weber, and Werner Sombart—incorporated these representations of medieval Jews’ economic roles into their grand narratives.

我认为对犹太人经济角色的表述是更大的诉求的表征：或隐或显地，它们传达了难以界定的、受基督教影响的市场的理想，而不是描述犹太人在经济中的实际参与。这种方法几乎只在提到中世纪时被采用，因为人们普遍认为在十七世纪中期，“商业科学” 开始摆脱对商人道德操守的宗教关注。5在这里，我反而表明，中世纪晚期对犹太人的描述以及他们所谓的处理信贷的模式，在不同的节点上以新的面貌重塑，在法国大革命之前一直是欧洲商业社会定义的核心，现代社会思想的创始人 —— 卡尔·马克思、马克斯·韦伯和维尔纳·桑巴特 —— 将这些对中世纪犹太人的经济角色的描述纳入了他们的宏大叙事。

In the pages that follow, readers will encounter familiar names and famous moments in European history, such as those I just mentioned, but will also be introduced to a host of unknown figures and unpredictable connections across themes and periods. In trying to make sense of fragments of the past that our blind spots have led us to neglect, I weave together strains of scholarship that have been growing further and further apart. That is why this book does not fall squarely into any single field of historical inquiry but is rather an exercise in demonstrating the potential (and, no doubt, the pitfalls) of roaming across times and places, blending economic and religious history, approaching the history of economic thought from new angles, and integrating Jewish history more fully into the narrative of Europe’s past.

在接下来的篇幅中，读者会遇到欧洲历史上熟悉的名字和著名的时刻，比如我刚才提到的那些，但也会被介绍给许多不知名的人物和跨主题、跨时期的不可预知的联系。在试图弄清我们的盲点导致我们忽视的过去的碎片时，我把已经越来越远的学术流派编织在一起。这就是为什么这本书并不完全属于任何单一的历史调查领域，而是在展示跨越时间和地点的漫游、融合经济和宗教历史、从新的角度接近经济思想史以及将犹太历史更充分地融入欧洲历史叙事中的潜力（以及毫无疑问的陷阱）的练习。

In piecing together the traces left by the legend that attributed to medieval Jews a foundational role in the creation of modern private finance, my ultimate aim is to demonstrate that throughout European history, debates about the market’s reach have been inseparable from the construction of legal and symbolic hierarchies of inclusion and exclusion. The impersonality of the market is a recent ideal and remains an elusive reality.

在拼凑将中世纪犹太人在创造现代私人金融中的基础作用归功于中世纪犹太人的传说所留下的痕迹时，我的最终目的是要证明，在整个欧洲历史上，关于市场范围的辩论与包容和排斥的法律和象征性等级的构建是密不可分的。市场的非人格化是最近的理想，仍然是一个难以捉摸的现实。

THE PROMISE AND PERIL OF CREDIT

信用的承诺和危险

Introduction

简介

FEW TODAY KNOW WHAT bills of exchange are or how they worked. But from the sixteenth through much of the nineteenth century, bills of exchange were ubiquitous across Europe. Around 1615, an English traveler visiting Venice counseled those interested in following his itinerary on how to obtain ready cash in local currency: “Returne thy money in England by bill of exchange that thou maiest receive it againe in Venice.”1 So many used these bills as remittances that they soon acquired metaphorical meanings. An Anglican preacher, for example, declared, “Our prayers are our bills of exchange; and they are allowed in Heaven, when they come from pious and humble hearts: But if wee bee broken in our religion, and bankrouts of grace, God will protest our bills, hee will not bee wonne with our prayers.”2 A century later, in the mid-eighteenth century, this system of payment fueled the darkest side of the booming Atlantic trade: the majority of slave cargoes in the British Caribbean were sold for bills of exchange redeemable in London.3

今天很少有人知道汇票（bills of exchange）是什么，也不知道它们是如何运作的。但从 16 世纪到 19 世纪的大部分时间，汇票在整个欧洲无处不在。1615 年左右，一位访问威尼斯的英国旅行者向那些有兴趣跟随他的行程的人建议如何获得当地货币的现钞。“用汇票把你在英国的钱还给你，这样你就可以在威尼斯再次收到它。”1如此多的人使用这些票据作为汇款，它们很快就获得了隐喻的含义。例如，一位英国圣公会的传教士宣称：“我们的祈祷是我们的汇票；当它们来自虔诚和谦逊的心时，它们在天堂是被允许的。但是，如果我们的宗教信仰破灭了，恩典破灭了，上帝会抗议我们的票据，我们无法用它来赢得上帝。”2一个世纪后，在十八世纪中叶，这种支付系统助长了蓬勃发展的大西洋贸易中最黑暗的一面：英国加勒比海地区的大多数奴隶货物是以可在伦敦赎回的汇票出售的。3

Credit default swaps, an innovation of the 1990s and the target of Buffett’s censure, are only the latest creation of financial engineering, developed in order to facilitate both risk management and speculation. The rate of innovation in the financial sector of preindustrial Europe was slower than that seen today, but not imperceptible. Between 1250 and 1650, bills of exchange introduced considerable novelties, which is why they once were a venerable topic in economic and legal history. In those centuries, they boosted long-distance trade and international finance, and they remained the lifeblood of European and colonial commerce even after corporate stocks began to be sold in Amsterdam and London in the early seventeenth century. During the period of their use, bills of exchange garnered considerable attention among enthusiasts and critics alike, not only for their ability to move and generate wealth in seemingly mysterious ways, but also for their potential to trick naïve investors. As such, they epitomized the promise and the peril of early modern commercial credit.

信用违约掉期是 20 世纪 90 年代的一项创新，也是巴菲特指责的对象，它只是金融工程的最新创造，是为了促进风险管理和投机而开发的。前工业时代的欧洲金融部门的创新速度比今天要慢，但并不是不明显。在 1250 年和 1650 年之间，汇票引入了相当多的新事物，这就是为什么它们曾经是经济和法律史上一个令人敬畏的话题。在那几个世纪里，它们促进了长途贸易和国际金融，即使在十七世纪初阿姆斯特丹和伦敦开始出售公司股票后，它们仍然是欧洲和殖民地商业的命脉。在使用期间，汇票在爱好者和批评者中获得了相当大的关注，不仅因为它们能够以看似神秘的方式移动和创造财富，而且还因为它们有可能欺骗天真的投资者。因此，它们是现代早期商业信贷的承诺和危险的缩影。

What was so admirable and yet controversial about bills of exchange? Almost everything, especially in the eyes of the inexperienced. Materially, these bills (from the Latin word for “letter,” bulla ) were slips of paper, smaller than today’s personal checks, on which someone who was legally or socially recognized as a merchant scribbled a few coded words before adding his (or, more rarely, her) signature. With these coded words, he ordered his agent to pay a specified amount, in a set currency and at a set date, to a third party. The original and principal function of bills of exchange was to transfer funds to distant locations where they could be redeemed in local currency and thus used to purchase goods or pay down a debt. They offered merchants a safe alternative to the transport of minted coins, protecting their wealth from pirates, corrupt customs guards, storms, and landslides. Over time, bills of exchange also came to be used for purely speculative purposes. Experienced and savvy bankers could buy and sell these instruments without any intent of acquiring merchandise but merely to profit from fluctuating currency exchange rates. In this respect they signaled private finance’s incipient autonomy from commodity trade.

汇票有什么令人钦佩但又有争议的地方呢？几乎是一切，特别是在没有经验的人眼中。从实质上讲，这些票据（来自拉丁语中的 “信”，bulla）是一张纸条，比今天的个人支票要小，被法律或社会承认为商人的人在上面潦草地写下几个密码字，然后再加上他（或更罕见的是她）的签名。通过这些编码词，他命令他的代理人在规定的日期以规定的货币向第三方支付特定的金额。汇票的最初和主要功能是将资金转移到遥远的地方，在那里可以用当地货币兑换，从而用于购买商品或偿还债务。它们为商人提供了一个比运输铸币更安全的选择，保护他们的财富不受海盗、腐败的海关卫兵、风暴和山崩的影响。随着时间的推移，汇票也开始被用于纯粹的投机目的。有经验和精明的银行家可以购买和出售这些票据，而不打算购买商品，只是为了从货币汇率的波动中获利。在这方面，它们标志着私人金融开始从商品贸易中自主出来。

Bills of exchange were the invisible currency of early modern Europe’s “international republic of money.”4 No formal membership was needed to join this commonwealth, which was made up of merchants who cooperated and competed with one another, spoke different languages, and hailed from different regions. A mixture of informal oversight and legal sanctions held this commonwealth together, and after the sixteenth century its boundaries expanded in conjunction with Europe’s first period of sustained economic growth since the Black Death and the aggressive overseas expansion that accompanied it. What assured the circulation of bills of exchange among the members of this amorphous republic of money, as an eighteenth-century jurist noted, was “a merchant’s reputation, the extent and solidity of his business, the wisdom of the banker ensuring the creditworthiness of those letters.”5 Given how little public information about the assets of private merchants was then available, anyone engaging in transactions involving these bills depended first and foremost on channels of epistolary communication, occasional informers, relatives, and distant friends. A commercial bank chartered in Vienna in 1787 demanded that Greek merchants provide three sound trading houses as guarantors if they wished to cash a second bill of exchange—a measure of the bank’s difficulty in ascertaining the solvency of its clients.6

汇票是现代早期欧洲的 “国际货币共和国” 的无形货币。4加入这个共同体不需要正式的成员资格，它是由相互合作和竞争的商人组成的，他们讲不同的语言，来自不同的地区。非正式的监督和法律制裁的混合体将这个共同体维系在一起，16 世纪后，随着欧洲自黑死病以来的第一个持续经济增长期以及伴随着黑死病而来的积极的海外扩张，其边界也随之扩大。正如一位十八世纪的法学家所指出的那样，是什么保证了汇票在这个无定形的货币共和国成员之间的流通，是 “商人的声誉，他的业务范围和稳固性，银行家的智慧，确保这些信件的信用”。5鉴于当时关于私人商人资产的公共信息非常少，任何从事涉及这些票据的交易的人都首先依赖于书信沟通渠道、偶尔的线人、亲戚和远方的朋友。1787 年在维也纳特许经营的一家商业银行要求希腊商人提供三家健全的贸易公司作为担保人，，如果他们希望兑现第二张汇票的话 —— 这表明该银行很难确定其客户的偿付能力。6

By the time their invention was attributed to Jews, bills of exchange were frequently endorsed and passed on from one holder to another. Consequently, they were often confused with money. However, unlike commodity money or minted coins, bills of exchange had no intrinsic value. Unlike paper money designated as legal tender (whether backed by precious metals or land or, more rarely in the early modern period, issued as fiat money), they were secured not by sovereign authorities but solely by the individuals who signed them. While a state that accepts paper money as a form of tax payment can oblige taxpayers to use that same paper money in their private transactions, the circulation of bills of exchange was entirely voluntary, and a merchant retained the right to refuse to pay a bill drawn on his name.

当汇票被认为是犹太人发明的时候，汇票经常被背书并从一个持有人传给另一个持有人。因此，它们经常被与货币混淆。然而，与商品货币或铸币不同，汇票没有内在的价值。与被指定为法定货币的纸币不同（无论是由贵金属或土地支持，还是在现代早期更少见的作为法定货币发行），它们不是由主权当局，而只是由签署它们的个人来担保。虽然一个接受纸币作为纳税形式的国家可以强迫纳税人在他们的私人交易中使用同样的纸币，但汇票的流通完全是自愿的，商人保留了拒绝支付以其名义开出的账单的权利。

Naturally, bills of exchange had multiple connections to public finance. State agents, such as tax collectors or army suppliers, used them regularly to move funds from one region to another. More importantly, variations in currency exchange rates depended on the bullion reserves in the region, which in turn depended to a significant extent on a state’s monetary and trade policy (although private merchants themselves sometimes moved bullion from one location to another in order to alter exchange rates). But unlike state bonds, annuities, and the stocks that financed chartered corporations, bills of exchange were primarily an instrument of private finance, and to study them challenges the conventional nexus drawn by historians between money and sovereignty.

当然，汇票与公共财政有多种联系。国家代理人，如征税人或军队供应商，经常使用它们将资金从一个地区转移到另一个地区。更重要的是，货币汇率的变化取决于该地区的金银储备，而金银储备又在很大程度上取决于一个国家的货币和贸易政策（尽管私人商人自己有时会把金银从一个地方转移到另一个地方，以改变汇率）。但是，与国家债券、年金和为特许公司提供资金的股票不同，汇票主要是一种私人融资工具，研究它们挑战了历史学家在货币和主权之间的传统联系。

The usefulness of bills of exchange was matched only by their opacity. This combination ensured that they came to symbolize what was most appealing and most anxiety generating about private credit. By moving funds in invisible ways across mountains and oceans, bills of exchange functioned as the lubricant of the “reciprocal commerce” celebrated by many Enlightenment thinkers. At the same time, the lack of transparency with which they fulfilled their functions caused many to worry that cliques of traders possessed undue advantages over others. Moreover, by abstracting value from any tangible referent, bills of exchange amplified widespread fears about social disintegration and the erosion of traditional hierarchies that accompanied the expansion of commerce.

汇票的有用性只与它们的不透明性相匹配。这种结合确保了它们象征着私人信贷中最吸引人和最令人焦虑的东西。通过以无形的方式跨越山脉和海洋转移资金，汇票成为许多启蒙思想家所称颂的 “互惠商业” 的润滑剂。同时，由于汇票在履行其职能时缺乏透明度，许多人担心交易商的小团体会对其他人拥有不正当的优势。此外，由于将价值从任何有形的参照物中抽象出来，汇票扩大了人们对社会解体和传统等级制度的侵蚀的普遍担忧，而这种担忧伴随着商业的扩张。

Ultimately, bills of exchange represented the ability of merchants to regulate their own activity. Adam Smith regarded this self-regulation as beneficial to society at large, but he was neither the first nor the last to address the topic. This book examines some of the strongest reactions that bills of exchange, as emblems of merchants’ self-regulation, generated among the learned public. It focuses on the metaphorical associations between these bills and Jews because this connection was frequently drawn in expressions of suspicion about the growing expansion and autonomy of private finance in early modern Europe.

归根结底，汇票代表了商人规范自己活动的能力。亚当·斯密认为这种自我调节对整个社会是有益的，但他既不是第一个也不是最后一个讨论这个问题的人。本书研究了汇票作为商人自律的象征在有学识的公众中产生的一些最强烈的反应。它侧重于这些票据和犹太人之间的隐喻性联系，因为这种联系经常被用于表达对现代早期欧洲私人金融日益扩张和自主的怀疑。

Starting in the mid-seventeenth century, a number of authors, first in France and then across Europe, maintained that those Jews who had been expelled from the kingdom of France at various points in time between the seventh and fourteenth centuries had devised bills of exchange in order to evade the confiscation of their properties and to smuggle their wealth abroad. The guile of Jews and the resourcefulness of fugitives in general were the two lessons most commonly extracted from this narrative. From Old Regime France, the legend attributing to medieval Jews the invention of bills of exchange spread widely, with echoes heard as far as Brazil and Russia. Subsequently it was resurrected in the nineteenth century, when it informed some of the most influential narratives about the so-called Rise of the West and provoked harsh reactions among scholars of the Middle Ages during the interwar period.

从十七世纪中叶开始，一些作者，首先是法国的作者，然后是整个欧洲的作者，认为那些在七世纪到十四世纪的不同时期被驱逐出法兰西王国的犹太人设计了汇票，以逃避对其财产的没收并将其财富偷运到国外。犹太人的狡猾和一般逃亡者的机智是最常从这个叙述中提取的两个教训。从旧制度下的法国开始，将汇票的发明归功于中世纪犹太人的传说广泛传播，其回声远至巴西和俄罗斯。随后，它在 19 世纪又被复活了，当时它为一些关于所谓西方崛起的最有影响力的叙述提供了信息，并在战时的中世纪学者中引起了激烈的反应。

Today, one is hard-pressed to find anyone who recognizes the existence (let alone deciphers the meaning) of this tale of origins, both within and beyond academia. I know of only one recent attempt to interrogate its significance: an article published in Hebrew in 2004 by Benjamin Arbel. The article’s chief goal is to set the record straight and dispel any residual claim that Jews possessed superior financial prowess, although in the process Arbel unearths important and little-known facts about Jews’ handling of bills of exchange in the sixteenth-century Mediterranean.7

今天，在学术界内外，人们很难找到承认这个起源故事的存在（更不用说解读其意义）的人了。据我所知，最近只有一次尝试质疑它的意义：本杰明·阿贝尔（Benjamin Arbel）于 2004 年用希伯来文发表的一篇文章。这篇文章的主要目标是澄清事实，消除任何关于犹太人拥有卓越财务能力的残余说法，尽管在这个过程中，阿贝尔发现了关于犹太人在十六世纪地中海地区处理汇票的重要而鲜为人知的事实。7

My goal is different. Of course, I stress the lack of any empirical basis for the legend that pointed to Jews as the originators of European financial development. I insist, however, on treating the legend for what it is: a legend. I reconstruct the aspirations and collective fears of those who invoked it, the reasoning of those who contested it, and the agenda of those who reassembled its moving parts into ever more variations on a theme. In so doing, I map changing and conflicting attitudes toward commercial credit and discuss why Jews, who in the legend are figments of the Christian imagination, provided a broad spectrum of tropes through which those attitudes could be articulated.

我的目标是不同的。当然，我强调，指出犹太人是欧洲金融发展的始作俑者的传说缺乏任何经验基础。然而，我坚持把这个传说当作它原本应该是什么：一个传说。我重建了那些引用它的人的愿望和集体恐惧，那些质疑它的人的推理，以及那些把它的活动部分重新组合成一个主题的更多变化的人的议程。在这样做的过程中，我描绘了对商业信贷不断变化和冲突的态度，并讨论了为什么犹太人（在传说中是基督教想象的产物）提供了一个广泛的题材，通过这些题材可以阐述这些态度。

The legend today is so mystifying that I have felt the need to unpack all its constitutive elements in considerable detail and to recount just how many forms it took and how many authors contended with it. The result is the long journey from the Middle Ages through the twentieth century traced in the coming pages. My larger ambition, put succinctly, is to show the heuristic value of Christian representations of Jewish economic roles for probing long-held narratives about the power and limits of the market to create more equal societies. I am not concerned with the question of whether or not Jews ever had a putatively special relationship with capitalism—a question that, incidentally, I do not believe can be treated separately from its intellectual genealogy. Nor do I posit that in early modern Europe it was impossible to talk about credit without talking about Jews. That would simply not be true. Rather, I draw attention to one consistent assumption that ran through different European cultures from the fourteenth to the twentieth centuries: the idea that Jews were nowhere and everywhere. This idea is at the heart of the legend of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange.

今天的传奇是如此神秘，以至于我觉得有必要相当详细地解读它的所有构成要素，并叙述它有多少种形式，有多少作者与它争论。其结果是，从中世纪到二十世纪的漫长旅程，在接下来的几页中得以追溯。简而言之，我更大的野心是展示基督教对犹太人经济角色的表述的启发式价值，以探究长期以来关于市场创造更平等社会的力量和限制的叙述。我并不关心犹太人是否曾与资本主义有所谓的特殊关系 —— 顺便说一句，我不认为这个问题可以与资本主义的知识谱系分开处理。我也不认为在现代早期的欧洲，不谈犹太人就不可能谈及信贷。这根本不是事实。相反，我提请注意从十四世纪到二十世纪贯穿不同欧洲文化的一个一致的假设：犹太人无处不在的想法。这种想法是犹太人发明汇票的传说的核心。

The theme of Jewish invisibility took different forms across time and space depending on the models of interaction with the majority-Christian society to which Jews were subjected: forced conversion, acculturation, or legal equality. After the mass conversions that followed the pogroms perpetrated in Spain in 1391, the difficulty of distinguishing Jewish converts to Catholicism from the rest of the population became the focus of ecclesiastical and secular efforts, which culminated in the “purity of blood” statutes (1448) and the establishment of a modern Inquisition (1478).8 The decrees ordering the expulsion or forced conversion of Jews in Castile and Aragon (1492), Portugal (1497), and Navarre (1498) escalated the paranoia that surrounded these presumed “crypto-Jews.” The legend of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange was born in the one region of Europe other than Iberia where, after the mid-sixteenth century, crypto-Judaism was a de facto reality: the southwest of France. There, Iberian refugees were welcomed as “Portuguese merchants” and, until 1723, were prohibited from practicing Judaism in the open but always suspected of doing so in secret. These so-called New Christians, the wealthiest of whom were concentrated in professions connected with maritime and regional trade, were treated as invisible Jews: their inner religious convictions (whatever they were) had to conform to the outward practice of Catholicism, but their allegiance to Catholicism and to the kingdom of France was constantly doubted; Jews were nowhere to be seen, but their financial power was assumed to be everywhere.

犹太人的隐蔽性主题在不同的时间和空间采取了不同的形式，这取决于犹太人与多数基督教社会的互动模式：强迫转换、文化融合或法律平等。在 1391 年西班牙发生大屠杀之后，大规模的皈依者成为教会和世俗努力的焦点，这在 “血统纯正” 法规（1448）和现代宗教裁判所的建立（1478）中达到顶峰。8在卡斯蒂利亚和阿拉贡（1492）、葡萄牙（1497）和纳瓦拉（1498），命令驱逐犹太人或强迫其改变信仰的法令使围绕这些假定的 “隐性犹太人” 的偏执情绪升级。犹太人发明汇票的传说诞生于欧洲除伊比利亚以外的一个地区，在那里，16 世纪中期以后，隐蔽的犹太教成为事实上的现实：法国的西南部。在那里，伊比利亚难民作为 “葡萄牙商人” 受到欢迎，直到 1723 年，他们被禁止公开信奉犹太教，但总是被怀疑在秘密地信奉。这些所谓的新基督徒，其中最富有的人集中在与海上和区域贸易有关的职业中，被当作隐形的犹太人对待：他们的内在宗教信仰（无论它们是什么）必须符合天主教的外在实践，但他们对天主教和法兰西王国的忠诚却一直受到怀疑；犹太人无处可寻，但他们的经济实力却被认为无处不在。

The invisibility of Jews in those port cities of western and Mediterranean Europe where Iberian converts were allowed to make a home as Jews after the late sixteenth century—notably Venice, Livorno, Amsterdam, Hamburg, and, later on, London—was of a different sort. It was neither theological nor complete but the result of a long process of acculturation and deliberate efforts to integrate this group into the fabric of commercial society. In those areas of Europe, Sephardic merchants acquired unprecedented contractual equality in the commercial sphere at the very same time that all merchants who were involved in long-distance trade largely abandoned guilds. The weakness of corporate organizations within the upper echelons of private international trade together with ad hoc policies designed to attract New Christian refugees with fortunes and trading connections meant that Sephardic merchants could now join the international republic of money in ways that they had not been able to do before. They could now enter into contracts with anyone of their choosing, uphold their property rights before secular courts, and even buy state bonds—a privilege that came with financial and symbolic benefits that had earlier been denied to Jewish bankers in medieval Italian city-states with a public debt.9

犹太人在西欧和地中海的那些港口城市的隐蔽性是不同的，在这些城市，伊比利亚皈依者被允许作为犹太人安家，特别是威尼斯、利沃诺、阿姆斯特丹、汉堡以及后来的伦敦。它既不是神学上的，也不是完整的，而是一个长期的文化适应过程和有意将这个群体融入商业社会结构的结果。在欧洲的这些地区，塞法尔商人在商业领域获得了前所未有的契约平等，与此同时，所有参与长途贸易的商人基本上都放弃了行会。私人国际贸易上层的公司组织的弱点，加上旨在吸引拥有财富和贸易关系的新基督徒难民的特别政策，意味着塞法尔德商人现在可以以他们以前无法做到的方式加入国际货币共和国。他们现在可以与自己选择的任何人签订合同，在世俗法庭上维护自己的财产权，甚至可以购买国家债券 —— 这种特权带来了金融和象征性的好处，而这些好处早先是中世纪意大利城邦的犹太银行家所不具备的。9

In many other respects, Sephardim continued to endure restrictive legal measures and to serve as the targets of scorn and mistrust. But their newly acquired economic privileges put pressure on existing corporate structures and engendered changes that extended well beyond the economic sphere. In both southern and northern Europe, Sephardic Jews cultivated the collective self-image of a respectable merchant community, subordinated some of their religious norms to the demands of commerce with non-Jews, and drew sharp lines between themselves and other Jewish groups that more visibly conformed to Christian stereotypes. Acculturated by choice or by necessity, these postexpulsion communities of New Christians and New Jews, small as they were, were prized for their commercial skills, better liked than their Ashkenazi brethren (because they were more in tune with the local customs), and yet still not fully trusted to play by the rules of Christian commerical society. As a result, they represented both the progress and the dangers of market exchanges that increasingly transcended the traditional hierarchies of clearly demarcated corporate entities.

在其他许多方面，塞法尔迪人继续忍受着限制性的法律措施，并成为蔑视和不信任的对象。但他们新获得的经济特权给现有的企业结构带来了压力，并引发了远远超出经济领域的变化。在南欧和北欧，塞法尔犹太人培养了一个受人尊敬的商人群体的集体自我形象，使他们的一些宗教规范服从于与非犹太人的商业需求，并在他们与其他更明显地符合基督教定型观念的犹太群体之间划出鲜明的界限。这些被驱逐后的新基督徒和新犹太人群体，不管是出于选择还是出于需要，都因其商业技能而受到重视，比他们的阿什肯纳兹兄弟更受欢迎（因为他们更符合当地的习俗），但仍然不被完全信任，无法按基督教商业社会的规则行事。因此，他们既代表了市场交换的进步，也代表了市场交换的危险，而市场交换越来越超越了传统的等级分明的企业实体。

After the French Revolution granted Jewish men citizenship rights, making them legally indistinguishable from their peers, Jews’ invisibility assumed yet another guise—and the most paradoxical to date. Assimilation bred new fears of Jewish separatism. Indistinguishable from the broader polity but supposedly clannish, Jews were now seen as willing and able to undermine the nation from within in ways that were particularly difficult to unmask. This view soon became the mantra of conservative thinkers, but it appeared with different intensities across a large spectrum of authors and framed the legend’s postemancipation meanings. In Old Regime corporate societies, the fears caused by the emergence of an increasingly impersonal commercial world could be pinned on a group that was highly acculturated but still legally and socially distinct from the dominant one. (Marriages between Jews and Christians, for example, required the conversion of one or the other spouse.) Later, in the postemancipation regimes’ atmosphere of aspiring universalism, those who did not trust the invisible hand to control misbehavior could resurrect ancient tropes and identify Jews as the obscure force behind economic abuse and corruption. During the democratic age, a new essentialism regarding Jews’ collective traits took shape, which, like so-called scientific racism, hardened those hierarchies that legal equality had sought to soften.

在法国大革命赋予犹太人公民权，使他们在法律上与同龄人没有区别之后，犹太人的隐蔽性又有了新的表现 —— 而且是迄今为止最矛盾的表现。同化产生了新的恐惧，犹太人的分离主义。犹太人与更广泛的政体没有区别，但据说是宗族性的，他们现在被视为愿意并能够从内部破坏国家，而这种破坏方式特别难以揭穿。这种观点很快成为保守派思想家的口头禅，但它以不同的强度出现在众多作者的作品中，并构成了解放后传说的含义。在旧制度的企业社会中，一个越来越不近人情的商业世界的出现所引起的恐惧可以归咎于一个高度文化化但在法律和社会上仍与主流社会不同的群体。（例如，犹太人和基督教徒之间的婚姻要求配偶一方或另一方改变信仰。）后来，在解放后的政权中，在渴望普遍主义的氛围中，那些不相信看不见的手能控制不当行为的人可以复活古老的陈词滥调，把犹太人指为经济滥用和腐败背后的隐蔽力量。在民主时代，一种关于犹太人集体特征的新的本质主义正在形成，它和所谓的科学种族主义一样，使法律平等试图软化的那些等级制度变得更加牢固。

The legend of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange emerged and evolved as part of the collective suspicion produced by forced baptism, acculturation, and assimilation—three very different phenomena, but all accompanied by apprehensions about moral contagion and the subversion of the established order. Throughout this book, I will illustrate how easily the anxieties created by Jews’ potential invisibility in the marketplace could be mapped onto the increasing abstraction of the paper economy. The legend’s myriad threads, in other words, bring to the fore the misgivings that went hand in hand with the rise of capitalism and formal equality as pillars of European modernity.

犹太人发明汇票的传说是作为强迫洗礼、文化融合和同化所产生的集体怀疑的一部分而出现和演变的 —— 这三种现象非常不同，但都伴随着对道德传染和颠覆既定秩序的担忧。在这本书中，我将说明犹太人在市场上的潜在隐蔽性所造成的焦虑是多么容易被映射到日益抽象的纸面经济中。换句话说，这个传说的无数条线索使人们对资本主义和形式上的平等作为欧洲现代性的支柱而崛起的疑虑凸显出来。

———

Turning from topic to approach, I wish to single out three broad historiographical debates on which my analysis impinges. The first is the question of what constitutes “the economy” as a field of inquiry and what is included in the canon we use to access this field, a concern that has become particularly relevant in light of the impact of the digital revolution on the study of Europe’s past. The second is the relationship between what we might call “practices” and “representations” and the tendency some scholars have had to pit the two against each other. Finally, the third is the perennial question of periodization, which Jewish history and Christian prejudice toward Jews bring into sharp relief, especially when, as I do, we examine a singular but mutable figure, the Jewish usurer, across several historical periods. The next three sections expand on each of these problems.

从主题到方法，我想单独指出我的分析所涉及的三个广泛的历史学辩论。第一个问题是什么构成了 “经济” 这一调查领域，以及什么被纳入我们用来进入这一领域的典籍，鉴于数字革命对欧洲历史研究的影响，这一问题变得尤为重要。第二个问题是我们可以称之为 “实践” 和 “表述” 之间的关系，以及一些学者将两者对立起来的倾向。最后，第三个问题是长期存在的时代化问题，即，犹太历史和基督教对犹太人的偏见令人震惊，尤为让我震惊，我们在几个历史时期考察一个单一却又易变的人物 —— 犹太高利贷者。接下来的三节将分别对这些问题进行阐述。

The Ars Mercatoria : Sources and Canons

《重商法》：来源和准则

I first encountered what I later started to call the legend of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange while rereading Jacques Savary’s Le parfait négociant (1675), the single most influential merchant manual of early modern Europe. I was looking for something else, but a chapter on the origins of bills of exchange caught my attention. It stated that Jews expelled from France between the years 640 and 1316 had invented these bills as a way of sheltering their assets when fleeing the kingdom.10 I was surprised. The story was riveting, and in spite of many years spent reading about commerce and Jews, I had never heard of it. Le parfait négociant was a blockbuster, so influential and rich in information that it is difficult to imagine an economic historian of preindustrial Europe without at least a cursory knowledge of it. So why had I never heard of this story? Arguably, economic historians ignored it because it was unfounded, while Jewish historians, who might have noticed it, were unlikely to peruse such a source.

我在重读雅克·萨瓦里（Jacques Savary）的《完美的交易员》（Le parfait négociant）（1675）时，第一次遇到了我后来开始称之为 “犹太人发明汇票” 的传说；这是现代早期欧洲唯一最有影响的商人手册。我正在寻找别的东西，但关于汇票起源的一章引起了我的注意。它说，在 640 年至 1316 年间被驱逐出法国的犹太人发明了这些票据，作为逃离王国时保护其资产的一种方式。10我很惊讶。这个故事很吸引人，尽管多年来我一直在阅读有关商业和犹太人的书籍，但我从未听说过这个故事。《完美的交易员》是一部巨著，影响巨大，信息丰富，很难想象一个前工业化欧洲的经济史学家至少对它有粗略的了解。那么，为什么我从未听说过这个故事？可以说，经济史学家忽视了它，因为它毫无根据，而可能注意到它的犹太史学家则不太可能仔细阅读这样的资料。

Since I was sitting near a computer linked to my university’s library system, I typed a few keywords into an online database, The Making of the Modern World , to see if I could find other mentions of the story and, ideally, its provenance. It did not take long at all before I identified a title I was not familiar with and that, it turned out, none of the colleagues I consulted knew either: Étienne Cleirac’s Us et coustumes , a compilation of maritime laws accompanied by extensive commentary printed in Bordeaux in 1647.11 The first steps of my research went quickly. It took much longer to reconstruct the genealogy of what I now describe as a legend and to unravel its meanings and ramifications.

由于我坐在与大学图书馆系统相连的电脑旁，我在一个在线数据库 “现代世界的形成” 中输入了几个关键词，看看是否能找到关于这个故事的其他记载，最好能找到它的出处。没过多久，我就找到了一个我不熟悉的书名，事实证明，我所咨询的同事中也没有人知道 —— 埃蒂安·克莱拉克（Étienne Cleirac）的《用途和习俗》（Us et coustumes）。这是一本海商法汇编，附有大量评论，于 1647 年在波尔多印刷。11我研究的第一步很快就完成了。我花了更多的时间来重建我现在所说的传奇的谱系，并解开其含义和影响。

In 1977, Albert Hirschman opened his The Passions and the Interests , a brilliant work that is critically important for my purposes, by noting that during the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, “with the ‘disciplines’ of economics and political science not yet in existence at the time, there were no interdisciplinary boundaries to cross.”12 This observation captures not only the spirit of its author, impatient as Hirschman was with all disciplinary strictures, but also the amorphous nature of the sources on which my investigation is based. Today a number of electronic repositories of printed material from early modern Europe permit us to re-create the vastness of the archives that Hirschman had in mind and to mine them beyond the key texts he sampled in support of his influential account of the emergence of the idea that commerce promoted proto-democratic political regimes.

1977 年，阿尔伯特·赫希曼在他的《激情与利益》（The Passions and the Interests）中开篇指出，在十七和十八世纪，“由于当时经济学和政治学的 ‘学科’ 尚未存在，没有跨学科的界限可言”。12这一观察不仅抓住了其作者的精神，因为赫希曼对所有的学科限制都感到不耐烦，而且也抓住了我的调查所依据的资料的无定形性质。今天，一些来自现代早期欧洲的电子印刷材料库允许我们重新创建赫希曼心目中浩瀚的档案，并在他为支持其关于商业促进原民主政体的想法的出现而抽样的关键文本之外对其进行挖掘。

My book is proof that digital libraries can serve as a powerful corrective to anachronism insofar as they broaden the canon of texts and authors that we can scrutinize. Countless scholars before me undoubtedly read the chapter in Savary’s Le parfait négociant that ascribes to medieval French Jews the invention of bills of exchange. Savary cites no source for this narrative. Short of monstrous erudition or a stroke of good luck, how could anyone trace the roots of his account or its evolution over time? It is thanks to The Making of the Modern World that I was able to bring Cleirac’s Us et coustumes de la mer , a work that few today have heard of, back into the fold of the writings on all things relating to commerce and the economy, or ars mercatoria , where it once held pride of place. Inquiries about the boundaries of the canon are certainly not new; traditional bibliographical and reading methods have already yielded consequential insights, and I am hardly the first to rely on digital libraries.13 But digital collections and their potential grow by the day, and they have been used less in European economic history than in other fields (see appendix 1 ).

我的书证明，数字图书馆可以作为一种强大的纠正不合时宜的手段，因为它们扩大了我们可以仔细研究的文本和作者的典籍。在我之前的无数学者无疑都读过萨瓦里的《完美的交易员》中的一章，该章将汇票的发明归功于中世纪的法国犹太人。萨瓦里没有为这一叙述引用资料。如果不是博学多才或运气好，怎么可能有人追踪到他的说法的根源或其随时间的演变？正是由于《现代世界的形成》，我才得以将克莱拉克的《海洋的用途和习俗》（Us et coustumes de la mer）这部今天很少有人听说过的作品重新纳入与商业和经济有关的所有著作中，或称 “商船”（ars mercatoria），它曾经在那里占据了傲人的地位。对典籍边界的探究当然不是什么新鲜事；传统的书目和阅读方法已经产生了重要的见解，而我也不是第一个依靠数字图书馆的人。13但数字馆藏及其潜力与日俱增，而它们在欧洲经济史上的应用却比其他领域少（见附录 1）。

There are, of course, serious limits to the productive disturbance that data-mining tools can produce. In the case of The Making of the Modern World , the exclusion of manuscript sources, the overrepresentation of English-language texts, and the imperfection of its optical recognition devices caution us against using it as the referential universe for a statistical analysis of the incidence of certain keywords. For this and other reasons, I chose to cast “distant reading” aside—that is, not to resort to quantitative treatments of published titles but to rely instead on a more conventional combination of close and contextualized reading.14

当然，数据挖掘工具所能产生的生产性干扰是有严重限制的。就《现代世界的形成》而言，手稿来源的排除，英语文本的过度呈现，以及其光学识别设备的不完善，都提醒我们不要把它作为统计分析某些关键词发生率的参照系。由于这个原因和其他原因，我选择将 “远距离阅读” 抛在一边 —— 也就是说，不诉诸于对已发表的标题的定量处理，而是依靠更传统的近距离阅读和上下文阅读的结合。14

The availability of digital platforms has nonetheless been critical to my ability to map the legend’s transmission and sketch the larger labyrinth of textual worlds within which it traveled. Since early modern authors (with the exception of biblical and legal scholars) made sparing use of footnotes or other bibliographical reference systems, full-text keyword searches are crucial to identifying chains of intertextuality. Moreover, to speak of a canon is to refer not only to a set of texts and authors, but also to their classification into schools of thought—in our case, those of mercantilism, anticommercial classical republicanism, doux commerce , the Gournay circle, and physiocracy, to cite only the most well-known trends within French economic thought from the late seventeenth century to the Revolution. Of course, many scholars have challenged the stability of these “schools.” Scans of searchable digital libraries challenge these traditional interpretative frames even more. References to the legend of the Jewish origins of bills of exchange are sometimes the result of intentional borrowings and other times the byproduct of uncritical copying. They cross genres and widely accepted ideological fault lines to the point of blurring those lines.

然而，数字平台的可用性对于我绘制传说的传播图和勾勒它所处的更大的文本世界的迷宫的能力至关重要。由于早期现代作者（除圣经和法律学者外）很少使用脚注或其他书目参考系统，全文关键词搜索对于识别互文性链至关重要。此外，说到教规，不仅是指一组文本和作者，也是指他们的思想流派分类 —— 在我们的例子中包括，重商主义（mercantilism）、反商业的古典共和主义（anticommercial classical republicanism）、甜蜜的交易（Doux commerce）、古尔内圈（Gournay circle）和 理政（physiocracy）…… 仅举 17 世纪后期至大革命期间法国经济思想中最著名的趋势。当然，许多学者对这些 “流派” 的稳定性提出了质疑。对可搜索的数字图书馆的扫描更挑战了这些传统的解释框架。对汇票的犹太起源传说的引用，有时是有意借用的结果，有时则是不加批判的复制的副产品。它们跨越流派和广泛接受的意识形态断层，以至于模糊了这些界限。

Images as Practices, Practices as Images

作为实践的图像，作为图像的实践

In addition to questions about sources and reading modalities, I was drawn to this project because the study of both commercial credit and Jewish life in premodern Europe defies the traditional division of labor between intellectual and cultural historians, on the one hand, and social and economic historians, on the other. The so-called “history wars” of the last quarter of the twentieth century raised important epistemological questions about the relationship between discourse, power, and social change, but also built high walls between practitioners of different areas of historical inquiry. The chapters that follow constitute my effort to surmount these walls, even as I am all too aware of the reasons why they exist and the difficulty of meshing dissimilar approaches.

除了关于来源和阅读方式的问题，我被吸引到这个项目，因为对前现代欧洲的商业信贷和犹太人生活的研究违背了知识和文化史学家与社会和经济史学家之间的传统分工。二十世纪最后四分之一的所谓 “历史战争” 提出了关于话语、权力和社会变革之间关系的重要认识论问题，但也在不同历史调查领域的从业者之间建立了高墙。接下来的章节构成了我超越这些墙的努力，即使我非常清楚这些墙存在的原因以及将不同的方法结合起来的困难。

My inquiry began not with any specific interest in the legend of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange, but with a puzzle: early modern merchant manuals and dictionaries of trade aimed at legitimizing commerce and laid out the norms that facilitated engagement in commercial transactions beyond close-knit groups, but they were also peppered with stereotypes about certain communities of traders. Why did these stereotypes multiply alongside the effort to broaden the boundaries of European commercial society? What was the meaning of these biases? Did they inform a proto-sociology of merchants, or did they serve a different function? And what accounted for the attributes ascribed to each group? Savary and many other commentators, as we will see, compared Jewish merchants to those from eastern churches, such as Armenians and Greeks, and even to some groups from Central and South Asia. How did these seeds of Orientalism emerge, evolve, and crystallize in European commercial literature, which sometimes contrasted one group with another and other times lumped all of them together as paragons of economic slyness? What impact did these images have on merchants’ strategies? That is, what kind of signals, if any, did labels such as “Jews,” “Greeks,” and “Armenians” send in competitive marketplaces plagued by a scarcity of information about the creditworthiness of individual actors, especially those coming to town from afar or moving within separate circles?

我的调查不是从对犹太人发明汇票的传说的具体兴趣开始的，而是从一个难题开始的：早期的现代商人手册和贸易词典旨在使商业合法化，并规定了便于在紧密的团体之外从事商业交易的规范，但它们也充斥着对某些商人群体的成见。为什么在努力扩大欧洲商业社会的边界的同时，这些陈规定型观念会成倍增加？这些偏见的含义是什么？它们是为商人的原社会学提供信息，还是发挥了不同的作用？赋予每个群体的属性又是什么原因？正如我们将看到的那样，萨瓦里和许多其他评论家将犹太商人与来自东方教会的商人，如亚美尼亚人和希腊人，甚至与来自中亚和南亚的一些群体进行比较。这些东方主义的种子是如何在欧洲商业文献中出现、演变和具体化的，这些文献有时将一个群体与另一个群体进行对比，有时则将所有这些群体混为一谈，作为经济狡诈的典范？这些形象对商人的战略有什么影响？也就是说，在竞争激烈的市场上，“犹太人”、“希腊人” 和 “亚美尼亚人” 这样的标签发出了什么样的信号（如果有的话），这些标签被有关个人行为者（尤其是那些从远方来的人或在不同圈子里活动的人）信誉的信息所困扰着？

A related and complementary set of questions concerns the status and credibility of women. In eighteenth-century Paris, for example, it became easier for aristocratic women to obtain credit in the growing number of shops where the latest fashionable garments were sold, even if in reality they were not always in a position to repay their debts—an indication that rank remained a pivot of economic reputation.15 Contemporary Enlightenment texts often identified women as avatars of luxury and consumption, whether to condemn the volatility and corruption of commercial society or, by contrast, to exalt its expanding possibilities. There are obvious parallels between women and Jews and their respective positions in credit markets, not least because both groups were deprived of legal equality during the Old Regime. There are also many differences in the access that each group had to credit and to legal recourse, as well as obvious differences in the economic power enjoyed by a variety of Jewish and Christian women. In eighteenth-century France, only women who were members of a guild or merchants’ widows who were “publically known as merchants” could legally sign bills of exchange, but there is evidence that transgressions of this norm occurred. When and how were women able to obtain commercial credit? How did social perception affect their reputation in the sphere of market transactions? Although I am unable to take up these issues in this book, I spell them out because they animate my broader agenda and might provide the impetus for further comparisons of the legal and social purchase of different marginalized groups.

一组相关的、互补的问题涉及妇女的地位和信誉。例如，在 18 世纪的巴黎，贵族妇女更容易在越来越多的出售最新时尚服装的商店里获得信贷，即使在现实中她们并不总是有能力偿还债务 —— 这表明等级仍然是经济声誉的一个支点。15当代启蒙运动的文本经常将妇女认定为奢侈品和消费的化身，无论是谴责商业社会的动荡和腐败，还是与此相反，赞美其不断扩大的可能性。妇女和犹太人以及她们各自在信贷市场上的地位有明显的相似之处，特别是因为这两个群体在旧制度下都被剥夺了法律平等。每个群体在获得信贷和法律追索权方面也有许多不同之处，各种犹太妇女和基督教妇女享有的经济权力也有明显不同。在 18 世纪的法国，只有身为行会成员的妇女或 “公开称为商人” 的商人遗孀才能合法地签署汇票，但有证据表明发生了违反这一规范的情况。妇女何时以及如何能够获得商业信贷？社会观念如何影响她们在市场交易领域的声誉？尽管我无法在本书中讨论这些问题，但我还是把它们写了出来，因为它们激发了我更广泛的议程，并可能为进一步比较不同边缘化群体的法律和社会购买提供动力。

Cultural constructions of propriety in credit markets do not speak solely to questions of representation but also fulfill regulatory functions, albeit in ways difficult to measure. A merchant’s reputation was the black box of premodern commercial credit. It follows that the reputation of Jewish merchants in Christian Europe, like that of other stigmatized minorities, was normally a product of both documented individual behavior and collective stereotyping. The goal of my analysis is not to calculate the degree to which belief in the legend of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange affected credit relations between individual Jews and non-Jews, but to show that the legend’s intellectual evolution was nourished by and gave voice to preoccupations that were real and tangible. Rightly or wrongly, an individual’s public conduct was usually taken to be a reflection of his or her aptitude and financial standing. But could all individuals control their public image—or were some seen through a collective lens? Who was subjected to this vetting and when?

在信贷市场中，文化上对正当性的建构并不只涉及代表权的问题，也履行着监管的功能，尽管方式难以衡量。商人的声誉是前现代商业信贷的黑箱。因此，基督教欧洲的犹太商人的声誉，就像其他被污名化的少数民族的声誉一样，通常是有记录的个人行为和集体成见的产物。我分析的目的不是要计算对犹太人发明汇票的传说的信仰在多大程度上影响了个别犹太人和非犹太人之间的信贷关系，而是要表明，这个传说的思想演变是由真实和具体的关注点滋养出来的。无论对错，一个人的公共行为通常被认为是他或她的能力和财务状况的反映。但是，所有的人都能控制自己的公众形象吗？还是有些人是通过一个集体镜头来看待的？谁在什么时候接受了这种审查？

As a general rule, the greater the uncertainty under which credit relations are established, the more tempting, and arguably sensible, it is for lenders to resort to collective stereotypes in judging potential borrowers. Imperfect as they are in measuring an individual’s competence and rectitude, collective stereotypes in premodern societies reflected the existence of segmented communities, each of which was the object of greater or lesser mistrust and more or less able to monitor its members. The notion that collective stereotyping in credit markets is discriminatory is very recent, both culturally and legally. Even in today’s markets, which are comparatively more open and freer from overt discrimination, actors often resort to what economic sociologists call “status signals” in order to advertise their performance and products.16

一般来说，建立信贷关系的不确定性越大，贷款人在判断潜在借款人时就越有诱惑力，而且可以说是明智的。尽管集体定型观念在衡量个人的能力和正直方面并不完美，但在前现代社会中，集体定型观念反映了细分社区的存在，每个社区或多或少都是不信任的对象，或多或少都能监督其成员。信用市场中的集体定型观念是歧视性的，这在文化上和法律上都是最近才有的。即使在今天的市场上，相对来说更开放，更没有公开的歧视，行为者也经常诉诸于经济社会学家所说的 “地位信号”，以宣传他们的业绩和产品。16

A simple fact is indicative of the legend’s normative function in the commercial sphere: the tale did not first appear in the sermon of a Franciscan friar, an Elizabethan play, an anti-usury tract, or a Christian polemic against the so-called “errors of the Jews”—all genres that abounded at the time and reveled in antisemitic tropes. Rather, its earliest and principal vehicles were compilations intended to valorize the role of commerce in a feudal society and to offer merchants concrete guidance. Occasionally, we also find mentions of the legend in the everyday documents drafted by French Catholic merchants. A report submitted in 1702 by the Deputies of Commerce, a council of twelve merchants from the kingdom’s major cities charged with advising the crown, asked the king to curb the “abuses” committed by tax farmers and state financiers who surreptitiously exported funds by means of bills of exchange. The report was far from an indictment of bills of exchange as such, but by opening with a recapitulation of their supposed invention by the Jews expelled from France “on account of their usuries,” it arguably appropriated the legend in order to introduce the notion that there were more and less legitimate ways of handling those bills.17

一个简单的事实表明了这个传说在商业领域的规范功能：这个故事并没有首先出现在方济各会修士的布道中，也没有出现在伊丽莎白时代的戏剧中，更没有出现在反对所谓 “犹太人的错误” 的基督教论战中 —— 所有这些体裁在当时都比比皆是，而且充满了反犹太主义的色彩。相反，它最早和主要的载体是旨在评价商业在封建社会中的作用并为商人提供具体指导的汇编。偶尔，我们也能在法国天主教商人起草的日常文件中找到对该传说的提及。1702 年，商业代表们提交了一份报告，这是一个由来自王国主要城市的 12 名商人组成的理事会，负责向王室提出建议，要求国王遏制税农和国家金融家通过汇票偷偷出口资金的 “滥用” 行为。这份报告远不是对汇票本身的控诉，但通过开篇对所谓被 “以高利贷为由” 逐出法国的犹太人发明的汇票进行复述，可以说是挪用了这个传说，以便提出这样一个概念，即处理这些汇票有多种合法方式。17

This is a striking example of the fact that we cannot assume that a sort of pragmatic tolerance infused merchant culture. The moralizing and sometimes venomous tone of petitions and didactic literature produced by and/or for merchants had a clear prescriptive value. After all, the parameters of public action that rulers set for different merchant groups responded to the public perception of each of these groups and a generalized distrust of Jews’ loyalty to the state and to society. In the absence of a modern conception of separation between church and state, Jews’ rejection of Christian revelation cast them in the eyes of elites and the uneducated alike as infidels lacking fama and fides , that is, public reputation and trustworthiness. For this reason, although the legal status of Jews varied greatly from place to place, nowhere could they hold public office, join craft guilds, or give testimony against Christians in a court of law.

这是一个突出的例子，说明我们不能假定商人文化中注入了某种实用主义的宽容。由商人和/或为商人制作的请愿书和说教文学的道德化，有时甚至是毒舌的语气，有明显的规定性价值。毕竟，统治者为不同商人群体设定的公共行动参数，回应了公众对这些群体的看法以及对犹太人对国家和社会的忠诚度的普遍不信任。在没有现代政教分离概念的情况下，犹太人对基督教启示的拒绝使他们在精英和未受教育者的眼中成为缺乏家庭（fama）和宗教信仰（fides）的异教徒，，即公众声誉和可信度。由于这个原因，尽管犹太人的法律地位在不同的地方有很大差异，但他们在任何地方都不能担任公职，加入手工业行会，或在法庭上提供不利于基督徒的证词。

Negative group stereotypes tend to be remarkably impermeable to reality, even as they possess a striking ability to conjure new meanings out of a finite repertoire. This twin characteristic is a distinctive feature of Christian prejudice against Jews and is apparent in the legend under investigation, which fused medieval clichés about Jewish usury and seventeenth-century exaggerated admiration for Jewish commerce. Jewish lending to Christians in the late Middle Ages was largely confined to pawnbroking for the poor and loans to rulers. Bills of exchange, by contrast, were icons of the early modern paper economy, capable of moving funds across distances in invisible ways, yielding profits with no direct connection to the sale of material goods, and proving susceptible to equally mysterious defaults. In spite of new regulations issued after the sixteenth century by municipal, state, and fair authorities, bills of exchange were difficult to monitor, and in the matter of their management, expert merchants somehow always knew better than lawyers, judges, and government officials.

负面的群体刻板印象往往对现实有明显的不可渗透性，即使它们拥有一种惊人的能力，可以从有限的剧目中变出新的含义。这种双重特征是基督教对犹太人偏见的一个明显特征，在所调查的传说中也很明显，它融合了中世纪关于犹太人高利贷的陈词滥调和十七世纪对犹太商业的夸大赞美。在中世纪晚期，犹太人对基督徒的借贷主要限于为穷人提供典当和向统治者提供贷款。相比之下，汇票是现代早期纸币经济的标志，能够以无形的方式将资金转移到远方，产生的利润与物质产品的销售没有直接联系，并证明容易出现同样神秘的违约。尽管 16 世纪后，市政、州政府和议会当局颁布了新的法规，但汇票很难被监控，而且在管理问题上，专家级的商人总是比律师、法官和政府官员更了解情况。

By pointing to Jews as the inventors of bills of exchange, the legend did not identify any specific type of abuse that was occurring but rather cast suspicion on commercial credit in general by playing into widely shared cultural assumptions about Jews’ unscrupulous dealings. In so doing, the legend became a substitute for hard-to-define normative criteria for the rightful handling of bills of exchange. Its subsequent adaptations, then, recombined different elements of the sketchy historical narrative on which it was grounded for different ends. Some of these accounts were closer to the original version than others, but all grappled with the aspirations and fears generated by the paper credit instruments’ abstraction of wealth from tangible assets.

通过指出犹太人是汇票的发明者，这个传说并没有确定正在发生的任何具体类型的滥用行为，而是通过利用广泛共享的关于犹太人不择手段的文化假设，使人们对商业信贷普遍产生怀疑。这样一来，这个传说就成了难以界定的正确处理汇票的规范性标准的替代物。然后，它后来的改编，为不同的目的重新组合了它所依据的简略的历史叙述的不同元素。其中一些说法比其他说法更接近原始版本，但所有这些说法都在努力解决纸质信贷工具从有形资产中抽象出的财富所产生的愿望和恐惧。

In this respect, my approach echoes William Sewell, Jr.’s self-consciously oxymoronic quest to write “a concrete history of social abstraction,” that is, a history of those practices and institutions that created the conditions for more anonymous market exchanges and were thus part of the process by which the market became a metaphor for a democratic political order.18 Bills of exchange lend themselves particularly well to this task. As material artifacts, they had no intrinsic value. Their monetary worth was the measure of the credibility assigned to the chains of signatories who backed them, rather than of any sovereign authority. At the same time, because they had to be physically transported from one place to another in order to be redeemed, their circulation depended on concrete communication infrastructures and was embedded in personal networks of recognition, which relied on epistolary exchanges and other verification systems.

在这方面，我的方法呼应了小威廉·苏威尔（William Sewell, Jr.）自觉矛盾的追求，即撰写 “社会抽象的具体历史”，也就是那些为更多匿名市场交易创造条件的实践和机构的历史，从而成为市场成为民主政治秩序的隐喻过程的一部分。18汇票特别适合这项任务。作为物质工艺品，它们没有内在的价值。它们的货币价值是对支持它们的一连串签字人的信誉的衡量，而不是任何主权当局的 。同时，由于它们必须从一个地方实际运到另一个地方才能被赎回，它们的流通依赖于具体的通信基础设施，并被嵌入个人的认可网络中，这些网络依赖于书信往来和其他验证系统。

But I also insist more than Sewell probably would on the asymmetric nature of the exchanges that these abstract credit instruments promoted. His interest in isolating the social practices that underpinned the eruption of egalitarianism during the revolutionary years has led him, in my view, to overestimate the transparency and openness of Parisian coffeehouses and promenades, which he regards as spaces where men and, to an increasing degree, women disguised their legal identities in ways that subverted a cardinal principle of Old Regime hierarchies: status. Recovering Jürgen Habermas’s explicitly neo-Marxist approach (which previous Anglophone appropriations of Habermas had largely eschewed), Sewell overplays the egalitarian ethos of the proto-capitalist classes.19 I believe that we ought to take his invitation to locate the material bases of emerging social abstraction and democratic politics seriously, but that we cannot overlook the apprehension that anonymity generated or the lack of fairness that plagued competitive markets of the time.20

但我也比苏威尔更坚持这些抽象的信用工具所促进的交流的不对称性。在我看来，他对孤立支撑革命年代平等主义爆发的社会实践的兴趣，导致他高估了巴黎咖啡馆和长廊的透明度和开放性，他认为这些地方是男性以及越来越多的女性以颠覆旧制度等级制度的基本原则（即地位）的方式掩饰其法律身份的空间。苏威尔恢复了尤尔根·哈贝马斯（Jürgen Habermas）明确的新马克思主义方法（neo-Marxist approach，以前英国人对哈贝马斯的挪用基本上都避开了），过度渲染了原资本主义阶层的平等主义精神。19我认为，我们应该认真对待他的邀请，找到新兴社会抽象和民主政治的物质基础，但我们不能忽视匿名产生的忧虑或困扰当时竞争市场的缺乏公平性。20

Bills of exchange are ideal objects for this type of analysis because they embody the tension that existed between egalitarianism and oligopolies in early modern commercial credit markets. Their diffusion was greeted by praise of their utility but also denunciations of the potential harm they could inflict. Jonathan Sheehan and Dror Warman have recently argued that the South Sea Bubble of 1720 triggered a Europe-wide intellectual and cultural shift that displaced both providentialism and mechanical materialism in favor of the concept of self-organization in many spheres of intellectual inquiry.21 There may be an interesting coincidence between the 1720 financial crash and a host of philosophical trends, but in the realm of economic thought, broadly conceived, self-organization had by this time already been recognized as a powerful force. Self-organization is in fact what bills of exchange epitomized and to what the legend of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange responded. Merchants’ autonomy and self-organization were both desirable and unsettling. The legend offered no solution to this conundrum but, in most of its permutations, acted as a warning, because Christian observers agreed that to trade bills of exchange “in the Jewish manner” meant something dangerous and unwelcome.

汇票是这类分析的理想对象，因为它们体现了现代早期商业信贷市场中平等主义和寡头垄断之间的紧张关系。它们的传播受到了对其效用的赞扬，但也有对其可能造成的潜在危害的谴责。乔纳森·希恩（Jonathan Sheehan）和德罗·沃曼在最近（Dror Warman）争辩说，1720 年的南海泡沫引发了欧洲范围内的知识和文化转变，在许多知识探索领域取代了天命论和机械唯物论，而支持自组织的概念。211720 年的金融风暴和一系列哲学趋势之间可能存在有趣的巧合，但在经济思想领域，从广义上讲，自组织此时已经被认为是一种强大的力量。事实上，自组织正是汇票的缩影，也是犹太人发明汇票的传说的回应。商人的自主权和自我组织既令人向往又令人不安。这个传说没有为这一难题提供解决方案，但在其大多数变体中，都起到了警告的作用，因为基督教观察家认为，“以犹太人的方式” 进行汇票交易意味着一些危险和不受欢迎的事情。

Continuities and Change

连续性和变化

Formulated in the mid-seventeenth century as money markets were becoming more and more impersonal, the legend of the Jewish origin of bills of exchange grafted medieval clichés about Jewish pawnbroking onto the early modern reality of new instruments of credit. By the early twentieth century, then, this story became a pseudo-fact in credible academic accounts. This exceedingly long chronology raises questions about the permanence and reconstitution of stereotypes. These questions in turn prompt us to probe the pertinence of labels such as “medieval,” “early modern,” and “modern” for Jewish and European history at large.

17 世纪中期，随着货币市场变得越来越不近人情，汇票的犹太起源传说将中世纪关于犹太典当业的陈词滥调嫁接到现代早期新信贷工具的现实中。那么，到了二十世纪初，这个故事在可靠的学术报告中成为了一个伪事实。这种超长的时间顺序提出了关于定型观念的持久性和重构的问题。这些问题反过来又促使我们去探究诸如 “中世纪”、“早期现代” 和 “现代” 等标签对整个犹太和欧洲历史的相关性。

Those scholars of European Jewry who are wedded to a “lachrymose” narrative are also prone to emphasize continuity, in the form of persecution, rather than change (although considerable disagreement exists about whether racialized antisemitism in the second half of the nineteenth century constituted a new phenomenon or a mere evolution of preexisting themes). By contrast, confronted with the variety of manifestations of Jewish life and thought, many historians tend to stress adaptation more or at least as much as discrimination.22

那些拘泥于 “流言蜚语” 叙事的欧洲犹太人学者也容易强调迫害形式的连续性，而不是变化（尽管对于 19 世纪下半叶的种族化反犹太主义是否构成一种新现象或仅仅是以前存在的主题的演变，存在相当大的分歧）。相比之下，面对犹太人生活和思想的各种表现形式，许多历史学家倾向于强调适应性，或者至少与歧视一样。22

Every inquiry into Christian representations of Jews, however, shows that this contrast is overly simplistic. Prejudice is at once tenacious and protean. It builds on motifs from earlier times that are transmitted through both learned and popular culture and at the same time gives voice to tensions that are locally bound and highly specific. This dual nature of prejudice is fully reflected in the legend of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange. That is also why by the mid-eighteenth century, different characterizations of the economic roles played by Jews began to correspond to larger narratives about continuity and change between what today we refer to as the “medieval” and “early modern” periods in European history. Montesquieu’s The Spirit of the Laws (1748) linked the notion of Jews as forerunners of European capitalism to the view of the medieval church as an anticommercial institution and in so doing cast a long shadow over future scholarly endeavors and lay conceptions alike. For the French philosophe, in the Middle Ages Jews dominated commerce because the church demonized commerce and therefore good Christians shunned it. In his view, Jews invented bills of exchange at the time of Europe’s maritime explorations and colonial expansion—the onset of what today we would call early modernity—and thus helped inaugurate a new epoch during which the influence of the church receded and commerce promoted “softer” politics and social mores.

然而，对基督教对犹太人的描述的每一次调查都表明，这种对比过于简单化。偏见既是顽强的，又是保护性的。它建立在早期的主题上，这些主题通过学问和流行文化传播，同时也表达了当地的和高度具体的紧张关系。偏见的这种双重性质在犹太人发明汇票的传说中得到了充分体现。这也是为什么到了 18 世纪中叶，对犹太人所扮演的经济角色的不同描述开始与今天我们所说的欧洲历史上的 “中世纪” 和 “早期现代” 时期之间的连续性和变化的大型叙事相对应。孟德斯鸠的《法律的精神》（1748）将犹太人作为欧洲资本主义先驱的概念与中世纪教会作为反商业机构的观点联系起来，从而为未来的学术努力和非专业人士的概念投下了长期的阴影。在这位法国哲学家看来，在中世纪，犹太人主宰了商业，因为教会将商业妖魔化，因此善良的基督徒回避它。在他看来，犹太人在欧洲的海洋探险和殖民扩张时期发明了汇票 —— 也就是我们今天所说的早期现代的开始 —— 从而帮助开创了一个新的时代，在这个时代，教会的影响退去，商业促进了 “柔和的” 政治和社会风气。

For generations to come, progressive liberal historians seized upon the caesura that Montesquieu posited between a Catholic obscurantist Middle Ages and a secular early modernity propelled by commerce, and branded it into a standard periodization. Marxist and conservative social theorists also embraced the philosophe’s discontinuity between the Middle Ages and the sixteenth century, albeit with different cultural and political valences. In the interwar period, however, specialists of medieval Europe challenged this paradigmatic chronology by dating the origins of modern European capitalism to the twelfth and thirteenth centuries and portraying it as a notable achievement of Christian communal civilization, untainted by Jewish influence. Since the 1970s, the marginalization of the sixteenth century—the period when bills of exchange gave rise to new forms of financialization— in the historiography of European economy and economic thought has reintroduced the idea of a sharp break between late medieval and early modern financial institutions.

在未来的几代人中，进步的自由主义历史学家抓住了孟德斯鸠在天主教蒙昧主义的中世纪和由商业推动的世俗的早期现代性之间提出的尾音，并将其打造成一个标准的时期划分。马克思主义和保守的社会理论家也接受了哲学家在中世纪和 16 世纪之间的不连续性，尽管文化和政治价值不同。然而，在战时，中世纪欧洲的专家们挑战了这种范式的年表，将现代欧洲资本主义的起源追溯到十二和十三世纪，并将其描绘成基督教社区文明的显著成就，没有受到犹太人的影响。自 20 世纪 70 年代以来，在欧洲经济和经济思想的历史学中，16 世纪 —— 汇票产生新的金融化形式的时期 —— 被边缘化，重新提出了中世纪晚期和现代早期金融机构之间存在急剧分裂的观点。

Through a different set of reflections, scholars of European Jewry have also come to emphasize discontinuity and now recognize three distinct moments in Christian thought about Jews’ economic roles across the medieval and early modern periods, each with its own temporal and geographical specificities. The first moment, which coincided with the economic boom of Italian city-states and culminated in the norms issued at the Fourth Lateran Council (1215) to regulate the Jewish presence amid Christians, was dominated by writings on usury by moral theologians and canon lawyers. There are two sides to the thirteenth-century conception of usury, which shaped European representations of Jews and credit for centuries to come. On the one hand, Jews were thought to embody the practice of usury. Having denied the divinity of Christ, they were presumed to feel no allegiance to the Christians among whom they lived and whom they cheated at liberty. As proof and consequence of Jews’ theological infidelity, secular rulers assigned to them the function of pawnbrokers and allowed them to charge high interest rates. On the other hand, both religious and lay commentators defined usury (the opposite of charity) as the ultimate antisocial behavior, one that was not a prerogative of Jews. Franciscan friars, in particular, who proved instrumental in devising a Christian ethic for the urban renewal of late medieval Italy, formulated a conception of Jewish usury as a metric against which to measure everyone’s conduct. If Jews were programmed to exploit Christians, all economically exploitative behavior could be portrayed as metaphorically Jewish.23

通过一系列不同的思考，研究欧洲犹太人的学者们也开始强调不连续性，现在他们认识到，在整个中世纪和现代早期，基督教关于犹太人经济角色的思想有三个不同的时刻，每个时刻都有其自身的时间和地理特点。第一个时刻与意大利城邦的经济繁荣相吻合，并在第四届拉特兰会议（1215）上发布的规范中达到高潮，以规范基督徒中的犹太人的存在，由道德神学家和教规律师撰写的关于高利贷的文章主导。十三世纪的高利贷概念有两个方面，它塑造了欧洲人对犹太人和信贷的描述，并影响到未来几个世纪。一方面，犹太人被认为体现了高利贷的做法。由于否认基督的神性，他们被认为对他们生活在其中的基督徒没有忠诚，他们在自由中欺骗了他们。作为犹太人不忠于神学的证明和后果，世俗统治者赋予他们典当商的职能，并允许他们收取高额利息。另一方面，宗教和非宗教评论家都将高利贷（慈善的反面）定义为最终的反社会行为，这并不是犹太人的特权。特别是方济各会士，他们在为中世纪晚期意大利的城市重建设计基督教伦理方面发挥了重要作用，他们制定了一个关于犹太人高利贷的概念，作为衡量所有人行为的标准。如果犹太人被设计为剥削基督徒，那么所有经济上的剥削行为都可以被描绘成隐喻的犹太人。23

After the mid-sixteenth century, in pockets of Europe there emerged a second discourse, which was also linked to a new set of policies, dubbed “philosemitic mercantilism” by Jonathan Israel.24 These policies favored greater inclusion for Jews on the grounds that they possessed unique commercial skills that could benefit both the state and society in an age of growing competition between European powers for the control of overseas resources and territories. Although far more inclusive of real-life Jews than their medieval antecedents, seventeenth-century doctrines of toleration inspired by philosemitic mercantilism still regarded Jews as a discrete and potentially oligopolistic group that required ad hoc regulation within a corporate social order. These doctrines left no room for ideals regarding the anonymity of the market and all-around free competition. In Bordeaux, where Cleirac lived and wrote, the French crown implemented policies founded on a peculiar version of these beliefs.

十六世纪中期以后，在欧洲的一些地方出现了第二种话语，它也与一套新的政策有关，被乔纳森·伊斯雷尔（Jonathan Israel）称为 “重商主义哲学”。24这些政策主张对犹太人给予更多的包容，理由是他们拥有独特的商业技能，在欧洲大国之间为控制海外资源和领土的竞争日益激烈的时代，这些技能可以使国家和社会受益。尽管对现实生活中的犹太人的包容远远超过了他们在中世纪的前身，但十七世纪由重商主义哲学启发的宽容理论仍然将犹太人视为一个离散的、可能是寡头垄断的群体，需要在企业社会秩序中进行特别的监管。这些理论没有为市场的匿名性和全面的自由竞争的理想留下空间。在克莱拉克（Cleirac）生活和写作的波尔多，法国王室实施的政策建立在这些信念的特殊版本上。

Finally, a third discourse on the connection between Jews and the monied economy appeared along the Franco-German border in the last quarter of the eighteenth century. This late Enlightenment discourse is the most familiar to us because it still informs a good portion of modern historiography. It postulates that Jews’ hyperspecialization in commerce was the result of historical circumstances rather than nature. According to this account, since the fall of the Second Temple in 70 CE, centuries of persecution and exclusion from other economic sectors imposed by Christian rulers forced Jews to devote themselves to commerce; in the process, Jews came to excel at it. This discourse has been called a “new paradigm” because, unlike previous ones, it relieved Jews of any blame, condemned their oppressors, assumed the reversibility of Jews’ economic proclivities, and went further than any existing theory of toleration in advocating Jewish civic and political equality.25

最后，关于犹太人和货币经济之间的联系的第三种论述在十八世纪最后四分之一出现在法德边境。这种启蒙运动后期的论述是我们最熟悉的，因为它仍然影响着现代历史学的很大一部分。它假定犹太人在商业方面的过度专业化是历史环境而非自然的结果。根据这种说法，自公元 70 年第二座圣殿倒塌以来，几个世纪的迫害和基督教统治者对其他经济部门的排斥，迫使犹太人投身于商业；在这个过程中，犹太人开始擅长于此。这一论述被称为 “新范式”，因为与以前的论述不同，它免除了对犹太人的任何指责，谴责了他们的压迫者，假定犹太人的经济倾向是可逆的，并且在倡导犹太人的公民和政治平等方面比任何现有的宽容理论走得更远。25

There are good reasons to stress the differences among these three discourses, including the rejection of a “lachrymose” narrative of fixed enmity against Jews. At the same time, this tripartite scheme errs on the side of discontinuity, eliding the facility with which elements from each of these discourses migrated from one to the other and were recycled in new syntheses. The fusion of the figure of the medieval Jewish pawnbroker with that of the all-powerful early modern Jewish merchant, for example, became complete in France during the last quarter of the eighteenth century in the course of debates about whether or not to grant equal rights to Jewish men. No champion of the Jewish cause advanced an argument based on Jews’ commercial prowess or heralded as models the highly acculturated Sephardim of Bordeaux, although some scholars today argue that this group’s success provided reformers with the rationale for granting French Jews legal equality. In fact, the process leading to the first emancipation of Jews in Europe reveals that ostensibly positive assessments of Jewish contributions to commerce never rendered medieval images of Jewish usurers obsolete.

我们有充分的理由强调这三种话语之间的差异，包括拒绝对犹太人的固定敌意的 “流言” 叙述。同时，这种三方方案在不连续性方面犯了错误，忽略了这些话语中的每一种元素从一个地方迁移到另一个地方并在新的综合体中循环使用的便利。例如，中世纪犹太典当商的形象与现代早期叱咤风云的犹太商人的形象的融合，在 18 世纪最后 25 年的法国，在关于是否给予犹太男子平等权利的辩论过程中变得完整。犹太人事业的冠军，没有人以犹太人的商业能力为基础提出论点，也没有人把波尔多的高度文化化的塞法尔迪人誉为典范，尽管今天有些学者认为，这个群体的成功为改革者提供了给予法国犹太人法律平等的理由。事实上，导致欧洲犹太人第一次解放的过程表明，表面上对犹太人对商业贡献的积极评价从未使中世纪的犹太高利贷者形象变得过时。
