克莱拉克的犹太人是过去的幻影，使他的读者能够理解现在，而他塑造的传说，或至少是广播的传说，其成功归功于它利用中世纪的犹太高利贷者的形象来表达现代早期对错综复杂和无处不在的汇票的忧虑。其中，犹太人首先被描述为中世纪法国国王下令驱逐的对象，并暗指 13 世纪的圣餐奇迹。然后，通过快节奏的叙述，表面上看是犹太人的发明 —— 汇票，据说在阿姆斯特丹达到了顶峰，阿姆斯特丹是十七世纪的世界经济之都，是商业信贷（而不是典当）的中心，也是所有早期现代欧洲商业社会中最跨宗派的地方。在拼凑这个故事的过程中，克莱拉克把犹太高利贷者的形象作为一种防御机制，当时市场交易的日益非个人化被认为是对既定社会等级制度和传统权威形式的威胁。下一章将说明克莱拉克抓住的犹太高利贷者的形象是如何既顽强又可塑的，这些双重品质说明了这个传说的持久性和可塑性。

3

The Riddle of Usury

高利贷之谜

THE NOTION THAT the church stalled economic development in Catholic Europe and, conversely, that a few brave merchants succeeded in business by ignoring Catholic doctrines about usury, at least until their last confession, long dominated lay and scholarly views of the Middle Ages, particularly in the Anglo-American world. But a fertile field of historiographical research in the past half century has put these views to rest and made us fully aware of what Étienne Cleirac and his contemporaries knew all too well: the Catholic Church neither opposed all forms of profit and entrepreneurship nor turned a blind eye to infringements of its own doctrines; instead, it struggled to reach a consensus regarding acceptable forms of wealth and wealth management. From this perspective, we can recognize Cleirac’s tirades against Jews and usury as vernacular expressions of learned debates about which contracts were illegitimate and which agreeable, as well as about who could permissibly be party to either.1

教会阻碍了天主教欧洲的经济发展，相反，少数勇敢的商人通过无视天主教关于高利贷的教义，至少在他们最后的忏悔之前，在商业上获得了成功，这种观点长期以来主导着非专业人士和学者对中世纪的看法，尤其是在英美世界。但在过去半个世纪里，一个肥沃的历史学研究领域让这些观点不攻自破，并让我们充分认识到艾蒂安·克莱拉克和他同时代的人都很清楚：天主教会既不反对所有形式的利润和企业家精神，也不对违反其自身教义的行为视而不见；相反，它努力就可接受的财富和财富管理形式达成共识。从这个角度来看，我们可以认识到克莱拉克对犹太人和高利贷的抨击是对哪些合同是非法的，哪些是可以接受的，以及谁可以被允许成为其中一方的学问辩论的白话表达。1

The next chapter will situate Cleirac and his works in the context of their time. For now, I will resume my analysis of his text where I left it. Cleirac’s words locate him at an important and little understood historical junction, when the late medieval habit of treating money and the economy as part of the moral and theological universe intersected with the emerging “science of commerce,” that is, the increasingly secularized literature that discussed commerce as a profession and an object of government policies.2 This literature assigned multifarious meanings to the word usury . Church doctrines about usury were neither uniform nor uncontested. Different definitions of the practice coexisted, and clergymen granted considerable leeway to ecclesiastical or secular tribunals investigating those charged with the sin (a sin that in some polities had been made into a crime). The most salient phase in these debates, for the purpose of understanding Cleirac’s musings on the topic, occurred in the sixteenth century, when Catholic theologians devised new and subtle arguments about the legitimacy of various financial contracts, including marine insurance and bills of exchange, in order to control but not hamper the expansion of European commercial society.

下一章将把克莱拉克和他的作品置于他们的时代背景中。现在，我将在我离开的地方继续分析他的文本。克莱拉克的文字将他定位在一个重要而又鲜为人知的历史路口，当时中世纪晚期将货币和经济视为道德和神学世界的一部分的习惯与新兴的 “商业科学” 相交，也就是说，日益世俗化的文献将商业作为一种职业和政府政策的对象来讨论。2这些文献为高利贷这个词赋予了多种含义。教会关于高利贷的教义既不统一也没有争议。对这种做法的不同定义并存，神职人员对调查那些被指控犯有高利贷的人的教会或世俗法庭给予了相当大的回旋余地（在一些政体中，这种罪行已被定为犯罪）。这些辩论中最突出的阶段，，以便理解克莱拉克对这个问题的思考，发生在 16 世纪，当时天主教神学家对各种金融合同，包括海事保险和汇票的合法性提出了新的微妙论点，以便控制但不妨碍欧洲商业社会的扩张。

By the eighteenth century, writers of the ars mercatoria treated the term usury as a placeholder for all sorts of unsavory economic behaviors, and because of the enduring influence of an earlier discourse, they often assumed that Jews personified such behaviors. As a result, allusions to Jews continued to function as symbolic standards against which economic conduct could be measured long after the Middle Ages.

到了 18 世纪，商法典的作者们把高利贷这个词当作各种不光彩的经济行为的代名词，而且由于早期话语的持久影响，他们常常认为犹太人就是这些行为的化身。因此，对犹太人的影射在中世纪之后的很长一段时间里，仍然作为衡量经济行为的象征性标准发挥作用。

Usury and Its Enigmas

高利贷及其谜团

Historians cannot determine the interest rates charged on bills of exchange because they were included in the currency conversion rate. The stratagem was similar to the one that a series of recent consolidated class actions alleged Visa, Mastercard, and Diners Club had engaged in as a way of hiding foreign transaction fees behind currency conversion rates.3 Some scholars assume that in the premodern period this expedient allowed merchants and bankers to avoid charges of usury and represented the ingenuity of Catholic merchants wishing to bypass canon law. In reality, theologians and canon lawyers were not easily fooled. As the complexity of bills of exchange grew, so did the financial expertise of those intent on combating usury and the intricacies of church rules condemning it. That is why, a few specialists aside, “usury is perhaps the most ridiculed, but least understood, idea in the history of economics.”4

历史学家无法确定对汇票收取的利率，因为它们被包含在货币兑换率中。这种策略类似于最近的一系列合并集体诉讼指控维萨、万事达和大莱卡从事的在货币兑换率背后隐藏外国交易费用的方式。3一些学者认为，在前现代时期，这种权宜之计使商人和银行家能够避免高利贷的指控，并代表了希望绕过教规法的天主教商人的聪明才智。实际上，神学家和教规律师并不容易被愚弄。随着汇票的复杂性增加，那些打算打击高利贷的人的金融专业知识和谴责高利贷的复杂的教会规则也在增加。这就是为什么，除了一些专家之外，“高利贷也许是经济学史上最被嘲笑，但最不被理解的想法”。4

The Old Testament (Exodus 22:24–25, Leviticus 23:33–37, Deuteronomy 23:19–20, Psalms 15:5), one passage in the Gospel of Luke (6:34–35), and several Patristic texts provided authoritative scriptural foundations for the strictest position articulated in Gratian’s Decretum , according to which “any sum returned in excess to the principal is usury.”5 Thomist theologians meanwhile rediscovered Aristotle’s doctrine of the sterility of money (Politics 1:10, Nicomachean Ethics 5:5), which they adopted as a complementary anti-usury argument.6 But even before Reformed leaders in the sixteenth century questioned strict Scholastic interpretations of usury, Catholic moral theologians and canon lawyers had already devised two sets of responses to this thorny problem, both of which are reflected in Cleirac’s commentary: the first developed new taxonomies of legitimate and illegitimate credit contracts; the second approached charges of usurious behavior on an ad hoc basis, judging conduct case by case and issuing exceptions rather than sweeping condemnations. All anti-usury injunctions, in any case, only applied to Christians. Excluded from the community of believers, Jews were allowed to charge interest and soon became widely accepted symbols of rapacious moneylending.

旧约（《出埃及记》22:24-25，《利未记》23:33-37，《申命记》23:19-20，《诗篇》15:5），《路加福音》中的一段话（6:34-35），以及一些教父的文本为格拉西安的《宣言》（Decretum）中阐述的最严格立场提供了权威的圣经基础，据此 “任何超过本金归还的款项都是高利贷”。5同时，托马斯神学家重新发现了亚里士多德关于货币不育的学说（《政治学》1:10，《尼各马可伦理学》5:5），他们将其作为反高利贷的补充论据。6但是，甚至在 16 世纪改革派领袖质疑严格的学说对高利贷的解释之前，天主教道德神学家和教会律师已经对这个棘手的问题设计了两套反应，这两套反应都反映在克莱拉克的评注中：第一套对合法和不合法的信贷合同制定了新的分类法；第二套对高利贷行为的指控采取特殊处理，逐案判断，发布例外而不是全面的谴责。在任何情况下，所有反高利贷的禁令都只适用于基督徒。犹太人被排除在信徒群体之外，被允许收取利息，并很快成为被广泛接受的放高利贷的象征。

Cleirac derives his equation of Jews and usury from some of the most bellicose Christian depictions of this equivalence, notably those by Church Father Ambrose of Milan and Canon 67 of the Fourth Lateran Council.7 In 1215, the Fourth Lateran Council required Jews living amid Christians to wear distinctive clothing and crystallized the association between Jews and usury in Canon 67, which described Christian society and church properties as being devoured by Jews, who were said to extort “heavy and immoderate usuries” (graves immoderatasque usuras ).8 At the time, some Jewish scholars who were fully versed in Scholastic thought challenged church doctrine and Christian hypocrisy in matters of Jewish moneylending.9 But these texts were neither accessible nor of interest to Cleirac. His training and his faith took him else-where—specifically, to the new ethics developed by moral theologians and canon lawyers, especially Franciscan friars, for mercantile urban elites in the wake of the commercial revolution of the Middle Ages and to the writings of their sixteenth-century successors.

克莱拉克将犹太人和高利贷等同起来，是源于基督教对这种等同关系的一些最激进的描述，特别是米兰的教父安布罗斯和第四届拉特兰会议的第 67 条。71215 年，第四届拉特兰会议要求生活在基督徒中间的犹太人穿上特殊的衣服，并在第 67 条中明确了犹太人和高利贷之间的联系，该条描述了基督教社会和教会财产被犹太人吞噬，据说他们勒索 “沉重而不节制的高利贷”（graves immoderatasque usuras）。8当时，一些精通学术思想的犹太学者对教会教义和基督教在犹太人放贷问题上的虚伪行为提出质疑。9但这些文本对克莱拉克来说既不容易理解，也不感兴趣。他的训练和他的信仰把他带到了别的地方 —— 特别是道德神学家和教会律师，尤其是方济各会的修士，在中世纪的商业革命之后为城市商业精英制定的新伦理，以及他们在 16 世纪的继承者的著作。

Unlike earlier medieval monks who railed against the moneyed economy, Franciscan friars did not condemn all forms of profit. Rather, they scrutinized each and every business contract, outlined theories of just prices and private property, and devised ingenious justifications of the church’s management of its own large landed and movable wealth. Aiming to regulate the market according to its moral principles, the church strove to distinguish between usury and beneficial credit transactions rather than banning all profit-making activities. Bernardino da Siena (d. 1444), the vocal Franciscan preacher later proclaimed a saint and a leader of antisemitic persecutions, was among the many in his order who not only denounced fraud and avarice but also stressed the positive impact that trade had on civic life: “Nothing contributes to the Commune so much as the profit of the guilds and of the merchandize that is bought and sold,” he declared.10 Literal readings of scripture never went away, but the doctrines of the Roman Catholic Church came to encompass a variety of competing definitions of usury, and theologians, moral philosophers, and canon and civil lawyers debated which credit instruments were legitimate and which were not.

与中世纪早期抨击金钱经济的僧侣不同，方济各会士并没有谴责所有形式的利润。相反，他们仔细研究了每一份商业合同，概述了公正的价格和私有财产的理论，并为教会管理自己的大量土地和动产制定了巧妙的理由。为了根据其道德原则规范市场，教会努力区分高利贷和有益的信贷交易，而不是禁止所有营利活动。锡耶纳·德·伯纳丁（Bernardino da Siena，卒于 1444），这位声名显赫的方济各会传教士后来被宣布为圣人，是反犹太主义迫害的领导者，他是其教团中许多人中的一员，不仅谴责欺诈和贪婪，还强调贸易对公民生活的积极影响：“没有什么比行会的利润和买卖的商品对公社的贡献更大了”，他宣布。10对圣经的字面解读从未消失，但罗马天主教会的教义却包含了各种相互竞争的高利贷定义，神学家、道德哲学家、教规和民事律师都在辩论哪些信贷工具是合法的，哪些是不合法的。

Marine insurance was among the first credit contracts to find wide acceptance. Pope Gregory IX’s decretal Naviganti (1236) denied that the assumption of risk (periculum sortis ) justified charging any interest, but its wording left the door open to protracted disquisitions about the nature of usury.11 Only a few decades later, the noted Franciscan John Duns Scotus admitted that professional merchants were allowed to derive a profit in exchange for servicing society at large (as long as their commercial activities involved neither fraud nor duress) and, more specifically, that they could be paid a premium to cover the risk of transporting goods.12 By the early fifteenth century, the Florentine lawyer Lorenzo Ridolfi and others had proposed a different but even more powerful counterargument to the papal injunction of 1236: marine insurance was acceptable because it was not a loan but a type of contract unknown in ancient Roman law (contractus innominatus ), a form of lease in which the insurer took on the assumption of risk from the merchant and was entitled to demand remuneration in exchange.13

海事保险是最早被广泛接受的信贷合同之一。教皇格雷戈里九世的海员法令（Naviganti，1236）否认承担风险（periculum sortis）可以证明收取任何利息是合理的，但其措辞使人们对高利贷的性质进行了长期的讨论。11仅仅几十年后，著名的方济各会士约翰·邓斯库特承认，允许职业商人通过为整个社会服务来获取利润（只要他们的商业活动不涉及欺诈或胁迫），更具体地说，可以向他们支付保险费以支付运输货物的风险。12到 15 世纪初，佛罗伦萨律师洛伦佐·里多菲和其他人对 1236 年的教皇禁令提出了一个不同但更有力的反驳：海事保险是可以接受的，因为它不是贷款，而是一种在古罗马法中不为人知的合同类型（contractus innominatus），一种租赁形式，其中保险人承担了商人的风险，有权要求以报酬作为交换。13

The recognition that marine insurance provided collective benefits and its classification as a lease paved the way for the full legitimation of premium insurance. During the next period of rapid economic growth, the sixteenth century, the most influential moral theologians at the University of Salamanca, including two Dominicans, Francisco de Vitoria (1492–1546) and Domingo de Soto (1495–1560), and the Jesuit Luis de Molina (1535–1600), reaffirmed the legitimacy of marine insurance. In Us et coustumes de la mer , Cleirac cites a well-known Spanish confessional manual of the time to support his statement that marine insurance is an asset to the flourishing of the state.14 Molina proved particularly influential in this regard because he argued that marine insurance was a purchase-and-sale contract, rather than a credit contract, and thus not susceptible to usury charges.15 Jurists embraced his definition, which the Genoese commercial law expert Sigismondo Scaccia repeated in 1619.16

承认海事保险提供了集体利益，并将其归类为租赁，为保费保险的全面合法化铺平了道路。在下一个经济快速增长时期，即 16 世纪，萨拉曼卡大学最有影响力的道德神学家，包括两位多米尼加人弗朗西斯科·德·维托利亚（1492-1546）和多明戈·德·索托（1495-1560），以及耶稣会士路易斯·德·莫利纳（1535-1600），重申了海事保险的合法性。在《海洋的用途和习俗》 中，克莱拉克引用了当时著名的西班牙忏悔手册来支持他的声明，即海事保险是国家繁荣发展的资产。14莫利纳在这方面被证明是特别有影响力的，因为他认为海事保险是一种买卖合同，而不是一种信贷合同，因此不容易受到高利贷的影响。15法学家们接受了他的定义，热那亚商法专家西吉斯蒙德·斯卡西亚（Sigismondo Scaccia）在 1619 年重复了这个定义。16

Cleirac knew this argument well, since it constituted the core principle of the first article of the Guidon de la mer , the object of his commentary.17 He was even familiar with pertinent jurisprudence that adopted this definition. Indeed, before introducing the extravagant tale of the Jewish invention of marine insurance and bills of exchange, Cleirac notes that the high civil court of Genoa, the Rota , defined marine insurance as a purchase-and-sale contract in which the price was justified and determined by the risk involved (“emptioni & venditoni propter prætium quod datur ratione periculi”).18

克莱拉克非常了解这一论点，因为它构成了《海洋指南》第一条的核心原则，是他评论的对象。17他甚至对采用这一定义的相关法学也很熟悉。事实上，在介绍犹太人发明海事保险和汇票的奢侈故事之前，克莱拉克指出，热那亚的高级民事法庭，即 Rota，将海事保险定义为一种买卖合同，其中的价格是合理的，并由所涉及的风险决定（“emptioni & venditoni propter prætium quod datur ratione periculi”）。18

The same logic came to be applied to bills of exchange.19 They passed muster as long as, following Aristotle and Roman law, they were classified not as money (which could be loaned) but as nonfungible goods like horses and real estate, which were not susceptible to a loan contract (mutuum ) because they could be returned in the same condition as when they were given.20 Sustained through longer and fully-articulated disquisitions, the argument was widely accepted by the time Cleirac penned his commentary, with one important caveat: whereas marine insurance was no longer suspected of being usurious, different types of bills of exchange still stirred considerable controversy. The majority of churchmen accepted as legitimate four-party bills, which they described as “real exchanges,” but suspicion continued to follow more complex instruments, such as dry exchange, that had come to the fore at the financial fairs of Lyon and Besançon and in Europe’s major commercial hubs.

同样的逻辑也适用于汇票。19只要按照亚里士多德和罗马法，不把它们归类为货币（可以借出），而是归类为马匹和房地产等非易腐物品，它们就能通过审核，因为它们可以在归还时保持原状。20通过更长的时间和充分阐述的讨论，这一论点在克莱拉克撰写评论时已被广泛接受，但有一个重要的注意事项：虽然海事保险不再被怀疑是高利贷，但不同类型的汇票仍然引起了很大的争议。大多数教会人士认为四方汇票是合法的，他们将其描述为 “真正的交换”，但对更复杂的票据仍有怀疑，如干汇，它们在里昂和贝桑松的金融博览会以及欧洲的主要商业中心崭露头角。

Cleirac appears to have been well acquainted with these technical debates and the leading voices of Second Scholasticism, who had updated Franciscan teachings to address the increasing financial sophistication of the time. With unusual clarity, he synthesizes the views of two leading Catholic theologians of the sixteenth century: “In reality, those banking activities and insurances that are treated as honorable, upright, and legal activities are greatly useful and helpful to business, even according to the opinion of Thomas de Vio, known as Cardinal Cajetan, in his Tractatus de cambijs , chapter 5, and Navarrus, in his Enchiridion , chapter 17, no. 284.”

克莱拉克似乎非常熟悉这些技术性的辩论和第二学术派的主要声音，他们更新了方济各会的教义，以应对当时日益复杂的金融形势。他以不同寻常的清晰度，综合了十六世纪两位主要天主教神学家的观点。“实际上，那些被视为光荣的、正直的、合法的银行活动和保险对商业有很大的作用和帮助，甚至根据托马斯·德·维奥（被称为红衣主教卡耶坦）在其《变化论》（Tractatus de cambijs）, 第五章和纳瓦鲁斯在其《忏悔者手册》（The Enchiridion）, 第十七章第 284 句中的观点。

The Dominican Tommaso de Vio, better known as Cardinal Cajetan (1469–1534), is usually remembered as a commentator of Aquinas’s Summa and a fierce opponent of the Reformation (he questioned Luther at the Diet of Augsburg in 1518–1519 and refused to annul Henry VIII’s marriage to Catherine of Aragon). But he was also the author of several treatises on the economy, including one on exchange dealings, De cambiis , written in 1499 and first published in 1506, which sought to categorize licit and illicit forms of exchange and concluded that neither moneychanging involving real coins nor classic bills of exchange were usurious, only re-exchange contracts and dry exchange. Having rejected the notion that four-party bills of exchange were loans, Cajetan’s treatise, in the chapter that Cleirac cites, affirmed the usefulness of honest moneychangers who acted for the well-being of society (civitas ).21

多米尼加人托马索·德·维奥（Tommaso de Vio），也就是人们所熟知的红衣主教卡耶坦（1469-1534），通常以阿奎那《苏美尔》的注释者和宗教改革的激烈反对者的身份被人们记住（他在 1518-1519 年的奥格斯堡议会上质疑路德，并拒绝宣布亨利八世与阿拉贡凯瑟琳的婚姻无效）。但他也是几篇经济论文的作者，其中包括一篇关于交换交易的论文《变革的原因》（De cambiis），写于 1499 年，首次出版于 1506 年，该论文试图对合法和非法的交换形式进行分类，并得出结论，涉及真正硬币的货币交换和经典汇票都不是高利贷，只有再交换合同和干式交换。在拒绝了四方汇票是贷款的概念后，卡耶坦的论文在克莱拉克引用的那一章中肯定了诚实的货币兑换商的作用，他们的行为是为了社会的福祉（civitas）。21

Cleirac’s other reference in this passage is to Martín Azpilcueta, also known as Doctor Navarrus (1491–1586), another towering figure of Second Scholasticism. The Enchiridion , Navarrus’s handbook for confessors and penitents, distilled subtle moral and economic arguments about topics such as usury, ecclesiastical properties, and money, and became an extremely popular publication. Chapter 17 of the Enchiridion was a commentary on the seventh commandment, “Thou shalt not steal,” and delivered a harsh condemnation of usury. Cleirac zooms in on a section that Navarrus added to the revised Latin edition of his handbook focusing on dry exchange as opposed to the four-party bill of exchange. There, agreeing with Cajetan, de Soto, and others, Navarrus declared dry exchange to be against natural, divine, and human justice.22

克莱拉克在这段话中提到了马丁·阿兹皮尔库埃塔（Martín Azpilcueta），又称纳瓦鲁斯博士（1491-1586），他是第二学术派的另一位杰出人物。纳瓦鲁斯的《忏悔者和忏悔者手册》提炼了关于高利贷、教会财产和货币等主题的微妙的道德和经济论点，并成为一本非常受欢迎的出版物。《手册》的第 17 章是对第七条戒律 “不可偷盗” 的评论，对高利贷进行了严厉的谴责。克莱拉克放大了纳瓦鲁斯在其手册的拉丁文修订版中加入的一节，重点是干式交换，而不是四方汇票。在那里，纳瓦鲁斯同意卡耶坦、德索托等人的观点，宣布干式交易违反自然、神圣和人类的正义。22

It was precisely this differentiation between unmitigated censures of usury and condemnations of certain types of bills of exchange that interested Cleirac and that he helped popularize. Like most of his contemporaries, however, he clearly found the taxonomy of contractual forms to be insufficient for establishing what constituted acceptable credit practices. To complement the frameworks proposed by moral philosophers and canon and civil lawyers, Cleirac turned to a familiar cultural referent: the figure of the Jewish usurer.

正是这种对高利贷的无情指责和对某些类型汇票的谴责之间的区别，使克莱拉克感兴趣，并帮助他普及了这种区别。然而，像他同时代的大多数人一样，他显然发现合同形式的分类法不足以确定什么构成可接受的信贷做法。为了补充道德哲学家、教规和民事律师提出的框架，克莱拉克转向了一个熟悉的文化参照物：犹太高利贷者的形象。

The oblivion into which the legend we are grappling with has fallen today has much to do with the fact that modern scholars of commercial and maritime law are accustomed to thinking that by the seventeenth century, this field of inquiry had entered the sphere of politics and left that of theology. In reality, the figure of the Jewish usurer hardly disappeared from the early modern imagination and impressed on readers the notion of improper financial behavior more effectively than did arguments based on casuistry and canon law. A 1585 French manual of practical arithmetic instructed merchants to calculate compound interest at the same time as it denounced compound interest as “usury of usury” and a Jewish habit that was “execrable” and “abominable” (two adjectives that, as we saw in chapter 2 , were typical of anti-Jewish Christian polemics).23 Forty years later, a treatise on bills of exchange called dry exchange “adulterous,” conflating sexual transgression with financial immorality.24 Cleirac concurred and added that dry exchange was “pure Jewishness” (pure Iuifverie ).25

今天，我们正在处理的这个传说之所以被遗忘，在很大程度上与以下事实有关：现代商法和海商法学者习惯于认为，到了 17 世纪，这一研究领域已经进入政治领域，离开了神学领域。实际上，犹太高利贷者的形象几乎没有从现代早期的想象中消失，并且比基于案例法和教会法的论证更有效地给读者留下了不正当金融行为的概念。一本 1585 年的法国实用算术手册指导商人计算复利，同时谴责复利是 “高利贷中的高利贷”，是 “可恶” 和 “可憎” 的犹太习惯（正如我们在第二章看到的，这两个形容词是反犹太基督教论战的典型）。2340 年后，一篇关于汇票的论文称干式交换为 “通奸”，将性侵犯与金融不道德混为一谈。24克莱拉克对此表示赞同，并补充说干汇是 “纯粹的犹太性”（pure Iuifverie）。25

Even if he was particularly insistent in linking usury to Jews, Cleirac was not alone in this tendency among the authors of early modern didactic texts about merchant practice, whom we might otherwise assume would have taken a more neutral stance. In order to pinpoint specific contracts as acceptable or unacceptable, these texts resorted to the same association between Jews and usury. They thus demonstrate the power of language and tradition to police the boundaries of proper credit and to define, at least in negative terms, ethical standards of behavior and sources of collective identification.

即使他特别坚持将高利贷与犹太人联系起来，但在关于商人行为的早期现代说教文本的作者中，克莱拉克并不是唯一具有这种倾向的人，否则我们可能会认为他们会采取更中立的立场。为了确定具体的合同是可接受的还是不可接受的，这些文本采用了犹太人和高利贷之间的相同联系。因此，它们展示了语言和传统的力量，以监督适当信贷的界限，并至少在消极方面界定行为的道德标准和集体认同的来源。

From Jews to Lombards and Cahorsins

从犹太人到伦巴第人和卡奥辛人

Midway into the narrative of what I am calling the legend of the Jewish invention of marine insurance and bills of exchange, Cleirac shifts his target, if not his tone. Having called both credit instruments “Jewish from birth, both in their invention and denomination,” he explains that Jews were not the worst culprits in the crime of lending at interest. Even more repugnant, he claims, were those Christians who adopted “this Jewish intrigue” and, “after they retained the models of these letters [i.e., bills of exchange], learned to use them effectively.” He refers to these individuals as “Lombards and Cahorsins.”

在叙述我所说的犹太人发明海事保险和汇票的传说的中途，克莱拉克转移了目标，如果不是他的语气的话。他称这两种信贷工具 “无论在发明上还是在名称上都是天生的犹太人”，他解释说，犹太人并不是最严重的，他们犯下了借贷利息的罪魁祸首。他声称，更令人厌恶的是那些采用 “这种犹太阴谋” 的基督徒，“在他们保留了这些信件即汇票的模型之后，学会了有效地使用它们”。他把这些人称为 “伦巴第人和卡奥尔森人”。

The unexpected arrival of this sort of usurers from south of the Alps caused them [i.e., the Jews] great discontent and pain, because they [i.e., the Jews] saw that their imitators, their disciples, their acolytes, and their wretched clerks had mastered the art of usury to an even greater extent than they did; they [i.e., Lombard bankers] had become even more evil and malicious insofar as usury and rapaciousness were concerned; they bent and concocted their practices, and extracted from people greater profits and loot than Jews dared to aim for or demand; and those scoundrels were now being treated as noblemen, held in esteem as men of honor and merit, and considerably well-placed in their favors—e lodati ne van, non che impuniti — whereas Jews were hated, treated as jackanapes, and continuously ridiculed with contempt and affront, marked with a yellow hat, harassed as pages and lackeys at every occasion.

这种来自阿尔卑斯山以南的高利贷者的意外到来，使他们即犹太人非常不满和痛苦，因为他们即犹太人看到，他们的模仿者、他们的弟子、他们的信徒和他们可恶的文员已经掌握了高利贷的艺术，甚至比他们更厉害；他们即伦巴第银行家在高利贷和贪婪方面变得更加邪恶和恶毒；他们弯曲和编造他们的做法，从人们身上榨取比他们更多的利润和财富。伦巴第银行家]在高利贷和贪婪方面变得更加邪恶和恶毒；他们歪曲和捏造他们的做法，从人们身上榨取比犹太人敢于瞄准或要求的更大的利润和掠夺。这些恶棍现在被当作贵族对待，被当作有荣誉和功绩的人而受到尊敬，并在他们的宠爱中得到相当大的地位 —— 他们受到赞美，并不是说他们没有受到惩罚（e lodati ne van, non che impuniti） —— 而犹太人则被憎恨，被当作豺狼（jackanapes），并不断受到蔑视和侮辱的嘲笑，被戴上黄帽子，在任何场合都被当作仆人和奴仆来骚扰。

Lombards, originally hailing from Asti in Piedmont, were licensed Christian moneylenders and bankers whose presence became particularly visible in those regions of Europe from which Jews had been expelled. By 1323, Paris had a Rue des Lombards. The town of Cahors, north of Toulouse, was also invariably associated with devious Christian bankers. Specialists have since corrected several misconceptions concerning the alleged rapaciousness of Lombards and Cahorsins.26 Here, however, it is the traditional image of these groups as incarnations of avarice and duplicity that matters more than the reality of their lending practices. In this portrayal, the terms Lombards and Cahorsins lost all geographical specificity and became stands-in for usurious Christian moneylenders. A businessman defending the noted Tuscan merchant Francesco Datini after he joined the guild of bankers and money-changers (Arte del Cambio ) in 1398, for example, declared: “‘They will say, he is a caor sino ’ and I reply, ‘He does not do it to be a usurer, for he will leave all he has to the poor!’”27 A near contemporary of Cleirac wrote that Lombard announced the presence of usury in the same way as Monte di Pietà signaled the absence of usury.28

伦巴第人最初来自皮埃蒙特的阿斯蒂，是有执照的基督教放债人和银行家，他们的存在在犹太人被驱逐出欧洲的那些地区变得特别明显。到 1323 年，巴黎有一条伦巴第大街。图卢兹北部的卡奥尔镇也无一例外地与狡猾的基督教银行家联系在一起。此后，专家们纠正了关于所谓的伦巴第人和卡奥尔人的贪婪的一些错误观念。26然而，在这里，这些群体作为贪婪和奸诈的化身的传统形象比他们的借贷行为的现实更为重要。在这种描述中，伦巴第人和卡奥尔森这两个词失去了所有的地理特征，成为基督教放债人的代表。例如，一位商人在托斯卡纳著名商人弗朗西斯科·达蒂尼于 1398 年加入银行家和货币兑换商协会（Arte del Cambio）后为他辩护，他宣称 “他们会说，他是一个‘caor sino’，我回答说，‘他这样做不是为了当高利贷者，因为他要把自己所有的东西留给穷人！’”27克莱拉克的一位近代认同者写道，伦巴第宣布高利贷的存在，与蒙特·迪·皮塔表示没有高利贷的方式相同。28

In canto XI of Dante’s Inferno , Cahors takes the place of Gomorrah next to Sodom—a passage that Cleirac cites in full.29 Following the Aristotelian view absorbed by Thomist theology that “money is barren,” sodomy became a synonym for usury. Cleirac finds confirmation of the analogy between Jewish usury and nonreproductive sex in Paul’s epistle to the Ephesians (5:3–5), which branded all “fornicators” as “idolaters.”30 The Benedictine monk and English chronicler Matthew Paris (d. 1259), Cleirac’s most trusted guide in matters of usury (he is cited a total of five times), denounced not only Jews but also those Christian merchants and bankers who succeeded in “cloaking their usury under the shadow of trade” (“usuram sub specie negotiationis palliantes”).31 Usury, like sodomy, was viewed as an antisocial behavior, and Jews were alleged to excel at it. Blaming Jews for all the evils that had befallen Christian society, a seventeenth-century Portuguese polemicist accused them of having introduced sodomy and incest in Portugal and Africa and described them, drawing on a popular trope of the day, as dogs and horses that could not control their instincts (“cães ou cavalos desenfreados”).32

在但丁的《地狱》第十一节中，卡奥尔取代了所多玛旁边的蛾摩拉 —— 克莱拉克完整地引用了这段话。29根据被托马斯神学吸收的亚里士多德的观点，即 “金钱是贫瘠的”，鸡奸成为成为高利贷的同义词。克莱拉克在保罗给以弗所人的书信（5:3-5）中找到了犹太高利贷和非生殖性行为之间的类比确认，该书信将所有 “通奸者” 称为 “拜偶像者”。30本笃会修士和英国编年史家马修·帕里斯（卒于 1259）是克莱拉克在高利贷问题上最信任的指导者（他总共被引用了五次），他不仅谴责犹太人，还谴责那些成功地 “在贸易的阴影下掩盖其高利贷”（“usuram sub specie negotiationis palliantes”）的基督教商人和银行家。31高利贷，就像鸡奸一样，被视为一种反社会行为，而犹太人被指擅长此道。一位十七世纪的葡萄牙论战者将基督教社会遭遇的所有罪恶归咎于犹太人，指责他们在葡萄牙和非洲引入了鸡奸和乱伦，并根据当时流行的说法将他们描述为无法控制自己本能的狗和马（“cães ou cavalos desenfreados”）。32

In Cleirac’s words, Lombards and Cahorsins “mastered the art of usury to an even greater extent than they [the Jews] did” and “extracted from people greater profits and loot than Jews dared to aim for or demand.” Having learned to use bills of exchange (“these Jewish inventions”), Christian bankers now only handled “the feather and the sheet of paper,” that is, intangible credit instruments rather than minted coins. In so doing, they confounded debtors and preyed on them more easily.

用克莱拉克的话说，伦巴第人和卡奥尔森人 “掌握了高利贷的艺术，其程度甚至超过了他们（犹太人）”，并 “从人们身上榨取了比犹太人敢于瞄准或要求的更大的利润和掠夺”。在学会使用汇票（“这些犹太人的发明”）之后，基督教银行家现在只处理 “羽毛和纸片”，即无形的信贷工具，而不是铸造的硬币。这样一来，他们就把债务人搞糊涂了，更容易对他们下手了。

In Cleirac’s assessment, Lombards not only had “become even more evil and malicious insofar as usury and rapaciousness were concerned” but were also, concerningly, “treated as noblemen, held in esteem as men of honor and merit.” In this serious indictment of Christian rulers and society, Cleirac’s humanistic education comes to his rescue, affording him a touch of humor in an otherwise grim portrait. He turns to the Renaissance Italian poet Ludovico Ariosto, who satirized the frequency with which Jews were “harassed . . . at every occasion” (I supposti , III.1) and denounced the hypocrisy of punishing women for adultery while praising men for the same sin (Orlando Furioso , IV.66.8).33 In spite of the comic relief provided by Ariosto, Cleirac still insists on the gravity of the problem. At least “Jews were hated, treated as jackanapes, and continuously ridiculed,” he notes. The requirement that they be “marked with a yellow hat” literalized their status as outcasts. But what, if anything, could cordon off Lombards from other Christians? All other measures having failed, the 1274 church canon entitled The Abyss of Usury (a document mentioned by Villani) demanded that Christian rulers expel foreign Christian moneylenders from all their domains (chapter 2 ).

在克莱拉克的评估中，伦巴第人不仅 “在高利贷和贪婪方面变得更加邪恶和恶毒”，而且令人担忧的是，他们还 “被当作贵族，被当作有荣誉和功绩的人而受到尊敬”。在对基督教统治者和社会的这一严肃的控诉中，克莱拉克所受的人文教育对他有所帮助，使他在这幅严峻的画卷中获得了一丝幽默感。他求助于文艺复兴时期的意大利诗人路多维科·阿里奥斯托（Ludovico Ariosto），后者讽刺了犹太人 “在每个场合都受到骚扰”（I supposti，III.1）的频率，并谴责了惩罚通奸妇女而赞美犯有同样罪行的男人的虚伪行为（Orlando Furioso，IV.66.8）。（33尽管阿里奥斯托提供了喜剧性的安慰，克莱拉克仍然坚持问题的严重性。他指出，至少 “犹太人受到了憎恨，被当作傻瓜，并不断受到嘲笑”。要求他们 “戴上黄帽子” 的要求使他们作为被遗弃者的地位文字化。但是，如果有的话，有什么可以将伦巴第人与其他基督徒隔离开来？在所有其他措施都失败后，1274 年的教会教规《高利贷深渊》Villani 提到的一份文件）要求基督教统治者将外国基督教放债人从其所有领地驱逐出去（第二章）。

Cleirac gives the following summary of those historical events: “Eventually, these Lombard bankers became so intolerable due to their exorbitant usurious charges, exactions, extortions and illicit profits, that they were treated in France in the same fashion as Jews were.” He recounts the sequence of expulsions of Lombards from medieval France in greater detail than he provides for their Jewish equivalents, singling out those ordered by Saint Louis (r. 1226–1270) and Philip the Fair (r. 1285–1314). Cleirac also laments that Lombards (“these rustics”) continued to wield considerable influence at court and in 1311 were readmitted to the kingdom “on condition that they would become honest in the future and would abstain from all their bad practices.” That did not happen. In fact, “instead of reforming themselves, these parasitical hypocrites became even more dissolute.” King Philip VI of Valois (r. 1328–1350) had no choice but to expel them. Finally, in 1347, he “purged his kingdom of them and drove them out of France.”34

克莱拉克对这些历史事件做了如下总结。“最终，这些伦巴第银行家因其高昂的高利贷费用、苛捐杂税、敲诈勒索和非法利润而变得如此令人难以忍受，以至于他们在法国受到了与犹太人同样的待遇。他叙述了中世纪法国驱逐伦巴第人的顺序，比他为犹太人提供的更详细，特别是圣路易（1226-1270）和菲利普王子（1285-1314）下令驱逐的人。克莱拉克还对伦巴第人（“这些乡巴佬”）继续在宫廷中拥有相当大的影响力表示遗憾，并在 1311 年被重新允许进入王国，“条件是他们今后要变得诚实，并戒除所有的坏习惯”。这并没有发生。事实上，“这些寄生的伪君子非但没有改过自新，反而变得更加放荡不羁”。瓦卢斯国王菲利普六世（1328-1350）别无选择，只能将他们驱逐出去。最后，在 1347 年，他 “在他的王国里清除了他们，把他们赶出了法国”。34

When relaying the chronology of Jews’ expulsions from medieval France in the first part of his narrative, Cleirac makes no reference to specific chronicles or other sources of information. By contrast, when outlining the actions taken by French kings against foreign Christian moneylenders, he offers more details and relies not only on older narratives by the chronicler Jean Froissart (c. 1337–c. 1405) and the royal secretary and historian Nicole Gilles (d. 1503), but also on more recent writers, including Étienne Pasquier (1529–1615), a historian one generation younger than Cleirac who based his work on documents he had examined firsthand while an officer in the royal treasury.35 A compilation by French lawyer and jurist Adam Théveneau serves as a further reminder that public authorities had taken steps to curb usury in France since the fourteenth century.36 Catholic authors like Cleirac, in other words, had access to considerably less factual information about the Jewish past than the Christian past, but this imbalance did not prevent them from using a few known episodes in Jewish history for didactic purposes.

克莱拉克在叙述的第一部分中转述犹太人被驱逐出中世纪法国的年表时，没有提到具体的编年史或其他信息来源。相比之下，在概述法国国王对外国基督教放债人采取的行动时，他提供了更多细节，不仅依靠编年史家让·弗罗伊萨尔（Jean Froissart，约 1337-约 1405）和皇家秘书兼历史学家尼科尔·吉尔（Nicole Gilles，卒于 1503）的较早叙述，而且还依靠较近的作家，包括比克莱拉克小一辈的历史学家艾蒂安·帕斯基耶（Étienne Pasquier，1529-1615），他的作品基于他在皇家财政部担任官员时亲手查阅的文件。35法国律师和法学家亚当·泰维诺（Adam Théveneau）的汇编进一步提醒人们，自 14 世纪以来，公共当局已经采取措施来遏制法国的高利贷。36换句话说，像克莱拉克这样的天主教作家能够获得的关于犹太人历史的事实信息要比基督教历史少得多，但这种不平衡并不妨碍他们利用犹太人历史中的一些已知事件进行说教。

Jewish Usury: Theology, Law, and Metaphor

犹太高利贷：神学、法律和隐喻

In the end, the primary targets of Cleirac’s spiteful portrayal of Jews are not Jews themselves but Lombards, Cahorsins, Guelfs, and all other Christian bankers: “These malicious liars, whose frauds are aimed to take people by surprise and to pillage their fortunes, . . . enriched themselves at the expense of their debtors, whom they initially pretended to wish to assist charitably in their adversities, only to lure them into their net.” The ill intent of those able to manipulate credit instruments with ease was viewed as even more lamentable because it exploited naïve borrowers whose needs were pressing. Cleirac describes Christian bankers who had perfected the art of trading in bills of exchange as predatory lenders:

最后，克莱拉克对犹太人的主要描写对象不是犹太人本身，而是伦巴第人、卡霍尔人、古尔夫人和所有其他基督教银行家。“这些恶意的骗子，他们的欺诈行为旨在让人们措手不及，掠夺他们的财富，…… 以牺牲债务人的利益为代价使自己致富，他们最初假装希望慈善地帮助，只是为了引诱他们入网”。那些能够轻松操纵信贷工具的人的不良意图被视为更加可悲，因为它剥削了那些需求迫切的天真借款人。克莱拉克将那些已经完善了汇票交易艺术的基督教银行家描述为掠夺性的贷款人。

Having hooked their debtors, they became even more eager to seize every possible gain, to exact usury, exchange and re-exchange rates, stipulate fines, expenditures, damages and interest, and other such shameful incremental charges, so that they never wanted to receive back the principal as long as the debtor was left solvent. They were elated by the facility with which deeds of protest and overdue terms could apply. When a debtor was weak or in difficulty, they never left him in peace, but tormented him at every scheduled date when interest payments came due, that is, every month (because in these matters usance and month are synonyms, in the sense that usury means interest payments stipulated by month) and they never ended their harassment until they had taken everything from their debtors.

在勾引了他们的债务人之后，他们更加渴望攫取一切可能的利益，索取高利贷、兑换和再兑换率，规定罚款、开支、损害赔偿和利息，以及其他此类可耻的递增费用，因此，只要债务人还有偿付能力，他们就永远不想收回本金。他们对抗议契约和逾期条款可以适用的便利感到高兴。当债务人身体虚弱或有困难时，他们从不放过他，而是在每一个利息支付到期的预定日期，即每个月（因为在这些问题上，高利贷和月是同义词，在这个意义上，高利贷意味着按月支付利息）折磨他，直到他们从债务人那里得到一切，他们才结束骚扰。

Layered with technical language, this merciless denunciation of Lombards and Cahorsins indicates that, no matter how extravagant his commentary may appear to us, Cleirac assumed his readers were well versed in the financial intricacies of bills of exchange. He also counted on them to recognize the description of Christian bankers as “imitators,” “disciples,” “acolytes,” and “wretched clerks” of Jews. As Léon Poliakov noted more than fifty years ago, to say “‘Jewish usury’ does not necessarily mean that it is or was carried on by Jews.”37Peius iudaizare , or “behaving in a manner even worse than the Jews,” is how the Cistercian monk Bernard of Clairvaux (1090–1153) famously described the conduct of Christian moneylenders, adding that it would be more appropriate to call them “baptized Jews” than Christians.38 In the early Christian church, the sin of “Judaizing” described the actions of those Jews who had recently converted to Christianity but continued to observe certain rites of their former religion, such as fasting and circumcision. During the medieval commercial revolution, the verb “to Judaize” ceased to carry a literal meaning and became the cornerstone of a discursive edifice in which Christian usurers were cast as “baptized Jews.”

这种对伦巴第人和卡霍尔森人的无情谴责充满了技术性语言，表明无论他的评论在我们看来多么奢侈，克莱拉克都认为他的读者非常了解汇票的复杂金融问题。他还指望他们能认识到基督教银行家被描述为犹太人的 “模仿者”、“门徒”、“信徒” 和 “可恶的文员”。正如莱昂·波利亚科夫（Léon Poliakov）在 50 多年前指出的，说 “‘犹太高利贷’ 并不一定意味着它是或曾经是由犹太人进行的”。37Peius iudaizare，或 “行为方式甚至比犹太人更糟糕”，这是克莱尔沃的西多会僧侣伯纳德（1090-1153）对基督教放债人行为的著名描述，并补充说称他们为 “受洗的犹太人” 比基督徒更合适。38在早期的基督教会中，“犹太化” 的罪恶描述了那些最近皈依基督教但继续遵守其以前宗教的某些仪式的犹太人的行为，如禁食和割礼。在中世纪的商业革命中，“犹太化” 这个动词不再具有字面意义，而是成为一种话语大厦的基石，其中基督教高利贷者被视为 “受洗的犹太人”。

Wherever Jewish converts to Christianity were a lived reality, the insidious analogy between Christian usurers and “baptized Jews” acquired particular poignancy.39 It was in the aftermath of the mass conversions that occurred in Spain after the violent pogroms against Jews of the 1390s that the Valencian Dominican preacher Saint Vincent Ferrer (1350–1419) railed: “Today, nearly everything is avarice, for almost everyone commits usury, which used not to be done except by Jews. But today Christians do it too, as if they were Jews.”40 This rhetorical casting of Christian merchants who engaged in unacceptable behavior as Jews gained enormous traction and lived on well beyond the confines of those locations where the recently converted Jews were the object of policing and suspicion.41

只要犹太人皈依基督教是一种生活现实，基督教高利贷者和 “受洗的犹太人” 之间阴险的比喻就会获得特别的 。39正是在 1390 年代针对犹太人的暴力大屠杀之后，西班牙发生了大规模的皈依，瓦伦西亚的多米尼加传教士圣文森特·费雷尔（1350-1419）抨击道。“今天，几乎所有的事情都是贪婪，因为几乎每个人都在放高利贷，以前除了犹太人，没有人这样做。但今天基督徒也这样做，就像他们是犹太人一样”。40这种将从事不可接受的行为的基督徒商人视为犹太人的言论获得了巨大的吸引力，并远远超出了那些新近皈依的犹太人成为警察和怀疑对象的地方的范围。41

To call a dishonest Christian a Jew was the easiest answer to a wrenching question: What defined a good merchant? No single or uniform Catholic theory of usury existed. Even theologians’ obsessive attempts to create typologies of credit contracts, such as those formulated by Cajetan and Navarrus, did not resolve the matter. Part of the ambiguity was intentional. Thirteenth-century theologians and canon lawyers had devised a vast array of “exceptions” to the stringent norm that “any sum returned in excess to the principal is usury.” These exceptions were not aberrations but rather constitutive elements of a moral and theological paradigm designed to make the reputation ( fama ) of contracting parties a defining criterion of the legitimacy of credit contracts and thus to understand market exchanges as mirrors of social relations and hierarchies that existed outside of the marketplace.42 In this sense, the antisocial nature of usury retained its versatile symbolic power well beyond the historical context in which it emerged (the moral theology of the early thirteenth century). That is why Cleirac could still mobilize the trope of Jewish usury in the seventeenth century, when commercial society was acquiring more pronounced contractual features.

把一个不诚实的基督徒称为犹太人，是对一个令人揪心的问题最简单的回答。什么是好商人的定义？没有单一或统一的天主教高利贷理论存在。即使神学家们执着地试图创建信贷合同的类型学，如卡耶坦和纳瓦鲁斯制定的那些，也没有解决这个问题。部分的模糊性是故意的。十三世纪的神学家和教规律师为 “任何超出本金的回报都是高利贷” 这一严格的规范设计了大量的 “例外”。这些例外情况并不是反常的，而是道德和神学范式的构成要素，旨在使签约方的声誉（fama）成为信贷合同合法性的决定性标准，从而将市场交易理解为存在于市场之外的社会关系和等级制度的镜像。42在这个意义上，高利贷的反社会性质在它出现的历史背景（13 世纪初的道德神学）之外，还保留了其多功能的象征性力量。这就是为什么克莱拉克在十七世纪仍然可以调动犹太人高利贷的特质，当时商业社会正在获得更明显的契约特征。

Government tribunals did not offer clearer directives on usury than the church. Secular authorities turned many sexual and economic sins into crimes, but in matters of usury, it was the latitude, rather than strictures, of theological and canonical definitions that influenced civil law and jurisprudence, especially in Catholic states.43 France long resisted setting a cap on the interest allowed on private loans, and both norms and customs of lending varied greatly across the kingdom. During Cleirac’s lifetime, royal legislation still formally forbade lending at interest and reiterated the state’s opposition to all forms of usury.44 A special regime was devised for certain types of long-term credit instruments backed by collateral, which normally took the form of real estate; such instruments were in essence private annuities that demanded the repayment of low rates of interest (rentes perpétuelles and rentes viagères ).45 The crown capped interest rates on annuities at 6.25 percent per annum in 1601 and lowered this ceiling to 5 percent in 1655, where it stayed for most of the eighteenth century.46

政府法庭在高利贷方面没有比教会提供更明确的指示。世俗当局将许多性犯罪和经济犯罪变成了犯罪，但在高利贷问题上，影响民法和判例的是神学和教规的定义的自由度，而不是严格性，特别是在天主教国家。43法国长期以来一直抵制对私人贷款的利息设置上限，而且整个王国的借贷规范和习俗都有很大的不同。在克莱拉克在世时，皇家立法仍然正式禁止放贷收取利息，并重申国家反对一切形式的高利贷行为。44为某些类型的长期信贷工具设计了一个特殊的制度，这些工具有抵押物支持，通常采取不动产的形式；这些工具实质上是私人年金，要求以低利率偿还永久年金（rentes perpétuelles）和人寿年金（rentes viagères）。451601 年，王室将年金的年利率上限定为 6.25%，1655 年将这一上限降至 5%，并在 18 世纪的大部分时间内保持不变。46

Meanwhile, royal authorities exhibited considerable hesitation about setting similar terms for commercial credit. The city of Lyon was the exception. There, royal edicts spoke of “interest” rather than “usury” in reference to bills transacted at the fairs to shield them from criticism.47 Jean-Baptiste Colbert sought to codify a lawful 5 percent interest rate for commercial loans, but the committee he charged with drafting the 1673 ordinance on commerce rejected his proposal for fear of antagonizing the Faculty of Theology at the Sorbonne, which opposed the measure because it put a price on usury. As a compromise, the final 1673 ordinance (title VI, art. 1) allowed merchants and others dealing in bills of exchange to charge interest, but not to hide it behind the principal (which is what all merchants did).48 The discrepancy between law and practice, however, soon gave way to rampant abuses and inspired reformers like Étienne Bonnot de Condillac and Anne-Robert-Jacques Turgot in the 1770s to call for legitimizing interest-bearing loans and letting the market equalize their rates.49 The arbiters who adjudicated lawsuits over bills of exchange for the commercial court of Paris sometimes detected an injury (lésion ) in the exchange rate and recommended compensation.50 Only the Revolution lifted all legal restrictions on charging interest on loans and moved to regulate interest rates on October 12, 1789.51 Until then, though they were never numerous, usury trials were held and offenders punished with bans and rites of public humiliation reminiscent of earlier times, in which they were made to kneel in public squares holding a sign labeling them “manifest usurers.”52

同时，皇家当局对制定类似的商业信贷条件表现出相当的犹豫。里昂市是个例外。在那里，皇家法令在提到在集市上交易的票据时说的是 “利息” 而不是 “高利贷”，以避免他们受到批评。47让·巴蒂斯特·科尔贝尔试图为商业贷款编纂一个合法的 5% 的利率，但他负责起草 1673 年商业条例的委员会拒绝了他的建议，因为他担心与索邦大学神学院对立，后者反对这项措施，因为它为高利贷设定了价格。作为一种妥协，最终的 1673 年法令（第六章，第 1 条）允许商人和其他从事汇票交易的人收取利息，但不能将其隐藏在本金后面（这是所有商人的做法）。48然而，法律与实践之间的差异很快就导致了猖獗的滥用行为，并激发了埃蒂安·邦诺·德·孔迪拉克和安妮·罗伯特·雅克·涂尔干等改革者在 1770 年代呼吁使有息贷款合法化，并让市场来平衡其利率。49为巴黎商业法庭裁决汇票诉讼的仲裁人有时会发现汇率的损伤（lésion），并建议给予补偿。50只有大革命解除了对贷款收取利息的所有法律限制，并在 1789 年 10 月 12 日开始对利率进行监管。51在那之前，虽然他们的数量不多，但还是举行了高利贷审判，并以禁令和公开羞辱的仪式来惩罚犯罪者，这让人想起了早期的时代，他们被要求在公共广场上跪下，举着一个标有 “明显的高利贷者” 的标志。52

Evidently, it was not to positive law or to the courts that one could turn in the mid-seventeenth century for clear-cut answers about the legitimacy of all forms of bills of exchange. Merchant manuals and legal commentaries sought to fill the void. The extent to which these texts, which varied in scope, originality, and precision, were meant and able to impart practical knowledge to aspiring or experienced practitioners remains debatable. Most certainly, they fulfilled a different but essential function in the self-regulation of European commercial society: they forged a shared understanding of the cultural underpinnings that sustained the more or less detailed formal norms of the credit contracts they illustrated.

显然，在 17 世纪中叶，人们无法从实在法或法院那里获得关于所有形式汇票合法性的明确答案。商业手册和法律评论试图填补这一空白。这些文本的范围、原创性和精确性各不相同，它们在多大程度上意味着能够向有抱负或有经验的从业者传授实用知识，这一点仍有争议。最肯定的是，它们在欧洲商业社会的自我调节中履行了一个不同但必不可少的功能：它们形成了对文化基础的共同理解，这些文化基础支撑着它们所说明的信贷合同的或多或少的详细的正式规范。

Cleirac partook in this effort. His predecessors, including Jean Trenchant and Mathias Maréschal, had followed more conventional paths, adopting the taxonomy of legitimate and illegitimate bills of exchange established by moral theologians.53 A trained lawyer, Cleirac oscillates between an all-encompassing meaning of usury as improper economic practice and a narrower jurisprudential approach. In Us et coustumes de la mer , in addition to citing the opinions of theologians like Cajetan, Navarrus, and Coli, who all declared dry exchange to be usurious, he mentions a sentence (arrêt ) issued by Bordeaux’s royal appellate court (parlement ) on July 16, 1637, confirming an earlier ruling of the city’s commercial tribunal against someone caught using dry exchange.54 Cleirac exhibits a more contradictory attitude toward marine insurance. He dismisses those who still regarded it as a form of speculation rather than as the price of risk, but he also stresses the uncertainty under which premiums were negotiated and enforced (e.g., the difficulty of verifying when a shipwreck occurred, the incompetence of ship captains who prolonged a voyage) and calls underwriters “truly usurious and Jewish” for speculating on this uncertainty.55 Rather than expressing unrelenting opposition to all credit contracts, these accusations confirm the facility with which Cleirac summoned the figure of the Jewish usurer to condemn economic practices that he judged to be unfair but the dubiousness of which he could not better articulate.

克莱拉克参与了这项工作。他的前任，包括让·特伦查德（Jean Trenchant）和马蒂亚斯·马雷沙尔（Mathias Maréschal），走的是更传统的道路，采用道德神学家建立的合法和不合法汇票的分类法 。53作为一名训练有素的律师，克莱拉克在高利贷作为不正当经济行为的全面含义和较窄的法学方法之间摇摆不定。在《海洋的用途和习俗》中，除了引用卡耶坦、纳瓦鲁斯和科利等神学家的意见，他们都宣布干汇是高利贷，他还提到了波尔多皇家上诉法院（parlement）于 1637 年 7 月 16 日作出的判决（arrêt），确认了该市商业法庭先前对使用干汇的人作出的裁决。54克莱拉克对海事保险表现出一种更加矛盾的态度。他驳斥了那些仍将其视为一种投机形式而非风险价格的人，但他也强调了保费谈判和执行的不确定性（例如，难以核实沉船发生的时间，延长航程的船长的无能），并称承保人在这种不确定性上进行投机是 “真正的高利贷和犹太教”。55这些指责并不是对所有信贷合同的无情反对，而是证实了克莱拉克召唤犹太高利贷者的形象来谴责他认为不公平但又无法更好地阐明其可疑性的经济行为的便利。

In his treatise on bills of exchange, Usance du négoce (a shorter work than Us et coustumes de la mer and a standalone piece rather than a commentary), Cleirac also alternates between description and moralizing admonishment, between crude attacks against usury and subtler accounts of specific credit contracts, between accurate citations and fanciful readings. In addition to Cajetan and Navarrus, he invokes a noted Florentine merchant in Flanders, Ludovico Guicciardini, to argue that four-party bills of exchange are “useful and genuine, when used with moderation and loyalty.”56 He stresses the need to combine the knowledge of customary norms related to bills of exchange with “human prudence.”57 Unable to define how exactly “human prudence” affects credit operations, he singles out people whom he asserts obviously lack this quality: Jews, to be sure, since they were “cheaters” and thus willing to take advantage of any opportunity regardless of its consequences, but also “Mohammedans,” “Turks,” and “Saracens,” all of whom lagged behind the Jews in financial sophistication.58 With rare precision, in one instance, he gives a number to the practices he describes: 12 percent annual interest, by his estimation, was the standard rate charged by “bankers, Jews, and dirty usurers.”59 Reverting to old habits, he calls dry exchange “a business of Jews and Cahorsins.”60

在他关于汇票的论文《交易的使用》（比《海洋的用途和习俗》更短的作品，也是一篇独立的作品，而不是评论）中，克莱拉克也在描述和道德训诫之间，在对高利贷的粗暴攻击和对具体信贷合同的巧妙描述之间，在准确引用和幻想的解读之间交替进行。除了卡耶坦和纳瓦鲁斯之外，他还援引了佛兰德斯的一位知名佛罗伦萨商人卢多维科·吉夏尔迪尼的观点，认为四方汇票 “如果使用得适度和忠诚，是有用的和真实的”。56他强调需要将与汇票有关的习惯规范的知识与 “人类的审慎” 结合起来。57由于无法准确定义 “人类的谨慎” 如何影响信贷业务，他挑出了那些他断言明显缺乏这种品质的人。当然是犹太人，因为他们是 “骗子”，因此愿意利用任何机会而不计后果，但还有 “穆罕默德人”、“土耳其人” 和 “撒拉逊人”，他们在金融方面的复杂性都落后于犹太人。58在一个例子中，他以罕见的精确度为他所描述的做法提供了一个数字。据他估计，12% 的年利息是 “银行家、犹太人和肮脏的高利贷者” 收取的标准利率。59他重拾旧习，称干货交易是 “犹太人和卡霍尔森的生意”。60

In so many words, Cleirac reveals the impossibility of giving a precise and exhaustive definition of “good business.” Nowhere does he define usury in unambiguous terms. Rather, usury is how he refers to everything he regards as the opposite of prudent, upright, and legal ways of handling bills of exchange. As the next chapter will show, Cleirac’s marketplace promoted talent and created new riches, but it was also full of menaces and villains, replete with jealousy between groups, and haunted by the possibility of fraud. It was anything but an ecumenical meeting place of faceless merchants, seafarers, and underwriters. Regulation mattered (that is why Cleirac chose to study maritime and commercial law in the first place), yet regulation alone could not guarantee the fair conduct of trade. Cleirac resorted to stereotyping not only because prejudice against Jews was rooted in the mentality of the time, but also because written norms about bills of exchange and other financial instruments were still sparse during the first half of the seventeenth century. By conjuring “Jewish extortion” (Iuifve tortionaire ), he could explain the ineffable: objectionable ways of handling bills of exchange that went undetected.61

在这么多的字里行间，克莱拉克揭示了给 “好的商业” 下一个精确而详尽的定义是不可能的。他在任何地方都没有以毫不含糊的措辞来定义高利贷 。相反，高利贷是他对一切他认为与处理汇票的审慎、正直和合法方式相反的事物的称呼。正如下一章所显示的，克莱拉克的市场促进了人才的发展，创造了新的财富，但它也充满了威胁和恶棍，充满了群体之间的嫉妒，并被欺诈的可能性所困扰。它不是一个由不露面的商人、海员和承销商组成的大公无私的聚会场所。监管很重要（这也是克莱拉克当初选择研究海商法的原因），但仅靠监管并不能保证贸易的公平进行。克莱拉克采用陈规定型观念，不仅是因为对犹太人的偏见植根于当时的心态，而且还因为在 17 世纪上半叶，关于汇票和其他金融工具的书面规范仍然很稀少。通过想象 “犹太人的敲诈”（Iuifve tortionaire），他可以解释不可描述的事情：处理汇票的不良方式没有被发现。61

Should Cleirac’s railing against Jews and others he lumps together with them ultimately surprise us? The answer is yes and no. His words are more venomous than those that punctuate other merchant manuals, legal commentaries, and dictionaries of trade, and his work is sometimes amateurish. But his habit of alternating between technical disquisitions about credit instruments, tenets of moral theology, and invocations of Jewish usury as the archetype of financial misconduct would have been entirely recognizable to his readers. In this respect, Us et coustumes de la mer belongs to the continental literature on commercial and maritime law of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, which, Rodolfo Savelli reminds us, displayed a distinctive osmosis of law, theology, and merchant culture.62 As the language of commerce became more and more secular, it did not shed its didactic invocations of Jewish usury.

克莱拉克对犹太人和其他被他归为一类的人的抨击最终是否应该让我们感到惊讶？答案是肯定的，也是否定的。他的文字比其他商人手册、法律评论和贸易词典中的文字更毒辣，而且他的作品有时很业余。但是，他习惯于在关于信贷工具的技术论述、道德神学的信条和援引犹太人的高利贷作为金融不当行为的原型之间交替进行，这对他的读者来说是完全可以识别的。在这方面，《海洋的用途和习俗》属于 16 世纪和 17 世纪关于商业和海事法的大陆文献，鲁道夫·萨韦利（Rodolfo Savelli）提醒我们，这些文献显示了法律、神学和商人文化的独特渗透。62随着商业语言变得越来越世俗化，它并没有摆脱对犹太高利贷的说教性援引。

Conclusion

总结

This chapter and the previous one have parsed Cleirac’s jumbled arguments in an effort to render them as intelligible as I believe they would have been to his many seventeenth-century readers. In the process, I have set aside an important detail to which we must return. Cleirac maintains that “insurance policies and bills of exchange were unknown to ancient Roman jurisprudence.” This portion of his otherwise outlandish account of the emergence of Europe’s financial instruments is truthful and, far from representing a mere legal technicality, gestures toward a pivotal component of the logic that undergirds the legend.

这一章和上一章对克莱拉克杂乱无章的论点进行了分析，努力使它们像我相信的那样，对他的许多 17 世纪的读者来说是可以理解的。在这个过程中，我把一个重要的细节放在一边，我们必须回到这里。克莱拉克认为，“保险单和汇票在古罗马法学中是不存在的”。在他关于欧洲金融工具出现的其他离奇的叙述中，这部分内容是真实的，而且远非仅仅代表一个法律上的技术性问题，表明了支撑这个传说的逻辑中的一个关键组成部分。

Medieval and early modern legal scholars searched long and hard for the Roman origins of both marine insurance and bills of exchange and eventually concluded that premium-based insurance, the forerunner of our modern forms of insurance, as opposed to other risk-sharing agreements, did not exist in antiquity and that examples of credit transfers noted by classical authors did not amount to proper bills of exchange. The sentence of the Genoese Rota with which Cleirac opens his commentary on the first article of the Guidon de la mer defined marine insurance as a contractus innominatus (“nameless contract”), a category developed by medieval jurists to indicate contracts that did not have a specific equivalent in the Roman civil law of obligations. Thus called because they lacked a name in the authoritative ancient sources, nameless contracts were voluntary bilateral agreements in which each party, acting with equal contractual power, promised to do his part to fulfill the agreement.63 Marine insurance and bills of exchange fell into this category, which Cleirac, a graduate of law, knew well.64

中世纪和近代早期的法律学者对海事保险和汇票的罗马起源进行了长时间的研究，并最终得出结论：相对于其他风险分担协议，我们现代保险形式的前身 —— 基于保险费的保险在古代并不存在，而且古典作家所提到的信用转移的例子也不等于适当的汇票。克莱拉克在《海洋指南》第一条的评注中以《热那亚罗塔》的一句话作为开篇，将海事保险定义为无名合同（“无名合同”），这是一个由中世纪法学家发展起来的类别，以表示在罗马民法义务中没有具体对应的合同。无名合同之所以被称为无名合同，是因为它们在权威的古代资料中没有名称，是自愿的双边协议，其中每一方以平等的合同权力行事，承诺尽其所能履行协议。63海事保险和汇票就属于这一类，作为法律专业毕业生的克莱拉克对此非常了解。64

Improbable as their designation sounds, nameless contracts belong to a momentous chapter in the history of European law, one during which new legal classifications emerged as expressions of the political and social order of city-states where, after the late eleventh century, urban elites tied to commercial interests affirmed their independence from the feudal aristocracy. The late medieval growth of long-distance trade demanded that full contractual rights be given to social groups that until then had been regarded as inferior to the titled nobility. It also demanded the recognition of new financial contracts and the development of new doctrines and customary practices to absorb those contracts into existing legal systems. The two requirements were really one. Reciprocity, consensus, and good faith were the defining elements of the new contracts, which were in turn predicated upon the legal ability of some (though not all) individuals to enter into voluntary contracts with one another. The men at the helm of the medieval city-states and those who belonged to the high-ranking guilds were the primary beneficiaries of these new legal doctrines. The poor, slaves, captives, unfree domestic labor, male rural workers, and the vast majority of women remained severely restricted in their contractual autonomy.

尽管无名合同的名称听起来很不可思议，但它属于欧洲法律史上的重要一章，在这一章中，新的法律分类作为城邦政治和社会秩序的表达而出现，在 11 世纪末以后，与商业利益挂钩的城市精英确认了他们对封建贵族的独立性。中世纪晚期长距离贸易的增长要求给予社会群体充分的契约权利，而在那之前，这些社会群体一直被认为是低于有产权的贵族的。它还要求承认新的金融合同，并发展新的学说和习惯做法，将这些合同纳入现有的法律体系。这两个要求实际上是一体的。互惠、共识和善意是新合同的决定性因素，而新合同的前提是一些（但不是所有）个人有法律能力彼此签订自愿合同。中世纪城邦的掌舵者和那些属于高级行会的人是这些新法律理论的主要受益者。穷人、奴隶、俘虏、不自由的家务劳动者、男性农村工人和绝大多数妇女的契约自主权仍然受到严重限制。

Confronted with the expansion of credit instruments during the commercial revolution of the Middle Ages, jurists and lawyers were tasked with reconciling the conception of social groups as belonging to a fixed natural hierarchy with the recognition of the freedom of consenting individuals to enter into voluntary commercial agreements with their peers.65 Debates of enormous consequence for the course of European history focusing on the interplay of an individual’s legal status (as defined by birth or, more rarely, through a rite of passage) and his freedom to choose among a broader or narrower set of contractual options infused the legalistic disquisitions that between the eleventh and thirteenth centuries began to redefine the law of obligations on the Continent. During the sixteenth century, a time of rapid demographic and economic growth, the pace of these legal and social transformations accelerated and provoked a crisis of legibility in the market. In this early phase of European globalization, international merchants increasingly operated with “the feather and the sheet of paper,” that is, immaterial payment and credit instruments. They were no longer required to enroll in guilds (unlike artisans) and thus escaped guilds’ supervision.66 As merchant guilds, the institutions that had traditionally guaranteed the good standing of their members, lost ground, traders involved in transactions across long distances had to resort to other means to prove their good reputation. Rank alone had never been a sufficient metric of credibility, but the expansion of the boundaries of commercial society represented something new: the promise of broader participation in market exchanges and the peril of the indiscriminate mixing of actors using increasingly abstract credit instruments.

面对中世纪商业革命期间信贷工具的扩张，法学家和律师的任务是：将社会群体属于固定的自然等级制度的概念与承认同意的个人与他们的同行达成自愿商业协议的自由相协调。65对欧洲历史进程具有巨大影响的辩论，集中在个人的法律地位（由出生或更少的通过仪式确定）与他在更广泛或更狭窄的合同选择中进行选择的自由之间的相互作用，在 11 世纪和 13 世纪之间开始重新定义欧洲大陆的义务法的法律论述。在十六世纪这个人口和经济快速增长的时期，这些法律和社会变革的步伐加快了，并引发了市场的可读性危机。在欧洲全球化的这一早期阶段，国际商人越来越多地使用 “羽毛和纸片”，即非物质的支付和信用工具进行经营。他们不再需要加入行会（与工匠不同），因此逃避了行会的监督。66由于商人行会这个传统上保证其成员良好声誉的机构失去了地位，参与远距离交易的商人不得不求助于其他手段来证明他们的良好声誉。单纯的等级从来都不是衡量信誉的充分标准，但商业社会边界的扩大代表了一些新的东西：更广泛地参与市场交换的承诺，以及使用日益抽象的信贷工具的行为者不分青红皂白地混合的危险。

How were investors and entrepreneurs wishing to enter into a voluntary bilateral agreement with someone outside of their immediate circle to verify the integrity and expertise of the contracting party? The legend of the Jewish invention of marine insurance and bills of exchange, erroneous as it was, provided an answer to this vital and yet intractable question. The legend evoked risks that could not be calculated easily and drew symbolic boundaries in a world in which intangible financial instruments and the erosion of merchants’ corporate status made the impersonality of the market as threatening as it was potentially beneficial.

希望与直系亲属以外的人签订自愿双边协议的投资者和企业家如何验证签约方的诚信和专业知识？犹太人发明海事保险和汇票的传说，尽管是错误的，但为这个重要而又棘手的问题提供了答案。这个传说唤起了不容易计算的风险，并在一个无形的金融工具和商人的公司地位受到侵蚀的世界中划出了象征性的界限，使市场的非个人化既具有威胁性又具有潜在的好处。

On a discursive level, a striking continuity linked the twelfth-century French abbot of Clairvaux to the seventeenth-century lawyer of Bordeaux: the frequent semantic slippage between Jews and untrustworthy creditors in general. Visual and textual examples of this analogy survive in artifacts from the seventeenth-century Spanish Low Countries, where no Jews had resided since the Black Death and where “Lombards” replaced them until 1618. In paintings large and small, Christian moneylenders were depicted with recognizable “Jewish” attributes.67 On the level of everyday reality, by the mid-sixteenth century, the notion of “baptized Jews” was as much a lived experience as a metaphor in Bordeaux, since many of the Jews who were fleeing the Iberian inquisitions passed through or settled in the region north of the Pyrenees. Not the world of the ghetto, but the conversion crises of the 1490s, as the next chapter will show, loomed large in the pages of Us et coustumes de la mer .

在话语层面上，一个惊人的连续性将十二世纪的法国克莱尔沃修道院院长和十七世纪的波尔多律师联系在一起：犹太人和一般不值得信赖的债权人之间经常出现语义滑移。这种类比的视觉和文字例子存于十七世纪西班牙低地国家的文物中，那里自黑死病以来就没有犹太人居住，在 1618 年前，“伦巴第人” 取代了他们。在大大小小的画作中，基督教放债人被描绘成具有可识别的 “犹太人” 属性。67在日常现实的层面上，到 16 世纪中期，“受洗的犹太人” 这一概念在波尔多既是一种生活经验，也是一种隐喻，因为许多逃离伊比利亚宗教裁判所的犹太人都经过或定居在比利牛斯山脉以北的地区。正如下一章所显示的那样，在《海洋的用途和习俗》的书中，不是犹太区的世界，而是 1490 年代的皈依危机。

4

Bordeaux, the Specter of Crypto-Judaism, and the Changing Status of Commerce

波尔多，隐蔽犹太教的幽灵，以及商业地位的变化

THE PREVIOUS TWO CHAPTERS have treated Cleirac’s annotations as “a tissue of quotations drawn from the innumerable centers of culture” and shown that, out of this “tissue,” a new narrative came to life.1 The next chapters will survey the fate of this narrative—a fate that surely surpassed its author’s expectations and embedded variants of the original formulation into a chain of intertextual transmission. For now, I wish to illustrate the circumstances in which Cleirac composed his writings. I do so not in the name of the illusion against which Roland Barthes famously protested: “When the Author has been found, the text is ‘explained.’”2 Rather, by immersing the legend of the Jewish invention of marine insurance and bills of exchange in the time and place in which it was first committed to print, I continue in my effort to recover some of the implicit connections that readers would likely have made at the time and that today elude us.

前两章将克莱拉克的注释视为 “从无数文化中心提取的引文组织”，并表明从这个 “组织” 中，一个新的叙事得以诞生。1接下来的章节将对这一叙事的命运进行调查 —— 这一命运肯定超过了作者的预期，并将原始表述的变体嵌入到互文传播的链条中。现在，我想说明克莱拉克在什么情况下创作了他的作品。我这样做并不是以罗兰·巴特著名的抗议的幻觉为名：“当作者被找到后，文本就被 ‘解释’ 了”。2相反，通过让犹太人发明海事保险和汇票的传说沉浸在它首次被付梓的时间和地点中，我继续努力恢复读者在当时可能会产生的一些隐含的联系，而这些联系在今天却无法被我们发现。

Étienne Cleirac (1583–1657) was born, lived, and died in Bordeaux, where a street is named after him (figure 4.1 ). Then a mid-ranking urban center, Bordeaux was the site of an important humanist secondary school and a law school, a burgeoning Atlantic port and banking center, and one of only two French cities (the other was Metz, annexed to France in 1552) where a Jewish minority resided. Bordeaux’s Jewish minority, however, was unusual in the sense that, unlike Metz’s, it was not openly Jewish. In 1550, the French crown invited “merchants and other Portuguese known as New Christians” to settle in the southwestern region of the kingdom, exempting them from the need to request naturalization letters. This invitation automatically guaranteed these immigrants’ families the same privileges as all French subjects, including freedom of movement, full property rights, and the ability to conduct any economic activities they wished.3 By this measure, “his most Christian majesty,” as the French king was addressed at the time, aimed to inject capital and talent into his trading system. The ordinance’s beneficiaries, though unnamed, were unmistakable: those former Jews who, having been forcibly converted to Catholicism in Spain and Portugal during the 1490s, wished to escape. Even more specifically, the ordinance targeted those New Christians who lived in Portugal, for whom the recent creation of a national inquisition in 1536 constituted a mounting threat.

艾蒂安·克莱拉克（1583-1657）在波尔多出生、生活和死亡，那里有一条以他名字命名的街道（图 4.1）。当时，波尔多是一个中等规模的城市中心，是一所重要的人文主义中学和法学院的所在地，是一个新兴的大西洋港口和银行中心，也是法国仅有的两个有少数犹太人居住的城市之一（另一个是梅斯，1552 年被并入法国）。然而，波尔多的犹太少数民族是不寻常的，因为它与梅斯的不同，不是公开的犹太人。1550 年，法国王室邀请 “商人和其他被称为新基督徒的葡萄牙人” 在王国的西南部地区定居，免除了他们申请归化信的需要， 。这一邀请自动保证了这些移民的家庭享有与所有法国臣民相同的特权，包括行动自由、充分的财产权，以及从事任何他们希望的经济活动的能力。3通过这一措施，法国国王当时被称呼为 “最虔诚的陛下”，旨在为其贸易体系注入资本和人才。该法令的受益者虽然没有名字，但却是明确无误的：那些在 1490 年代在西班牙和葡萄牙被强行改信天主教的前犹太人，他们希望逃离。更具体地说，该法令针对的是那些居住在葡萄牙的新基督徒，对他们来说，最近在 1536 年建立的国家宗教裁判所构成了越来越大的威胁。

In the mid-sixteenth century, other towns in Europe, including Florence, Ferrara, and Antwerp, also welcomed New Christians in spite of the Catholic Church’s objection to leniency toward baptized Jews, whom Rome regarded as prone to living secretly as Jews in defiance of the sanctity of baptism. But this type of accommodation was short-lived. By the 1590s, secular authorities preferred to invite Iberian émigrés to settle in their territories as Jews, rather than as New Christians, in order to dispel any residual ambiguity surrounding their religious identity. As a result, new Sephardic Jewish communities were established in Venice, Livorno, Hamburg, and Amsterdam. In Bordeaux, however, the institutional arrangement devised in 1550 continued for more than a century and a half. The absence of any modern inquisition tribunal in France allowed for the emergence of a regime of toleration in which crypto-Judaism was an open secret. The theological notion of “baptized Jews” thus found its most lasting institutional incarnation outside of Iberia in southwestern France. While few in number, “Portuguese merchants” were overrepresented among Bordeaux’s international traders and well established in certain manufacturing sectors (silk and Moroccan leather in particular), local retail markets, and the medical profession.4 For all the reasons we have recounted, New Christians’ concealed religious identity not only troubled religious authorities but also heightened fears that behind any reputable merchant might lurk a “Jewish usurer.”

十六世纪中期，欧洲的其他城镇，包括佛罗伦萨、费拉拉和安特卫普，也欢迎新基督徒，尽管天主教会反对对受洗的犹太人宽大处理，罗马认为他们容易以犹太人的身份秘密生活，藐视洗礼的神圣性。但这种迁就是短暂的。到 1590 年代，世俗当局倾向于邀请伊比利亚移民作为犹太人而不是新基督徒在其领土上定居，以消除围绕其宗教身份的任何残留的模糊性。因此，在威尼斯、利沃诺、汉堡和阿姆斯特丹都建立了新的塞法尔犹太人社区。然而，在波尔多，1550 年设计的制度安排持续了一个半世纪以上。由于法国没有任何现代的宗教裁判所法庭，因此出现了一种宽容的制度，在这种制度下，隐蔽的犹太教是一个公开的秘密。因此，“受洗的犹太人” 这一神学概念在伊比利亚以外的法国西南部找到了其最持久的制度化身。虽然数量不多，但 “葡萄牙商人” 在波尔多的国际贸易商中占有很大的比例，并在某些制造业（尤其是丝绸和摩洛哥皮革）、当地零售市场和医疗行业建立了良好的基础。4由于我们所叙述的所有原因，新基督徒隐藏的宗教身份不仅困扰着宗教当局，而且还加剧了人们的恐惧，即任何有信誉的商人背后都可能潜伏着一个 “犹太高利贷者”。

The consolidation of the Portuguese community in Bordeaux after the Wars of Religion (1562–1598) coincided with a period of economic and legal changes that tested the traditional division in Old Regime French society between noblemen and merchants. Historians have written extensively on the venality of France’s legal and administrative offices, first institutionalized under Francis I (r. 1515–1547), and on the creation of the “nobility of the robe” (as opposed to the “nobility of the sword”), a title and idea that undermined genealogical conceptions of nobility.5 They have also dissected the appearance of “merit” in the aristocratic language of the seventeenth century and the need to reconcile merit with deep-seated notions of lineage and the hereditary quality of “honor.”6

宗教战争（1562-1598）后，波尔多的葡萄牙人社区得到了巩固，而这一时期的经济和法律变革考验了旧制度下法国社会在贵族和商人之间的传统划分。历史学家们对法国法律和行政机构的腐败现象进行了广泛的研究，这些机构在弗朗西斯一世（Francis I，1515-1547）时期首次被制度化，并对 “长袍贵族”（相对于 “剑的贵族”）的产生进行了研究，这种称号和观念破坏了贵族的家谱概念。5他们还剖析了 17 世纪贵族语言中 “功绩” 的出现，以及将功绩与根深蒂固的血统观念和 “荣誉” 的世袭品质相协调的必要性。6

We know much less about the changing legal and cultural status of commerce in the seventeenth century, especially during its first half, before Jean-Baptiste Colbert, who served as Louis XIV’s controller-general of finance from 1665 until his death in 1683, initiated a series of consequential reforms. Idiosyncratic as they are, Cleirac’s writings afford us a unique entry point into this transformative and yet neglected phase of French history, offering the view of a sympathetic but distressed participant-observer at a time when ongoing economic changes and the crown’s political ambitions were putting pressure on long-held ideas about the place of commerce in a well-ordered corporate society. The meaning of the word “merchant” had evolved over the years: it no longer exclusively denoted someone affiliated with a guild but referred to anyone who carried out a range of commercial transactions. As a result, both noblemen and Jews could be designated as merchants. New symbolic hierarchies, Cleirac implies, had to be erected as legal ones were being eroded.

我们对十七世纪商业的法律和文化地位的变化知之甚少，特别是在十七世纪上半叶，从 1665 年到 1683 年去世的路易十四的财政总管让·巴蒂斯特·科尔贝尔发起了一系列重要的改革。尽管克莱拉克的著作很古怪，但它为我们提供了一个独特的切入点，让我们了解法国历史上这一变革性但被忽视的阶段，提供了一个同情但痛苦的参与者 —— 观察者的观点，当时正在进行的经济变革和王室的政治野心对商业在一个有秩序的企业社会中的地位的长期观念造成了压力。多年来，“商人” 这个词的含义已经发生了变化：它不再仅仅指隶属于某个行会的人，而是指进行一系列商业交易的人。因此，贵族和犹太人都可以被指定为商人。克莱拉克暗示，新的象征性等级制度必须建立起来，因为法律等级制度正在被削弱。

After graduating from the Collège de Guyenne, one of the kingdom’s most renowned humanist secondary schools (both Michel de Montaigne and Joseph Scaliger had been educated there), Cleirac studied law and spent the rest of his life working as a barrister (avocat ) at the royal appellate court (parlement ) of Bordeaux and, briefly, as a royal legal official (procureur du roy ) in the city’s admiralty (figure 4.2 ).7 In 1616 he acquired the status of bourgeois , a title that at the time granted not only social recognition but also fiscal exemptions, and two years later he married.8 While many in his profession embraced the Calvinist faith, Cleirac remained fiercely Catholic and monarchist, whether out of conviction or necessity. His professional career suffered from his son’s prominent involvement in the Ormée (1651–1653), Bordeaux’s radical arm of the Fronde, which rallied many artisans, merchants, lawyers, low-ranking magistrates, and a few clergymen to revolt against the monarchy.9 Forced to retreat to his residence in the countryside as a result of his son’s activities, Cleirac immersed himself in reading and writing. At the time of his death, he had amassed a vast collection of 671 books.10

克莱拉克毕业于古耶纳学院（Collège de Guyenne），这是王国最著名的人文主义中学之一（米歇尔·蒙田和约瑟夫·斯卡利格都曾在那里接受教育），他学习法律，并在波尔多皇家上诉法院（parlement）担任大律师（avocat），还曾短暂地在该市的海事局担任皇家法律官员（procureur du roy）（图 4.2）。71616 年，他获得了资产阶级的地位，这个头衔在当时不仅能获得社会认可，还能获得财政豁免，两年后他结婚了。8当他的行业中的许多人接受了加尔文主义信仰时，克莱拉克仍然是激烈的天主教徒和君主主义者，无论是出于信念还是出于需要。他的职业生涯因其儿子参与奥米（1651-1653）而受到影响，奥米是波尔多的激进派，召集了许多工匠、商人、律师、低级行政官员和一些神职人员来反抗君主制。9由于儿子的活动，克莱拉克被迫退回到他在乡下的住所，沉浸在阅读和写作中。在他去世的时候，他已经积累了 671 本书的庞大收藏。10

Unusually for a man of his time and background, Cleirac turned his attention not to the ius commune or the French coutumes , subjects that animated both theorists and critics of absolutism, but to maritime law. He approached the topic from a stance steeped in humanistic learning and Roman law but also armed with firsthand experience, having participated in complex deliberations involving shipowners, captains, sailors, merchants, and underwriters. Probably driven by self-promotion, he aimed to produce a text that would be of practical use to judges and administrators. Today virtually unknown outside a small circle of experts, Us et coustumes de la mer proved a remarkable publishing success.11 An arcane and specialized subject, then as now, maritime law in the early seventeenth century overlapped with multiple spheres of knowledge, life, and government. It was not a topic of instruction in law schools, but since the mid-sixteenth century it had generated a few important scholarly treatments, which served as guides to magistrates who adjudicated commercial and financial litigation. Meanwhile, the growing centrality of overseas trade in the international system of great powers put maritime and commercial law squarely at the center of emerging interstate and domestic politics.

与他所处的时代和背景不同的是，克莱拉克没有把注意力转移到公有制或法国人的海关上，这些话题让专制主义的理论家和批评家都很兴奋，而是转向了海商法。他以一种浸透了人文知识和罗马法的姿态来探讨这个问题，同时也用第一手的经验来武装自己，因为他参与了涉及船主、船长、水手、商人和承保人的复杂讨论。也许是受自我推销的驱使，他的目标是编写一份对法官和行政人员有实际用途的文本。今天，在专家的小圈子之外几乎无人知晓，《海洋的用途和习俗》证明了出版的巨大成功。11与现在一样，17 世纪初的海商法是一个神秘而专业的课题，与知识、生活和政府等多个领域相重叠。它不是法学院的教学课题，但自十六世纪中叶以来，它已经产生了一些重要的学术处理方法，成为裁决商业和金融诉讼的治安法官的指南。同时，海外贸易在大国国际体系中日益重要的地位，使海商法成为新兴的国家间和国内政治的中心。

The two best-known French contributions to European statecraft in these fields are the royal ordinances on commercial (1673) and maritime (1681) law. Both of these ordinances were the fruit of a long period of legal, political, and intellectual gestation. It was during that period and against the backdrop of the peculiar composition of Bordeaux’s commercial society that Cleirac included the legend of the Jewish invention of marine insurance and bills of exchange in his commentary on Rouen’s rules of marine insurance.

法国在这些领域对欧洲国家的两个最著名的贡献是关于商业法（1673）和海事法（1681）的皇家法令。这两项法令都是经过长期的法律、政治和思想酝酿而产生的。正是在这一时期，在波尔多商业社会的特殊构成的背景下，克莱拉克在他对鲁昂海事保险规则的评论中加入了犹太人发明海事保险和汇票的传说。

A Forgotten Bestseller of the Ars Mercatoria

一本被遗忘的《墨卡托利亚报》的畅销书

Nothing like Us et coustumes de la mer —a vernacular publication that assembled, translated, and commented on legal norms of maritime trade developed in western and northern Europe since the twelfth century—existed in Europe when it first appeared in Bordeaux in 1647.12 Judging by its publication record, it filled a void. Printed in-quarto (roughly 10 × 8 inches), the 1647 edition is a voluminous text of 576 pages, plus index and appendices. An expanded version appeared in Bordeaux in 1661 in a print run of at least 1,200 copies, an extraordinarily high run for any nonreligious book, and all the more so for one devoted to maritime law.13 For purposes of comparison, consider that in 1528, the first edition of Baldassare Castiglione’s Courtier , one of early modern Europe’s veritable bestsellers, comprised 1,030 copies.14 Print runs grew over time, but in the early seventeenth century it was still rare for more than 1,000 copies of nonreligious books to be printed; publishers only made some 2,000 to 3,000 copies of certain dictionaries and Roman or canon law compilations.15

《海洋的用途和习俗》（一种汇集、翻译和评论自十二世纪以来在西欧和北欧发展起来的海上贸易法律规范的方言出版物），当它于 1647 年在波尔多首次出现时，在欧洲并不存在这样的东西。12从其出版记录来看，它填补了一个空白。1647 年版以四开本印刷（大约 10×8 英寸），全文共 576 页，加上索引和附录，篇幅庞大。1661 年在波尔多出现了一个扩展版本，印刷量至少为 1200 册，这对于任何非宗教书籍来说都是非常高的，而对于一本专门讨论海商法的书籍来说更是如此。13为了便于比较，请看 1528 年巴尔达萨雷-卡斯蒂里奥内（Baldassare Castiglione）的《经纪商》（Courtier）的第一版，这是现代早期欧洲名副其实的畅销书之一，共有 1,030 册。14随着时间的推移，印刷量不断增加，但在 17 世纪初，非宗教书籍的印刷量超过 1,000 册的情况仍很罕见；出版商只为某些字典和罗马法或教会法汇编制作了约 2,000 至 3,000 册。15

The 1661 edition of Us et coustumes de la mer replaced the first and was reis-sued with minimal alterations four more times: in Paris in 1665, in Rouen in 1671 and 1682, and in Amsterdam in 1788.16 The choice to publish the work in the vernacular set Cleirac apart from other jurists and proved a recipe for success, albeit one that largely bypassed him, since he died four years before the second edition went to press. Until the appearance of Jean-Marie Pardessus’s monumental compilation in the mid-nineteenth century, Us et coustumes de la mer was the single most comprehensive collection of European maritime laws published in the vernacular.17

1661 年版的《海洋的用途和习俗》）取代了第一版，并以最小的改动重新出版了四次：1665 年在巴黎，1671 年和 1682 年在鲁昂，以及 1788 年在阿姆斯特丹。16选择用白话文出版这部作品使克莱拉克与其他法学家区分开来，并被证明是成功的秘诀，尽管这在很大程度上绕过了他，因为他在第二版出版前四年就去世了。在 19 世纪中期让·马里·帕德索斯（Jean-Marie Pardessus）的巨著问世之前，《我们和海洋》是以白话文出版的唯一一部最全面的欧洲海商法集。17

The volume is divided into three sections. The first comprises the Judgments of Oléron, the Laws of Wisby, and the rules of the Hanseatic League from 1591, which Cleirac incorrectly dates to 1597 (although the mistake is perhaps simply due to a typographical error). The second section focuses on marine insurance, reproducing the Guidon de la mer as well as the norms on marine insurance promulgated by Philip II in Antwerp in 1563 (inaccurately dated to 1593) and an ordinance published in Amsterdam in 1598, together with the relevant formulas. Finally, the third section consists of a redacted and copiously annotated assemblage of French royal ordinances pertaining to internal and seaborne navigation in times of war and peace issued between 1400 and 1584. It expands, reorganizes, and comments on all decrees concerning the jurisdiction of the admiralty of France listed in the most extensive collection of French royal ordinances to date, the so-called “Code Henri,” after King Henry III (r. 1574–1589), who had commissioned it.18 At the end of the volume, Cleirac appends an earlier minor work, Explication des termes de marine (1636), a short text that belonged to the emerging genre of maritime and naval dictionaries and contained a rudimentary glossary of terms pertaining to maritime trade and contracts, followed by a description of flags used by ships of different states.19

该卷分为三个部分。第一部分包括《Oléron 判决书》、《Wisby 法》和 1591 年的汉萨同盟规则，克莱拉克错误地将其日期定为 1597 年（尽管这个错误可能只是由于印刷错误）。第二部分侧重于海事保险，再现了《海洋指南》以及菲利普二世 1563 年在安特卫普颁布的海事保险规范（日期不准确，为 1593）和 1598 年在阿姆斯特丹发布的条例，以及相关公式。最后，第三部分由经过编辑和大量注释的法国皇家法令组成，这些法令涉及 1400 年至 1584 年间发布的战时和和平时期的国内和海上航行。它扩展、重组并评论了迄今为止最广泛的法国皇家法令集，即所谓的 “亨利法典” 中列出的所有关于法国海军管辖权的法令，亨利三世（1574-1589）国王曾委托该法典。18在卷末，克莱拉克附上了一部较早的小作品《海洋术语解释》（1636），这是一部短文，属于新兴的海洋和海军词典类型，包含了与海上贸易和合同有关的基本词汇，随后描述了不同国家的船只使用的旗帜。19

Only the book’s first section was translated into English in 1686, when it appeared as The Ancient Sea-laws of Oleron, Wisby and the Hanse-towns Still in Force and was immediately reprinted together with Gerard Malynes’s Consuetudo, vel Lex Mercatoria, or, The Ancient Law-Merchant (first published in 1622), one of the most popular English-language merchant manuals of the period.20 The English translation omitted the Guidon de la mer , and thus Cleirac’s commentary that featured the pseudo-historical narrative of the Jewish invention of marine insurance and bills of exchange. The omission was logical, since the Judgments of Oléron, the contested authorship of which elicited competing patriotic accounts from French and English writers, and the Laws of Wisby, which influenced the rules of Dutch and Baltic navigation, were the most interesting texts edited by Cleirac for English-speaking readers.21 This editorial choice, however, affected the legend’s reception in England (chapter 7 ).

该书只有第一部分在 1686 年被翻译成英文，当时它以《Oleron、Wisby 和 Hanse-towns 仍然有效的古代海商法》出现，并立即与杰拉德-马林斯（Gerard Malynes）的《Consuetudo, vel Lex Mercatoria, 古代海商法》（1622 年首次出版）一起重印，后者是当时最受欢迎的英文商人手册之一。（20英译本省略了《海洋指南》，因此也省略了克莱拉克的评论，该评论的特点是对犹太人发明海事保险和汇票的伪历史叙述。这一删减是合乎逻辑的，因为《奥莱隆判决书》（Judgments of Oléron）和《维斯比法》（Laws of Wisby）是克莱拉克为英语读者编辑的最有趣的文本，前者的作者身份有争议，引起了法国和英国作家对爱国主义的争论，后者影响了荷兰和波罗的海航行规则。21然而，这种编辑上的选择影响了传说在英国的接受程度第七章）。

The seven pages of Us et coustumes de la mer that recount when and why Jews invented marine insurance and bills of exchange and how misguided Christian bankers adopted those credit instruments are unusually unwieldy. All of Cleirac’s commentaries, however, juxtapose predictable and legitimate sources with more improbable ones. The result is a mishmash of citations from the Hebrew Bible, the New Testament, and the writings of greater and lesser Roman and Greek authors, Church Fathers, saints, theologians, antiquarians, geographers, medieval chroniclers, towering humanists like Gerolamo Cardano and Scaliger, novelists and poets like Dante, Boccaccio, and Ariosto, and historians like Nicole Gilles and Étienne Pasquier, as well as collections of proverbs and travelers’ accounts. Only when he added citations from the Qur’an and The Prophecies of Merlin to the second edition did Cleirac feel compelled to explain that he chose to include the works of such “ignorant and ridiculous” authors not because he believed their superstitions but because they were their own worst enemies, in the sense that they could not hide their fallacies.22

海洋的用途和习俗中的七页叙述了犹太人何时和为何发明了海事保险和汇票，以及被误导的基督教银行家如何采用这些信贷工具，这段话异常不容易理解。然而，克莱拉克的所有评论都将可预测的合法来源与更不可能的来源并列在一起。其结果是杂乱无章地引用了希伯来圣经、新约、大大小小的罗马和希腊作家、教父、圣徒、神学家、古学家、地理学家、中世纪编年史家、高大的人文主义者如杰罗拉莫·卡达诺（Gerolamo Cardano）和斯卡利格（Scaliger）、小说家和诗人如但丁（Dante）、薄伽丘（Boccaccio）和阿里奥斯多（Ariosto）、历史学家如尼科尔·吉勒（Nicole Gilles）和埃蒂安·帕斯基耶（Étienne Pasquier）的著作，以及谚语集和旅行者的叙述。只有当他在第二版中引用了《古兰经》和《梅林的预言》时，克莱拉克才不得不解释说，他选择收录这些 “无知而可笑” 的作者的作品，不是因为他相信他们的迷信，而是因为他们是自己最大的敌人，因为他们无法掩盖自己的谬误。22

The eclecticism of Us et coustumes de la mer gives it a flavor of dilettantism and has earned its author a mixed reputation among modern specialists, yet this characteristic was arguably one of the primary ingredients of its appeal. The work translated and digested for a broad reading public concerns about the world of commerce that were located at the intersection of law, theology, humanism, and practical merchant culture. At least one person studied the book sufficiently seriously to compile a (generally accurate) printed list of all the authors cited in it (figure 4.3 ).23

《海洋的用途和习俗》的折衷主义给它带来了散漫主义的味道，并为其作者在现代专家中赢得了不同的声誉，然而这一特点可以说是其吸引力的主要成分之一。这部作品翻译并消化了公众对商业世界的关注，这些关注位于法律、神学、人文主义和实际商业文化的交叉点。至少有一个人对该书进行了认真的研究，编纂了一份该书中引用的所有作者的印刷清单（一般来说是准确的）（图 4.3）。23

Us et coustumes de la mer was and remains difficult to classify. A nearly exact contemporary of Hugo Grotius (1583–1645), Cleirac lacked that scholar’s original mind and eloquence. He drew from established models of legal scholarship, but the muddled nature of his annotations departs from the rigor of Latin treatises on commercial and maritime law by jurists like the Anconetan Benvenuto Stracca, the Portuguese Pedro de Santarém, the Roman Sigismondo Scaccia, and the Genoese Raffaele della Torre, not to mention Grotius and his rival John Selden.24 More than any of those treatises, Us et coustumes de la mer abounds in practical instructions, examples of contracts, and moralizing tales about credit, yet it is neither a merchant handbook nor a confessor manual. Leaning on his training, Cleirac repeatedly references Roman law, jurisprudence, and French regional customs. And while he turns regularly to prominent legal scholars like Andrea Alciato (1492–1550), Charles du Moulin (1500–1566), Jacques Cujas (1522–1590), and Charles Loyseau (1566–1627), he does not disdain more modest French jurists and lawyers with expertise in local statutes and customs.25

《海洋的用途和习俗》过去和现在都难以归类。作为与雨果·格劳秀斯（1583-1645）几乎完全同时代的人，克莱拉克缺乏这位学者的原创思维和雄辩能力。他借鉴了既定的法律学术模式，但他的注释却与安科内坦人本文努托·是特拉卡（Benvenuto Stracca）、葡萄牙人佩德罗·德·桑塔雷姆（Pedro de Santarém）、罗马人西吉斯蒙德·斯卡西亚（Sigismondo Scaccia）和热那亚人拉斐尔·德拉·托雷（Raffaele della Torre）等法学家关于商业和海事法的拉丁文论文的严谨性相去甚远，更不用说格劳秀斯和他的竞争对手约翰·塞尔登（John Selden）。24比起这些论文中的任何一篇，《海洋的用途和习俗》充满了实用的说明、合同的例子和关于信用的道德故事，但它既不是一本商人手册，也不是一本忏悔者手册。克莱拉克依靠自己的训练，反复参考罗马法、法理学和法国地区的习俗。虽然他经常求助于安德烈·阿尔恰托（1492-1550）、查尔斯·杜穆兰（1500-1566）、雅克·库哈斯（1522-1590）和查尔斯·罗伊索（1566-1627）等著名法律学者，但他并不蔑视在当地法规和习俗方面具有专长的更谦虚的法国法学家和律师。25

Cleirac’s sparing use of practical or normative books about trade is symptomatic of his position as a half-removed observer of the world of maritime trade.
