A catchword used by both Cleirac and the Savarys, the term fripon became a staple of all eighteenth-century gentile descriptions of Jews’ economic roles, regardless of the author’s ideological leaning. A fripon was a rogue or, as a period French-English dictionary defined it, “an unworthie fellow, one that useth, or is given to, base trickes, and . . . hath no inclination to any goodness.”63 Bernard Mandeville’s Fable of the Bees, or, Private Vices, Public Benefits (1714) was rendered into French as La fable des abeilles, ou, Les fripons devenus honnestes gens . In Antoine Furetière’s dictionary (1690), a fripon was someone who could not be trusted (“fourbe, qui n’a ni honneur, ni foi, ni probité”) but also a near synonym for Jews, described as “great usurers, cheaters, and double-dealers” (“les Juifs sont de grands usuriers, frippiers, & trompeurs”).64 The recurrence of the terms fripon and friponnerie in eighteenth-century French references to Jews is significant because it underscores the constraints that language imposed on the emergence of a counterdiscourse premised on a more positive relationship between Jews and credit.

作为克莱拉克和萨瓦里家族的口头禅，fripon 一词成为 18 世纪所有外邦人描述犹太人经济角色的主要内容，无论作者的意识形态倾向如何。fripon 是一个流氓，或者，正如当时的法英词典所定义的那样，“一个不值得信赖的家伙，一个使用或被赋予卑鄙伎俩的人，…… 没有任何善良的倾向。”63伯纳德·曼德维尔的《蜜蜂的寓言》，或《私人的恶习，公共的利益》（1714）被译成法语，称为《蜜蜂的寓言》，或《蜜蜂变成了诚实的人》（Les fripons devenus honnestes gens）。在 Antoine Furetière 的字典（1690）中，fripon 是不能被信任的人（“fourbe, qui n'a ni honneur, ni foi, ni probité”），但也是犹太人的近义词，被描述为 “伟大的高利贷者、骗子和双重交易者”（“les Juifs sont de grands usuriers, frippiers, & trompeurs”）。64在十八世纪法国人对犹太人的描述中反复出现 fripon和 friponnerie 这两个词是很重要的，因为它强调了语言对以犹太人和信贷之间更积极的关系为前提的反话语出现的限制。

If the words “usury” and friponnerie were invariably conntected to Jews, “commerce” and “credit” were not, as evidenced, for example, in the definitions of these terms in contemporary French dictionaries. In the economic reality of the time, Jews could be pawnbrokers, lending on collateral to the poor, or merchants negotiating bills of exchange for the conduct of long-distance trade. In the discursive themes of the time, by contrast, Jews belonged almost exclusively to the former domain. The medieval characterization of usury as an antisocial economic activity monopolized by religious infidels persisted, even as the term acquired a more secular connotation of “illicit profit.” Arguing that the spirit of commerce could tame a despotic monarch in a society of orders, Montesquieu could point to Jews as the origins of the new spirit without questioning established hierarchies. However, once egalitarian demands grew louder, the champions of Jewish rights were at pains to distinguish between usury and commerce and not at all inclined to attribute to Jews a positive role in initiating the development of commercial society.

如果说 “高利贷” 和 friponnerie 这两个词总是和犹太人联系在一起，那么 “商业” 和 “信贷” 则不是，例如，在当代法语词典中对这些词的定义，就是证明。在当时的经济现实中，犹太人可以是典当商，以抵押品向穷人放贷，也可以是为进行长途贸易而进行汇票谈判的商人。相比之下，在当时的讨论主题中，犹太人几乎只属于前一个领域。中世纪对高利贷的描述是一种由宗教异教徒垄断的反社会经济活动，即使这个词获得了 “非法利润” 这一更世俗的内涵，这种描述依然存在。孟德斯鸠认为，商业精神可以驯服秩序社会中的专制君主，他可以指出犹太人是新精神的起源，而不质疑既定的等级制度。然而，一旦平等主义的要求越来越高，犹太人权利的拥护者就会不厌其烦地把高利贷和商业区分开来，而且根本不倾向于把启动商业社会发展的积极作用归于犹太人。

For Lacretelle, the sorry state of French Jews compared unfavorably with that of the Jews of Holland, parts of Italy and Germany, and especially the American colonies, where “commerce brought them a bit closer to the ordinary human condition,” making them “more honest and more faithful in their dealings.”65 In revising his works for posterity, Lacretelle stressed this point by turning to a familiar subject: the legend, as recounted by Montesquieu.66 Yet even Lacretelle, who attributed to commerce a more positive role than later supporters of Jewish civic and political rights, failed to uphold French Sephardim as models. His plea for Jewish civic rights anticipated the unresolved tension between moneylending and commerce that would characterize all emancipation debates. “Usury,” Lacretelle wrote, “seems to have made Jews, at all times, into its loyal agents.”67 As he reasoned, Jews had been banned from artisanal and commercial activities because Christians feared competition; as a result, Jews had specialized in moneylending, which had corrupted their moral fiber. Here and there, Lacretelle held up the Sephardim as proof of the beneficial effects of commerce, but he did so tangentially and without conviction. More often, he associated Jews with retail trade and moneylending.

在拉克雷特看来，法国犹太人的悲惨境遇与荷兰、意大利和德国部分地区，特别是美国殖民地的犹太人相比，是很不利的，在那里，“商业使他们稍微接近普通人的状况”，使他们 “在交易中更加诚实，更加忠实”。65在为后世修订作品时，拉克雷泰勒通过转向一个熟悉的主题来强调这一点：孟德斯鸠讲述的传说。66然而，即使是拉克雷特尔，他比后来的犹太人公民权利和政治权利的支持者更积极地归因于商业，也未能将法国的塞法尔迪姆人作为典范来维护。他对犹太人公民权利的恳求预示着放贷和商业之间尚未解决的紧张关系，这种关系将成为所有解放辩论的特点。拉克雷泰尔写道：“高利贷”，“似乎在任何时候都使犹太人成为其忠诚的代理人。”67正如他所推断的那样，犹太人被禁止从事手工业和商业活动，因为基督徒害怕竞争；因此，犹太人专门从事放贷活动，这腐蚀了他们的道德品质。拉克雷特在这里和那里举出了塞法尔迪姆人作为商业的有益影响的证据，但他这样做是切题的，没有说服力。更多时候，他把犹太人与零售贸易和放贷联系起来。

The thread that linked seventeenth-century philosemitic mercantilism to Montesquieu’s doux commerce became looser and looser as the emancipation debates progressed. In actuality, Jewish lending activities in Alsace had little in common with their critics’ portrayal of them. Notarial records show Jews to have been a minority among the creditors in the region, even if they were overrepresented among rural moneylenders.68 In spite of these facts, Christian resentment against Jewish moneylending in Alsace ran deep. In 1777–1778, a crown official with an aversion to Jews and a gift for inflammatory rhetoric named François-Joseph-Antoine Hell engineered an unprecedented defamation campaign against the region’s Jews. He persuaded Alsatian peasants not to repay their debts to Jews and distributed forged receipts attesting to the extinction of those debts.69

随着解放辩论的进行，将 17 世纪的重商主义哲学与孟德斯鸠的 “商业机密” 联系起来的线索变得越来越松散。实际上，犹太人在阿尔萨斯的借贷活动与批评者对他们的描述没有什么共同之处。公证记录显示，犹太人在该地区的债权人中只占少数，即使他们在农村放债人中的人数过多。68尽管有这些事实，基督教对阿尔萨斯的犹太人放贷的怨恨还是很深。1777-1778 年，一位厌恶犹太人并擅长煽动性言辞的王室官员，名叫弗朗索瓦·约瑟夫·安托万·赫尔，策划了一场前所未有的针对该地区犹太人的诽谤运动。他劝说阿尔萨斯的农民不要偿还他们欠犹太人的债务，并分发伪造的收据，证明这些债务已经消失。69

The ease with which Hell seized on peasants’ hatred of Jewish moneylenders alarmed the Alsatian Jewish leader Cerf Berr (1730–1793), who hired a Prussian civil servant with radical inclinations, Christian Wilhelm von Dohm (1751–1820), to pen the most vigorous defense to date of Jewish civic and political rights. Dohm recommended that Jews shift their economic endeavors away from trade and toward manufacturing and agriculture.70 A century earlier, the ecclesiastical historian Claude Fleury had expressed admiration for the simple life of ancient Israelites, whom he believed had been devoted to cultivating the land in Palestine, while condemning the corruption, greediness, and duplicity of postexilic Jews in the diaspora.71 By the 1780s, this narrative had become a leitmotif among gentile backers of Jewish rights.72

赫尔利用农民对犹太放债人的仇恨，轻而易举地使阿尔萨斯的犹太领袖塞尔夫·贝尔（Cerf Berr，1730-1793）感到震惊，他雇用了一位有激进倾向的普鲁士公务员克里斯蒂安·威廉·冯·杜姆（Christian Wilhelm von Dohm，1751-1820），为犹太人的公民权和政治权利撰写了迄今为止最有力的辩护。杜姆建议犹太人将他们的经济活动从贸易转向制造业和农业。70一个世纪前，教会历史学家克劳德·弗勒里（Claude Fleury）对古代以色列人的简单生活表示钦佩，他认为他们一直致力于在巴勒斯坦耕种土地，同时谴责散居各地的后世犹太人的腐败、贪婪和阴险。71到了 1780 年代，这种叙述已经成为支持犹太人权利的外邦人的主题词。72

Dohm depicted the Middle Ages in terms not dissimilar to Montesquieu’s, describing them as a time when church persecutions had forced Jews into shameful businesses, but, unlike Montesquieu, he did not attribute to Jews the ability to free society at large (or themselves, for that matter) from the evil effects of their specialization in the moneyed economy thanks to the invention of bills of exchange. Only after the fall of the Roman Empire, Dohm wrote, did the Jews turn to commerce. Though the byproduct of persecution, overspecialization in commerce meant that fraud and usury became distinctive traits of the Jewish character.73 In order to “cure this corruption,” Dohm proposed not only to open all professions to Jews, but also to institute specific measures to “distance Jews from the profession of commerce and to seek to lessen its influence on their character.”74 In Jonathan Karp’s analysis, Dohm decried Jews’ concentration in mercantile professions “not because he was opposed to commerce per se but because . . . he believed that commerce was too important to be left to Jews.”75 In this view, a universalist commercial society was one in which Jews neither held an oligopolistic position nor tainted gentiles involved in the same activities.

杜姆用与孟德斯鸠不相上下的术语描绘了中世纪，将其描述为教会迫害迫使犹太人从事可耻生意的时代，但与孟德斯鸠不同的是，他并没有将由于汇票的发明而使整个社会（或他们自己）摆脱货币经济专业化的恶果的能力归于犹太人。杜姆写道，只有在罗马帝国灭亡后，犹太人才转向商业。虽然是迫害的副产品，但过度专注于商业意味着欺诈和高利贷成为犹太人性格中的独特特征。73为了 “治疗这种腐败”，杜姆不仅建议向犹太人开放所有的职业，而且还建议采取具体措施，“使犹太人远离商业职业，并设法减少其对犹太人性格的影响”。74在乔纳森·卡普的分析中，杜姆谴责犹太人集中从事商业职业，“不是因为他反对商业本身，而是因为…… 他认为商业太重要了，不能留给犹太人。”75在这种观点中，一个普遍主义的商业社会是犹太人既不占据寡头地位，也不玷污参与同样活动的外邦人。

This reading, however, obscures the blurring of commerce and usury in Dohm’s seminal text. Although a deist, Dohm was deeply influenced by Christian theological and popular notions that saw usury as the antithesis of commerce, which was understood as a social bond, and reaffirmed the Jews’ exclusion from French society. If Dohm blamed centuries of harassment for “the moral depravity of Jews,” he also depicted the effects of harassment in familiar terms: a Jew could not be “a good citizen, a sociable fellow” (“un bon citoyen, un homme sociable”).76 Echoing a thirteenth-century trope, he added: “Their [the Jews’] character tends to lead them to commit usury and fraud in commerce. . . . [T]heir religious biases render them asocial.”77

然而，这种解读掩盖了杜姆的开创性文本中商业和高利贷的模糊性。尽管杜姆是个神学家，但他深受基督教神学和流行观念的影响，这些观念将高利贷视为商业的对立面，而商业被理解为一种社会纽带，并重申了犹太人被排斥在法国社会之外。如果杜姆将几个世纪的骚扰归咎于 “犹太人的道德堕落”，那么他也用熟悉的 ：一个犹太人不可能成为 “一个好公民，一个善于交际的家伙”（“un bon citoyen, un homme sociable”），描述了骚扰的影响。76他呼应十三世纪的说法，补充道：“他们（犹太人）的性格倾向于导致他们在商业中放高利贷和欺诈…… 他们的宗教偏见使他们不合群”。77

A critic of the deleterious influence that commerce supposedly exerted on the collective character of Jews, Dohm did not celebrate the Sephardim. He borrowed from a Sephardic author the belief that Jews “were the first to establish banks” in Bordeaux and Bayonne but buried the statement in a footnote and did not otherwise praise Sephardic commercial talent.78 The same statement would resurface in other texts in the years to come, but no author linked Montesquieu’s version of the legend to the idea that Jews founded the first banks in southwestern France in order to downplay the equation of Jews and usury or to argue that Jews’ financial contributions benefited the country at large.

作为一个批评商业对犹太人的集体性格所产生的有害影响的人，杜姆并没有赞美塞法尔迪人。他从一位塞法尔人作者那里借用了犹太人在波尔多和巴约纳 “第一个建立银行” 的信念，但把这句话埋在了一个脚注里，没有以其他方式赞扬塞法尔人的商业才能。78在以后的岁月里，同样的说法会在其他文本中再次出现，但没有作者将孟德斯鸠的传说版本与犹太人在法国西南部建立第一家银行的观点联系起来，以淡化犹太人与高利贷的等同关系，或论证犹太人的金融贡献使整个国家受益。

Dohm’s pamphlet provided the blueprint for the French-language debates that ensued, and particularly for the submissions to an essay competition sponsored by the Royal Society of Arts and Sciences in Metz in 1785, a contest that Hertzberg calls “the central event in the battle of opinion [about Jews] in the last years before the Revolution.”79 The competition took as its theme the question: “Are there ways of making the Jews more useful and happier in France?” There were three winners: Claude-Antonie Thiéry, a Protestant barrister from Nancy; Zalkind Hourwitz, a Polish Jew who had recently immigrated to Paris and would soon be hired by the Bibliothèque du Roy as an interpreter of Oriental languages; and Abbé Henri Grégoire (1750–1831), a priest who later overshadowed the other two. All three concurred that education and economic activities were vital tools to “regenerate” Jews and thus make them eligible for full citizenship.80 All three also associated Jews with usury. The only Jewish voice, Hourwitz, boiled down all Christian accusations against Jews to two: usury and friperie (“they are usurers & fripons because they are oppressed”).81 The latter term and its cognates also appeared frequently in Grégoire’s moral characterization of the Jews.82

杜姆的小册子为随后的法语辩论提供了蓝本，特别是为 1785 年在梅斯举行的皇家艺术与科学学会主办的征文比赛提供了蓝本，赫兹伯格称这次比赛是 “大革命前最后几年关于犹太人的舆论斗争的核心事件”。79这次竞赛的主题是。“是否有办法让犹太人在法国更有用、更快乐？” 有三位获奖者。克劳德·安东尼·蒂埃里（Claude-Antonie Thiéry），来自南锡的新教大律师；扎尔金·霍维茨（Zalkind Hourwitz），一个最近移民到巴黎的波兰犹太人，不久将被罗伊图书馆聘为东方语言的翻译；以及阿贝·亨利·格雷瓜尔（Abbé Henri Grégoire，1750-1831），一个后来盖过其他两人的牧师。这三个人都认为，教育和经济活动是使犹太人 “再生” 的重要工具，从而使他们有资格成为正式公民。80这三个人还将犹太人与高利贷联系起来。唯一的犹太人声音，侯威兹（Hourwitz），将基督教对犹太人的所有指控归结为两个：高利贷 和friperie（“他们是高利贷和 fripons，因为他们被压迫”）。81后一个词及其同义词也经常出现在格雷瓜尔对犹太人的道德描述中。82

All advocates of emancipation conceived of Jewish usury as a product of history rather than nature, but none of them made a concerted effort to distinguish between commerce and moneylending. Thiéry lamented that Jews “soon forgot their primitive simplicity and renounced life in the fields in favor of arts and commerce.”83 In a chapter titled “In What Manner the Jews Became a Commercial People and Usurers,” Grégoire repeated the narrative that ancient Israelites had been farmers, declaring that they had even “neglected commerce, though they inhabited a maritime country, abounding with excellent harbours.”84 Postexilic Jews, according to this account, had been forced into commerce, and commerce had corrupted them. Here commerce was no longer, as in Montesquieu’s narrative, the steppingstone toward a new, less rapacious and divisive form of sociability, and bills of exchange were no longer the antithesis of medieval usury.

所有主张解放的人都认为犹太人的高利贷是历史的产物，而不是自然的产物，但他们都没有一致的努力来区分商业和放贷。泰瑞哀叹说，犹太人 “很快就忘记了他们原始的纯朴，放弃了田间的生活，而选择了艺术和商业”。83在题为 “犹太人以何种方式成为商业民族和高利贷者” 的一章中，格雷瓜尔重复了古代以色列人是农民的说法，宣称他们甚至 “忽略了商业，尽管他们居住在一个海洋国家，那里有很多优秀的港口”。84根据这种说法，后世的犹太人是被迫从事商业的，商业使他们堕落。在这里，商业不再像孟德斯鸠的叙述那样，是走向一种新的、不那么贪婪和分裂的社会形式的垫脚石，汇票也不再是中世纪高利贷的对立面。

When Grégoire resurrected the legend of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange, he was aiming to cast Jewish economic talents in a thoroughly negative light. His was no casual remark. So resolved was Grégoire to assert the legend’s authenticity that he went out of his way to dismiss alternative accounts pointing to Florentines or Germans as the inventors of bills of exchange.85 Borrowing Montesquieu’s phrase, he maintained that by inventing bills of exchange, Jews could “elude violence and support themselves by means of riches almost invisible.”86 But the meaning he attributed to the phrase was unlike that which Montesquieu had intended. Rather than benefiting commercial society as a whole, for Grégoire, this invention furthered the interests of Jews alone. Jewish commerce was usurious because it fulfilled an egotistic purpose.

当格雷瓜尔重提犹太人发明汇票的传说时，他的目的是要把犹太人的经济才能投射到一个完全负面的光线中。他不是随便说说的。格雷瓜尔如此坚决地主张这个传说的真实性，以至于他不顾一切地否定了指向佛罗伦萨人或德国人作为汇票发明者的其他说法。85他借用孟德斯鸠的话说，通过发明汇票，犹太人可以 “躲避暴力，通过几乎看不见的财富来养活自己”。86但他赋予这句话的含义与孟德斯鸠的意图不同。在格雷瓜尔看来，这一发明并没有使整个商业社会受益，而是仅仅促进了犹太人的利益。犹太人的商业是高利贷，因为它满足了一个自我主义的目的。

Born to a modest family in a small village in Lorraine, Grégoire keenly felt the plight of the peasantry, who railed against Jewish moneylenders.87 In his appropriation of the legend, he turned Montesquieu’s narrative on its head and demonstrated that Cleirac’s earlier rendering remained alive. In fact, the entire section of Grégoire’s Essay devoted to Jews’ economic activities was in many ways a dialogue with Montesquieu. For the priest, during the Middle Ages commerce was synonymous with Jews: “Every commercial resource was found naturally in their hands.”88 While he emphasized the harms caused by Christian persecution, he also described Jews as possessing (or having developed—the reasoning is unclear) qualities that over time became innate, such as “a thirst for gain,” “an acuteness which in an instant could see what profits were to be made,” and a “genius for calculation” (génie calculateur ).89 Secular authorities who deprived Jews of alternative means of livelihood in the interest of securing their financial services were to blame for Jews’ association with commerce, but the fact remained that Jews “worship no other idol but money, and are infested with no other leprosy but usury.”90 Like other fervent partisans of Jewish rights before and after him, Grégoire easily slipped into essentialized views of Jewish economic cunning at the same time that he sought to undo them.

格雷瓜尔出生在洛林一个小村庄的一个普通家庭，他敏锐地感受到了农民的困境，他们对犹太放债人进行抨击。87在他对这个传说的挪用中，他颠覆了孟德斯鸠的叙述，并证明克莱拉克早先的渲染仍有生命力。事实上，格雷瓜尔的《对话》中专门讨论犹太人经济活动的整个章节在很多方面都是与孟德斯鸠的对话。对神父来说，在中世纪，商业是犹太人的同义词。“每一种商业资源都自然而然地掌握在他们手中”。88虽然他强调了基督教迫害造成的伤害，但他也将犹太人描述为拥有（或发展了 —— 推理不清楚）一些品质，这些品质随着时间的推移变成了天生的，如 “对利益的渴望”，“一种能在瞬间看到什么利润的敏锐性”，以及 “计算的天才”（génie calculateur）。89世俗当局为了确保犹太人的金融服务而剥夺了他们的其他谋生手段，这应该归咎于犹太人与商业的联系，但事实是，犹太人 “除了金钱，没有其他偶像，除了高利贷，没有其他麻风病”。90像他之前和之后的其他狂热的犹太权利拥护者一样，格雷瓜尔很容易陷入对犹太人经济狡诈的本质化看法，同时他又试图消除这些看法。

In a subtle rebuttal of Montesquieu, Grégoire volunteered “a remark, which no person, perhaps, [has] ever yet made,” namely, that as Christians began to engage in commerce in the late Middle Ages, they provided competition for the Jews and thus reined in “the robbery of the Jews.” As the pursuit of profit became acceptable among Christians, “security” and “sincerity” came to be increasingly valued because of their importance in guaranteeing respect for contractual obligations. Among Christians, he added, the spirit of commerce led to the development of a self-policing commercial society: “The rays of reason, enlightening the mazy path of usury, taught the people to be on their guard against the frauds of the usurer.”91 For reasons that Grégoire did not elucidate, the spirit of commerce did not transform Jews in the same way. His logic echoed earlier hostile views of Jews as rivals of Christian merchants. But now, with the ascent of nationalism, these arguments acquired new potency. If all merchants were suspected of being unpatriotic (“the merchant, become a citizen of the world, . . . is seldom a zealous patriot”), Jews were unredeemable: rootless people (“not attached to the soil”), they would be perceived as always willing to sell out to the highest bidder.92

在对孟德斯鸠的巧妙反驳中，格雷瓜尔主动提出了 “一句话，也许还没有人说过”，即随着基督教徒在中世纪后期开始从事商业活动，他们为犹太人提供了竞争，从而抑制了 “犹太人的抢劫”。随着对利润的追求在基督徒中变得可以接受，“安全” 和 “真诚” 越来越受到重视，因为它们在保证尊重合同义务方面非常重要。他补充说，在基督徒中，商业精神导致了一个自我监督的商业社会的发展。“理性的光芒，照亮了高利贷的迷途，教导人们要警惕高利贷者的欺诈行为”。91由于格雷瓜尔没有阐明的原因，商业精神并没有以同样的方式改变犹太人。他的逻辑呼应了早期对犹太人作为基督教商人的对手的敌视。但现在，随着民族主义的兴起，这些论点获得了新的效力。如果所有的商人都被怀疑是不爱国的（“商人，成为世界公民，…… 很少是热心的爱国者”），犹太人是不可救药的：无根的人（“不依附于土壤”），他们会被认为总是愿意出卖给出价最高的人。92

This was a different sort of cosmopolitanism from the one captured in Voltaire’s romanticized description of the London Royal Exchange, and one with considerable purchase. In 1767, in a corporatist defense of their privileges against the incursion of Jews, the representatives of the six guilds of Paris, an ancient institution that still wielded some influence, defined usury as the tool Jews used to oppress Christians (after all, the Bible allowed Jews to charge interest to non-Jews). As a result, Jews were said to be unable to join any other “nation” because their aim was always to dissolve rather than unite an existing “political society.” That is also why they were not, the petition continued, “cosmopolitan”: “They belonged to nowhere in the universe,” rather than to everywhere.93 Jewish asociality, in other words, was a direct extension of Jews’ religious infidelity, and usury was the confirmation of their proclivity to exploit Christian society. As patriotism became the foundation of the new political order, the trope of Jews’ multiple allegiances was used to render them unfit for citizenship and became a weapon in the hands of those opposing Jewish emancipation.94

这是一种不同于伏尔泰对伦敦皇家交易所的浪漫化描述中所捕捉到的世界主义，而且是一种有相当购买力的世界主义。1767 年，巴黎六大行会（一个仍然具有一定影响力的古老机构）的代表在为他们的特权进行企业主义辩护时，将高利贷定义为犹太人用来压迫基督徒的工具（毕竟，圣经允许犹太人向非犹太人收取利息）。因此，据说犹太人无法加入任何其他 “国家”，因为他们的目的始终是解散而不是团结一个现有的 “政治社会”。请愿书继续说，这也是为什么他们不是 “世界性的”。他们 “不属于宇宙中的任何地方”，而属于任何地方。93换句话说，犹太人的非社会性是犹太人宗教不忠的直接延伸，而高利贷是对他们利用基督教社会的倾向性的确认。随着爱国主义成为新政治秩序的基础，犹太人的多重效忠的说法被用来使他们不适合做公民，并成为反对犹太人解放的人手中的武器。94

At the onset of the Revolution, Grégoire moved to Paris and abandoned apologetics in favor of political action, embracing radical positions in the National Constituent Assembly. In October 1789, his Motion en faveur des Juifs laid out the arguments for granting Jews full equality. Grégoire’s political activism was not aimed at Jews alone. In fact, he fought equally if not more fervently for the emancipation of African slaves in the French Caribbean. I will return to this point in the next section, but it needs to be noted here if we are to understand Grégoire’s statements about Jews as evidence of the possibilities of and constraints placed on minority groups’ participation in an egalitarian (Christian) society. Grégoire’s activism was conditional on Jews’ shedding what he regarded as moral, social, and religious liabilities that were incompatible with those of citizens. His view of usury as constitutive of Jewish character was one of the pillars of this conditional approach to emancipation.

大革命开始后，格雷瓜尔搬到了巴黎，放弃了道歉，转而采取政治行动，在国民制宪会议上采取了激进的立场。1789 年 10 月，他的《支持犹太人的动议》提出了给予犹太人完全平等的论点。格雷瓜尔的政治活动并不只针对犹太人。事实上，他同样为解放法国加勒比海地区的非洲奴隶而奋斗，如果不是更加狂热的话。我将在下一节中回到这一点，但如果我们要把格雷瓜尔关于犹太人的言论理解为少数群体参与平等主义（基督教）社会的可能性和限制的证据，就需要在这里指出这一点。格雷瓜尔的行动主义是以犹太人摆脱他所认为的与公民不相容的道德、社会和宗教责任为条件的。他认为高利贷是犹太人性格的组成部分，是这种有条件的解放方式的支柱之一。

In his Essay , Grégoire had borrowed from Dohm the claim that Jews brought banking to Bordeaux and Bayonne. But the contention, in light of Grégoire’s use of the legend, was not meant as a compliment.95 Perhaps impressed by his encounter with a delegation of Jews from southwestern France, in his Motion the revolutionary priest hailed the respectability of the Jews of Amsterdam, The Hague, Berlin, and Bordeaux, describing them more generously than he had in his Essay . In the Motion , however, Grégoire resorted once again to the legend as evidence of the interdependence of Jewish commerce and usury.96 More generally, throughout his work, he sometimes referred to “the Jews” collectively and sometimes contrasted the Sephardim and Ashkenazim, although ultimately he hoped for the conversion of all of them.97

在他的《对话》中，格雷瓜尔从杜姆那里借用了犹太人给波尔多和巴约纳带来银行业务的说法。但从格雷瓜尔对这个传说的使用来看，这种说法并不是为了恭维。95也许是被他与来自法国西南部的犹太人代表团的相遇所打动，这位革命牧师在他的《动议》中赞扬了阿姆斯特丹、海牙、柏林和波尔多的犹太人的可敬性，对他们的描述比他在《对话》中更慷慨。然而，在《动议》中，格雷瓜尔再次诉诸于这个传说，以证明犹太人的商业和高利贷的相互依存关系。96更为普遍的是，在他的整个作品中，他有时统称 “犹太人”，有时将塞法尔迪人和阿什肯纳兹人进行对比，尽管他最终希望他们所有人都能改变信仰。97

How did Jews respond, rhetorically, to these indictments? Among the entrants in the Metz contest, Hourwitz alone came close to singling out the Sephardim as the living example of regeneration. But he too alternated between distinguishing Sephardic commerce from Ashkenazic moneylending and conflating the two. In both cases, he indicated that usury separated Jews from the rest of the population. To remedy the situation, Hourwitz advocated Jews’ admission to craft guilds and liberal professions and recommended that they be allowed to cultivate the land—all measures that would decrease the number of merchants among them “and thus the number of fripons .”98 He urged Jews to take concrete steps to abandon all particularism, to develop closer ties to gentile customers, and to submit themselves to “the inspection of la police ” in order to diminish opportunities “to cheat and steal” and thus enhance the chances that merchants among them would turn “into more honest men.”99 If they followed his recommendations, he concluded, the Jews of the eastern regions would “over time, become as happy and as useful to the state as their coreligionists from Bordeaux and Bayonne.”100 Nevertheless, Hourwitz’s depiction of Jewish economic activities displeased the leaders of Bordeaux’s Jewish community, who were offended by his essay’s call for regulation and likening of commerce to usury.101

犹太人是如何在修辞上回应这些指责的？在梅斯竞赛的参赛者中，只有侯威兹接近于把塞法尔人挑出来作为再生的活生生的例子。但他也在区分塞法尔人的商业和阿什肯纳人的放债之间交替出现，并将两者混为一谈。在这两种情况下，他都表示高利贷将犹太人与其他人口分开。为了纠正这种情况，胡维茨主张让犹太人加入手工业行会和自由职业，并建议允许他们耕种土地 —— 所有这些措施将减少他们中的商人数量，“从而减少炸药的数量”。98他敦促犹太人采取具体措施，放弃一切特殊主义，与外邦人客户建立更紧密的联系，并接受 “警察的检查”，以减少 “欺骗和偷窃” 的机会，从而增加他们中的商人 “变成更诚实的人” 的机会。99他总结说，如果他们遵循他的建议，东部地区的犹太人将 “随着时间的推移，变得和他们在波尔多和巴约纳的同胞一样幸福，对国家一样有用。”100 然而，侯威兹对犹太人经济活动的描述使波尔多的犹太社区领导人感到不满，他们对他文章中呼吁监管和将商业比作高利贷的做法感到不满。101

Other Jewish advocates also hinted at the utility of Jewish commerce or the beneficial effects that commerce had on the Sephardim of southwestern France, but unlike their seventeenth-century predecessors, they did not obtain new rights on the grounds that Jews’ skills in commerce and finance were useful to France. In 1788, the Sephardim petitioned Chrétien Guillaume de Lamoignon de Malesherbes, the minister charged with reforming the status of non-Catholic French subjects, to be admitted to the chambers of commerce of the kingdom on account of what they “contribute[d] to the progress of commerce.”102 Their request was denied. There was a historical reason for this refusal. The stakes were different from those of 150 years earlier, when privileges—rather than rights—were the cardinal principles of politics. In the seventeenth century, Simone Luzzatto and Menasseh ben Israel could win their cases with Christian rulers by overstating Jews’ economic contributions. After the Revolution began, such arguments were no longer tenable. The deputies of the Jewish community of Bordeaux, addressing Grégoire in August 1789, cited “a multitude of associations devoted to trade and charity” as examples of the “fraternity between Christians and Jews” that entitled them to equal rights yet refrained from elaborating any further on their economic activities.103

其他犹太倡导者也暗示了犹太商业的效用，或商业对法国西南部的塞法尔迪人的有利影响，但与他们十七世纪的前辈不同，他们并没有以犹太人的商业和金融技能对法国有用为由获得新的权利。1788 年，塞法尔迪姆人向负责改革非天主教法国臣民地位的部长克雷蒂安·纪尧姆·德·拉莫尼翁·德·马勒舍贝斯（Chrétien Guillaume de Lamoignon de Malesherbes）请愿，要求允许他们进入王国的商会，理由是他们 “对商业进步做出了贡献”。102他们的请求被拒绝了。这一拒绝是有历史原因的。当时的利害关系与 150 年前不同，当时特权 —— 而不是权利 —— 是政治的主要原则。在十七世纪，西蒙·卢扎托和米纳西·本·以色列可以通过夸大犹太人的经济贡献而在基督教统治者面前获胜。大革命开始后，这种论点不再站得住脚。1789 年 8 月，波尔多犹太社区的代表在向格雷瓜尔讲话时，引用了 “大量致力于贸易和慈善的协会” 作为 “基督徒和犹太人之间的博爱” 的例子，使他们有权获得平等的权利，但却没有进一步阐述他们的经济活动。103

Jews’ advocacy of their rights at this time no longer revolved around claims of commercial utility. In January 1790, three representatives of the Spanish and Portuguese Jews of Bordeaux sent a letter to the National Constituent Assembly detailing how the Jews of the southwest differed from those of the rest of France and Europe at large. The letter argued that the Sephardim “were both négociants and farmers” and contributed to the flourishing of the region where they lived. But more than anything else, it stressed the civic equality that the Jews of southwestern France enjoyed with all other “co-citizens” thanks to the privileges granted to them by the crown in 1550 and again in 1776. It was on the basis of those privileges that they had been allowed to participate in the elections for the National Assembly. There was no difference, the representatives wrote, between the Jews of southwestern France and “French Catholics,” either in the “civil order” or in the “moral order.”104 The battle for citizenship was a political struggle fought on legal and moral grounds rather than economic ones.

犹太人此时对其权利的主张不再是围绕商业效用的主张。1790 年 1 月，波尔多的西班牙和葡萄牙犹太人的三名代表向国家制宪会议发出了一封信，详细说明了西南部的犹太人与法国其他地区和整个欧洲的犹太人有什么不同。信中说，塞法尔迪姆人 “既是商人又是农民”，为他们生活的地区的繁荣做出了贡献。但更重要的是，它强调了法国西南部的犹太人与所有其他 “共同公民” 享有的公民平等，这要归功于王室在 1550 年和 1776 年给予他们的特权。正是基于这些特权，他们被允许参加国民议会的选举。代表们写道，法国西南部的犹太人和 “法国天主教徒” 之间没有任何区别，无论是在 “公民秩序” 还是在 “道德秩序” 方面。104争取公民权的斗争是一场基于法律和道德而非经济理由的政治斗争。

Jewish authors from northeastern France used different slogans to advance their cause and put even less faith in the emancipatory effects of commerce. In a memo drafted to recruit Dohm to take on the cause of the Jews, the Strasbourg leader Cerf Berr touted freedom of commerce as an antidote to the causes of Jewish moneylending in Alsace. But he also exalted the economic functions of court Jews like himself, who served the economic needs of the state, more than he reaffirmed the tenets of doux commerce .105 In October 1789, Isaac Berr-Bing was even more cautious in demanding the lifting of all restrictions on Jewish occupations and property rights in Alsace and Lorraine. While celebrating the orderly society of the regions’ Jews, he lamented that petty trade (la petite friperie ) was the only occupation that sustained the two-thirds of the community who lived in poverty and stressed that no Jew in the area had ever engaged in wholesale trade in grain, “because our religion condemns those who amass this basic food staple.”106 The grain crisis of the summer prior had been the first major test of the revolutionary government, and Berr-Bing knew well the fears of oligopolies and famines that it had provoked. He chose to make the case for Judaism as a religion that inspired charity rather than emphasizing the virtues of large-scale commercial transactions handled by Jews.

法国东北部的犹太作者们用不同的口号来推动他们的事业，甚至不相信商业的解放作用。在一份为招募杜姆从事犹太人事业而起草的备忘录中，斯特拉斯堡的领导人塞尔夫·贝尔吹捧商业自由，认为它是解决阿尔萨斯地区犹太人放债原因的解药。但他也夸大了像他这样的宫廷犹太人的经济功能，他们为国家的经济需求服务，而不是重申商业自由的信条。1051789 年 10 月，艾萨克·贝尔·宾在要求取消对犹太人在阿尔萨斯和洛林的职业和财产权的所有限制时甚至更加谨慎。在庆祝该地区犹太人的有序社会的同时，他感叹小买卖（la petite friperie）是维持该社区三分之二生活贫困的人的唯一职业，并强调该地区的犹太人从未从事过谷物批发贸易，“因为我们的宗教谴责那些囤积这种基本食物的人”。106前年夏天的粮食危机是对革命政府的第一次重大考验，贝尔·宾很清楚它所引发的对寡头垄断和饥荒的担忧。他选择将犹太教作为一种激发慈善的宗教，而不是强调由犹太人处理的大规模商业交易的优点。

Gentile observers were even more prone to conflate commerce with usury. In Alsace, an anonymous voice sympathetic to Jews praised their economic contributions to society and the state but equated “commerce” with “money-lending.”107 In a famous speech to the National Assembly on December 23, 1789, the Count of Clermont-Tonnerre said little of substance about the economic roles of Jews. He blamed the state’s restrictions on Jews’ professions, not their character, for their habit of lending at interest but lumped all moneyed professions together, without distinguishing between commerce and pawnbroking.108 At the opposite end of the political spectrum, Abbé Maury denied that Jews had ever been an agricultural people (“They were laborers neither under King David nor under King Solomon”) and equated them with the Barbary pirates, who were “occupied solely in commerce” and lived off robbery at sea.109

外邦人观察员甚至更容易将商业与高利贷混为一谈。在阿尔萨斯，一个同情犹太人的匿名声音赞扬了他们对社会和国家的经济贡献，但把 “商业” 等同于 “放债”。107在 1789 年 12 月 23 日对国民议会的一次著名演讲中，克莱蒙·唐纳尔伯爵对犹太人的经济作用没有说什么实质性的话。他指责国家对犹太人职业的限制，而不是他们的性格，因为他们有借贷利息的习惯，但他把所有有钱的职业混为一谈，没有区分商业和典当业的区别。108在政治光谱的另一端，阿贝-莫里（Abbé Maury）否认犹太人曾经是一个农业民族（“他们在大卫王和所罗门王时期都不是劳动者”），并将他们等同于巴巴里海盗，后者 “只从事商业”，靠海上抢劫为生。109

Jews and Other Minorities

犹太人和其他少数群体

In the revolutionary battle for equality, male Jews emerged as the winners while other disadvantaged groups were left behind. No single reason explains why Jewish men gained equality while women and blacks did not, although the temporary abolition of slavery (1794–1802) and Jews’ emancipation reveal the republican belief in the capacity of the Revolution to change the nature of men—although not women, who were never seen as real candidates for equality. Rather, the process of Jewish emancipation helps us better understand the limits of the Revolution’s universalism—limits derived not only from the perceived innate characteristics of each group that demanded inclusion in the new legal and political order but also from the need to reaffirm differences in this more egalitarian order. From both a historical and a theoretical perspective, women posed the greatest challenge to the universalism of human rights (not coincidentally called “the Rights of Man and of the Citizen” in the 1789 Declaration).124 A rare champion of women’s political equality, the Marquis of Condorcet was uncompromising in his defense of “natural rights” and the perfectibility of all humans. Yet he, too, had his favorite causes: he wrote more strenuously on behalf of slaves than Jews.125 Grégoire, by contrast, fought for active political rights for blacks and Jews but saw women as inherently unable to hold government and administrative positions.126

在争取平等的革命斗争中，男性犹太人成为赢家，而其他处境不利的群体则被抛在后面。没有任何单一的原因可以解释为什么犹太男子获得了平等，而妇女和黑人却没有，尽管奴隶制的暂时废除（1794-1802）和犹太人的解放揭示了共和党人相信革命有能力改变男子的性质 —— 尽管妇女没有，因为她们从未被视为平等的真正候选人。相反，犹太人的解放过程有助于我们更好地理解革命的普遍主义的局限性 —— 这种局限性不仅来自于要求被纳入新的法律和政治秩序的每个群体的感知的先天特征，也来自于在这个更加平等的秩序中重申差异的需要。从历史和理论的角度来看，妇女对人权的普遍性（在 1789 年的宣言中被称为 “人和公民的权利”，这并非巧合）构成了最大的挑战。124孔多塞侯爵是一位罕见的妇女政治平等的支持者，他毫不妥协地捍卫 “自然权利” 和所有人类的完美性。然而，他也有自己喜欢的事业：他为奴隶写的文章比为犹太人写的文章更有说服力。125相比之下，格雷瓜尔为黑人和犹太人争取积极的政治权利，但认为妇女天生就不能担任政府和行政职务。126

While he did not explicitly compare Jews and blacks, Grégoire relied on the same reasoning when he argued that both groups deserved inclusion in the body politic: as Christian persecutions hampered Jews, he noted, so “accidental circumstances and local causes have prevented or impeded the progress of civilization in Africa.”127 In this view, centuries of European exploitation rather than nature explained why free and enslaved blacks lingered in an inferior “degree of civilization”: “The natives of Africa and America would long ago have risen to the highest level of civilization if this good purpose would have been supported by a hundredth part of the efforts, the money, and the time that have been given over to tormenting and butchering many millions of these unfortunate people, whose blood calls for vengeance against Europe.”128

虽然他没有明确比较犹太人和黑人，但格雷瓜尔在论证这两个群体都应该被纳入政治体时，依靠的是同样的推理：他指出，正如基督教的迫害阻碍了犹太人一样，“偶然的环境和地方原因也阻止或阻碍了非洲的文明进步”。127在这种观点中，几个世纪以来欧洲人的剥削而不是自然，解释了为什么自由和被奴役的黑人在低劣的 “文明程度” 上徘徊。“非洲和美洲的土著人早就上升到了最高的文明水平，如果这一良好的目的能够得到百分之一的努力、金钱和时间的支持，而这些努力、金钱和时间却被用于折磨和屠杀数百万这些不幸的人，他们的血液需要向欧洲复仇。128

For all the similarities of Grégoire’s arguments in favor of blacks and Jews, the bon curé patently considered it easier to “regenerate” the former than the latter. It has even been noted that during an animated session of the National Assembly in December 1789, Grégoire remained silent on the question of the fate of the Jews, perhaps for fear of endangering the antislavery cause.129 For sure he was generous in enumerating the “moral qualities of the negroes,” their “upright character” and “true bravery,” “their talents . . . for arts and craftsmanship,” and the sophistication of their “political societies” in Africa.130 By contrast, one is hard pressed to find any praises of Jews’ cultural achievements in his Metz Essay . Rejecting Isaac de Pinto’s arguments, Grégoire was also skeptical of the existence of substantial differences between Ashkenazic and Sephardic Jews and more inclined to think that “the Jewish nation has been the most like itself, at all times, both in beliefs and usages.” Surely, he claimed, “there is more resemblance between the Jews of Ethiopia and those of England, than between the inhabitants of Picardy and those of Provence.”131 This was a low bar, which left no room for appreciating the Sephardim’s achievements in long-distance trade.

尽管格雷瓜尔支持黑人和犹太人的论点有很多相似之处，但这位好教士显然认为让前者 “再生” 比后者更容易。甚至有人指出，在 1789 年 12 月国民议会的一次热烈会议上，格雷瓜尔对犹太人的命运问题保持沉默，也许是担心危及反奴隶制事业。129可以肯定的是，他慷慨地列举了 “黑人的道德品质”，他们的 “正直性格” 和 “真正的勇敢”，“他们的天赋…… 艺术和手工艺”，以及他们在非洲 “政治社会” 的复杂性。130相比之下，人们很难在他的《梅兹论》中找到对犹太人文化成就的赞美。格雷瓜尔拒绝了艾萨克·德·平托的论点，他也对阿什肯纳兹和塞法尔犹太人之间存在的实质性差异持怀疑态度，更倾向于认为 “犹太民族在任何时候都是最像自己的，无论是信仰还是习惯”。当然，他声称，“埃塞俄比亚的犹太人和英国的犹太人之间的相似性比皮卡迪的居民和普罗旺斯的居民之间的相似性要大”。131这是一个很低的标准，它没有为欣赏塞法尔迪人在长途贸易中的成就留下任何空间。

The lingering particularism that inflected revolutionary ideals is arguably the thorniest legacy that the events of the 1790s have bequeathed to Western liberalism, setting up a clash between an abstract aspiration to equality and the irreducible existence of differences, including the affirmation of those differences by legal and demographic minorities themselves.132 As Maurice Samuels has recently reminded us, the 1791 decree that emancipated all Jews in France included none of the conditions that theorists of “regeneration” had demanded, and yet, at times, their desire that Jews shed any residual particularism seems to have been fulfilled.133 In 1792, a Hebrew version of the Marseillaise was sung in the synagogue of Metz to celebrate the victory of the republican army at Thionville, the Lorraine town from which Lacretelle had first launched the pro-Jewish cause.134 In that same year, while battling militarily for survival, the French Republic included a recently emancipated Jewish citizen among its army suppliers.135 Episodes such as these are cited as evidence of the “compatibility of republicanism and Judaism.”136 But that compatibility was short-lived. Subsequent incarnations of French secularism (laïcité ) reserved the blending of patriotism and the public display of religion for the majority of French citizens who, whether practicing Catholics or not, were (and still are) neither Jewish nor Muslim.

影响革命理想的挥之不去的特殊主义，可以说是 1790 年代的事件给西方自由主义留下的最棘手的遗产，它在抽象的平等愿望和不可减少的差异存在之间形成了冲突，包括法律和人口方面的少数群体本身对这些差异的肯定。132正如莫里斯·塞缪尔（Maurice Samuels）最近提醒我们的那样，1791 年解放法国所有犹太人的法令不包括 “再生” 理论家所要求的任何条件，然而，有时他们希望犹太人摆脱任何残留的特殊主义的愿望似乎已经实现了。1331792 年，一首希伯来语版本的《马赛曲》在梅斯的犹太教堂唱响，以庆祝共和军在蒂永维尔的胜利，蒂永维尔是洛林地区的一个小镇，拉克雷泰尔就是在这里首次发起亲犹太人的事业。134同年，在为生存而进行的军事斗争中，法兰西共和国将一名最近获得解放的犹太公民纳入其军队供应商之列。135诸如此类的事件被引为 “共和主义和犹太教相容” 的证据。136但这种兼容性是短暂的。后来的法国世俗主义（laïcité）为大多数法国公民保留了爱国主义和公开展示宗教的机会，这些人无论是否信奉天主教，既不是（现在也不是）犹太人也不是穆斯林。

Conclusion

总结

In his classic The Passions and the Interests , Hirschman departs from mainstream scholarship on Montesquieu to call attention to the contention that Jews invented bills of exchange. For his purposes, the validity and genealogy of that contention are irrelevant. Whether real or imaginary, the claim exemplifies Montesquieu’s argument that commercial expansion is incompatible with autocratic government. The legend is thus central to Hirschman’s overall thesis as captured by its subtitle: Political Arguments for Capitalism Before Its Triumph , with an emphasis on the word Political . Without denying the naïveté of some of Montesquieu’s generalizations, Hirschman finds that The Spirit of the Laws planted the seeds for a fully developed theory of the interdependence of commerce and democracy that deserves as much attention as the paradigms proposed by Adam Smith and Karl Marx. Brilliant and penetrating, if inevitably partial, The Passions and the Interests has been hugely influential, to the point of obscuring how The Spirit of the Laws was read at the time, certainly with regard to the assertion that Jews invented bills of exchange. In fact, commerce played a minor role, if any at all, in the political emancipation of Jews.

在他的经典之作《激情与利益》中，赫斯曼偏离了关于孟德斯鸠的主流学术研究，呼吁关注犹太人发明汇票的论点。就他的目的而言，这一论点的有效性和谱系并不重要。不管是真实的还是想象的，这一说法体现了孟德斯鸠的论点，即商业扩张与专制政府不相容。因此，这个传说对赫希曼的整体论点至关重要，正如其副标题所描述的。《资本主义胜利前的政治论证》，其中强调了政治一词。赫希曼不否认孟德斯鸠某些概括的天真，但他发现《法律的精神》为商业和民主的相互依存关系的全面发展理论埋下了种子，这种理论值得像亚当·斯密和卡尔·马克思提出的范式一样关注。 《激情与利益》（The Passions and the Interests）才华横溢、深入浅出，尽管不可避免地有其片面性，但却具有巨大的影响力，以至于掩盖了当时对《法律的精神》的解读，当然是关于犹太人发明汇票的论断方面。事实上，商业在犹太人的政治解放中发挥的作用很小，如果有的话。

Montesquieu set up a dichotomy between bills of exchange as new and fundamentally positive credit devices and usury as a medieval and nefarious credit practice. Historians of eighteenth-century French Jews have mapped this dichotomy onto the Sephardim/Ashkenazim divide and emphasized the divergent socioeconomic profiles of the Jewish communities in the southwestern and northeastern regions of the kingdom. The Sephardim engaged in long-distance trade and international finance and were better integrated into the fabric of local society, while the Ashkenazim, who were overwhelmingly occupied in moneylending and petty trade, experienced social isolation and were the targets of overt Christian hostility.

孟德斯鸠在汇票与高利贷之间建立了二分法，前者是新的、根本上积极的信贷手段，后者是中世纪的、邪恶的信贷行为。十八世纪法国犹太人的历史学家将这种二分法映射到塞法迪姆人/阿什肯纳齐姆人的分界线上，并强调王国西南部和东北部地区的犹太社区的社会经济状况存在差异。塞法尔迪人从事长途贸易和国际金融，并更好地融入了当地社会结构，而阿什肯纳兹人则主要从事放贷和小买卖，他们经历了社会孤立，并成为基督教公开敌视的目标。

In the accepted account of emancipation, articulated in both academic and popular histories of the Jews, this divide had direct political consequences because commerce made the Sephardim of Bordeaux into more respectable members of the wider community, paving the way for citizenship. In the early twentieth century, the author of a brief outline of the history of Jewish emancipation in France could write: “I dwell somewhat upon the Bordeaux Jews, for . . . it was their position more than any other single fact or argument whatsoever which carried the Jews of France past the crisis of their faith.” Although a few pages later he describes the debates in the National Assembly as “a chaos of ideas and motives,” the same author celebrates the Sephardim as pathbreakers.110 More recent scholarship refines but does not alter this picture and even suggests that the Sephardim of Bordeaux sought to distance themselves from their Ashkenazic brethren in 1789–1790 (and perhaps even to stall the latter’s emancipation) for fear of compromising their own chances.111

在犹太人的学术史和通俗史所阐述的关于解放的公认说法中，这种分歧具有直接的政治后果，因为商业使波尔多的塞法尔迪姆人成为更广泛社区中更值得尊敬的成员，为公民身份铺平了道路。二十世纪初，法国犹太人解放史简述的作者可以这样写道。“我对波尔多的犹太人做了一些介绍，因为…… 是他们的地位比任何其他单一的事实或论据都更能使法国的犹太人度过他们信仰的危机。” 尽管几页之后，他将国民议会的辩论描述为 “思想和动机的混乱”，但这位作者还是将塞法尔迪姆人赞美为开路先锋。110最近的学术研究完善了这一图景，但并没有改变，甚至认为波尔多的塞法尔迪姆人在 1789-1790 年试图与他们的阿什肯纳兹兄弟保持距离（甚至可能是为了拖延后者的解放），因为他们担心会影响自己的机会。111

This widely shared view of emancipation implies the existence of an invisible link connecting Montesquieu’s celebration of Jewish commercial activity, captured by his positive spin on the legend of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange, to the extension of citizenship to the Sephardim in January 1790, granted eighteen months before the same rights were conferred on all Jewish men of France. One scholar, making that link explicit, even wonders why Montesquieu fell short of advocating full equality for Jews.112 The analysis I have provided thus far demonstrates that the question is misguided.

这种广泛认同的解放观点意味着存在一种无形的联系，将孟德斯鸠对犹太人商业活动的赞美（他对犹太人发明汇票的传说进行了积极的转述）与 1790 年 1 月将公民权扩大到塞法尔迪姆人（在法国所有犹太人被赋予同样权利的 18 个月之前）联系起来。一位学者在明确了这种联系后，甚至想知道为什么孟德斯鸠没有主张犹太人完全平等。112到目前为止，我所提供的分析表明，这个问题是被误导的。

My case rests on my reading of the French Enlightenment, variegated as the phenomena that fall under this rubric are. Schechter has already demonstrated that interest in Jews in eighteenth-century French thought far exceeded what their numbers might logically call for, with images of Jews serving as vehicles to articulate concepts that had little or nothing to do with Jews.113 However, neither he nor any of the numerous scholars who have written about eighteenth-century French commerce broadly conceived have paid much attention to the historical and figurative presence of Jews in that realm. Given the centrality of doux commerce in French economic and political thought, it is important to highlight the role that Montesquieu attributed to Jews in the development of the spirit of commerce, as well as the “moderate” political implications of his account.114 He never argued explicitly in favor of a nonconfessional commercial society and believed that merchants should operate within the confines of a corporatist framework that constrained any potentially disruptive effects on existing hierarchies. Montesquieu’s unshakable belief in a society of orders allowed him to celebrate Jewish commerce in ways in which more egalitarian thinkers would not.

我的理由是我对法国启蒙运动的解读，尽管属于这一范畴的现象是多种多样的。谢赫特（Schechter）已经证明了，十八世纪法国思想界对犹太人的兴趣远远超过了他们的数量，犹太人的形象成为阐述与犹太人关系不大或毫无关系的概念的载体。113然而，无论是他还是任何一位广义上写过 18 世纪法国商业的学者，都没有对犹太人在该领域的历史和象征性存在给予过多关注。鉴于“商业之路” 在法国经济和政治思想中的核心地位，必须强调孟德斯鸠在商业精神的发展中赋予犹太人的作用，以及他的论述的 “温和” 政治含义。114他从未明确主张建立一个非宗教性的商业社会，并认为商人应在公司主义框架的范围内运作，限制对现有等级制度的任何潜在的破坏性影响。孟德斯鸠对秩序社会的坚定信念使他能够以更多平等主义思想家所不具备的方式赞美犹太商业。

His novel interpretation of the legend presupposed a discontinuity between medieval usury and early modern forms of credit but was far from a cry for equality. By the mid-eighteenth century, it had become a cliché for theorists of commercial society to maintain, as Forbonnais did, that commerce bound people into “reciprocal communication.”115 This communication was understood as compatible with the existence of inherent differences and hierarchies. In the 1760s, both the Encyclopédie and the Jewish authors who rebutted Voltaire’s anti-Jewish writings could celebrate Jewish merchants as “pegs and nails” in the edifice of global trade as well as emphasize the status of the Jews of Bordeaux and Bayonne as subjects of the crown (régnicoles ) rather than foreigners. In 1765, when Jacob Rodrigues Péreire (1715–1780), a leader of the then official Sephardic community, republished the lettres patentes that had granted the “Portuguese merchants” of Bordeaux their privileges from 1550 to 1723, he extolled these individuals’ “talent in making commerce flourish and their genius at creating new trade branches.”116 But emancipation was not even on the horizon in those years. In the most consistent defense of Jews’ contributions to commerce in the 1760s, the Parisian Jew Israël Bernard de Vallabrègue used the generic meaning of the word “citizen” in his argument for Jewish civic equality, without making any reference to active political rights.117

他对这个传说的新颖解释预设了中世纪高利贷和早期现代信贷形式之间的不连续性，但远不是对平等的呼唤。到了十八世纪中期，商业社会理论家们像福邦纳那样坚持认为，商业将人们捆绑在 “互惠的交流” 中，这已经成为一种陈词滥调。115这种交流被理解为与固有的差异和等级制度的存在相适应。在 1760 年代，《大百科全书》和反驳伏尔泰反犹太著作的犹太作家都可以把犹太商人作为全球贸易大厦的 “钉子” 来颂扬，并强调波尔多和巴约纳的犹太人作为王室臣民（régnicoles）而不是外国人的地位。1765 年，当当时官方的塞法尔社区领导人雅各布·罗德里格斯·佩雷尔（1715-1780）重新公布 1550 年至 1723 年授予波尔多 “葡萄牙商人” 特权的专利书时，他赞扬了这些人的 “使商业繁荣的才能和创造新贸易部门的天才”。116但在那些年里，解放甚至还没有出现在地平线上。在 1760 年代为犹太人对商业的贡献进行的最一致的辩护中，巴黎犹太人伯纳德·德·瓦拉布雷格（Bernard de Vallabrègue）在论证犹太人的公民平等时使用了 “公民” 一词的一般含义，没有提到积极的政治权利。117

Commerce, in other words, was undoubtedly the linchpin of early modern toleration policies that offered New Christians and New Jews in southwestern France privileges that their brethren in Alsace and Lorraine could not aspire to attain. Commerce also embedded Jewish and Christian merchants in networks of economic dependence (often connected via bills of exchange), both in Bordeaux and overseas. These privileges, and the social interactions they generated, however, were only acceptable in a society in which the majority population was clearly separated from Jews and the latter could not aspire to full membership in it. When equality became a possibility, few heralded the Jews of southwestern France as archetypes of the virtues of commercial credit in contrast to the Jews of northeastern France, who remained emblems of usury.

换句话说，商业无疑是现代早期宽容政策的关键，它为法国西南部的新基督徒和新犹太人提供了他们在阿尔萨斯和洛林的兄弟们无法企及的特权 。在波尔多和海外，商业也将犹太和基督教商人嵌入到经济依赖的网络中（通常通过汇票连接）。然而，这些特权以及它们所产生的社会互动，只有在一个多数人口与犹太人明显分离的社会中才能被接受，而后者也不能渴望成为社会的正式成员。当平等成为一种可能时，很少有人把法国西南部的犹太人誉为商业信贷美德的典型，与法国东北部的犹太人形成对比，后者仍然是高利贷的象征。

No matter how diverse they may be, all the texts examined here dating to the last quarter of the eighteenth century failed to differentiate between commerce and usury. Friponnerie was viewed as the hallmark of both. Usury and bad faith were understood to be the antisocial faces of commerce, and, in the eyes of even the most sympathetic observers, they remained historically (if not theologically) associated with Jews.118 The frequent blurring of the boundaries between commerce and usury in eighteenth-century French representations of Jewish economic roles not only proves the tenacity of discursive traditions, sometimes even when authors consciously tried to break with those traditions, but also demonstrates that the exaltation of Jews’ commercial prowess was a more effective rhetorical strategy in the context of Old Regime policies of toleration than it was during the struggle for emancipation. The lexical and conceptual slippage between commerce and usury that is detectable from Lacretelle onward signals the tenuousness of the line separating Ashkenazic moneylending from Sephardic commerce in the Christian imagination. That the Revolution emancipated the Jews of France in two steps, those of the southwest in January 1790 and all others in September 1791, arguably suggests that the Sephardim were regarded as more acculturated. But the 1790 decree, in line with the demands of Sephardic leaders, who clung to the hope of preserving their corporate autonomy, portrayed emancipation as the confirmation of preexisting privileges. When such language expressing continuity with the Old Regime disappeared from the 1791 decree, it was not—pace Hirschman—because commercial “interests” had displaced prevailing “passions” about Jews.119

无论它们多么不同，这里所研究的所有 18 世纪最后 25 年的文本都没有区分商业和高利贷。高利贷被看作是两者的标志。高利贷和不诚信被理解为商业的反社会面孔，而且，在最有同情心的观察家眼中，它们在历史上（如果不是在神学上）仍然与犹太人有关。118在十八世纪法国对犹太人经济角色的表述中，商业和高利贷之间的界限经常模糊不清，这不仅证明了话语传统的顽强性，有时甚至在作者有意识地试图打破这些传统时也是如此，而且还表明，在旧制度的宽容政策背景下，对犹太人商业能力的赞美是一种更有效的修辞策略，而在争取解放的斗争中则不然。从 Lacretelle 开始，商业和高利贷之间的词汇和概念滑移，表明在基督教的想象中，将阿什肯纳兹人的放贷和塞法尔人的商业分开的界限是很脆弱的。大革命分两步解放了法国的犹太人，1790 年 1 月解放了西南地区的犹太人，1791 年 9 月解放了所有其他地区的犹太人，这可以说表明塞法尔迪人被认为是更有文化的。但是，1790 年的法令符合西法德人领导人的要求，他们坚持希望保留他们的团体自治权，将解放描述为对以前存在的特权的确认。当这种表达与旧制度连续性的语言从 1791 年的法令中消失时，并不是因为商业 “利益” 取代了对犹太人的普遍 “激情” —— 赫斯曼说。119

Amid the “cacophony of arguments” marshaled in favor of emancipation, the virtues of commerce were never used as weapons by pro-Jewish advocates.120 Only the little crossover that exists between French and Jewish historiographies and the scant attention that both pay to the language used by the champions of Jewish rights to describe Jews’ economic roles can explain why many scholars still regard Sephardic merchants as the driving force in the emancipation process. Perhaps nowhere is the disconnect between scholarship on Jewish emancipation and scholarship on the Revolution more pronounced than in the treatment of Honoré-Gabriel de Riqueti, Count of Mirabeau (1749–1791), son of the noted physiocrat and the most influential politician of the first year of the National Assembly (1789–1790). Historians of European Jewry know him for his laudatory portrait of Moses Mendelssohn and his support of Jewish rights in a pamphlet that was modeled largely on Dohm’s ideas.121 Historians of the Revolution know him as a master orator, the fierce and opportunistic adversary of Finance Minister Jacques Necker, and the writer of a “climactic pamphlet,” Dénonciation de l’agiotage (Denunciation of Speculation ), which belonged to a series that, while serving the interests of a circle of bankers and friends who gambled in stocks and foreign currencies, condemned the crown’s handling of the public debt and financial markets.122

在支持解放的 “喧嚣的论调” 中，商业的美德从未被亲犹太人的倡导者用作武器。120只有法国历史学和犹太历史学之间存在的少量交叉，以及两者对犹太权利倡导者，描述犹太人的经济作用所使用的语言的关注，才能解释为什么许多学者仍然把塞法尔商人视为解放进程的推动力。也许，关于犹太人解放的学术研究与关于大革命的学术研究之间的脱节，在对待米拉波伯爵（Honoré-Gabriel de Riqueti，1749-1791）的问题上最为明显，他是著名的生理学家的儿子，也是国民议会第一年（1789-1790）最具影响力的政治家。欧洲犹太人的历史学家知道他为摩西·门德尔松（Moses Mendelssohn）画了一幅赞美的肖像，并在一本主要以杜姆的思想为原型的小册子中支持犹太人的权利。121大革命的历史学家们知道他是一位演说家，是财政部长雅克·内克尔（Jacques Necker）激烈的机会主义对手，也是 “高潮小册子”《谴责投机》（Dénonciation de l'agiotage）的作者，该书属于一个系列，在为那些在股票和外国货币中赌博的银行家和朋友圈的利益服务的同时，谴责了王室对公共债务和金融市场的管理。122

In fact, the two Mirabeaus have a lot in common. Both of his influential pamphlets, the one on Jews and the one on speculation, were written in 1787 when Mirabeau was in Berlin, where Mendelssohn had lived until his death the year before. Both conveyed the same message, one resonant of physiocratic principles, which favored economic liberalization, including the abolition of guilds and other corporate institutions that had long restricted Jews’ economic activities, but deplored commerce and banking. In this formulation, in order to become citizens and patriots, Jews had to recover the supposedly rural way of life of the ancient Israelites and sever their long-held ties to commerce, which Mirabeau called “the veritable, or rather the only cause of the corruption of the Jews.”123 Montesquieu had denounced John Law but did not see private credit as existing on a continuum with public finance. On the eve of the Revolution, however, the awareness of how easily private speculators could alter the value of the royal treasury made it more difficult to sustain the difference between private and public finance.

事实上，这两位米拉波有很多共同点。他的两本有影响力的小册子，一本是关于犹太人的，另一本是关于投机的，都写于 1787 年，当时米拉博在柏林，门德尔松在那里一直住到前一年去世。这两本小册子传达了同样的信息，一个与生理学家的原则相呼应的信息，即赞成经济自由化，包括废除长期以来限制犹太人经济活动的行会和其他企业机构，但对商业和银行业务表示遗憾。在这种表述中，为了成为公民和爱国者，犹太人必须恢复古代以色列人的所谓农村生活方式，并切断他们长期以来与商业的联系，米拉波称商业是 “犹太人腐败的真正原因，或者说是唯一原因”。123孟德斯鸠曾谴责过约翰·罗，但并不认为私人信贷与公共财政存在于一个连续体。然而，在大革命的前夕，人们意识到私人投机者可以很容易地改变皇家国库的价值，这使得维持私人和公共财政之间的差异变得更加困难。

Overall, the economic dimension of Jewish emancipation exposes the limits of French universalism. In the aftermath of the Revolution, the poor economic condition of the majority of French Jews and entrenched suspicions about their usurious character had a decisive effect on the stalling of the advancement of formal equality. Responding to the popular hostility unleashed by the emancipation decrees and persistent complaints that Jews in the northeastern regions “followed no other profession than that of usurers,” in 1806 Napoleon convened the Assembly of Jewish Notables, later constituted as the Grand Sanhedrin, to address problems raised by the imperfect assimilation of Jews. In the meantime, he suspended repayments of all loans made by Jews to “husbandmen, not traders,” for a year’s time.137 Usury, alongside marriage, divorce, rabbinical authority, and military service, figured prominently among the controversial questions that Jews were asked to answer as evidence of their willingness to assimilate.

总之，犹太人解放的经济层面暴露了法国普遍主义的局限性。在大革命之后，大多数法国犹太人糟糕的经济状况和对他们高利贷性质根深蒂固的怀疑，对推进正式平等的进程产生了决定性的影响。为了回应解放法令所释放出的民众敌意，以及对东北部地区的犹太人 “除了高利贷者之外没有其他职业” 的持续抱怨，1806 年，，拿破仑召开了犹太人名流大会，后来被称为大圣公会，以解决犹太人不完全同化所带来的问题。同时，他暂停偿还犹太人向 “丈夫而非商人” 提供的所有贷款，为期一年。137高利贷与结婚、离婚、犹太教权威和兵役一样，都是犹太人被要求回答的有争议的问题，作为他们愿意同化的证据。

With the cooperation of the Assembly’s head, Abraham Furtado, who was, conveniently, a leading Sephardi from Bordeaux and a former Girondin, Napoleon secured assent to what came to be known among French Jews as the “infamous decree.” Promulgated on March 17, 1808, it ruled invalid all loans made by Jews with interest rates above 10 percent a year or issued to minors, women, and soldiers. The state imposed further restrictions on Jews who wished to engage in commerce: they had to obtain a special license, which required a review of their character and verification that they had not previously engaged in usurious activities. These measures, together with other limitations on Jews’ civil rights, applied only to the Jews of Alsace and Lorraine, were set to last for ten years, and aimed to alter not only the socioeconomic profile but also the inner character of the newly emancipated group. The Jews of southwestern France were spared these humiliating restrictions but were also much fewer in number than their Ashkenazic brethren and did not loom as large in the French imagination.

在议会主席亚伯拉罕·福尔塔多（Abraham Furtado）的合作下，拿破仑获得了被法国犹太人称为 “臭名昭著的法令” 的支持，而福尔塔多恰恰是来自波尔多的主要塞法迪人和前吉伦丁人。该法令于 1808 年 3 月 17 日颁布，规定犹太人提供的所有年利率超过 10% 的贷款或向未成年人、妇女和士兵发放的贷款均为无效。国家对希望从事商业活动的犹太人施加了进一步的限制：他们必须获得特别的许可证，这需要对他们的性格进行审查，并核实他们以前没有从事过高利贷活动。这些措施，加上对犹太人公民权利的其他限制，只适用于阿尔萨斯和洛林的犹太人，规定持续十年，其目的不仅是改变社会经济状况，而且是改变这个新解放的群体的内在特征。法国西南部的犹太人没有受到这些羞辱性的限制，但他们的人数也比他们的阿什肯纳兹兄弟少得多，在法国人的想象中也没有那么大。

Once again, usury was the symbol of something bigger—namely, the suspicion that Jews might be unable to partake in civil and political society as fair players. Forced into (or assumed to occupy) an economic position from which they could take advantage of everyone else, Jews were regarded by most as unable to meet the demands of equality. The transformation of their legal status that occurred during the Revolution was enormous, but representations of Jews after emancipation continued to be predicated on a centuries-long discursive tradition. In the late Middle Ages, economic and religious infidelity were cited as reasons for excluding Jews not only from the urban patriciate that ruled commercially minded city-states, but also from the ideology of the common good more generally. In the newborn French nation-state, Jews’ usurious character was perceived as deriving from a lack of patriotism.

再一次，高利贷是更大的东西的象征，即怀疑犹太人可能无法作为公平的参与者参与公民和政治社会。犹太人被迫进入（或被认为占据）一种经济地位，在这种地位上他们可以占其他人的便宜，大多数人认为犹太人无法满足平等的要求。大革命期间发生的犹太人法律地位的转变是巨大的，但解放后对犹太人的描述仍然是以一个长达几个世纪的话语传统为前提的。在中世纪晚期，经济和宗教上的不忠被作为排除犹太人的理由，不仅是将他们排除在统治商业化城邦的城市贵族阶层之外，而且还将他们排除在更普遍的共同利益的意识形态之外。在新生的法国民族国家，犹太人的高利贷特征被认为是源于缺乏爱国主义。

The transition from a medieval to a modern conception of political belonging was gradual—and accompanied by changes in the meaning of the word “nation”—but it did not dispense with persistent fears of economic oligopolies and conspiracies. Among the reasons given by the six guilds of Paris for rejecting the membership of Jewish merchants in 1767, one turned to an alchemical metaphor: Jews were like particles of quicksilver, which run in all directions but ultimately always unite in one single block. Whereas French Catholic merchant houses operated as individual units in fair competition with one another, every single Jew, the Parisian merchants claimed, was inseparable from his larger “nation,” and therefore each one could destabilize “the harmony of political societies.”138 The same logic was articulated in new language after the Revolution. In 1810, even Grégoire accused the Jews of dis-loyalty to France: “The Jew has his eyes constantly turned toward Jerusalem, desiring only it for his patrie [motherland].”139 The charge that Jews constituted “a nation within the nation” became a leitmotif.140

从中世纪到现代的政治归属概念的转变是渐进的，并伴随着 “民族” 一词含义的变化，但它并没有消除对经济寡头垄断和阴谋的持续恐惧。1767 年，巴黎的六个行会，在拒绝犹太商人加入的理由中，有一条是关于炼金术的比喻。犹太人就像流星银的颗粒，它们向四面八方奔跑，但最终总是团结在一块。巴黎商人声称，法国的天主教商行作为独立的单位，在彼此之间进行公平竞争，而每一个犹太人都与他更大的 “民族” 密不可分，因此每个人都可能破坏 “政治社会的和谐”。138同样的逻辑在大革命后被用新的语言表述出来。1810 年，甚至格雷瓜尔也指责犹太人对法国不忠诚。“犹太人的眼睛一直盯着耶路撒冷，只希望它是他的祖国”。139犹太人构成 “国中之国” 的指控成为一个主题词。140

By following the winding paths of the legend of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange across eighteenth-century France, I have revisited key moments in the history of the Enlightenment and the Revolution. In contrast to the tendency of most histories of economic thought to slice up the eighteenth century into discrete, if sometimes temporally overlapping, doctrines, ranging from the anticommercial stand of Fénelon’s classical republicanism to the physiocrats’ call for the liberalization of trade and manufacture and for the primacy of agriculture over public and private credit, I have stressed the extent to which the legend traversed such partitions. Its malleability allowed it to serve multiple purposes. Montesquieu appropriated it in order to develop a critique of despotism and religious intolerance that hinged on an exaggerated image of Jewish commercial ingenuity. Later in the century, Grégoire evoked it to reinforce a historical connection between Jews and rapacious moneylending that at times veered toward essentialism.

通过沿着犹太人发明汇票的传说在十八世纪法国的曲折道路，我重新审视了启蒙运动和大革命历史上的关键时刻。大多数经济思想史都倾向于将十八世纪切割成独立的、有时甚至是时间上重叠的学说，从费内隆的古典共和主义的反商业立场到生理学家呼吁贸易和制造业自由化以及农业对公共和私人信贷的首要地位，与此相反，我强调了这个传说穿越这些分区的程度。它的可塑性使它可以为多种目的服务。孟德斯鸠利用它来发展对专制主义和宗教不容忍的批判，这种批判依赖于犹太人商业智慧的夸张形象。在本世纪晚些时候，格雷瓜尔用它来加强犹太人和贪婪的放贷之间的历史联系，这种联系有时会偏向于本质主义。

It is not a coincidence that Montesquieu wrote in Bordeaux and Grégoire in Lorraine, but the trajectory of the legend that identified Jews as the originators of modern European financial instruments suggests something deeper. The revolutionary promise of equality carried with it the prospect of a fully realized society of contract, in which credit markets would shed their religious and corporatist biases in favor of anonymous competition. Equality and anonymity in turn carried with them new risks: How could one discern which economic actors were reputable and which duplicitous in an impersonal market? As emancipation promised to eliminate every last vestige of formal discrimination against Jewish economic actors, Cleirac’s concerns from a century and a half earlier about the inability to detect fraud in the new paper economy regained purchase. At the dawn of the democratic age, emancipation was an indisputable achievement, yet the backlashes it generated echoed older responses. Christian abhorrence for crypto-Judaism resurfaced in new guises. The demand for one form of regeneration, the economic, replaced the original religious concept of spiritual rebirth. Even more important, citizenship replaced baptism as the requisite rite of passage but remained equally unpersuasive in dispelling Christian mistrust of the newly emancipated Jews. Equality at once expanded the boundaries of commercial society and rendered Jews more and more indistinguishable from all other citizens. Once again, Jews’ invisibility intensified fears of contamination, and their perceived ubiquity continued to serve as a metaphor for the perils lurking behind ever more complex financial markets.

孟德斯鸠在波尔多写作，格雷瓜尔在洛林写作，这不是一个巧合，但认定犹太人是现代欧洲金融工具的创始人的传说的轨迹表明了更深层次的东西。平等的革命承诺带来了一个完全实现的契约社会的前景，在这个社会中，信贷市场将摆脱其宗教和公司主义的偏见，支持匿名的竞争。平等和匿名性反过来又带来了新的风险。在一个非个人化的市场中，人们如何辨别哪些经济行为者是有信誉的，哪些是两面派的？随着解放承诺消除对犹太经济行为者的最后一点正式歧视，克莱拉克一个半世纪前关于在新的纸面经济中无法发现欺诈行为的担忧重新得到了重视。在民主时代来临之际，解放是一项无可争议的成就，但它所产生的反击却与以前的反应相呼应。基督教对隐蔽的犹太教的憎恶以新的面目重新出现。对一种再生形式的要求，即经济上的再生，取代了原来宗教上的精神重生概念。更重要的是，公民权取代了洗礼，成为必要的通过仪式，但在消除基督教对新解放的犹太人的不信任方面同样缺乏说服力。平等同时扩大了商业社会的边界，并使犹太人越来越无法与所有其他公民区分开来。犹太人的隐蔽性再次加剧了人们对污染的恐惧，他们被认为无处不在，继续成为潜伏在越来越复杂的金融市场背后的危险的隐喻。

7

Distant Echoes

遥远的回声

THE REWORKING OF THE legend of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange by Montesquieu proved the most influential reinterpretation of Étienne Cleirac’s 1647 narrative and injected new life into the tale. The fact that the same narrative of Jewish ingenuity could radiate diverse, even contradictory, meanings is one of the reasons why it traveled so far and retained its power for so long. In the pages that follow, I analyze the legend’s echoes beyond France up to 1800 and how they intersected with a variety of discourses about the morality of commercial credit. For the sake of clarity, the chapter is organized by politico-linguistic regions, although intellectuals and state administrators in eighteenth-century Europe borrowed ideas from one another and crossed borders more easily than they would after the advent of the nation-state. I organize the traces left by the legend across Europe by the regions in which it appeared in print in order of frequency: England/Britain, the Holy Roman Empire, the Italian and Iberian peninsulas, and the United Provinces.1 A final section examines the first published appropriation of the legend by an Anglo-Jewish author.

孟德斯鸠对犹太人发明汇票的传说的重塑，证明了对艾蒂安·克莱拉克 1647 年叙述的最有影响力的重新解释，并为这个故事注入了新的活力。同一个关于犹太人智慧的叙述可以散发出不同的、甚至是矛盾的含义，这也是它走得如此之远并长期保持其力量的原因之一。在接下来的篇幅中，我分析了这个传说在 1800 年之前在法国以外的回响，以及它们如何与关于商业信贷道德的各种话语交织在一起。为清晰起见，本章按政治语言区域组织，尽管十八世纪欧洲的知识分子和国家行政人员相互借用思想，比民族国家出现后更容易跨越国界。我将传说在欧洲各地留下的痕迹按其出现在印刷品中的地区按频率排列。英格兰/英国、神圣罗马帝国、意大利和伊比利亚半岛，以及联合省。1最后一节研究了英国犹太作家首次发表的对该传说的挪用。

By using the legend as my Ariadne’s thread across the Continent and beyond the Channel, my purpose is neither to compile an exhaustive list of all authors who discussed the idea that Jews invented marine insurance or bills of exchange nor to force those authors into preestablished schools of thought. Rather, I wish to tackle the three broad issues that I outlined in the introduction: the definition of a canon, the relationship between images and practices, and the continuities and changes in Christian representations of Jewish commerce. Along which routes did the tale of the Jewish invention of Europe’s financial instruments travel beyond France, and how did it acquire local purchase? And what does the legend tell us about the persistence of discursive traditions that associated Jews and money and the ways in which those traditions intersected with or skirted specific polemics about the status of commerce in the social and political order? As we progress into the eighteenth century, we also need to address an additional topic: changing scholarly procedures of verification. Did the least plausible aspects of the legend set in motion the process of formulating new standards of proof, or did they remain impermeable to them?

通过把这个传说作为我的阿里阿德涅穿越欧洲大陆和英吉利海峡的线索，我的目的既不是要编制一份讨论犹太人发明了海事保险或汇票这一观点的所有作者的详尽清单，也不是要把这些作者强行纳入预先确立的思想流派。相反，我希望解决我在导言中概述的三个广泛问题：典籍的定义、图像和实践之间的关系，以及基督教对犹太商业表述的连续性和变化。犹太人发明欧洲金融工具的故事是沿着哪条路线传到法国以外的地方的，以及它是如何在当地被购买的？这个传说告诉我们，将犹太人和金钱联系在一起的话语，以及这些传统与商业在社会和政治秩序中的地位的具体争论相交错或回避的方式是什么？随着我们进入 18 世纪，我们还需要解决一个额外的问题：不断变化的学术验证程序。传说中最不靠谱的方面是启动了制定新的证明标准的过程，还是仍然无法渗透到其中？

As noted before, statistics are not adequate tools with which to answer these questions. Even if we wanted to verify the incidence of the legend in quantitative terms, a comprehensive bibliography of all European books only exists for the period before 1600, rendering it nearly impossible to calculate the frequency of words, passages, or even titles in the material printed during the two centuries that followed.2 Nor does a capacious and clearly demarcated corpus exist against which to measure the legend’s recurrence within all works dealing with the economy writ large.3 The higher incidence of references to the alleged Jewish invention of marine insurance and bills of exchange that can be seen in English works might be related to the output of English-language printed media, which we can reasonably assume to have been higher than that of Portugal, for example, or to the likely overrepresentation of English-language material in the rare book collections currently available online. Only further expansion of these collections will permit us to test some of the arguments I present in this chapter.

如前所述，统计数据并不是回答这些问题的适当工具。即使我们想从数量上验证该传说的发生率，也只存在 1600 年之前的欧洲所有书籍的综合书目，这使得我们几乎不可能计算出随后两个世纪中印刷的材料中的单词、段落甚至标题的频率。2也不存在一个容量大、分工明确的语料库，以衡量该传说在所有涉及经济的作品中的重复出现。3在英语作品中可以看到关于所谓的犹太人发明海事保险和汇票的提及率较高，这可能与英语印刷媒体的产量有关，我们可以合理地假设其产量高于葡萄牙的产量，或者与英语材料在目前在线提供的珍稀书籍收藏中可能占比过大有关。只有进一步扩大这些藏书才能让我们检验我在本章中提出的一些论点。

One point is indisputable: it would be misleading to focus only on canonical works. Savary and Montesquieu were exceptional amplifiers of the legend, but genres during this period were by definition blurred, and now-forgotten texts such as Cleirac’s Us et coustumes de la mer continued to be read widely. During the eighteenth century, accounts of the origins of bills of exchange and marine insurance figured in an increasingly wide spectrum of works, ranging from merchant handbooks to treatises like The Spirit of the Laws , encyclopedias, legal commentaries, novels, and more.4 Moreover, it was primarily in lesser-known publications that the legend’s credibility was scrutinized and challenged. And because even works that sought to debunk the legend indirectly propagated it, appendix 6 lists all printed works that mentioned the legend regardless of whether they endorsed it or not. Appendix 6, however, cannot do justice to the myriad ways in which the legend was rewritten or the varied discursive contexts in which it was embedded. That is the task of this chapter.

有一点是毋庸置疑的：只关注正统作品是一种误导。萨瓦里和孟德斯鸠是传奇的特殊传播者，但这一时期的流派从定义上来说是模糊的，现在已经被遗忘的文本，如克莱拉克的《海洋的用途和习俗》继续被广泛阅读。在 18 世纪，汇票和海事保险的起源在越来越多的作品中出现，从商人手册到《法律的精神》等论文，以及百科全书、法律评论、小说等等。4此外，主要是在不太知名的出版物中，传说的可信度受到了审查和挑战。由于即使是试图揭穿该传说的作品也间接地宣传了该传说，因此附录 6 列出了所有提到该传说的印刷品，无论它们是否赞同该传说。然而，附录 6 无法公正地说明传说被改写的无数方式，也无法说明它所处的各种话语背景。这就是本章的任务。

As I have done with regard to France, I scan the broader environment of the legend’s reception. Multiple factors affected its dissemination, standing, and reworking, including authorial credibility, the effects of serial publication and intertextual transmission, the local politics of commerce and finance, and reform projects aiming to improve the conditions of Jewish life. Given the vastness of the terrain I cover, my analysis is more cursory than it has been in the previous chapters. It nonetheless yields several important findings that challenge received wisdom about how both real and imaginary Jews figured in the making of European commercial society.

正如我对法国所做的那样，我扫描了该传说的更广泛的接受环境。多种因素影响了它的传播、地位、和再创作，包括作者的可信度、连续出版和文本间传播的影响、当地的商业和金融政治，以及旨在改善犹太人生活条件的改革项目。鉴于我所涉及的领域非常广泛，我的分析比前几章更加粗略。然而，它产生了几个重要的发现，对关于现实和想象中的犹太人如何参与欧洲商业社会的形成的公认智慧提出了挑战。

First, the legend that pointed to Jews as the creators of European private finance did not travel along confessional lines. Developed in Catholic France, the legend also appeared in England, the Reformed areas of the Holy Roman Empire, and the United Provinces. The Catholic–Protestant divide, to which scholars of Western capitalism have attributed great significance, turns out not to be a pertinent axis along which to organize our inquiry. Second, although they were shaped by an arsenal of Christian representations of Jews that traversed periods and cultures, public debates about Jews’ economic credibility were more intense where cultural acceptance of the merchant profession and the place of commerce and finance in national politics was most contentious. This explains why we detect the lowest incidence of the legend in both the most and the least tolerant areas of Europe: the United Provinces and the Iberian peninsula, respectively. These were also the two regions where commerce enjoyed the highest and the lowest levels of legal and cultural recognition. As in France, then, elsewhere in Europe the legend conveyed the most elusive critiques of the evils of credit in those contexts where the expansion of credit was underway. Third, we cannot establish a simple correlation between the degree of a society’s commercialization and positive images of Jews. In England and the United Provinces, the emergence of the stock market (rather than bills of exchange) was the catalyst for an increase in hostile views toward Jews, who symbolized the dangers brought by financial speculation. It is thus not surprising that arguments about Jewish commercial prowess did not advance the cause of Jewish emancipation in these countries.

首先，指出犹太人是欧洲私人金融的创造者的传说并没有沿着宗教信仰的路线传播。这个传说在天主教法国发展起来，也出现在英国、神圣罗马帝国的改革地区和联合省。西方资本主义的学者们认为天主教与新教的分歧具有重大意义，但事实证明，这并不是组织我们调查的一个相关轴线。其次，尽管它们是由跨越时期和文化的基督教对犹太人的描述形成的，但在对商人职业的文化接受以及商业和金融在国家政治中的地位争议最大的地方，关于犹太人的经济信誉的公开辩论更为激烈。这就解释了为什么我们在欧洲最宽容的地区和最不宽容的地区都发现了该传说的最低发生率：联合省和伊比利亚半岛，分别。这也是商业享有最高和最低的法律和文化认可度的两个地区。因此，与法国一样，在欧洲其他地方，在那些正在进行信贷扩张的背景下，该传说对信贷的恶行进行了最难以捉摸的批评。第三，我们不能在一个社会的商业化程度和犹太人的正面形象之间建立一种简单的关联。在英格兰和联合省，股票市场（而不是汇票）的出现是对犹太人的敌视增加的催化剂，犹太人象征着金融投机带来的危险。因此，关于犹太人商业能力的争论并没有推动这些国家的犹太人解放事业，这一点并不令人惊讶。

A lag of more than fifty years separates the legend’s appearance in French and its circulation in other languages, in part because of the time it took for the translation of Savary’s Le parfait négociant to permeate the foreign commercial literature. Translations of works by the Savary family and Montesquieu were the legend’s most influential vehicles of diffusion and transmutation. Most non-French versions of the legend, however, adapted the tale to make it palatable to new readerships. Montesquieu’s status certainly contributed to the legend’s credibility in the eighteenth century. At the same time, an increasing number of writers challenged the legend’s accuracy. They did so from an array of perspectives. Some simply picked up on earlier doubts about its logic. More deployed new evidentiary tools, including source criticism, to dispute the legend’s historical veracity and debunk its assertions. Others continued to believe that particular merchant communities were responsible for world-changing innovations but disputed the idea that the invention of marine insurance or bills of exchange should be attributed specifically to Jews.

这个传说在法语中的出现和在其他语言中的流传相隔了 50 多年，部分原因是萨瓦里的《完美的交易员》（Le parfait négociant）的翻译需要时间来渗透到外国商业文献中。萨瓦里家族和孟德斯鸠的作品的翻译是该传说最具影响力的传播和转化载体。然而，大多数非法国版本的传说都对故事进行了改编，以使其能被新的读者群接受。孟德斯鸠的地位当然有助于提高该传说在 18 世纪的可信度。与此同时，越来越多的作家，对该传说的准确性提出质疑。他们从不同的角度提出了质疑。一些人只是简单地继承了先前对其逻辑的怀疑。更多的人使用了新的证据工具，包括来源批评，来质疑该传说的历史真实性，并驳斥其主张。另一些人继续相信特定的商人群体对改变世界的创新负有责任，但对海事保险或汇票的发明应特别归功于犹太人的观点提出异议。

The legend’s reception thus provides a lens through which to analyze the impact of changing scholarly practices in the age of colossal encyclopedic projects, world histories of commerce, and renewed interest in studying Roman law. It also demonstrates how, as it traveled to different parts of Europe during the eighteenth century, the legend was absorbed into emerging proto-nationalist discourses. Many Italian authors insisted that Florentines rather than Jews had been the first to devise bills of exchange and to propel Europe’s commercial expansion, just as the glorious voyages undertaken by famous explorers and pathfinders had. Certain English and German authors also argued for alternative historical trajectories, although they could not attribute the invention to their ancestors as easily. In Germany during the latter part of the eighteenth century, the reworking of the legend even stimulated the emergence of a new and influential narrative about the economic function of Jews. According to this narrative, Christian resentment of Jews’ alleged domination of commerce spurred Europe’s late medieval economic growth by encouraging Christian merchants to take control of the financial innovations that Jews had presumably devised and, until then, monopolized. By the last quarter of the nineteenth century, this narrative had become a pillar of some of the most influential academic accounts of European economic history (chapter 8 ).

因此，该传说的接受提供了一个镜头，通过它可以分析在巨大的百科全书项目、世界商业史以及对研究罗马法的新兴趣时代不断变化的学术实践的影响。它还表明，在 18 世纪，当它被带到欧洲不同地区时，这个传说是如何被吸收到新兴的原民族主义话语中的。许多意大利作家坚持认为，佛罗伦萨人而不是犹太人是第一个设计汇票并推动欧洲商业扩张的人，就像著名的探险家和探路者所进行的光荣的航行一样。某些英国和德国的作者也认为有其他的历史轨迹，尽管他们不能轻易将发明归于他们的祖先。在 18 世纪后半期的德国，对这一传说的改编甚至刺激了一种关于犹太人的经济功能的新的、有影响力的叙述的出现。根据这种说法，基督徒对犹太人所谓的商业统治的怨恨刺激了欧洲中世纪晚期的经济增长，鼓励基督徒商人控制犹太人可能设计的金融创新，并在那之前垄断了这些创新。到了十九世纪的最后一个季度，这种说法已经成为一些最有影响力的欧洲经济史学术报告的支柱（第 8 章）。

For all of these reasons, the reception of the legend of the Jewish invention of marine insurance and bills of exchange anticipates some and even constitutes one of the most important developments in European economic thought up through the nineteenth century. Though my focus is necessarily on Christian images of Jews, I also discuss a few Jewish authors at the end of the chapter in order to assess their reaction to Christian presumptions about Jews’ ostensible commercial dexterity. One author in particular, Isaac D’Israeli (1766–1848), stands out not only because he was the first Jewish writer to mention the legend in print but also because, borrowing from Montesquieu, he endorsed it emphatically. How to explain D’Israeli? Admittedly, few Jewish authors wrote in vernacular about economic matters during the early modern period. But a body of Jewish apologetic writings did stress Jews’ economic talents (to the point of exaggeration) in order to secure more favorable treatment from Christian rulers interested in expanding their commercial reach (chapter 5 ). Had the legend primarily carried the positive meaning that Montesquieu attributed to it, Jewish authors, I suspect, would have evoked it in their pleas to secular authorities. Yet they did not. As we examine the first, hesitant introduction of the legend to Jewish self-representations at the end of the eighteenth century, we also need to interrogate this silence.

由于所有这些原因，对犹太人发明海事保险和汇票的传说的接受预示着一些，甚至构成了直到 19 世纪欧洲经济思想中最重要的发展之一。尽管我的重点必然是基督教的犹太人形象，但我也在本章末尾讨论了几位犹太作家，以评估他们对基督教关于犹太人表面上的商业灵巧的假设的反应。特别是一位作家艾萨克·德伊斯雷尔（Isaac D‘Israel，1766-1848），他之所以引人注目，不仅是因为他是第一个在印刷品中提到这一传说的犹太作家，而且还因为他借用孟德斯鸠的说法，强调赞同这一传说。如何解释德伊斯雷尔？诚然，在现代早期，很少有犹太作家用白话文写经济问题。但有一批犹太人的辩解文章确实强调了犹太人的经济 （甚至夸大其词），以便从有意扩大商业范围的基督教统治者那里获得更有利的待遇（第五章）。如果这个传说主要具有孟德斯鸠赋予它的积极意义，那么我猜想，犹太作者会在向世俗当局的请求中援引它。但他们没有这样做。当我们研究 18 世纪末犹太人自我介绍中第一次犹豫不决地引入该传说时，我们也需要对这种沉默进行审视。

England/Britain

英格兰/英国

If we exclude the translations of Savary’s Le parfait négociant into German (1676) and Dutch (1683), to which I will return, England (Great Britain after 1707) is the European country outside of France where we find the earliest mentions of the legend of the medieval Jewish invention of marine insurance and bills of exchange. There, the legend joined a variety of allegorical mentions of Jews that functioned as vehicles of expression for anxieties about the morality of private and public credit.

如果我们不把萨瓦里的《完美的交易员》翻译成德语（1676）和荷兰语（1683）（我将回到这里），英国（1707 年之后的英国）是法国之外的欧洲国家，在那里我们发现了最早的关于中世纪犹太人发明海事保险和汇票的传说。在那里，这个传说加入了对犹太人的各种寓言式的提及，这些寓言式的提及作为表达对私人和公共信贷道德的焦虑的载体。

If credit permeated all strata of English society even more than in France, the institutions that promoted and regulated it were considerably different from their French counterparts. Lower courts offered cheap remedies to litigants seeking to settle small debts. At the opposite end of the credit market, after 1613, the East India Company used equity rather than debt to finance its operations, issuing shares of its stock and paying dividends periodically. During the second half of the seventeenth century, a private and public securities market flourished, and the financial revolution of 1688–1694 joined the interests of the state and individual investors as never before in European history. In London, the number of individuals who owned and traded companies’ shares increased fivefold between the 1690s and the 1720s.5 The legal and cultural barriers to the nobility’s involvement in commerce and finance were considerably lower in England than in France. The status of Jews in these countries was also remarkably different. After the 1656 tacit readmission, the Jewish community in England evolved from a tiny Iberian New Christian presence to a growing and economically polarized group. As a result of these intersecting trends, in eighteenth-century England “Jewishness” assumed connotations that were not present in France, including the association of Jews with the stock market rather than with bills of exchange.6

如果说信用比法国更多地渗透到英国社会的各个阶层，那么促进和规范信用的机构则与法国的同类机构有很大不同。下级法院为寻求解决小额债务的诉讼人提供廉价的补救措施。在信贷市场的另一端，1613 年后，东印度公司利用股权而非债务为其业务融资，发行股票并定期支付股息。在 17 世纪下半叶，私人和公共证券市场蓬勃发展，1688-1694 年的金融革命将国家和个人投资者的利益结合起来，这在欧洲历史上前所未有。在伦敦，从 1690 年代到 1720 年代，拥有和交易公司股票的个人数量增加了五倍。5在英国，贵族参与商业和金融活动的法律和文化障碍比法国低得多。犹太人在这些国家的地位也有明显的不同。在 1656 年默许重新接纳之后，英国的犹太社区从一个小小的伊比利亚新基督教存在演变为一个不断增长和经济上两极分化的群体。由于这些交叉的趋势，在 18 世纪的英国，“犹太人” 具有法国所没有的内涵，包括将犹太人与股票市场而不是汇票联系起来。6

Post-Reformation England regulated usury in ways not dissimilar from those found in Catholic France: in 1571 annual interest rates of up to 10 percent were permitted on mortgages, a ceiling that by the early eighteenth century had declined to 5 percent.7 Meanwhile, the rampant need for credit during the sixteenth-century economic boom coincided with a shortage of minted coins. This situation was sometimes blamed on bills of exchange, which unsettled the balance of trade. In the short term, preoccupations about rapacious moneylending intensified. The discursive equation of usurers and Jews that we have examined at length was very much alive in Tudor and Stuart England. Francis Bacon opened his “Of Usury” (1625) by drawing on a trope we have encountered many times: “Usurers should have orange-tawney bonnets, because they do judaize.”8 As it had centuries earlier, the verb “to Judaize” singled out those who were construed as imitating Jews, rather than Jews themselves, and who therefore needed to wear a distinctive sign marking them apart from fair economic actors. Thomas Wilson’s A Discourse upon Usury (1572), a widely reprinted fictional dialogue about the merits and dangers of moneylending and credit, had relied on the same discursive equation of usurers and Jews. Wilson’s text, punctuated by religious sermons, was made up of opinionated exchanges between a merchant, two lawyers, and a preacher. In it, the latter (an “enemy to usurie”) rails against Jews’ penchant for usury in language reminiscent of Matthew Paris: all those Englishmen who “lende their money or their goods whatsoever for gain, I take them to be no better than Iewes.” One lawyer agrees with the preacher on this point: “No better do I call them [i.e., merchants] then Iewes, yea, worse than any infidel, that wittingly lvye by the onely gayne of their money.”9
