改革开放后的英格兰对高利贷的监管方式与天主教法国并无二致：1571 年允许抵押贷款的年利率高达 10%，，到 18 世纪初，这一上限已降至 5%。7同时，在 16 世纪的经济繁荣时期，对信贷的猖獗需求与铸币的短缺不谋而合。这种情况有时被归咎于汇票，它使贸易平衡发生了变化。在短期内，人们对贪婪的放贷的担忧加剧了。我们已经详细研究过的高利贷者和犹太人的话语等式，在都铎和斯图亚特时期的英国非常活跃。弗朗西斯·培根在他的 “高利贷”（1625）中，以我们已经多次遇到的一个特例作为开篇。“高利贷者应该有一顶橙色的帽子，因为他们在做犹太化。”8正如几个世纪前一样，“犹太化” 这个动词将那些被认为是模仿犹太人的人，而不是犹太人本身，因此他们需要戴上一个独特的标志，将他们与公平的经济行为者区分开来。托马斯·威尔逊的《高利贷论》（A Discourse upon Usury）（1572）是一篇广泛重印的关于放贷和信贷的优点和危险的虚构对话，它依靠的是对高利贷者和犹太人的同样的论述性等同。威尔逊的文本以宗教布道为点缀，由一个商人、两个律师和一个传教士之间的意见交流组成。其中，后者（一个 “高利贷的敌人”）用让人想起马修·帕里斯的语言抨击犹太人对高利贷的嗜好：所有那些 “为了利益而借钱或借物的英国人，我认为他们并不比犹太人好”。在这一点上，一位律师同意传教士的观点：“我称他们即商人比 Iewes 好不到哪里去，是的，比任何异教徒都差，他们故意以自己的钱财为代价进行诈骗。”9

After Lord Protector Oliver Cromwell quietly agreed to allow the practice of Judaism in London in 1656, Jews became a lived reality in England for the first time since the royal expulsion of 1290. The size of the Jewish community remained relatively small until the mid-eighteenth century, when refugees from central and eastern Europe arrived in large numbers and tested the cohesion of Anglo Jewry as well as its collective image. In England, the divide between Sephardim and Ashkenazim was no less pronounced than in France, but unlike in France, it did not correspond to an equivalent degree of geographical segregation. Most Jews lived in London. Sephardim counted among themselves few wealthy traders, financiers, and army suppliers, but those who reached that level of economic success were highly visible. Most Ashkenazic Jews, by contrast, were poor, sometimes extremely so, and regarded as petty criminals. Evidence from the historical insurance market gives us a measure of their bad repute. In 1786, after a fire destroyed the house of some people referred to as “the lower Order of Jews,” the surveyors reported back to the underwriters that “from every appearance of the persons and inhabitations of many of the claimants, they had the greatest reason to suspect their accounts to be false and fraudulent.”10 The insinuation was that members of “the lower Order of Jews” had likely set fire to the house themselves in order to cash in on the rewards. We have no way of determining whether the allegation was true. The point is rather that the lack of credibility associated with Jews (or at least Ashkenazim) not only served as an ethical yardstick against which to judge everyone’s behavior but could also have a tangible effect on Jews’ daily lives.

在护国公奥利弗·克伦威尔（Oliver Cromwell）于 1656 年悄悄同意允许在伦敦从事犹太教活动后，犹太人自 1290 年皇家驱逐以来首次成为英格兰的生活现实。犹太人社区的规模一直相对较小，直到 18 世纪中期，来自中欧和东欧的难民大量涌入，考验着英国犹太人的凝聚力及其集体形象。在英国，塞法尔迪人和阿什肯纳兹人之间的分歧并不亚于法国，但与法国不同的是，这种分歧并不对应于同等程度的地理隔离。大多数犹太人居住在伦敦。塞法尔迪人中有少数富有的商人、金融家和军队供应商，但那些达到这种经济成功水平的人非常引人注目。相比之下，大多数阿什肯纳兹的犹太人都很穷，有时甚至非常穷，并被视为小罪犯。历史上保险市场的证据给了我们一个衡量他们坏名声的标准。1786 年，在一场大火烧毁了一些被称为 “下层犹太人” 的房屋后，调查员向承保人报告说，“从许多索赔人的个人和居住地的每一个外观来看，他们有最大的理由怀疑他们的账户是虚假和欺诈性的。”10暗示 “下层犹太人” 的成员可能自己放火烧了房子，以兑现奖励。我们没有办法确定这一指控是否属实。关键是，与犹太人（或至少是阿什肯纳兹人）相关的信誉缺失不仅是判断每个人行为的道德标准，而且还可能对犹太人的日常生活产生切实的影响。

For all the enthusiasm that surrounded the rapid commercialization of seventeenth-and eighteenth-century England, an equally profound awareness existed that, as Julian Hoppit puts it, “credit had negative as well as positive features,” and not all of those features were easily measurable.11 Concerns about the potentially destructive consequences of reckless speculation, the moral corruption generated by excessive spending, and the devious motives of those who pumped cash into the pockets of needy borrowers accompanied the expansion of private, public, and corporate credit.

对于围绕着十七和十八世纪英国快速商业化的所有热情，人们同样深刻地认识到，正如朱利安·霍皮特所说，“信贷有消极和积极的特点”，而且并非所有这些特点都是容易衡量的。11伴随着私人、公共和公司信贷的扩张，人们对不计后果的投机、过度消费产生的道德败坏以及那些将现金注入贫困借款人口袋的人的邪恶动机表示担忧。

Literary scholars have detected a pronounced gender bias in the language with which these concerns were expressed, exemplified by Daniel Defoe’s “Lady Credit,” who personified the flimsy, irrational, and improper character of Britain’s booming financial speculation.12 However, these scholars have rarely looked at literary figures of Jews alongside those of women in English representations of credit. In London and other cities, credit and its discontents were the talk of the town. Surveying the polemical and practical literature on credit between 1680 and the 1790s, Hoppit corrects the progressive perspective that places Adam Smith at the apex of a long-term transformation of English (later British) social and economic thought and concludes that most ordinary commentaries on credit throughout the period were informed “by ideas that were more often backward than forward looking.”13 Among these backward-looking ideas he notes the association of Jews with pawnbroking, an association that inflated Jewish involvement in that activity at the time but served as a criticism of financial extortion conducted by well-known political figures.14

文学学者在表达这些关切的语言中发现了明显的性别偏见，丹尼尔·笛福的 “信贷夫人” 就是一个例子，她将英国蓬勃发展的金融投机活动的脆弱、非理性和不正当的特点表现得淋漓尽致。12然而，这些学者很少将犹太人的文学形象与英国人对信贷的表述中的妇女形象放在一起研究。在伦敦和其他城市，信贷和它的不满情绪是全城的话题。霍皮特调查了 1680 年至 1790 年代之间关于信用的论战和实践文献，纠正了将亚当·斯密置于英国（后来的英国）社会和经济思想长期转型的顶点的进步观点，并得出结论，整个时期关于信用的大多数普通评论 “更多的是由向后看而不是向前看的想法” 提供。13在这些落后的思想中，他注意到犹太人与典当业的联系，这种联系在当时夸大了犹太人对该活动的参与，但却成为对知名政治人物进行金融勒索的批评。14

Legislation to regulate financial markets, and stockbrokers in particular, was proposed numerous times during the eighteenth century but dismissed in the interest of protecting the fiscal needs of the state.15 This legislative vacuum opened the door for symbolic regulatory tools: out-groups such as Huguenots, Jews, and the Dutch, who populated but did not dominate the London financial market, were constructed as personifications of oligopoly and deceit. Trapped in a half-real and half-imaginary medieval past, the figure of the Jewish usurer continued to exert considerable influence in early modern England, as it did in France. Invoking this figure allowed one to draw the moral line between merchants contributing to the common good and those seeking to enrich themselves at all costs.

十八世纪，人们曾多次提出立法监管金融市场，特别是股票经纪人，但由于要保护国家的财政需求而被驳回。15这种立法真空为象征性的监管工具打开了大门：胡格诺派教徒、犹太人和荷兰人等外在群体，他们在伦敦金融市场上居住，但并不占主导地位，他们被构建为寡头垄断和欺骗的化身。犹太高利贷者的形象被困在半真实半想象的中世纪过去，在现代早期的英国继续发挥着巨大的影响力，就像在法国那样。援引这个人物，人们可以在为公共利益做出贡献的商人和那些不惜一切代价为自己谋利的商人之间划定道德界限。

Meanwhile, a new theme marked the conversion of the Jewish pawnbroker into the Jewish financier in England: the association of the latter with trading in stocks rather than in bills of exchange. Amid the thousands of pages Defoe wrote on commerce, he spoke sparingly of Jews, but when he did, it was primarily to denounce them as the epitome of unrestrained speculation.16 His depiction of Exchange Alley, the area of narrow streets and coffeehouses where brokers who had been expelled from the Royal Exchange traded in stocks, centered on the repellent character of Jewish dealers: “The Alley throngs with Jews, Jobbers and Brokers, their names are needless, their Characters dirty as their employment, and the best thing that I can yet find out to say of them, is, that there happens to be two honest Men among them.”17

同时，在英国，一个新的主题标志着犹太典当商向犹太金融家的转变：后者与股票交易而非汇票交易的联系。在笛福写的数千页关于商业的文章中，他很少提到犹太人，但当他提到时，主要是谴责他们是无节制投机的缩影。16他对交易所小巷的描述，即那些被皇家交易所驱逐出来的经纪人在那里进行股票交易的狭窄街道和咖啡馆，集中体现了犹太交易员的令人厌恶的特点。“巷子里挤满了犹太人、职业者和经纪人，他们的名字没有必要，他们的性格和他们的职业一样肮脏，而我能找到的对他们最好的评价是，他们中恰好有两个诚实的人。”17

The collapse of the speculative frenzy known as the South Sea Bubble in 1720 brought to the surface thinly veiled resentments against Jews, which, as we will see, had already emerged in the United Provinces after the Amsterdam stock market took a sudden plunge in 1688.18 In times of exuberant speculation, exaltation of the virtues of commerce often gave way to conservative critiques: opportunists tricked naïve investors, gambled on the fictional value of paper instruments, and endangered the well-being of the country for the sole purpose of advancing their station. Theatrical representations satirized the promise of social mobility that credit offered and often resorted to Jewish characters to do so.19 Many of these critiques had clear political connotations. As Jonathan Karp has noted, the Tory Party—the defender of landed interests and values—turned the figure of the Jewish “stockjobber” (a term heavily used in the public sphere after 1720) into a weapon of propaganda against Whig campaigns in favor of expanding overseas trade and the power of the Bank of England.20

1720 年被称为 “南海泡沫” 的投机狂潮的崩溃使人们对犹太人的怨恨浮出水面，正如我们将看到的那样，在 1688 年阿姆斯特丹股票市场突然暴跌之后，这种怨恨已经在联合省出现了。18在投机盛行的时代，对商业美德的赞美往往让位于保守的批评：机会主义者欺骗了天真的投资者，在纸质工具的虚构价值上赌博，并且仅仅为了提高自己的地位而危害国家的福祉。戏剧表现讽刺了信贷所提供的社会流动的承诺，并经常借助于犹太人的角色来做到这一点。19这些批评中有许多具有明显的政治内涵。正如乔纳森·卡普所指出的，托利党 —— 土地利益和价值观的捍卫者 —— 将犹太 “股票经纪人”（1720 年后在公共领域大量使用的术语）的形象变成了反对辉格党扩大海外贸易和英格兰银行权力的宣传武器。20

Lord Bolingbroke and his Tory supporters were the most vocal but not the only detractors of the paper economy. David Hume, like Montesquieu, famously despised the public debt more than private credit.21 Adam Smith, who had witnessed the effects of the Panic of 1772 in Scotland, described in detail the advantages of banknotes and bills of exchange but also warned about the risks brought by the “excessive circulation of paper money,” that is, the imbalance between banknotes and bills of exchange in circulation and a country’s bullion reserves. In condemning such excesses, Smith invoked Greek mythology rather than anti-Jewish clichés, contrasting “the Dædalian wings of paper money” with “the solid ground of gold and silver.”22 Those who espoused the anticommercial ethos of classical republicanism were more likely to borrow from the stockpile of anti-Jewish rhetoric. Writing from London in 1786, John Adams urged Thomas Jefferson to strengthen Congress’ control over public finance. His outsized fear that European speculators might bring the United States to its knees found expression in terms that we have come to recognize: “Jews and Judaizing Christians are now scheming to buy up all our continental notes at two or three shillings in the pound, in order to oblige us to pay them at twenty shillings. This will be richer plunder than that of Algerines, or Lloyd’s coffee houses.”23 Here, as in other instances, the boundaries between private and public credit were blurred.

波林布鲁克勋爵和他的托利党支持者是最有发言权的，但不是唯一的纸币经济的反对者。大卫·休谟和孟德斯鸠一样，对公共债务的鄙视比对私人信贷的鄙视更为著名。21亚当·斯密见证了 1772 年苏格兰恐慌的影响，他详细描述了纸币和汇票的优势，但也警告了 “纸币过度流通” 带来的风险，即流通中的纸币和汇票与一个国家的金银储备之间的不平衡。在谴责这种过度流通时，斯密引用了希腊神话而不是反犹太人的陈词滥调，将 “纸币的达达利之翼” 与 “金银的坚实地面” 进行对比。22那些拥护古典共和主义的反商业精神的人更有可能从反犹太主义的修辞库中借用。1786 年，约翰·亚当斯从伦敦写信，敦促托马斯·杰斐逊加强国会对公共财政的控制。他对欧洲投机者可能使美国屈服的过度恐惧，以我们已经认识到的术语表达出来。“犹太人和犹太化的基督徒现在正密谋以每磅 2 或 3 先令的价格购买我们所有的大陆纸币，以迫使我们以 20 先令的价格支付它们。这将是比阿尔及利亚人或劳埃德咖啡馆更丰富的掠夺。”23在这里，就像在其他情况下一样，私人和公共信贷之间的界限是模糊的。

In England as in France, metaphorical invocations of Jews not only greatly exaggerated Jews’ economic roles but also obscured real differences within Jewish society, and especially the gulf that separated affluent from impoverished Jews. The “Jew” in these narratives was either a treacherous money-lender or a masterful bond manipulator, both of which were seen as varieties of usurers. It was arguably with these images in mind that readers made sense of the references to the medieval Jewish invention of bills of exchange they encountered in English-language texts. Elizabethan literature, in which usury loomed large, did not attribute the invention of marine insurance or bills of exchange to Jews. Nor was the Jewish origin of these instruments mentioned in the earliest English treatises devoted solely to bills of exchange.24 Rather, more or less literal translations of the Savarys and Montesquieu were the primary sources of the tale across the Channel.25 The authority of these French texts and the ways in which translators adapted them thus proved decisive in shaping the legend’s reception. The writing of early modern merchant manuals and related works was not unlike that of encyclopedias: it relied on educated plagiarism. Some English merchant manuals translated Savary’s chapter on the origins of bills of exchange faithfully.26 Others produced imitations and pastiches that generated new twists in the legend.27 Still others omitted the tale altogether.28

在英国和法国，对犹太人的隐喻不仅极大地夸大了犹太人的经济作用，而且还掩盖了犹太社会内部的真正差异，特别是将富裕的犹太人和贫穷的犹太人分开的鸿沟。这些叙述中的 “犹太人” 要么是奸诈的放债人，要么是高超的债券操纵者，这两种人都被视为高利贷者的变种。可以说，读者正是考虑到了这些形象，才对他们在英语文本中遇到的关于中世纪犹太人发明汇票的提法产生了兴趣。伊丽莎白时期的文学作品中，高利贷的影子很大，但并没有把海事保险或汇票的发明归功于犹太人。在最早的专门讨论汇票的英国论文中也没有提到这些工具的犹太起源。24相反，萨瓦里（Savarys）和孟德斯鸠（Montesquieu）或多或少的字面翻译是海峡对岸的故事的主要来源。25因此，这些法国文本的权威性以及翻译者对其进行改编的方式在塑造该传说的接受度方面具有决定性作用。早期现代商人手册和相关作品的写作与百科全书的写作并无不同：它依赖于有教养的抄袭。一些英国商人手册忠实地翻译了萨瓦里关于汇票起源的章节。26另一些则是模仿和模仿，在传说中产生了新的转折点。27还有一些则完全省略了这个故事。28

The delayed blossoming of English dictionaries of trade made them less susceptible to tales of origins. By the mid-eighteenth century, the evolution of European commercial society from a barter system to one based on money and finally paper credit instruments such as bills of exchange was an accepted narrative, even if exactly how the latter had come into being remained the subject of much speculation. Wyndham Beawes’s Lex mercatoria rediviva , one of the most frequently reprinted English merchant manuals of the period, was agnostic about whether marine insurance had been invented by Roman emperor Claudius (as per Suetonius) or by French Jews in 1182 (as the Savarys claimed) but was certain that it had been brought into England “by some Italians from Lombardy, who at the same time came to settle at Antwerp” (the standard assumption to this day).29 With regard to bills of exchange, Beawes was equally torn, debating whether they had been invented by Jews banished from France under Philip Augustus and Philip the Tall or, “with a greater appearance of probability,” by the Florentine Ghibellines who sought refuge in Lyon.30

英国贸易词典的延迟开花，使它们不太容易受到起源故事的影响。到了 18 世纪中叶，欧洲商业社会从易货贸易体系演变为以货币为基础的体系，最后是以汇票等纸质信用工具为基础的体系，这是一个公认的说法，即使后者究竟是如何产生的，仍然是许多人猜测的 。温德姆·比韦斯（Wyndham Beawes）的《重述重商法》（Lex mercatoria rediviva），是当时最常重印的英国商人手册之一，对于海事保险是由罗马皇帝克劳狄斯（Claudius）发明的（按照 苏埃托尼乌斯 Suetonius 的说法）还是由法国犹太人在 1182 年发明的（按照萨瓦利斯 Savarys 的说法），他不置可否，但肯定的是它是由 “一些来自伦巴第的意大利人带入英国的，他们同时来到安特卫普定居”（直到今天的标准假设）。29关于汇票，比韦斯也同样纠结，他争论的是，汇票是被菲利普·奥古斯都和菲利普·高尔统治下的法国放逐的犹太人发明的，还是 “看起来更有可能” 由在里昂寻求庇护的佛罗伦萨吉贝里人发明的。30

The most authoritative and original engagement with the legend by a British author came from the pen of the prominent judge and jurist Sir William Blackstone (1723–1780). In his Commentaries on the Laws of England , he accepted the gist of the tale (that persecution had led to invention) but claimed a role for the English crown. The invention of bills of exchange, Blackstone wrote, occurred when Jews were “banished out of Guienne in 1297, and out of England in 1290.” At the time of the supposed events, the duchy of Guyenne was an English possession. By juxtaposing the two regions and the two dates, Blackstone sought to bring the story into an English domain and ensured that his account was incorporated into the Encyclopædia Britannica .31

英国作家对这一传说最权威、最新颖的论述来自著名法官和法学家威廉·布莱克斯通（William Blackstone）爵士（1723-1780）的笔下。在他的《英格兰法律评论》中，他接受了这个故事的要点（迫害导致了发明），但声称英国王室扮演了一个角色。布莱克斯通写道，汇票的发明发生在犹太人 “于 1297 年被驱逐出吉恩，于 1290 年被驱逐出英格兰” 的时候。在所谓的事件发生时，吉延公国是英国的属地。通过将这两个地区和两个日期并列，布莱克斯通试图将这个故事带入英国领域，并确保他的叙述被纳入《大英百科全书》。31

Overall, the legend met with considerable skepticism in England. One author qualified it as a product of French patriotism and declared it “extremely improbable.”32 The first comprehensive English treatment of marine insurance, published in 1787, relayed the versions given by both the Savarys and Montesquieu but concluded that the origin of marine insurance “is involved in so much obscurity” that no satisfactory explanation could be offered.33 Following unusual reasoning, another author described the development of bills of exchange as “a little uncertain” but ultimately backed the idea that Jews were their inventors, “because I have observed that, generally speaking, the Jews to this day practice this kind of commerce most, and understand it best of any people in the world.”34 This is the only instance I have encountered of an author invoking firsthand experience to maintain that Jews’ commercial conduct was consistent with the spirit of the legend and thus confirmed its veracity. Meanwhile, a translation of a German work at the close of the century introduced a new criterion for dismissing the legend: empirical verification. In 1690, Jacques Dupuis de la Serra had questioned the tale on account of its incoherence (chapter 5 ); now the legend was rejected because “no proof” supported it.35

总的来说，这个传说在英国受到了相当大的怀疑。一位作者将其定性为法国爱国主义的产物，并宣布其 “极其不可能”。（321787 年出版的英国第一部关于海事保险的全面论述，转述了萨瓦里夫妇和孟德斯鸠的版本，但得出结论说，海事保险的起源 “涉及到如此多的模糊之处”，无法提供令人满意的解释。33按照不寻常的推理，另一位作者将汇票的发展描述为 “有点不确定”，但最终支持犹太人是其发明者的观点，“因为我观察到，一般来说，犹太人到今天还在从事这种商业活动，而且是世界上任何民族中最了解这种商业的。34这是我遇到的唯一一个作者援引第一手经验来坚持认为犹太人的商业行为符合传说的精神，从而证实其真实性的例子。同时，在本世纪末，一部德国作品的译本引入了一个否定该传说的新标准：经验验证。1690 年，雅克·杜皮斯·德拉塞拉（Jacques Dupuis de la Serra）曾因其不连贯性而对该传说提出质疑第 5 章）；现在该传说被否定了，因为 “没有证据” 支持它。35

Only the followers of Montesquieu, fewer in Britain than on the Continent, clung to the positive depiction of Jews as having devised financial instruments able to undercut autocratic rulers and promote the flow of private credit. The translation of Montesquieu’s The Spirit of the Laws into English (1750) and the simultaneous publication of Beccaria’s A Discourse on Public Œconomy and Commerce (1769) in Italian, French, and English popularized the nexus between Jews’ persecution and their inventiveness, a connection that economic writer Thomas Mortimer (1730–1810) repeated without any shadow of a doubt.36 Montesquieu’s version of the legend was also echoed in several prefaces to technical works on bills of exchange, on which it conferred a historical veneer.37 But its real megaphone was Sir James Steuart (1713–1780), a Jacobite lord who lived in exile until 1763. Steuart’s treatise on political economy could not compete in originality with the economic writings of such giants of his time as Quesnay, Cantillon, Turgot, Hume, and Smith, but it is estimated that outside of Britain, through the 1780s, it was better known and more frequently cited than The Wealth of Nations .38 Steuart followed Montesquieu’s version of the legend closely, but he too added his own touches: while Montesquieu regarded bills of exchange as the preeminent credit instrument of private merchants who sought to escape the rapaciousness of despotic rulers, Steuart included the legend in a vigorous defense of public credit.39

只有孟德斯鸠的追随者（在英国比欧洲大陆少）坚持对犹太人的正面描述，认为他们设计了能够削弱专制统治者和促进私人信贷流动的金融工具。孟德斯鸠的《法律的精神》被翻译成英文（1750），贝卡里亚的《公共经济与商业论》（1769）同时以意大利语、法语和英语出版，使犹太人的迫害与他们的创造力之间的联系更加普及，经济作家托马斯·莫蒂默（1730-1810）毫无疑义地重复着这种联系。36孟德斯鸠的传奇版本也在一些关于汇票的技术著作的序言中得到了回应，它为这些著作披上了一层历史的外衣。37但它真正的传声筒是詹姆斯·斯蒂亚特爵士（1713-1780），一个流亡到 1763 年的雅各布派领主。斯图亚特的政治经济学论文在原创性上无法与当时的巨匠如魁奈、坎蒂隆、涂尔干、休谟和斯密的经济著作相提并论，但据估计，在英国之外，直到 1780 年代，它比《国富论》更有名，更经常被引用。38斯图亚特紧跟孟德斯鸠的传说版本，但他也加入了自己的润色：孟德斯鸠将汇票视为私人商人的主要信用工具，他们试图逃避专制统治者的贪婪，而斯图亚特则将这个传说纳入对公共信用的有力辩护。39

In short, the legend met a dual reception in England, as it had in France: works indebted to Cleirac or the Savarys cast Jews in a negative light but also led to a search for more stringent empirical verification, while those that followed Montesquieu placed Jews on a pedestal and dispensed with the need for accuracy. In England, however, Montesquieu’s version was marginalized and the legend never figured in contentious debates about the political status of Jews. In fact, by comparing the fate of the legend in France and Britain, we find that the political impact of representations of Jews’ economic roles on the two sides of the Channel was not as divergent as is usually believed.

简而言之，这个传说在英国受到了双重欢迎，就像它在法国一样：归功于克莱拉克或萨瓦里夫妇的作品对犹太人进行了否定，但也导致了对更严格的经验验证的探索，而那些追随孟德斯鸠的作品则将犹太人置于神坛之上，免除了对准确性的要求。然而，在英国，孟德斯鸠的版本被边缘化了，这个传说从未出现在关于犹太人政治地位的争论中。事实上，通过比较这个传说在法国和英国的命运，我们发现海峡两岸关于犹太人经济角色的表述的政治影响并不像人们通常认为的那样大相径庭。

John Toland, the earliest proponent of granting prosperous Jews who relocated to Britain the status of subjects of the crown (“naturalization”), insisted that Jews made vital contributions to international trade and did not demand that they be “regenerated,” but he was an unconventional figure. In 1714, Toland, an Irish Catholic who first converted to Anglicanism and later renounced Christianity altogether, published a pamphlet marshaling economic arguments in favor of allowing all Jews in the kingdom to be recognized as subjects of the crown.40 He was writing at a time of fierce disputes about the terms under which foreign Protestants should be naturalized. His pamphlet appeared in the same year that the Whigs regained control of Parliament. In 1753, Parliament passed the “Jewish Naturalization Act” allowing affluent foreign-born Jews to become subjects of the crown without taking the sacrament (a privilege that would entitle them, among other things, to enter all branches of trade and own ships). Another defender of this act, the Anglican reverend Josiah Tucker, who was also an effective polemicist and economic writer, spilled considerable ink to argue, counter to prevailing views, that this policy promoted British commercial interests.41

约翰·托兰（John Toland）是最早主张给予迁居英国的繁荣犹太人王室臣民地位（“归化”）的人，他坚持认为犹太人对国际贸易做出了重要贡献，并没有要求他们 “重生”，但他是一个非常规的人物。1714 年，托兰，一个先是皈依英国圣公会，后来又完全放弃基督教的爱尔兰天主教徒，发表了一本小册子，以经济论据支持允许王国的所有犹太人被承认为王室的臣民。40他写作时，正值关于外国新教徒入籍条件的激烈争议。他的这本小册子出现在辉格党重新控制议会的同一年。1753 年，议会通过了 “犹太人归化法”，允许富裕的外国出生的犹太人在不参加圣礼的情况下成为王室的臣民（这种特权除其他外，将使他们有权进入所有贸易部门并拥有船只）。该法案的另一位捍卫者，英国圣公会牧师约西亚·塔克（Josiah Tucker），也是一位有效的论战者和经济作家，与主流观点相反，他花费了大量笔墨来论证这一政策促进了英国的商业利益。41

Naturalization in mid-eighteenth-century Britain was an elite phenomenon rather than a political and legal status analogous to postrevolutionary French citizenship, yet it succeeded in stirring up an enormous uproar. Those opposing it mounted a vicious public campaign, waged by means of pamphlets, newspaper articles, sermons, plays, etchings, and public gatherings. In the end, the so-called “Jew Bill” was revoked. Neither its promoters nor its detractors seem to have invoked the legend of the Jewish invention of financial instruments in favor of or against it, but the resistance to the act proved in-grained stereotypes about Jewish usury to be stronger than the efforts to yoke Jewish commercial prowess to pro-naturalization arguments. In the many satires that circulated at the time, “Jews were widely represented as speculators and plundering usurers.”42 The protagonist of one sketch, “Mr. Judas the Broker,” is illustrative of such representations: a shadowy figure, Mr. Judas is willing to sell stocks in defiance of the Bubble Act, which in the aftermath of the 1720 crash forbade joint-stock companies lacking a royal charter from trading their shares.43

在十八世纪中期的英国，归化是一种精英现象，而不是类似于革命后法国公民身份的政治和法律地位，但它却成功地激起了一场巨大的骚动。反对者通过小册子、报纸文章、布道、戏剧、蚀刻画和公众集会等方式发起了一场恶毒的公众运动。最后，所谓的 “犹太人法案” 被撤销了。该法案的发起者和反对者似乎都没有援引犹太人发明金融工具的传说来支持或反对该法案，但对该法案的抵制证明，关于犹太人高利贷的根深蒂固的成见比将犹太人的商业能力与支持归化的论点挂钩的努力更强大。在当时流传的许多讽刺作品中，“犹太人被广泛描述为投机者和掠夺性高利贷者”。42一幅小品的主人公 “经纪人犹大先生” 就是这种表现的例证：犹大先生是一个阴暗的人物，他愿意无视《泡沫法案》而出售股票，该法案在 1720 年的股灾之后禁止没有皇家特许证的股份公司进行股票交易。43

In France, as we saw, advocates of Jewish emancipation avoided pro-commercial arguments in making their case (chapter 6 ).44 In Britain, such arguments were marshaled in favor of the more modest proposal of granting naturalization to a select group of prosperous Jews, but they backfired because large segments of the public perceived Jews as selfish speculators. Only in 1867 did adult male Jews gain the right to vote in Britain.

在法国，正如我们所看到的，犹太人解放的倡导者在提出他们的理由时避免了亲商业的论点（第六章）。44在英国，这种论点被用来支持更温和的建议，即让一部分富裕的犹太人入籍，但它们适得其反，因为大部分公众认为犹太人是自私的投机者。直到 1867 年，成年男性犹太人才在英国获得了选举权。

Holy Roman Empire

神圣罗马帝国

Savary’s Le parfait négociant appeared in German translation in 1676, a year after the French original, and became the earliest vehicle for the legend’s transmission into the German-language commercial and legal literature.45 Montesquieu’s influence followed in time. With regard to the claim that Jews might have invented marine insurance and/or bills of exchange, eighteenth-century German economic writers confirmed their well-known debt to French authors. But by reconstructing the trajectory of the legend and the objections to it, we can go a step further to map the landscape of German debates on the morality of commercial society and its relationship to the state during the eighteenth century. In the Holy Roman Empire, as elsewhere, this issue was treated in different, if overlapping, genres: merchant handbooks, which were most directly modeled on that of Savary; legal disquisitions on the origins of mercantile contracts, a literature largely unknown in Britain because of the feebler influence that Roman law exerted there; encyclopedias, some devoted to universal knowledge, others to trade alone; Cameralism, an amorphous and distinctively German tradition of academic writing on the economy and the fiscal needs of the state aimed at administrators and government officials; and, finally, treatises on the emerging “science of commerce” by Francophile admirers of Montesquieu.

萨瓦里的《完美的交易员》德文译本于 1676 年出现，比法文原著晚了一年，成为该传说传入德语商业和法律文献的最早载体。45孟德斯鸠的影响也随之而来。关于犹太人可能发明了海事保险和/或汇票的说法，18 世纪的德国经济作家证实了他们对法国作家众所周知的债务。但是，通过重建这个传说的轨迹以及对，我们可以更进一步地描绘出十八世纪德国关于商业社会道德及其与国家关系的辩论情况。在神圣罗马帝国，和其他地方一样，这个问题是在不同的流派中处理的，即使是重叠的。商人手册，其最直接的模式是萨瓦里的手册；关于商业合同起源的法律论述，这种文献在英国基本不为人知，因为罗马法在那里的影响较小；百科全书，有些致力于普及知识，有些则只涉及贸易。Cameralism，这是一种无定形的、独特的德国经济和国家财政需求的学术著作传统，针对的是行政人员和政府官员；最后，孟德斯鸠的法语崇拜者写的关于新兴 “商业科学” 的论文。

Mentions of Jews crop up in all of these genres and yet have been overlooked by scholars of both German political economy and central European Jews. These mentions are indebted to the manifold traditions we have examined so far but also reflect the conditions of regional and international trade in central Europe and the circumstances in which Jews lived and worked there. The stock market, essentially a London and Amsterdam institution (the Paris Bourse took off slowly only during the last quarter of the eighteenth century), was absent from central Europe during this time. Overall, the Jewish presence in Prussia, Austria, and the smaller German principalities and city-states was spotty and marked by tense relations with sovereigns and neighbors. Hamburg was the exception: in 1612 the Senate won its battle with the Lutheran clergy and allowed a small number of Sephardic merchants engaged in Atlantic trade to settle in the city-state with their families. A few Jewish merchants, most of them from Germany or Poland, were also active at the international fairs of Leipzig and Frankfurt am Main, which experienced a revival in the eighteenth century.46

在所有这些流派中都会提到犹太人，但却被研究德国政治经济和中欧犹太人的学者们所忽视。这些提法得益于我们迄今所研究的多种传统，但也反映了中欧地区和国际贸易的状况以及犹太人在那里生活和工作的情况。股票市场基本上是伦敦和阿姆斯特丹的机构（巴黎证券交易所在十八世纪的最后四分之一才慢慢起步），在这一时期，中欧并没有出现。总的来说，犹太人在普鲁士、奥地利以及较小的德国公国和城邦的存在是零星的，而且与君主和邻国的关系紧张。汉堡是个例外：1612 年，元老院在与路德教士的斗争中获胜，并允许少数从事大西洋贸易的塞法尔人商人与他们的家人在该城邦定居。少数犹太商人，大部分来自德国或波兰，也活跃在莱比锡和美因河畔法兰克福的国际博览会上，这些博览会在十八世纪经历了复兴。46

The social structure of the Jewish communities in the Habsburg Empire was strictly pyramidal, with the mass of poor folks excluded from artisanal professions and confined to small-scale retail topped by a few so-called court Jews, wealthy financiers and army suppliers who negotiated basic privileges for the entire community in return for their services to the ruler. Jews across the German-speaking territories were thus vulnerable to the will of the sovereign and were largely identified with poverty and criminality. In spite of these conditions, Christian merchants perceived even the poorest Jewish shopkeepers, salesmen, and peddlers as competitors and lamented their ostensibly excessive economic power, as shown by the 1672 “Petitions of the Estates to the Great Elector” of Brandenburg-Prussia.47 A century later, a prominent economic writer condemned all peddlers, and Jews in particular, for the poor quality of their merchandise.48

哈布斯堡帝国的犹太社区的社会结构是严格的金字塔式的，大量的穷人被排除在工匠职业之外，只能从事小规模的零售业，而少数所谓的宫廷犹太人、富有的金融家和军队供应商则为整个社区争取基本的特权，以回报他们对统治者的服务。因此，整个德语区的犹太人很容易受到君主意志的影响，并在很大程度上与贫穷和犯罪行为相联系。尽管存在这些情况，基督教商人甚至将最贫穷的犹太店主、售货员和小贩视为竞争对手，并对他们表面上过度的经济实力感到悲哀，1672 年勃兰登堡·普鲁士的 “庄园主向大选帝侯的请愿书” 就表明了这一点。47一个世纪后，一位著名的经济作家谴责了所有的小贩，特别是犹太人，因为他们的商品质量很差。48

More than their contemporaries elsewhere, German Orientalists and Biblical scholars produced virulent attacks on Judaism under the guise of learned exposés, joining new scholarly expertise with older theological polemics. Johann Andreas Eisenmenger’s 1700 Entdecktes Judenthum (Judaism Unmasked ) was the most hateful of these works, but many more, including one by the noted Johannes David Michaelis, relied on Hebraica to demonstrate Jews’ alleged inferiority and lack of respect toward Christians.49 In less scholarly publications, the portrait of Jews was rarely more favorable. By the late 1740s, writers like Christian Fürchtegott Gellert and, more famously, Gotthold Ephraim Lessing were offering positive representations of virtuous Jewish merchants. However, these works have stood the test of time not only because of their literary achievements but also because they rejected the then-dominant association of commerce with fraud, and with the Jews who symbolized it. Now forgotten are many more unremarkable texts that aired more conventional views.50 To a certain Johann Ludolf Holst, a law graduate and resident of Hamburg, the city with the largest resident community of international Jewish merchants in the Holy Roman Empire, we owe an extensive and unsympathetic treatment of the economic roles of Jews.51

与其他地方的同时代人相比，德国的东方学家和圣经学者在学识渊博的揭露书的幌子下对犹太教进行了猛烈的攻击，将新的学术专长与旧的神学论战结合起来。约翰·安德烈亚斯·艾森曼格（Johann Andreas Eisenmenger）1700 年的《揭开犹太教的面纱》（ Entdecktes Judenthum）是这些作品中最可恨的，但还有许多作品，包括著名的约翰·大卫·米凯利斯（Johannes David Michaelis）的作品，都是依靠希伯来语来证明犹太人所谓的劣等和对基督徒缺乏尊重。49在学术性不强的出版物中，对犹太人的描述很少有更有利的一面。到了 1740 年代末，像克里斯蒂安·弗赫特戈特·盖勒特（Christian Fürchtegott Gellert）以及更著名的戈托尔德·埃弗莱姆·莱辛（Gotthold Ephraim Lessing）这样的作家对有德行的犹太商人进行了正面描述。然而，这些作品经受住了时间的考验，不仅是因为它们的文学成就，还因为它们拒绝了当时占主导地位的商业与欺诈以及象征欺诈的犹太人的联系。现在被遗忘的还有许多不起眼的文本，它们宣扬了更多的传统观点。50汉堡是神圣罗马帝国最大的国际犹太商人居民社区，某位约翰·鲁道夫·霍尔斯特（Johann Ludolf Holst）是一位法律专业的毕业生和居民，我们要感谢他对犹太人的经济角色进行了广泛而不怀好意的处理。51

Emancipation was not imminent in central Europe. The 1782 Edict of Toleration of Habsburg emperor Joseph II paled in comparison to the privileges that Catholic states like Venice and Tuscany had granted Jews two centuries earlier. But because of the insistence of a few reformist voices, Jewish and gentile alike, the question of the “civic improvement” of Jews made its way into German-language works. Written on behalf of the Jews of Alsace, Christian Wilhelm von Dohm’s case for granting civic and political rights to Jews was more audacious than any other to date, and it was built on knowledge and arguments that German authors had debated for half a century.52 Dohm’s treatise, however, had a more immediate impact in France, where it inspired debates in favor of and against Jewish emancipation (chapter 6 ), than it did in the Holy Roman Empire.53

解放在中欧并不是迫在眉睫的。哈布斯堡皇帝约瑟夫二世 1782 年的《宽容法令》与威尼斯和托斯卡纳等天主教国家在两个世纪前给予犹太人的特权相比，显得微不足道。但由于少数改革派的坚持，无论是犹太人还是外邦人，犹太人的 “公民素质提高” 问题都进入了德语作品。克里斯蒂安·威廉·冯·杜姆（Christian Wilhelm von Dohm）代表阿尔萨斯的犹太人撰写的关于给予犹太人公民权和政治权利的论述，比迄今为止的任何其他论述都要大胆，它建立在德国作家辩论了半个世纪的知识和论点之上。（52然而，与神圣罗马帝国相比，杜姆的论文在法国产生了更直接的影响，它激发了支持和反对解放犹太人的辩论第 6 章）。53

Seeking to instruct future administrators on how to strengthen the welfare of their polities, Cameralist textbooks outlined methods to boost demographic growth (which was seen as the source and proof of all riches) and improve output in agriculture, manufacturing, and mining. Neither private nor public finance was key to Cameralist authors. Private finance appeared to them extraneous to the economic sphere of government administration, while the public debt was a moot topic because German rulers borrowed from bankers rather than subjects. By contrast, private credit was a more important theme in merchant handbooks, which owed a great deal to Savary and his sons. Two authors were instrumental in disseminating the legend of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange as part of their efforts to emulate French compilers of dictionaries of trade: Paul Jacob Marperger (1656–1730) and Carl Günter Ludovici (1707–1778).54 A member of the Prussian Royal Society of Sciences, Marperger served as a commercial court judge and took upon himself the task of assembling “the unwritten merchant laws or their so-called style” in order to guide judges like himself and other bureaucrats overseeing commercial disputes and councils. A professor of philosophy and later rector of the University of Leipzig, Ludovici invested considerable energy in large editorial projects, including the completion of a dictionary conceived by Johann Heinrich Zedler (1706–1763) that proved a monument of eighteenth-century German encyclopedic knowledge.55 All these projects relied greatly on the Savary brothers’ Dictionnaire universel de commerce .

为了指导未来的行政人员如何加强其政体的福利，喀麦尔派教科书概述了促进人口增长（被视为所有财富的来源和证明）和提高农业、制造业和采矿业产出的方法。私人或公共财政对喀麦尔主义作者来说都不是关键。在他们看来，私人金融与政府管理的经济领域无关，而公共债务则是一个没有意义的话题，因为德国统治者是从银行家，而不是从臣民那里借的。相比之下，私人信贷是商人手册中更重要的主题，这在很大程度上归功于萨瓦里父子。有两位作者在传播犹太人发明汇票的传说方面发挥了作用，这是他们努力模仿法国贸易词典编纂者的一部分：保罗·雅各布·马佩尔格（Paul Jacob Marperger，1656-1730）和卡尔·京特·卢多维奇（卡尔·京特·卢多维奇，1707-1778）。54作为普鲁士皇家科学学会的成员，马佩尔格曾担任商业法庭法官，并承担了收集 “不成文的商法或其所谓风格” 的任务，以指导像他这样的法官和其他监督商业纠纷和理事会的官僚。作为哲学教授和后来的莱比锡大学校长，卢多维奇在大型编辑项目上投入了大量精力，包括完成约翰·海因里希·泽德勒（Johann Heinrich Zedler，1706-1763）构思的词典，该词典被证明是十八世纪德国百科全书式知识的纪念碑。55所有这些项目都在很大程度上依赖于萨瓦里兄弟的《世界商业辞典》。

Through the usual mixture of deliberate plagiarism and thoughtless reproductions, the legend of the Jewish origin of bills of exchange that the Savarys had canonized infiltrated these German-language works. But German writers also expressed more doubts about it than their French counterparts. In 1709 Marperger relayed the legend of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange in full (including the names of the medieval French kings cited by Savary as responsible for banishing Jews from the Kingdom) but concluded that “it is more likely that the Ghibellines, who were expelled from Italy by the Guelph faction and for the most part moved to Germany and to the Low Countries, were responsible for the first real beginning of the trade in bills of exchange.”56 He gave a clearer reason for preferring an Italian source over a Jewish one a few years later in a book dedicated specifically to the history and functions of banks. There, he added that he was “certain that, as the Italians are clever tradesmen down to this very day and since most of the institutions that serve and facilitate maritime commerce come from them, the useful practice of banks must, too.”57 Zedler’s Lexicon took notice of Marperger’s update but also asserted that medieval French Jews invented marine insurance.58 When Ludovici undertook his adaptation of the dictionary compiled by the Savary brothers, he drew from the Lexicon as well.59

通过惯常的故意抄袭和不经意的复制，萨瓦里家族被封为典范的汇票犹太起源的传说渗透到这些德语作品中。但德国作家也比他们的法国同行对它表示了更多的怀疑。1709 年，马佩尔格（Marperger）完整地转述了犹太人发明汇票的传说（包括萨瓦里引用的负责将犹太人驱逐出王国的中世纪法国国王的名字），但他的结论是：“更有可能的是，被盖尔夫派驱逐出意大利、大部分迁往德国和低地国家的吉贝利人，对汇票贸易的第一次真正开始负责”。56几年后，在一本专门介绍银行历史和功能的书中，他给出了一个更明确的理由，即喜欢意大利人的资料而不是犹太人的资料。在那里，他补充说，他 “确信，由于意大利人至今仍是聪明的商人，而且由于大多数服务和促进海上贸易的机构都来自他们，银行的有益做法也必须如此。”57Zedler 的词典注意到了马佩尔格的更新，但也断言，中世纪的法国犹太人发明了海事保险。58当卢多维奇对萨瓦里兄弟编纂的词典进行改编时，他也借鉴了该词典。59

Overall, German authors tended to credit Italians rather than Jews with having expanded medieval commercial and banking activities. Today we know that their hypothesis is sounder than the rival interpretation focusing on Jews, but we also reject the wisdom of looking for a single point of origin for any complex phenomenon. Early signs of diffidence toward this search became visible at the beginning of the eighteenth century. As the proliferation of didactic multivolume compilations led to the mechanical reproduction of various tales of origins, German authors questioned the legend’s soundness more than readers elsewhere. A prolific author, Marperger changed his mind on the matter: only five years after he endorsed the idea that Ghibellines had invented bills of exchange, he aired an altogether different theory, arguing that these credit instruments were born out of the needs of long-distance trade.60 In yet another major compilation about “the science of commerce,” Ludovici, under the influence of Dupuis de la Serra, followed suit: while endorsing a probable Florentine origin, he also insisted that all financial contracts were a spontaneous response to the increasing complexity of international commerce.61

总的来说，德国作者倾向于将扩大中世纪商业和银行活动的责任归于意大利人而不是犹太人。今天我们知道，他们的假设比以犹太人为中心的敌对解释更可靠，但我们也拒绝为任何复杂的现象寻找一个单一的起源点的明智做法。对这种寻找的早期迹象，在十八世纪初变得明显。随着说教式的多卷汇编的扩散，导致各种起源故事的机械复制，德国作者比其他地方的读者更质疑传说的合理性。作为一个多产的作者，马佩尔格在这个问题上改变了主意：在他认可吉卜力人发明汇票的观点后仅五年，他就提出了一个完全不同的理论，认为这些信用工具是出于长途贸易的需要而产生的。60在另一本关于 “商业科学” 的重要汇编中，卢多维齐在杜普伊斯·德拉·塞拉的影响下，紧随其后：在认可可能是佛罗伦萨的起源的同时，他还坚持认为所有金融合同都是对日益复杂的国际商业的自发反应。61

Legal scholars also injected a healthy dose of skepticism about the putatively Jewish invention of marine insurance and bills of exchange into the debate. Steeped in Roman law, German jurists before and after the Reformation were equally versed in Scholastic and canonistic debates on usury. Those of Protestant confession, including the noted Wolfgang Adam Lauterbach (1618–1678), a member of the faculty of law in Tübingen, were more likely to reject Aristotelian doctrines about the sterility of money and defend the legitimacy of credit instruments.62 More generally, all jurists scrutinized the contractual nature of marine insurance and bills of exchange. By stating that “insurance policies and bills of exchange were unknown to Roman jurisprudence,” Cleirac had intervened—correctly—in lively and consequential debates about the existence or absence of Roman law antecedents of the contractual obligations that fueled Europe’s commercial expansion (chapter 3 ). German jurisprudence refined this point of contention. Discussions of maritime and commercial law, the bulk of which appeared in Latin dissertations, generally omitted any reference to the legend. Instead, they offered lengthy digressions on the dubious use of Cicero and other classical authors as evidence of the Roman origins of modern credit instruments.63 As part of these inquiries, a few German jurists discovered Cleirac’s Us et coustumes de la mer and, with it, the fabled story of the Jewish invention of marine insurance and bills of exchange, but their interest in the Bordelais author had more to do with the range of legal sources for the study of maritime law he provided, particularly the first modern edition of the Laws of Oléron.64

法律学者们还在辩论中对据称是犹太人发明的海事保险和汇票注入了健康的怀疑态度。深受罗马法熏陶的德国法学家在宗教改革前后都同样精通关于高利贷的学术和教规辩论。那些信奉新教的人，包括著名的沃尔夫冈·亚当·劳特巴赫（Wolfgang Adam Lauterbach，1618-1678），他是图宾根法律系的成员，更有可能拒绝亚里士多德关于货币不育的学说，并为信贷工具的合法性辩护。62更为普遍的是，所有法学家都仔细审查了海事保险和汇票的合同性质。克莱拉克指出，“罗马法学对保险单和汇票一无所知”，他正确地介入了关于合同义务是否存在罗马法先例的热烈而有影响的辩论，这些合同义务推动了欧洲的商业扩张（第三章）。德国法学完善了这一争论点。关于海商法的讨论，大部分出现在拉丁文的论文中，一般都没有提到传说。相反，他们对西塞罗和其他古典作家作为现代信用工具的罗马起源的证据的可疑使用进行了长时间的挖掘。63作为这些调查的一部分，一些德国法学家发现了克莱拉克的《Us et coustumes de lamer》，并发现了传说中犹太人发明海事保险和汇票的故事，但他们对这位波尔多作家的兴趣更多的是来自于他为海商法研究提供的一系列法律资料，尤其是第一版现代的《Oléron 法》。64

While German authors subjected the legend to empirical scrutiny, Montesquieu’s influence once again pushed interpretation in the opposite direction, encouraging the view that the tale was unquestionably true and conveying an uplifting message. Even before The Spirit of the Laws was translated into German in 1782, many German scholars had read it in French.65 No one drew more inspiration from it than Jakob Friedrich von Bielfeld (1717–1770), a graduate of Leiden University and court master of Prince Augustus Ferdinand of Prussia. In reproducing Montesquieu’s account of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange, Bielfeld applauded those “good princes” who chose to protect the tiny pieces of paper that had become “sacred” to the entire Europe commerçante .66

当德国作家对这个传说进行实证审查时，孟德斯鸠的影响再次将解释推向了相反的方向，鼓励人们认为这个故事无疑是真实的，并传达了一个令人振奋的信息。甚至在《法律的精神》于 1782 年被翻译成德文之前，许多德国学者已经用法文读过它。65没有人比雅各布·弗里德里希·冯·比尔菲尔德（Jakob Friedrich von Bielfeld，1717-1770）从该书中获得更多灵感，他毕业于莱顿大学，是普鲁士奥古斯都·费迪南德亲王的宫廷大师。在转载孟德斯鸠关于犹太人发明汇票的叙述时，Bielfeld 赞扬了那些选择保护对整个欧洲商业来说已经成为 “神圣” 的小纸片的 “好王子”。66

As a result of these multiple influences, by the end of the eighteenth century a broad spectrum of theories about the origins of European credit instruments characterized German economic literature, ranging from full endorsements of the legend67 to the preference for an Italian beginning68 and the outright rejection of the possibility of pinning down a single inventor.69 One prolific mathematics teacher in Hamburg, Johann Georg Büsch (1728–1800), held different views over the course of his lifetime.70

由于这些多方面的影响，到 18 世纪末，德国经济文献中出现了关于欧洲信贷工具起源的广泛理论，从完全认可传说67到倾向于以意大利为起点68以及直接拒绝确定单一发明者的可能性。69汉堡一位多产的数学教师约翰·乔治·布施（1728-1800）在他的一生中持有不同的观点。70

Out of this heterogeneity, one adaptation stands out because less than a century later it would become a commonplace explanation among German academics of the decline of Jews’ presumed economic supremacy in the early Middle Ages and the rise of postmedieval Europe (chapter 8 ). The Cameralist writer Friedrich Christoph Jonathan Fischer (1750–1797) sought to claim pride of place for medieval German merchants in the history of the origins of bills of exchange and, possibly, marine insurance. He argued that those inventions appeared at a time when the ingenuity of Christian merchants had been stimulated by a desire to free themselves from the domination of “Jews and Lombards.” For Fischer, “Christians could not watch indifferently the benefits that Jews and Lombards derived from their trade in money and from their business in bills of exchange [Wechselgeschäft ].”71 As the next chapter will show, the doyen of the German Historical School, Wilhelm Roscher, would later elaborate on this idea that, having copied Jews’ financial devices, Christians grew envious of their skills. One of the most influential narratives of the rise of European commerce and antisemitism therefore had its roots in a twist of the legend with which we are grappling.

在这种异质性中，有一种改编很突出，因为不到一个世纪后，它就成为德国学者对犹太人在中世纪早期假定的经济优势的衰落和中世纪后欧洲的崛起的一种普遍解释（第八章）。Cameralist 作家 Friedrich Christoph Jonathan Fischer（1750-1797）试图为中世纪的德国商人在汇票以及可能的海事保险的起源历史中争得一席之地。他认为，这些发明出现在基督教商人的聪明才智被从 “犹太人和伦巴第人” 的统治下解放出来的愿望所刺激的时候。对于费舍尔来说，“基督徒不能无动于衷地看着犹太人和伦巴第人从他们的货币贸易和汇票业务中获得的利益”。71正如下一章所显示的，德国历史学派的元老威廉·罗舍尔（Wilhelm Roscher）后来阐述了这一观点，即在复制了犹太人的金融工具后，基督徒对他们的技能越来越羡慕。因此，关于欧洲商业和反犹太主义兴起的最有影响力的叙述之一，其根源在于我们正在努力解决的这个传说的一个转折。

Italian Peninsula

意大利半岛

In spite of the wide resonance that Montesquieu’s work had with Italian Enlightenment figures, the legend of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange left only scant footprints on the Italian peninsula. There, a long tradition of merchant manuals and treatises on maritime and commercial law dating back to the late Middle Ages had fostered considerable knowledge of these credit instruments and their historical evolution. In 1641, six years before the publication of Cleirac’s Us et coustumes de la mer , a Latin treatise on exchange dealings likened their development to a river formed from a multiplicity of small contributory streams—a metaphor that signaled the impossibility of determining with precision where the river originated.72 The Jewish presence on the peninsula was also radically different from that in southwestern France. During the sixteenth century, under the dual pressure of ecclesiastical and state authorities, Iberian Jews fleeing to Venice, Livorno, and the Papal States were given shelter as long as they relinquished their Christian identity. As a consequence, crypto-Judaism was a relatively short-lived phenomenon in Italy.

尽管孟德斯鸠的作品在意大利启蒙运动人士中引起了广泛的反响，但犹太人发明汇票的传说在意大利半岛只留下了很少的脚印。在那里，可以追溯到中世纪晚期的商人手册和海商法论文的悠久传统，培养了对这些信贷工具及其历史演变的大量知识。1641 年，在克莱拉克的《海洋的用途和习俗》出版前六年，一篇关于外汇交易的拉丁文论文将其发展比作一条由多条小溪组成的河流 —— 这一比喻表明不可能准确地确定河流的发源地。72犹太人在半岛上的存在也与法国西南部的存在截然不同。十六世纪，在教会和国家当局的双重压力下，逃往威尼斯、里窝那和教皇国的伊比利亚犹太人得到了庇护，只要他们放弃基督教身份。因此，隐蔽的犹太教在意大利是一个相对短命的现象。

The tendency of Italian writers to claim the invention of bills of exchange for their ancestors also contributed to their rejection of the legend. In the earliest refutation of Cleirac, in 1690, Dupuis de la Serra proposed that the honor of having invented early credit instruments go to Florentine émigrés to Lyon. Predictably, this hypothesis met with a warm reception in Italy, where its spread was aided by a Latin and Italian translation of Dupuis de la Serra.73 Giuseppe Lorenzo Maria Casaregi (1670–1737), a jurist and preeminent scholar of commercial law, followed Dupuis de la Serra’s account in attributing the invention of bills of exchange to Guelf expatriates in Lyon, thus correcting the references that peppered the French literature treating Guelfs and Ghibel-lines as interchangeable groups.74 Several other Tuscan commentators naturally welcomed this theory. Some stressed the Florentines’ refugee status. Others, like Giovan Francesco Pagnini (1714–1789), a scholar of agrarian reforms and finance and a high official in the Tuscan Habsburg government, emphasized their leadership in international banking.75

意大利作家声称他们的祖先发明了汇票，这种倾向也促使他们拒绝了这个传说。在 1690 年对克莱拉克最早的反驳中，杜普斯·德拉塞拉（Dupuis de la Serra）提议将发明早期信贷工具的荣誉归于移居里昂的佛罗伦萨人。可以预见的是，这一假设在意大利受到了热烈的欢迎，它的传播得到了杜普斯·德拉塞拉的拉丁文和意大利文翻译的帮助。73Giuseppe Lorenzo Maria Casaregi（1670-1737），一位法学家和杰出的商法学者，遵循杜普斯·德拉塞拉的说法，将汇票的发明归功于里昂的 Guelf 侨民，从而纠正了法国文献中把 Guelfs 和 Ghibel-line 视为可互换群体的说法。74其他几位托斯卡纳评论家自然也欢迎这一理论。一些人强调佛罗伦萨人的难民身份。其他人，如农业改革和金融学者、托斯卡纳哈布斯堡政府的高级官员乔万·弗朗西斯科·帕尼尼（1714-1789），则强调他们在国际银行业的领导地位。75

In Livorno, the Italian city with the highest proportion of Jewish residents and the most tolerant policies toward them, the brothers Pompeo and Ascanio Baldasseroni, authors of treatises on exchange dealings and marine insurance, respectively, confirmed their preference for the Florentine origin of bills of exchange. Pompeo declared that Tuscany should count not only Galileo Galilei and Amerigo Vespucci among its “glories,” but also the inventors of bills of exchange.76 For Ascanio, Savary and Beawes were not to be trusted. Although he argued that Jews displayed a “natural inclination” for trade in bills of exchange and excelled at that activity, he asked that equal if not more credence be given to the Florentine hypothesis.77 A Genoese author had little to add except to mark his territory in the perpetual rivalry between Italian city-states, paying homage to the role that the Genoese, not just the Florentines, had played in spreading the invention of bills of exchange.78

在里窝那，这个拥有最高比例的犹太居民和对他们最宽容的政策的意大利城市，庞培和阿斯卡尼奥·巴尔达瑟罗尼兄弟，分别是关于汇兑交易和海事保险的论文作者，证实了他们对汇票的佛罗伦萨起源的偏爱。庞培宣称，托斯卡纳不仅应该把伽利略·伽利莱和亚美利哥·韦斯普奇算作其 “荣耀”，还应该把汇票的发明者算作其 “荣耀”。76对阿斯卡尼奥来说，萨瓦里和博韦斯是不值得信任的。尽管他认为犹太人在汇票交易方面表现出 “自然倾向”，并擅长这项活动，但他要求对佛罗伦萨的假设给予同等甚至更多的信任。77一位热那亚的作者除了在意大利城邦之间的长期竞争中标明自己的领地外，没有什么可补充的，，向热那亚人而不仅仅是佛罗伦萨人在传播汇票发明方面所发挥的作用表示敬意。78

Despite the mounting dismissal of the legend by those most versed in the legal and practical facets of commerce, Montesquieu’s version of the tale of Jewish invention insinuated itself into the works of the most influential figures of the Italian Enlightenment. Between 1754 and 1779, five academic chairs in what came to be known as political economy, which at the time was described alternately as “the science of commerce,” “mechanics and commerce,” “economic sciences,” or “civil economy,” were established in Naples, Milan, Modena, Catania, and Palermo. The occupants of the first two, Antonio Genovesi in Naples (1712–1769) and Cesare Beccaria in Milan (1738–1794), were also the most notable. They differed in their depiction of Jews’ role in the making of European commercial society, but both discussed the topic.

尽管那些最精通商业的法律和实践层面的人对这个传说越来越不屑一顾，但孟德斯鸠版本的犹太人发明的故事还是潜入了意大利启蒙运动中最有影响力的人物的作品中。1754 年至 1779 年间，在那不勒斯、米兰、摩德纳、卡塔尼亚和巴勒莫设立了五个被称为政治经济学的学术席位，当时政治经济学被交替描述为 “商业科学”、“机械和商业”、“经济科学” 或 “公民经济”。前两者的任职者，即那不勒斯的安东尼奥·热诺维西（1712-1769）和米兰的切萨雷·贝卡利亚（1738-1794），也是最引人注目的。他们对犹太人在欧洲商业社会形成过程中的作用的描述有所不同，但都讨论了这个话题。

Genovesi was, along with Ferdinando Galiani (1728–1787), the leading figure of the Neapolitan Enlightenment. His Delle lezioni di commercio (1765–1767) represented the culmination of an effort to synthesize a traditional eighteenth-century conception of commerce as promoting friendship between peoples and nations with the growing impetus, modeled on Newtonian science and pioneered by Galiani, to devise universal laws for the economy. The book was very well received and, as its numerous translations testify, earned Genovesi a place in the European pantheon of scholars who broke ground in the emerging field of political economy. In a chapter devoted to paper money (“Della moneta di carta”), he praised bills of exchange for supporting foreign trade and paper money for facilitating domestic trade. He also maintained that persecuted Jews at the time of the Crusades began to use bills of exchange in order to bring their assets abroad safely, implying that they had had a role in the early use of those instruments but also that it was a role that did not coincide with the Christian goal of reconquering the Holy Land.79

热诺维西与费迪南多·加利安尼（1728-1787）一样，是那不勒斯启蒙运动的领袖人物。他的Delle lezioni di commercio（1765-1767）代表了一种努力的顶峰，即把 18 世纪传统的促进民族和国家间友谊的商业概念与日益增长的、以牛顿科学为模式并由加里亚尼开创的为经济设计普遍规律的动力综合起来。这本书深受欢迎，正如它的众多译本所证明的那样，热诺维西在欧洲的万神殿中赢得了一席之地，在新兴的政治经济学领域取得了突破。在专门讨论纸币的一章中（“Della moneta di carta”），他称赞汇票支持对外贸易，纸币促进国内贸易。他还认为，在十字军东征时，受迫害的犹太人开始使用汇票，以便将他们的资产安全地带到国外，这意味着他们在这些工具的早期使用中发挥了作用，但这一作用与基督教重新征服圣地的目标并不一致。79

Other references to Jews in the rest of Genovesi’s work revealed a darker view of their economic roles than had been found in Montesquieu, whom he echoed only in assuming that “during the barbarous times that followed Greek and Latin politeness [politezza ],” Jews dominated trade. Genovesi took it upon himself to enumerate the evils of Jewish moneylending, which he declared “reached up to 30 and 40 and 100” percent interest rates until charitable lending institutions set up by Franciscan friars (the Monti di pietà ) put an end to those “bloody usuries.”80 Writing from Naples, a city that had chased Jews out in the early sixteenth century (except for a brief interlude in the 1740s), Genovesi depicted Jews as parasitical pawnbrokers and thus deviated from Montesquieu’s template.

在热诺维西的其他作品中提到犹太人时，对他们的经济作用的看法比孟德斯鸠的看法更黑暗，他只是附和孟德斯鸠，认为 “在希腊和拉丁礼貌之后的野蛮时代 politezza”， 犹太人主导了贸易。热诺维西主动列举了犹太人放贷的罪恶，他宣称其利率 “高达 30%、40% 和 100%”，直到方济各会修士设立的慈善贷款机构（the Monti di pietà）结束了这些 “血腥的高利贷”。80热诺维西在那不勒斯写作，这个城市在 16 世纪初就把犹太人赶走了（除了 1740 年代的一段短暂插曲），他把犹太人描绘成寄生的典当商，从而偏离了孟德斯鸠的模板。

Not so Cesare Beccaria, the celebrated author of the first European treatise condemning torture and the death penalty, who did not stray far at all from Montesquieu, offering an equally positive portrait of Jewish involvement in the creation of modern commercial society. On the occasion of his appointment to his chair in Milan in 1769, Beccaria delivered a speech that painted in broad strokes the historical process by which European commerce had achieved its dominance. Published simultaneously in Italian, French, and English, this brief text circulated widely. Beccaria glossed over the details and resorted to a more cautious formulation whereby Jews did not necessarily invent but certainly “had recourse to [ricorrono in the Italian original, recourent in the French translation] the invention of bills of exchange to save their treasures from the rapaciousness of tyrannical inquisitions.”81 Paraphrasing Montesquieu, Beccaria also praised bills of exchange for their ability to “augment to a great degree the certainty and readiness of communication among the trading nations.”82 He used commerce and communication as synonyms and viewed bills of exchange as the pillars of both. Like Montesquieu, Beccaria portayed Jews as having invented a tool of resistance against tyranny.83 Adapting another adage dear to Montesquieu, he grouped bills of exchange with the compass and the Spanish and Portuguese transoceanic explorations, the two other apexes of Western civilization, and added a patriotic touch by singling out the contributions of the Italian “genius” Christopher Columbus.

切萨雷·贝卡利亚（Cesare Beccaria）则不然，他是欧洲第一篇谴责酷刑和死刑的论文的著名作者，他完全没有偏离孟德斯鸠，对犹太人参与现代商业社会的创建进行了同样积极的描述。1769 年，贝卡里亚在米兰被任命为主席时，发表了一篇演讲，概括地描述了欧洲商业取得主导地位的历史过程。这篇简短的文章同时以意大利文、法文和英文出版，流传甚广。贝卡里亚掩盖了细节，采用了一种更谨慎的表述，即犹太人不一定发明了，但肯定 “求助于 —— 意大利语原文为 ricorrono，法语译文为 recourent —— 汇票的发明，以使他们的财宝免遭暴政审讯的掠夺。”81根据孟德斯鸠的说法，贝卡里亚还称赞汇票能够 “在很大程度上增加贸易国之间交流的确定性和准备性”。82他将商业和交流作为同义词，并将汇票视为两者的支柱。像孟德斯鸠一样，贝卡里亚把犹太人描述为发明了一种抵抗暴政的工具。83他改编了孟德斯鸠的另一句格言，将汇票与指南针以及西班牙和葡萄牙的跨洋探险这两个西方文明的顶点结合起来，并通过挑出意大利 “天才” 克里斯托弗·哥伦布的贡献来增加爱国主义色彩。

Montesquieu’s authoritativeness at this time was so great that few dared to disprove him. One exception was the Tuscan physician, botanist, and geographer Giovanni Targioni Tozzetti (1712–1783), who challenged the philosophe’s account of the birth of bills of exchange and did so, unlike Dupuis de la Serra, on strictly empirical grounds. Describing a manuscript containing the works of the noted thirteenth-century Pisan mathematician Leonardo Fibonacci, Tozzetti remarked that bills of exchange had been well known in Pisa at that time and concluded that both Montesquieu’s anecdote and any accounts attributing the invention of bills of exchange to Florentine émigrés in Lyon were proven wrong by this text.84 When Domenico Alberto Azuni (1749–1827), a foremost jurist and theorist of commercial law, took on the task of updating the Savary brothers’ dictionary of commerce, he incorporated Tozzetti’s correction.85 In so doing, he not only exalted Tuscany’s precocious capitalist development, but also proved the value of source criticism.

孟德斯鸠的权威性在这一时期是如此之高，以至于很少有人敢于反驳他。一个例外是托斯卡纳医生、植物学家和地理学家乔瓦尼·塔尔乔尼·托泽蒂（1712-1783），他对这位哲学家关于汇票诞生的说法提出了质疑，而且与杜普伊·德拉·塞拉不同，他是以严格的经验主义为依据提出质疑的。托泽蒂描述了一份包含 13 世纪皮萨著名数学家莱昂纳多·斐波纳契作品的手稿，他说当时汇票在皮萨已经很有名了，并得出结论，孟德斯鸠的轶事和任何将汇票的发明归功于里昂的佛罗伦萨移民的说法都被这一文本证明是错误的。84当多米尼克·阿尔贝托·阿苏尼（Domenico Alberto Azuni，1749-1827），一位最重要的法学家和商法理论家，承担起更新萨瓦里兄弟的商业词典的任务时，他纳入了托泽蒂的更正。85这样一来，他不仅颂扬了托斯卡纳早熟的资本主义发展，而且还证明了来源批评的价值。

Both the supporters and the detractors of the legend of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange in eighteenth-century Italy discussed the tale with little regard for the actual status of Jews living on the peninsula. The one exception was a debate that ensued in Mantua, a town then under Habsburg rule that in the 1770s and 1780s became the fulcrum of reformist initiatives and bitter counterattacks on them. The Jewish community in Mantua traced its origins to the twelfth century and boasted scholars and rabbis of great repute who epitomized the Ashkenazic-Italian tradition predating the arrival of Iberian refugees in the sixteenth century. Thanks to a rich manufacturing tradition, they were not as impoverished as the Jews of Alsace and Lorraine; nevertheless, they were poorer and less acculturated than the Sephardic merchants living in Venice and Livorno.86 In the early 1780s, the local nobleman Giovanni Battista Gherardo D’Arco (1739–1791) and the Jewish physician and maskil (Enlightened scholar) Benedetto Frizzi, also known as Benzion Rafael Kohen (1756–1844), engaged in an acrimonious debate about the Jews’ civic rights (or lack thereof) and in the process rehearsed trite arguments about the economic functions of Jews in Christian society.

在 18 世纪的意大利，犹太人发明汇票的传说的支持者和反对者在讨论这个故事时，都没有考虑到生活在半岛上的犹太人的实际地位。唯一的例外是在曼图亚发生的一场辩论，这个当时在哈布斯堡统治下的城镇，在 17 世纪 70 年代和 80 年代成为改革派倡议和对其进行激烈反击的支点。曼图亚的犹太社区可以追溯到十二世纪，并拥有声誉卓著的学者和拉比，他们是十六世纪伊比利亚难民到来之前的阿什肯纳兹·意大利传统的缩影。由于有丰富的制造业传统，他们并不像阿尔萨斯和洛林的犹太人那样贫困；然而，他们比生活在威尼斯和利沃诺的塞法尔德商人更穷，更没有文化。861780 年代初，当地贵族乔瓦尼·巴蒂斯塔·盖拉多·达科（1739-1791）和犹太医生兼掩蔽者（启蒙学者）贝内德托·弗里齐（又称本齐安·拉斐尔·科恩（1756-1844））就犹太人的公民权利（或缺乏公民权利）进行了激烈的辩论，并在此过程中排练了关于犹太人在基督教社会中经济职能的陈词滥调。

A self-styled physiocrat, D’Arco submitted a formulaic tribute to the civilizing properties of commerce to a prize competition sponsored by the Royal Academy of Marseilles. Denouncing the harm caused by monopolies, he pointed to Jewish businesses as his prime example.87 After his work was rejected by the French committee, D’Arco expanded on his view of Jews’ pernicious economic dominance, which he regarded as inseparable from their deviant religious beliefs, in a book with the ominous title On the Influence of the Ghetto on the State , which advocated curbing Jewish self-government in the wake of the 1782 Habsburg Edict of Toleration. Borrowing arguments that we have encountered before, and which the Turin jurist Giuseppe Sessa had recently reiterated, D’Arco praised Maria Theresa’s decision to expel Jews from Prague in 1745 as a way of eradicating their “asocial egotism” (egoismo insociale ).88

达科（D'Arco）是一个自诩为生理学家的人，他向马赛皇家学院主办的一个有奖竞赛提交了一份关于商业的文明属性的公式化颂词。他谴责垄断造成的危害，指出犹太企业是他的主要例子。87在他的作品被法国委员会拒绝后，达科在一本名为《论犹太区对国家的影响》的书中阐述了他对犹太人有害的经济支配地位的看法，他认为这与他们偏离的宗教信仰是分不开的，该书主张在 1782 年哈布斯堡宽容法令之后遏制犹太人自治。达科借用我们以前遇到过的、都灵法学家朱塞佩-塞萨（Giuseppe Sessa）最近重申过的论点，赞扬了玛丽亚·特蕾莎 1745 年将犹太人从布拉格驱逐出去的决定，认为这是消除他们 “非社会自我主义”（egoismo insociale）的一种方式。88

This was the central accusation that Frizzi sought to rebut. Persecution, he maintained, had made Jews circumspect rather than fraudulent, and commerce had instilled in them moderation and allowed them to perform multiple services to the state. He praised Jews not only for excelling at but also for inventing banking activities when expelled from France, as well as for spreading those techniques to all maritime states, including Venice, Amsterdam, and Bordeaux.89 Writing after Dohm, Frizzi went further than other contemporary Jewish apologists to extol the financial skills of Jews, but he did so in a context in which full emancipation was not on the table (indeed, he argued for more rather than less Jewish corporate self-government). He did not, however, go as far as taking credit for his people’s supposed invention of bills of exchange— a telling omission.

这是弗里兹试图反驳的核心指责。他认为, 迫害使犹太人变得谨慎而不是欺诈, 商业给他们灌输了节制, 使他们能够为国家做出多种贡献。他称赞犹太人不仅擅长而且还在被驱逐出法国时发明了银行业务，并将这些技术传播到所有海洋国家，包括威尼斯、阿姆斯特丹和波尔多。89在杜姆之后，弗里兹比其他当代犹太辩护士更进一步地赞美犹太人的金融技能，但他是在全面解放还没有被提上日程的情况下这样做的（事实上，他主张更多而不是更少的犹太企业自治）。然而，他并没有为他的人民发明了所谓的汇票而邀功 —— 这是一个很明显的遗漏。

Iberia

The legend reached Iberia late and had only a slight influence on Spanish and Portuguese debates on the morality of commerce. There are many reasons for its low profile. Early modern Iberian economic thought arguably peaked in the sixteenth century, when moral theologians and a few lay authors produced some of the most sophisticated explanations of the growing credit economy. As in Italy, these writers had a deep knowledge of exchange dealings, the emergence of which they attributed to the natural progression from barter to money and the need to find alternatives to the transport and conversion of minted coins.90 During the economic decline of the seventeenth century, advisors and critics of the crown, the so-called arbitristas , concentrated on proposing reforms of fiscal and commercial policies. By the eighteenth century, Spanish and Portuguese economic literature had become more dependent on foreign currents of thought and focused on the governance of mainland and imperial territories.

这个传说很晚才传到伊比利亚，对西班牙和葡萄牙关于商业道德的辩论只产生了一点影响。它的低调有很多原因。现代早期伊比利亚的经济思想可以说在 16 世纪达到了顶峰，当时道德神学家和一些非专业作者对不断增长的信用经济做出了一些最复杂的解释。与意大利一样，这些作家对交换交易有深刻的了解，他们把这种交易的出现归因于从易货贸易到货币的自然发展，以及需要找到运输和转换铸币的替代品。90在十七世纪的经济衰退期间，王室的顾问和批评者，即所谓的仲裁者，集中于提出财政和商业政策的改革。到了十八世纪，西班牙和葡萄牙的经济文献变得更加依赖外国思潮，并专注于大陆和帝国领土的治理。

Imported from abroad, the legend arrived in Iberia via the translations of Bielfeld and Genovesi. A brief if affirming reference to it appeared in terms that echoed Montesquieu in a compilation of the Catalan polymath and editor of medieval Barcelona’s Libro del consulado del mar , Antonio de Capmany y Montpalau (1742–1813).91 A different treatise, devoted entirely to bills of exchange, cited Savary and Villani alongside the refutation of their narrative by Dupuis de la Serra.92 Bernardo Danvila, a Valencian jurist and scion of a mercantile family, listed multiple possibilities for the origin of bills of exchange, including the Jewish hypothesis, in a chapter on money in his lectures on commerce.93

这个传说从国外传入，通过别菲尔德（Bielfeld）和吉诺维西（Genovesi）的翻译传到了伊比利亚。在加泰罗尼亚多面手、中世纪巴塞罗那《海洋领事书》的编辑安东尼奥·德·卡普曼尼·蒙帕劳（1742-1813）的汇编中，出现了一个简短但肯定的提法，其用语与孟德斯鸠相仿。91另一篇专门论述汇票的论文引用了萨瓦里和维拉尼，同时还驳斥了杜普伊斯·德拉·塞拉对他们的叙述。92巴伦西亚法学家、商贾世家的后代贝尔纳多·丹维拉在其商业讲座中关于货币的一章中列出了汇票起源的多种可能性，包括犹太人的假设。93

In the Portuguese world, as elsewhere, scholars rediscovered Cleirac in the last quarter of the eighteenth century, when Enlightenment reformists were advocating the passage of new comprehensive codes. While reading Cleirac as a source of earlier maritime laws, some were also drawn to the legend. The Brazilian economist, jurist, and historian José da Silva Lisboa, Baron and Viscount of Cairu, relied on Cleirac’s Us et coustumes de la mer to compile his own principles of maritime law, in which he recalled various theories about the origins of bills of exchange, including the one attributing their invention to Jews fleeing France in 1182.94

在葡萄牙世界，和其他地方一样，学者们在十八世纪最后一个季度重新发现了克莱拉克，当时启蒙运动的改革者们主张通过新的综合法典。在将克莱拉克作为早期海商法的来源来阅读的同时，一些人也被这个传说所吸引。巴西经济学家、法学家和历史学家何塞·达·席尔瓦·里斯本（ José da Silva Lisboa），凯鲁（Cairu）男爵和子爵，依靠克莱拉克的《海洋的用途和习俗》编写了他自己的海商法原则，其中他回顾了关于汇票起源的各种理论，包括将其发明归功于 1182 年逃离法国的犹太人。94

Proponents of economic liberalization at the close of the eighteenth century also clung to the legend, with some embracing more benign versions than others. A treatise inspired by French physiocrats criticized the Spanish crown for expelling Moriscos, whom it described as refined artisans and farmers. Surveying the sources of a state’s wealth (agriculture, taxes, the arts, industry, money, and coinage), that work referred to the legend to account for the shift from metal currency to bills of exchange and singled out Jews who were forced to flee England and France in the twelfth and thirteenth centuries. They deposited their assets with people they trusted, the author relayed, and thus drew up written documents that served as models for bills of exchange. In a seemingly neutral tone, he concluded that “the discovery of this secret, which probably existed before among the Jews because of their usuries, facilitated commercial operations.”95 The laissez-faire economist José Alonso Ortiz also noted that most of the authors he consulted attributed the invention of bills of exchange to persecuted Jews from the times of the Crusades. Ortiz did not defend the idea that Jews invented these bills but expressed certainty that they were among the first to have used them. How could he be so sure? Because Jews’ permanent displacement (“la condición errante de estas gentes”) and continuous persecution had led them to specialize in commerce, he declared, so much so that “they have always been the richest merchants in Europe.”96

十八世纪末，经济自由化的倡导者也坚持这个传说，其中一些人接受的是比其他人更善意的版本。一篇受法国生理学家启发的论文批评了西班牙，因为王室驱逐了莫里斯科人，它把莫里斯科人描述为高雅的工匠和农民。这部著作调查了一个国家的财富来源（农业、税收、艺术、工业、货币和硬币），提到了这个传说，以解释从金属货币到汇票的转变，并特别指出了在 12 和 13 世纪被迫逃离英国和法国的犹太人。作者转述说，他们将自己的资产存放在他们信任的人那里，因此起草了书面文件，作为汇票的模型。他以一种看似中立的语气总结说：“这个秘密的发现，可能以前就存在于犹太人中，因为他们的高利贷，促进了商业运作。”95自由放任的经济学家何塞·阿隆索·奥尔蒂斯也指出，他查阅的大多数作者都将汇票的发明归功于十字军东征时期受迫害的犹太人。奥尔蒂斯没有为犹太人发明这些票据的观点辩护，但表示确信他们是最早使用这些票据的人之一。他怎么能如此肯定呢？因为犹太人的长期流离失所（“la condición errante de estas gentes”）和持续迫害导致他们专门从事商业活动，他宣称，以至于 “他们一直是欧洲最富有的商人”。96

This assumption went unchallenged in a region that had freed itself of Jews 300 years earlier and where commerce and finance had gained only partial acceptance. Sporadic as these mentions of the legend were on the Iberian peninsula, they were never accompanied by demands for evidence, a reflex that elsewhere in Europe was corroding the credibility of the idea that the most advanced credit instruments were the brainchild of persecuted medieval Jews.

这一假设在一个 300 年前就摆脱了犹太人的地区没有受到质疑，而且商业和金融只获得了部分认可。尽管在伊比利亚半岛上零星地提到了这些传说，但它们从未伴随着对证据的要求，这种反射在欧洲其他地方正在腐蚀着最先进的信贷工具是受迫害的中世纪犹太人的创意这一观点的可信度。

United Provinces

联合省

Once they gained independence from the Spanish Low Countries, the Calvinist United Provinces went further than any other early modern European state in removing usury from the domain of moral theology and ecclesiastical power and placing it in the sphere of civil law. In 1658, the estates of Holland and West Friesland ruled that “the question of moneys loaned by banks does not fall within the jurisdiction of church boards, classes, or synods, but comes under the supervision of the civil government,” which takes it upon itself to protect the poor and “to ensure profit for the majority of the population.”97 As the phrasing of this norm implied, civil authorities saw themselves as being able to both let merchants lending at interest and shield the poor from economic exploitation. Did they succeed?

一旦从西班牙低地国家获得独立，加尔文主义联合省在将高利贷从道德神学和教会权力的领域移除，并将其置于民法的范围内，比任何其他早期现代欧洲国家走得更远。1658 年，荷兰和西弗里斯兰的庄园裁定，“银行贷款的问题不属于教会委员会、班级或宗教会议的管辖范围，而是在民事政府的监督之下”，民事政府负责保护穷人并 “确保大多数人的利益”。97正如这一规范的措辞所暗示的那样，民政当局认为自己既能让商人借出利息，又能保护穷人免受经济剥削。他们成功了吗？

The artwork of the Dutch Golden Age, Simon Schama has shown, not only celebrated opulence but also offered an opportunity for reflection on the ills of profligacy.98 But the visual arts were only the most striking vehicle used by elite Dutch culture to express moral concerns about the ubiquity of credit. The printing press did its part, too. The legend of the Jewish invention of marine insurance and bills of exchange, however, did not establish a firm footing in the Dutch commercial literature. This is all the more remarkable given that Dutch was the second language after German into which Savary’s Le parfait négociant was translated in 1683.99 It is tempting to jump to the quick conclusion that Amsterdam, the most tolerant city in early modern Europe, offered unparalleled safeguards to its Jewish population and therefore proved impermeable to a legend that, in most renditions, vilified Jews. The hypothesis is plausible, but we need to consider at least two other elements when trying to make sense of the lack of traction that the legend gained in the United Provinces. The first is the relative paucity of handbooks and dictionaries about trade that were written and published in Dutch compared to English, in spite of the pervasiveness of commerce in both societies. The second is the tendency of Dutch authors to invoke Jews to express disapproval of the excesses of the stock market rather than bills of exchange, a trait more consonant with a phenomenon we have already seen in England.

西蒙·沙马（Simon Schama）指出，荷兰黄金时代的艺术作品不仅赞美富足，而且还为反思挥霍的弊端提供了机会。98但是，视觉艺术只是荷兰精英文化用来表达对无处不在的信贷的道德担忧的最引人注目的工具。印刷机也发挥了它的作用。然而，关于犹太人发明海事保险和汇票的传说并没有在荷兰商业文学中站稳脚跟。鉴于荷兰语是继德语之后的第二种语言，1683 年萨瓦里的《完美的交易员》被翻译成这种语言，这就更加引人注目了。99我们很容易得出这样的结论：阿姆斯特丹是现代早期欧洲最宽容的城市，它为其犹太人提供了无与伦比的保障，因此证明它对一个在大多数版本中诋毁犹太人的传说是不可能渗透的。这一假设是合理的，但我们在试图解释该传说在联合省缺乏吸引力时，至少需要考虑其他两个因素。首先，与英语相比，用荷兰语编写和出版的贸易手册和字典相对较少，尽管商业在两个社会中都很普遍。其次是荷兰作者倾向于援引犹太人来表达对股票市场而不是汇票的过度行为的不满，这一特征与我们在英国已经看到的现象更为一致。

The United Provinces, a major hub of international trade, produced a remarkably small fraction of the Continent’s ars mercatoria . The Dutch population had generally high literacy rates and consumed a great deal of printed economic information in the form of broadsheets, price and stock lists, auction sale advertisements, and other ephemera. Moreover, some of Europe’s most influential theorists of republicanism and international and natural law, from the De La Court brothers to Hugo Grotius, not only were born in Holland but also voiced the intellectual and political predicaments of the milieus in which they lived. Nevertheless, eighteenth-century Dutch printing houses issued fewer merchant dictionaries and manuals than their English, French, and German counterparts, and most of those that were issued offered hands-on instructions rather than investigating the historical and philosophical aspects of commerce.100

联合省是国际贸易的主要中心，但其生产的商报只占欧洲大陆商报的一小部分。荷兰人的识字率普遍很高，并以大字报、价格和股票清单、拍卖广告和其他小册子的形式消费了大量的印刷经济信息。此外，欧洲一些最有影响力的共和主义、国际法和自然法理论家，从德拉考特兄弟到雨果·格劳秀斯，不仅出生在荷兰，而且还表达了他们所处环境的知识和政治困境。然而，与英国、法国和德国的印刷厂相比，18 世纪荷兰印刷厂发行的商人字典和手册较少，而且所发行的大多数字典和手册提供的是实践指导，而不是对商业的历史和哲学方面的调查。100

Among the exceptions is a manual compiled by the Huguenot refugee Jacques Le Moine de L’Espine, which appeared simultaneously in French and Dutch in Amsterdam in 1694 as La négoce d’Amsterdam /Den koophandel van Amsterdam . Ten years later, a revised Dutch edition opened with a chapter on the origins of bills of exchange that mixed together bits and pieces from Cleirac and Savary to relay the legend as a matter of fact.101 This text proved to be incredibly popular, with a total of twelve Dutch editions repeating the story of how Jews expelled from France invented bills of exchange. But aside from its inclusion in this well-liked merchant manual, the legend did not figure in many other works, except for the anonymous De koopman (The Merchant ), a collection of commonplaces that appeared later in the century.102 Nor did it enter the learned disquisitions of legal scholars.103

其中一个例外是由胡格诺派难民 Jacques Le Moine de L‘Espine 编撰的手册，该手册于 1694 年在阿姆斯特丹同时以法语和荷兰语出版，名为《阿姆斯特丹的贸易》。10 年后，修订后的荷兰版开篇写了关于汇票起源的一章，将克莱拉克和萨瓦里的片段混合在一起，将这个传说作为事实转述。101这个文本被证明是非常受欢迎的，总共有 12 个荷兰版本重复了被驱逐出法国的犹太人如何发明汇票的故事。但是，除了这本广受欢迎的商人手册之外，这个传说并没有出现在其他许多作品中，除了本世纪晚些时候出现的匿名的《商人》（De koopman）这本俗语集。102它也没有进入法律学者的学术讨论中。103

This is not to say that references to Jews were absent from Dutch public commentaries on commerce and finance. For both those who welcomed it and those who resented it, the presence of a sizable Jewish community in the heart of Holland was predicated on its real and preceived economic contributions to the commonwealth. In 1692, an anonymous piece published in the Dutch periodical Histoire des ouvrages des savants (1687–1709) put it bluntly: Jews “are tolerated for no other reason than the advantages that they bring to commerce,” in spite of the fact that “there is nothing that is more odious to Christianity.”104 Others voiced more benevolent opinions of Jews’ economic influence, if only to advance their own political agenda. In 1673, an English pamphleteer expressed his admiration for Dutch political economy by praising Amsterdam as a city that used to have nothing by way of commerce until it welcomed the Jews expelled from Iberia.105

这并不是说，荷兰关于商业和金融的公开评论中没有提到犹太人。对于那些欢迎和反感犹太人的人来说，在荷兰的中心地带存在一个相当大的犹太社区，是以其对联邦的实际和预想的经济贡献为前提的。1692 年，发表在荷兰期刊《学者作品的历史》（Histoire des ouvrages des savants，1687-1709）上的一篇匿名文章直截了当地指出。犹太人 “被容忍的原因无非是他们给商业带来的好处”，尽管事实上 “没有什么比基督教更令人厌恶的了”。104其他人对犹太人的经济影响发表了更多善意的意见，如果只是为了推进他们自己的政治议程的话。1673 年，一位英国小册子作者对荷兰的政治经济表示钦佩，他称赞阿姆斯特丹是一个曾经没有任何商业活动的城市，直到它欢迎从伊比利亚驱逐出来的犹太人。105

In times of financial crisis these stereotypes quickly acquired a more menacing tone, and Jews were accused of cornering the market. Still a small presence, they received little blame for the bust in tulip bulb prices in 1637, the most massive early speculative scheme gone awry.106 By contrast, the Amsterdam stock market crash of 1688 exposed what Jonathan Israel has called “a new strain of economic anti-Semitism rooted in the mystique of the stock market.”107 The 1720 South Sea Bubble sent shockwaves through Holland. Amid an explosion of printed material satirizing the “trade in wind,” caricatures of Jews vilified the unsavory financial deals in which they allegedly engaged. Part of the blame for the South Sea disaster fell on foreigners, English and Frenchmen in particular. But the greatest blame was placed on Jews, who were accused of having swindled honest and naïve Dutchmen into making foolish investments. Faced with a possible financial meltdown, Dutch society ceased to distinguish between refined Sephardim (still the majority of Jewish stock traders in 1720) and uncouth Ashkenazim.108

在金融危机时期，这些刻板印象迅速获得了更多的威胁性语气，犹太人被指责为垄断市场。在 1637 年的郁金香球茎价格暴跌中，他们仍然是一个小角色，没有受到什么指责，这是早期最大规模的投机计划出了问题。106相比之下，1688 年阿姆斯特丹的股票市场崩溃暴露了乔纳森·伊斯雷尔所说的 “一种植根于股票市场神秘性的新的经济反犹太主义”。1071720 年的南海泡沫给荷兰带来了冲击波。在讽刺 “风中交易” 的印刷品爆炸中，犹太人的漫画诋毁了他们据称参与的不光彩的金融交易。南海灾难的部分责任落在了外国人身上，特别是英国人和法国人。但最大的责任在于犹太人，他们被指控骗取了诚实和天真的荷兰人进行愚蠢的投资。面对可能的金融崩溃，荷兰社会不再区分高雅的塞法尔迪人（在 1720 年仍占犹太股票交易商的大多数）和粗鲁的阿什肯纳兹人。108

“Smous Levi” and “Greedy Judases” became staple characters in pamphlets and theater plays.109 One of these works depicted Harlequin, the duplicitous if endearing character of the commedia dell’arte , selling “wind” (instead of victuals) to a ship captain headed south: “Profit is expected in exchange for Wind; as Jew and Moonlighter try, out of selfishness, to confuse everything.”110 The trope was repeated in 1773 at the time of another financial crisis, when De koopman accused Portuguese Jews of encouraging rampant speculation in wind (windhandel ) rather than commodities.111 So widespread were these allegations that scholars have recently singled out Jean-Frédéric Bernard and Bernard Picard’s multivolume book on world religions, Ceremonies et coutumes religieuses de tous les peuples du monde , published in Amsterdam between 1723 and 1737, as an exception to the tendency to attribute the 1720 stock market crash to Jews.112

“Smous Levi” 和 “Greedy Judases” 成为小册子和戏剧中的主要人物。109其中一部作品描述了哈勒奎因，即喜剧中那个两面三刀但又令人喜爱的人物，向一位南下的船长出售 “风”（而不是食物） 。“用风来换取利润；因为犹太人和月光者出于自私，试图混淆一切。”1101773 年，在另一场金融危机发生时，德·库普曼指责葡萄牙犹太人鼓励猖獗的风投机（windhandel）而不是商品投机，这种说法再次出现。111这些指控如此普遍，以至于学者们最近挑出了让·弗雷德里克·伯纳德和伯纳德·皮卡德的多卷本世界宗教书《世界各民族的宗教仪式和礼仪》（Ceremonies et coutumes religieuses de tous les peuples dumonde，1723-1737 年间在阿姆斯特丹出版），作为将 1720 年的股市崩溃归咎于犹太人这一趋势的一个例外。112

In the United Provinces, the stock market was the source of much contention. The earliest European book entirely devoted to the subject appeared in Amsterdam, with the title Confusión de confusiones , in 1688. Its author was a Sephardic Jew, Joseph Penso de la Vega, born in Andalusia but raised in Amsterdam, where he achieved considerable notoriety. In de la Vega’s lifetime, Sephardim became more and more involved in the secondary market of East India Company stock, although they never dominated it. When rumors spread that Stadholder William III was planning to invade England, ranking officials in the city of Amsterdam (all by definition Christian) were equally if not more ready than Sephardic Jews to use insider information in order to sell their East India Company stocks before they took a dive.113

在联合省，股票市场是许多争论的根源。欧洲最早的一本专门讨论这个问题的书出现在阿姆斯特丹，书名是《混乱的困惑》（Confusión de confusiones），出版于 1688 年。该书的作者是塞法尔犹太人约瑟夫·彭索·德拉维加，他出生在安达卢西亚，但在阿姆斯特丹长大，在那里他取得了相当大的名声。在德拉维加的一生中，塞法尔人越来越多地参与到东印度公司股票的二级市场中，尽管他们从未主导过这个市场。当关于首相威廉三世计划入侵英国的谣言传开后，阿姆斯特丹市的高级官员（顾名思义都是基督徒）同样甚至比塞法尔迪犹太人更愿意利用内幕消息，以便在东印度公司股票跳水前将其出售。113

In Confusión de confusiones , “a naïve Philosopher” and a “discrete Merchant” seek to understand “the mysterious affair” of the stock market; a “knowledgeable Shareholder” answers their questions in four “curious dialogues.”114 Jona-than Israel reminds us that Amsterdam Jews strongly favored (and supported financially) William of Orange’s military plans but were frequently portrayed as unpatriotic. In his reading, de la Vega started to write his book precisely when news of William’s expedition became public, in May 1688, and completed it after stock values plummeted in August. For Israel, one of de la Vega’s aims was to cleanse the reputation of Jews, who were seen as having been instrumental in luring a great many modest people into the stock market under the false promise of certain gains.115 Others argue instead that Confusión de confusiones lacked any original economic insights and aimed solely at entertaining its readers while leaving them with the sense that the stock market was a dangerous place.116 In fact, the two interpretations are not incompatible. In the highly charged atmosphere of the time, de la Vega had every reason to embed his defense of Jews’ involvement in the stock market in an entertaining text that portrayed all shareholders and brokers as callous.

在Confusión de confusiones中，“一个天真的哲学家” 和一个 “离散的商人” 试图了解股票市场的 “神秘事务”；一个 “知识渊博的股东” 在四个 “好奇的对话” 中回答他们的问题。114乔纳森·伊斯雷尔（Jonathan Israel）提醒我们，阿姆斯特丹的犹太人强烈赞成（并在经济上支持）奥兰治的威廉的军事计划，但经常被描绘成不爱国。在他的解读中，德拉维加正是在 1688 年 5 月威廉的远征消息公开后开始写书，并在 8 月股票价值暴跌后完成。对以色列来说，德拉维加的目的之一是洗刷犹太人的名声，因为他们被视为在一定收益的虚假承诺下诱使大量谦虚的人进入股票市场。115另一些人则认为，《困惑》缺乏任何原创的经济见解，其目的只是为了娱乐读者，同时让他们感觉到股市是一个危险的地方。116事实上，这两种解释并不相悖。在当时高度紧张的气氛中，德拉维加完全有理由将他对犹太人参与股市的辩护嵌入一个娱乐性的文本中，将所有的股东和经纪人描绘成冷酷无情。

In truth, there are scant explicit references to Jews in the book, which, in the words of a specialist of Dutch Jewry, “contains no reference whatsoever to halakhic issues, and in fact totally ignores any specific Jewish questions” because “the stock exchange was considered to be outside the bounds of Jewish life.”117 An indirect reference can be found in the last chapter, arguably written after the dramatic stock dive of the summer of 1688, in which de la Vega describes “the climax of the exchange transactions” and deplores a new type of share called the ducaton , which Jewish brokers apparently used disproportionally and which had enticed “so many men with small means” to invest in stocks and lose everything.118

事实上，书中很少明确提到犹太人，用一位荷兰犹太人专家的话说，“书中根本没有提到哈雷克问题，事实上完全忽略了任何具体的犹太问题”，因为 “证券交易所被认为是在犹太人生活的范围之外”。117在最后一章中可以找到一个间接的参考，可以说是在 1688 年夏天股票大幅跳水之后写的，在这一章中，德拉维加描述了 “交易所交易的高潮”，并对一种叫做 “ducaton” 的新型股票表示遗憾，犹太经纪人显然过多地使用这种股票，这种股票吸引了 “许多财力有限的人” 投资于股票并失去一切。118

Written in Castilian and dedicated to a fellow Sephardi, Confusión de confusiones made for a more entertaining read than the standard manual of instructions but was also longwinded and enigmatic. Neither a merchant nor a stock trader, de la Vega had no direct knowledge of business or its relevant technical literature.119 Ultimately, he exploited the literary device of the dialogue as a way to avoid dogmatism and air opposing views. To counter the Philosopher’s scorn of the “frightful folly” in which “gamblers and speculators” are all “double-dealers,” he had the Shareholder make a detailed case for how it is possible to invest with moderation and avoid “excesses.”120

《困惑》是用卡斯蒂利亚语写的，献给一位塞法尔人朋友，比标准的说明手册更有娱乐性，但也很冗长，令人费解。德拉维加既不是商人也不是股票交易商，对商业或其相关的技术文献没有直接的了解。119最终，他利用了对话这一文学手段，作为避免教条主义和宣扬反对意见的一种方式。为了反驳哲学家对 “赌徒和投机者” 都是 “双重交易者” 的 “可怕的愚蠢” 的蔑视，他让股东详细说明了如何能够适度投资并避免 “过度”。120

For our purposes, it is important to note that de la Vega never hinted at the legend that attributed to medieval Jews the invention of marine insurance and bills of exchange. To set up his case, the treatise had the Merchant praise the stock market for avoiding the complications of commodity trade (“the importunities of instructions, the shipment of goods, and the circulation of bills of exchange are all so burdensome”).121 In any case, in 1688, five years after the translation of Savary’s Le parfait négociant into Dutch, the legend only carried negative connotations in the United Provinces, so mentioning it would not have provided a defense of Jews’ financial roles. That said, we should dig deeper into the ways in which early modern Jewish authors did—and did not—grapple with the legend as it spread across Europe.

就我们的目的而言，重要的是要注意，德拉维加从未暗示过将海事保险和汇票的发明归功于中世纪犹太人的传说。为了阐述他的观点，该论文让商人称赞股票市场避免了商品贸易的复杂性（“指示的进口、货物的运输和汇票的流通都是如此繁琐”）。121无论如何，在 1688 年，也就是萨瓦里的Le parfait négociant被翻译成荷兰语的五年之后，这个传说在联合省只带有负面的含义，所以提到它不会为犹太人的金融角色提供辩护。也就是说，我们应该更深入地研究现代早期犹太作家在这个传说传播到欧洲时是如何处理的，又是如何不处理的。

Jewish Voices

犹太之声

Silence is difficult to interpret, but it can be loud. Few Jewish writers before emancipation broached economic subjects in works written in European vernaculars. In the seventeenth century, two rabbis, Simone Luzzatto and Menasseh ben Israel, took it upon themselves to address Christian secular authorities in Venice and London, respectively, with eloquent defenses of Jewish commerce (chapter 5 ). A century later, in Amsterdam, the Sephardic layman Isaac de Pinto (1717–1787), an author even more prominent than de la Vega, wrote several works in Portuguese and French. None of them, however, alluded to the possibility that Jews might have invented marine insurance or bills of exchange. Their reticence should not go unnoticed.

沉默是难以解释的，但它可以是响亮的。在解放前，很少有犹太作家在用欧洲白话文写的作品中涉及经济主题。十七世纪，两位拉比西蒙·卢扎托和梅纳塞·本·以色列分别向威尼斯和伦敦的基督教世俗当局发表演讲，雄辩地捍卫了犹太人的 （第 5 章）。一个世纪后，在阿姆斯特丹，塞法尔族的普通人艾萨克·德·平托（1717-1787）是一位比德拉维加更著名的作家，他用葡萄牙语和法语写了几部作品。然而，他们都没有提到犹太人可能发明了海事保险或汇票的可能性。他们的沉默不应该被忽视。
