To counter the threat of expulsion faced by Venetian Jews in the 1630s, Luzzatto exaggerated the influence of Jewish merchants beyond any reasonable degree to demonstrate Jews’ utility to society and the state. In the process, he anticipated later arguments by attributing Jews’ contributions to the Venetian economy to structural conditions rather than innate skills: their geographical dispersal, exclusion from artisanal guilds and real estate ownership, and access to Ottoman markets, he posited, led Jews to specialize in overseas trade.122 A decade before Cleirac put the legend into circulation, Luzzatto cleverly appropriated negative stereotypes about Jews’ economic conduct to defend their basic existence in a seventeenth-century mercantilist state.

为了应对威尼斯犹太人在 1630 年代面临的驱逐威胁，卢扎托将犹太商人的影响力夸大到任何合理的程度，以证明犹太人对社会和国家的效用。在这个过程中，他预见到了后来的论点，将犹太人对威尼斯经济的贡献归因于结构性条件，而不是先天的技能：他认为，他们在地理上的分散，被排除在工匠行会和房地产所有权之外，以及进入奥斯曼市场的机会，导致犹太人专门从事海外贸易。122在克莱拉克将这一传说流传开来的十年前，卢扎托（Luzzatto）巧妙地挪用了关于犹太人经济行为的负面成见，为他们在十七世纪重商主义国家的基本存在进行辩护。

Luzzatto had considerable knowledge of the financial instruments used by international merchants, including bills of exchange. He probably issued the most lenient ruling a rabbi had delivered up to that moment in favor of those credit instruments that, according to stricter interpretations of Jewish law, infringed on usury prohibitions.123 However, he did not mention the Jewish invention of bills of exchange when describing Jews’ commercial talents in his plea to the Venetian authorities. Nor did Menasseh ben Israel in his “Humble Addresses” to Oliver Cromwell, which borrowed generously from Luzzatto’s arguments. Ben Israel’s silence is even more revealing than Luzzatto’s, because his apologetics stressed the “naturall instinct” for commerce with which “Providence and mercy of God” had endowed the Jews in the diaspora.124 His choice was in sync with that of most supporters of the 1656 readmission of Jews, among whom many were Puritans, who shunned economic arguments in favor of those predicated on religious millenarianism.125

卢扎托对国际商人使用的金融工具，包括汇票，有相当的了解。他可能发布了一个拉比到那时为止最宽松的裁决，以支持这些信贷工具，根据对犹太法的更严格解释，这些信贷工具违反了高利贷禁令。123然而，他在向威尼斯当局提出的请求中描述犹太人的商业才能时，并没有提到犹太人发明的汇票。梅纳塞·本·伊斯雷尔在他给奥利弗·克伦威尔的 “谦卑的讲话” 中也没有提到，该讲话慷慨地借用了卢扎托的论点。本·伊斯雷尔的沉默比卢扎托的沉默更有说服力，因为他的辩解强调了 “上帝的天意和怜悯” 赋予散居在外的犹太人的 “自然商业本能”。124他的选择与 1656 年重新接纳犹太人的大多数支持者的选择是一致的，其中许多人是清教徒，他们回避经济论点，而支持那些以宗教千禧年为前提的论点。125

Best known for his rebuttal of Voltaire’s disparaging attacks on Jews, de Pinto moved in high social and literary circles in Amsterdam, Paris, and London, and even tried his hand at international diplomacy.126 His economic writings in French, aimed at a gentile audience, largely avoided any specifically Jewish themes.127 However, they offered forceful and learned defenses of the economic policies and attitudes that favored the types of activities in which Jews were most involved. Weighing in on a controversy that was raging at the time, de Pinto denounced the equation of luxury with corruption and challenged the physiocratic doctrines of the Marquis of Mirabeau, the Count of Mirabeau’s father, which put agriculture ahead of commerce, as well as Hume’s denunciation of spiraling national debt.128 Instead, he glorified both public and private credit. In passing, he praised Iberian Jews as honest, industrious, and good subjects, but mostly left it to his readers to infer that Jews made positive contributions to the economic activities for which he advocated.129

德·平托以反驳伏尔泰对犹太人的轻蔑攻击而闻名，他在阿姆斯特丹、巴黎和伦敦的高级社会和文学界活动，甚至还尝试过国际外交。126他用法语写的经济著作，针对的是外邦人读者，基本上避免了任何具体的犹太主题。127然而，他们对有利于犹太人参与最多的活动类型的经济政策和态度进行了有力的、博学的辩护。德·平托参与了当时的一场争论，他谴责将奢侈品等同于腐败，并对米拉波侯爵（米拉波伯爵的父亲）将农业置于商业之上的生理学说以及休谟对不断攀升的国债的谴责提出质疑。128相反，他美化了公共和私人信贷。他顺便赞扬了伊比利亚的犹太人是诚实、勤劳和优秀的臣民，但主要是让他的读者来推断犹太人对他所倡导的经济活动做出了积极贡献。129

As noted earlier, we have no way of knowing whether the legend of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange existed in oral form before Cleirac published his commentary on the Rouen rules about maritime insurance. What we do know is that even if it did, Jewish authors did not embrace it as a weapon of self-defense. We also know that they hesitated to use it even after Montesquieu gave the tale of Jewish financial creativity a positive spin. De Pinto cited or echoed Montesquieu more than once in his arguments in favor of commerce but never recounted the version of the legend that appeared in The Spirit of the Laws . A century and a half would pass after the appearance of Cleirac’s commentary of 1647 before a Jewish author felt he could commit the narrative to print.130

如前所述，我们无从得知，在克莱拉克发表他对鲁昂海事保险规则的评注之前，犹太人发明汇票的传说是否以口头形式存在。我们知道的是，即使存在，犹太作者也没有把它作为一种自卫的武器来接受。我们还知道，即使在孟德斯鸠为犹太人的金融创造力的故事赋予了积极的意义之后，他们也对使用它犹豫不决。德·平托在支持商业的论点中不止一次地引用或呼应孟德斯鸠的观点，但从未叙述过《法律的精神》中出现的那个版本的传说。在克里拉克 1647 年的评论出现后，一个半世纪过去了，才有一位犹太作家认为他可以将这一叙事付诸印刷。130

That task fell to Isaac D’Israeli, father of the future British prime minister Benjamin Disraeli, in his Vaurien , a minor satirical novel published in 1797 that was meant to expose the superficiality of his age. Finance was one of the novel’s targets, alongside French “philosophie” and republicanism. “Enormous wealth is obtained by speculations; we have become a nation of jobbers,” the book declared.131 Unlike his Tory predecessors, D’Israeli used the term “jobbers” to refer to all Britons, not Jews alone. A fierce critic of traditional Judaism, he described Vaurien, the novel’s main character, as a “Jewish philosopher,” a pork-eating fellow and admirer of Moses Mendelssohn who exposes the absurdity of many prejudices targeting Jews while expressing other prejudices of his own, such as the alleged contrast between “the physiognomy as well as the customs” of Sephardic and Ashkenazic Jews.132 For Vaurien, the Jews’ “commercial character” is the result, not the cause, of their dispersal and suffering: “Christian injustice produced Jewish usury” and turned Jews into “objects of national pillage.”133 In a historical commentary appended to this fictional speech, D’Israeli added: “Despair with the Jews was the parent of invention, and bills of exchange were imagined by them.”134

这项任务落在了未来的英国首相本杰明·迪斯雷利的父亲艾萨克·德伊西的身上，他在 1797 年出版的一部小型讽刺小说《小流氓》（Vaurien）中，意在揭露其时代的肤浅性。金融是这部小说的目标之一，此外还有法国的 “哲学” 和共和主义。“该书宣称：” 巨大的财富是通过投机获得的；我们已经成为一个打工仔的国家。131与他的保守党前辈们不同，德伊西用 “打工者” 这个词来指代所有英国人，而不仅仅是犹太人。作为一个对传统犹太教的激烈批评者，他将小说的主角沃里安描述为一个 “犹太哲学家”，一个吃猪肉的家伙和摩西·门德尔松的崇拜者，他揭露了许多针对犹太人的偏见的荒谬性，同时表达了他自己的其他偏见，例如所谓的塞法尔犹太人和阿什肯纳兹犹太人的 “容貌和习俗” 之间的对比。132对沃里安来说，犹太人的 “商业特性” 是他们被驱散和遭受痛苦的结果，而不是原因。“基督教的不公正产生了犹太人的高利贷”，并使犹太人成为 “民族掠夺的对象”。133在这篇虚构的演讲所附的历史评论中，达伊西补充说：“犹太人的绝望是发明的根源，汇票是他们想象出来的”。134

In short, D’Israeli embraced and magnified Montesquieu’s positive depiction of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange. More than Montesquieu, he linked Jews’ persecution explicitly to their creativity. Writing only a few years after the emancipation of French Jews, however, he did not attach any political valence to the legend, in spite of the fact that Jews in Britain remained legally dis advantaged. His contribution resided elsewhere. A Jewish author, D’Israeli espoused and amplified Montesquieu’s idea that Jews had played a pivotal role in the arc of European civilization. He thus advanced a current of Jewish scholarship that flourished throughout the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries and that had as its objective the enumeration of “Jewish contributions to civilization.”135 In a later publication titled The Genius of Judaism (1833), D’Israeli expanded on his earlier argument: forced into “the most humiliating industry,” that is, “the commerce of money,” he declared, Jews were able to bring it “to a noble perfection”; by rendering fortunes invisible, “their genius produced the wonderful invention of bills of exchange,” which, together with “the art of printing . . . are sources of civilization, and connect together, as in one commonwealth, the whole universe.” Eventually, though, he added, the Jews’ “successful pursuits worked their own fatality.”136 Resentment followed triumph and led Christians to victimize those who had given them access to the most useful financial tools.

简而言之，达伊西接受并放大了孟德斯鸠对犹太人发明汇票的正面描述。与孟德斯鸠相比，他更多地将犹太人受到的迫害与他们的创造力明确地联系起来。然而，在法国犹太人获得解放仅几年之后，他并没有给这个传说附加任何政治价值，尽管英国的犹太人在法律上仍然处于不利地位。他的贡献在于其他方面。作为一名犹太作家，达伊西拥护并扩大了孟德斯鸠的观点，即犹太人在欧洲文明的发展过程中发挥了关键作用。因此，他推动了整个 19 世纪和 20 世纪初蓬勃发展的犹太学术潮流，并将列举 “犹太人对文明的贡献” 作为其目标。135在后来出版的《犹太教的天才》（1833）中，达伊西扩大了他先前的论点：他宣称，犹太人被迫从事 “最屈辱的行业”，即 “货币贸易”，但他们却能使其 “达到高贵的完美”；通过使财富不可见，“他们的天才创造了奇妙的汇票发明”，这与 “印刷术…… 是文明的来源，并将整个宇宙连接在一起，如同一个联邦。” 不过，他补充说，犹太人的 “成功追求最终导致了他们自己的死亡”。136胜利后的怨恨导致基督徒伤害了那些让他们获得最有用的金融工具的人。

In the end, D’Israeli’s treatment of the legend of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange sheds new light on two important discourses. Once introduced into the genre of Jewish contributions to civilization, the legend came to occupy a niche in Jews’ collective self-fashioning. In the 1820s, for example, in a petition to Pope Leo XII, the Jews of Rome listed their ancestors’ invention of bills of exchange and banking as evidence of the positive influence Jews had on industry and commerce everywhere, as well as their ability to incite emulation among non-Jews.137 Furthermore, D’Israeli’s emphasis on Christian resentment of Jewish financial inventiveness—an emphasis that, as we saw, the German Cameralist Fischer had recently aired—replaced Montesquieu’s version of the legend and became a new topos. As Michael Toch has demonstrated, and as the next chapter will show, nineteenth-century German academic works, whether by antisemitic scholars or Jewish apologists, cultivated the idea that Jews had dominated international trade in the early Middle Ages before being reduced to the status of pawnbrokers in the thirteenth century.138 The systematic reconstruction of the legend’s meandering paths that this and earlier chapters have pursued thus reveals something new about how this well-known scholarly consensus came to be.

最后，达伊西对犹太人发明汇票的传说的处理，为两个重要的论述提供了新的启示。一旦被引入犹太人对文明的贡献这一类型，这个传说就在犹太人的集体自我塑造中占据了一席之地。例如，在 19 世纪 20 年代，罗马的犹太人在给教皇利奥十二世的请愿书中列出了他们祖先发明的汇票和银行业务，作为犹太人对各地工业和商业产生积极影响的证据，以及他们煽动非犹太人效仿的能力。137此外，达伊西强调基督教对犹太人的金融发明的怨恨 —— 正如我们所看到的，德国的菲舍尔（Cameralist Fischer）最近也强调了这一点 —— 取代了孟德斯鸠的传奇版本，成为一个新的主题。正如迈克尔·托赫（Michael Toch）所证明的，也正如下一章所显示的，19 世纪的德国学术作品，无论是反犹太主义学者还是犹太教辩护士，都培养了这样一种观念，即犹太人在中世纪早期主导了国际贸易，然后在 13 世纪沦为典当商的地位。138因此，本章和前几章对这一传说的蜿蜒路径进行的系统重建，揭示了关于这一众所周知的学术共识是如何形成的新情况。

Conclusion

总结

Geologists designate as karstic certain landscapes, such as the borderlands between Italy and Slovenia, in which surface and groundwaters shape the terrain of soluble rocks by carving out large caves beneath the soil. Karstic landscapes are a topography of sinkholes and streams that disappear abruptly where they seep into the ground. Most streams continue to flow underground, but occasionally, some reemerge and erode the surface, only to run underground again at a later point—a process that is repeated over time. Scientists have only a modest ability to predict the courses of these aquifers—that is, when and where they will resurface and how they will mold the soil. By analogy, we can think of the discursive and material contexts covered in this chapter as soluble rocks and the manifold versions of the legend of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange as the corrosive streams that plunge underground and reappear from time to time—never in exactly the same guise, sometimes leaving only a minor trace, and other times creating more durable paths.

地质学家将某些景观指定为喀斯特地貌，如意大利和斯洛文尼亚之间的边境地区，其中地表水和地下水通过在土壤下刻出大的洞穴来塑造可溶岩的地形。喀斯特地貌是一种天坑和溪流的地形，它们在渗入地下的地方突然消失 。大多数溪流继续在地下流淌，但偶尔，一些溪流重新出现并侵蚀地表，只是在稍后的时间点再次流入地下 —— 这一过程随着时间的推移而重复。科学家们对于预测这些含水层的走向，也就是预测它们何时何地会重新浮出水面，以及它们将如何塑造土壤，仅有一点能力。通过类比，我们可以把本章所涉及的话语和物质背景看作是可溶性的岩石，把犹太人发明汇票的多种版本的传说看作是陷入地下并不时重新出现的腐蚀性溪流，它们从未以完全相同的面貌出现，有时只留下轻微的痕迹，有时则创造出更持久的路径。

This analogy brings into relief some of the challenges we confront when we attempt to uncover how ideas are forged, disseminated, and refashioned. A number of cultural and intellectual historians have made creative use of the term “morphology,” a neologism coined by Goethe while touring the botanical gardens of southern Italy and now the name of a branch of biology and linguistics, in order to make sense of similarities between ideas and cultural forms that manifest in disparate times and places and that, in the absence of direct lines of transmission, might otherwise seem unrelated. Critics have faulted these efforts for their tendency to recognize certain equivalences and not others or to overplay analogies between different versions of the same trope in spite of the fact that those differences might be equally revealing.139

这个比喻使我们在试图揭示思想是如何形成、传播和重塑的过程中所面临的一些挑战得以缓解。一些文化和思想史学家创造性地使用了 “形态学” 一词，这是歌德在游览意大利南部植物园时创造的一个新名词，现在是生物学和语言学的一个分支的名称，目的是使那些在不同的时间和地点出现的思想和文化形式之间的相似性有意义，如果没有直接的传播途径，它们可能看起来毫无关联。批评者指责这些努力倾向于承认某些等同性而不承认其他的等同性，或者过分渲染同一套路的不同版本之间的类比，尽管这些差异可能同样具有揭示性。139

By choosing karstic topography rather than morphology as a metaphor, I emphasize the intricate and sometimes unpredictable webs of meaning that connected a wide range of associations between Jews and credit across the landscape that I have surveyed. I do so to account for a central struggle of my inquiry: after the late Middle Ages, Christian associations of Jews with money displayed remarkable stability because they combined and recombined a set of preexisting tropes, yet these associations were not immutable. Our task is to interpret small differences, the hardest ones to decipher. To do so requires that we stress the permanence of discursive traditions alongside local struggles and the intentional disturbance introduced by certain authors while simultaneously making room for contingency—a balancing act that is hard to capture in a single formula but that I attempt to perform throughout the entire book.

通过选择岩溶地形而不是形态学作为隐喻，我强调了错综复杂、有时难以预测的意义之网，它将我所调查的景观中犹太人与信贷之间的广泛联系联系起来。我这样做是为了说明我的调查的一个核心斗争：在中世纪晚期之后，基督教对犹太人与金钱的关联表现出显著的稳定性，因为它们结合并重新组合了一套预先存在的套路，但这些关联并不是一成不变的。我们的任务是解释小的差异，即最难破译的差异。要做到这一点，我们需要强调话语传统的持久性，同时强调地方斗争和某些作者引入的有意干扰，同时为偶然性留出空间 —— 这是很难用一个公式来捕捉的平衡行为，但我试图在整本书中进行这种平衡。

Not every narrative of the development of European commercial society, even those found in merchant handbooks, focused on the introduction of bills of exchange. In the stadial conception of history embraced by John Locke, Hume, and Smith, the key moment in this narrative hinged on the earlier transition from barter, the hallmark of primitive societies, to market exchanges mediated via money (initially understood as a metallic currency), a transition that was less the result of state intervention (a later thesis known as Chartalism) than the continuation of the natural progressive arc of commerce’s civilizing mission. Espoused and advanced by the Scottish Enlightenment, this influential account also explains why the legend of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange never took center stage in the eighteenth century’s most canonic works of “economics,” which focused on the transition from barter to money and on the public debt more than on paper instruments of private credit.140 In Gerard Malynes’s widely read compilation of merchant customs and norms, for example, the appearance of metallic money (there dated to 300 BCE Rome) marked the momentous beginning of a new historical phase. The subsequent creation of “exchange by bills for moneys” was simply a response to the dual challenge of carrying precious metal and converting the huge variety of currencies that were then in circulation.141

并非所有关于欧洲商业社会发展的叙述，甚至是那些在商人手册中发现的叙述，都集中在汇票的引入上。在约翰·洛克、休谟和斯密所接受的历史分期概念中，这种叙述的关键时刻取决于早期的过渡，即从原始社会的标志 —— 易货贸易到通过货币（最初被理解为金属货币）进行的市场交换，这种过渡与其说是国家干预的结果（后来被称为 Chartalism 的理论），不如说是商业的文明使命的自然渐进弧线的延续。在苏格兰启蒙运动的支持和推动下，这种有影响力的说法也解释了为什么犹太人发明汇票的传说从未在 18 世纪最经典的 “经济学” 作品中占据中心位置，这些作品关注从易货贸易到货币的过渡，关注公共债务而不是私人信贷的纸质工具。140例如，在杰拉德·马林斯广为流传的商人习俗和规范汇编中，金属货币的出现（可追溯到公元前 300 年的罗马）标志着一个新历史阶段的重大开始。随后创造的 “以票换钱” 只是为了应对携带贵金属和兑换当时流通的大量货币的双重挑战。141

Interest in the transition from barter to money has similarly preoccupied modern scholars, even if they have debunked the idea that barter ever existed as a primordial and self-contained historical stage, and has thus distracted their attention from the existence of contemporaneous debates on the origins of what were once the most sophisticated paper instruments of private credit, notably premium insurance and bills of exchange. What this scholarship has failed to note is that, for a great many early modern writers, and obviously for Montesquieu, it was the transition from metallic currencies to bills of exchange that inaugurated a new era in the history of European commercial society—a transition depicted in unconditionally positive terms by the French philosophe and in more sober tones by those who praised the virtues of bills of exchange but worried about their unfettered diffusion.

对从易货贸易到货币的过渡的兴趣也同样困扰着现代学者，即使他们已经驳斥了易货贸易曾经作为一个原始和自足的历史阶段而存在的观点，并因此分散了他们对同时代存在的关于曾经是最复杂的私人信贷纸质工具，特别是保险费和汇票的起源的辩论的注意力。这种学术研究没有注意到的是，对许多早期现代作家来说，显然对孟德斯鸠来说，正是从金属货币到汇票的过渡开创了欧洲商业社会历史的新时代 —— 法国哲学家以无条件的积极术语描述了这种过渡，而那些赞扬汇票的优点但担心其不受约束的传播的人则以更清醒的语气描述了这种过渡。

The significance attributed to the replacement of coins with bills of exchange predated the fictitious account penned by Cleirac. By the mid-sixteenth century, Italian and Spanish authors had outlined an enduring counternarrative of this shift: merchants’ industriousness, not the prodigious talents of one refugee group or another, had led to the creation of new instruments capable of transferring money across regions for the purpose of moving goods from where they were abundant to where they were scarce, thus multiplying the beneficial effects of trade.142 In Germany possibly more than elsewhere, works of jurisprudence and merchant handbooks both adopted this naturalist thesis. A young German jurist wrote in 1646 that “the law of nations and necessity introduced exchange operations, which civil law confirmed and customs approved of.”143 A German guide to commerce drew a parallel with biological reproduction: “The bill of exchange with its laws was born from commerce like a child from his mother.”144 Recapitulating existing theories on the origins of marine insurance, a jurist and civic leader in Lübeck, a Hanseatic town with a long maritime and commercial tradition, noted that some believed it existed in Roman law under different names, while others dated it to the the fourteenth or fifteenth century.145

用汇票取代硬币的意义早于克莱拉克的虚构描述。到了 16 世纪中叶，意大利和西班牙的作者已经为这一转变勾勒出了一个持久的反面教材：商人的勤奋，而不是某个难民群体的杰出才能，导致了新工具的产生，这些工具能够跨地区转移货币，将货物从充足的地方转移到稀缺的地方，从而使贸易的有利影响成倍增加。142在德国，可能比其他地方更多的法学作品和商人手册都采用了这种自然主义的理论。一位年轻的德国法学家在 1646 年写道：“万国法和必要性引入了交换业务，民法对此予以确认，习俗”。143德国的一份商业指南将其与生物繁殖相提并论。“汇票及其法律是从商业中诞生的，就像一个孩子从他的母亲那里诞生一样”。144吕贝克是一个具有悠久海洋和商业传统的汉萨城市，在总结关于海事保险起源的现有理论时，一位法学家和公民领袖指出，有些人认为它以不同的名称存在于罗马法中，而另一些人则将它追溯到 14 或 15 世纪。145

A lively discussion about the process through which credit instruments emerged and developed was thus already underway when Cleirac entered it, but his influence on the debate remained conspicuous for a good 250 years. After the mid-seventeenth century, the majority of European authors who discussed the origins of bills of exchange or marine insurance mentioned medieval Jews as being among the possible candidates for these instruments’ inventors—whether the discussions sought to endorse that hypothesis, disprove it, or, most often, contemplate it alongside others. If early modern debates about the emergence of bills of exchange are our karstic landscape and the various theories about their origins are the aquatic streams, then Cleirac, Dupuis de la Serra, and Montesquieu can be seen as headwaters, because each of them put forward a strong theory with which others contended. But because of the mysteries of karstic connections, we also need to pay attention to the multiple and intersecting streams that molded a landscape that in the eighteenth century became more trafficked and intricate.

因此，当克莱拉克参与讨论时，一场关于信用工具产生和发展过程的热烈讨论已经开始，但他对这场辩论的影响在 250 年里一直很明显。17 世纪中叶以后，大多数讨论汇票或海事保险起源的欧洲作者都提到中世纪的犹太人是这些工具发明者的可能人选之一 —— 无论这些讨论是试图认可这一假设，还是否定这一假设，或者最常见的是将其与其他假设放在一起考虑。如果说早期现代关于汇票出现的辩论是我们的喀斯特地貌，关于其起源的各种理论是水生的溪流，那么克莱拉克、杜普伊斯·德拉·塞拉和孟德斯鸠可以被视为源头，因为他们每个人都提出了一个强有力的理论，而其他人则与之争论。但由于喀斯特地貌连接的神秘性，我们还需要注意多种和交叉的溪流，这些溪流塑造了一个在十八世纪变得更加交通和复杂的景观。

The multiplication of printed works, including serial publications such as encyclopedias and dictionaries, occurred at a time of weak standards for plagiarism and paved the way for the propagation of a trope that sometimes appeared as little more than a casual reference. All in all, authorial credibility was paramount in the dissemination of ideas, and few authors were seen as so authoritative as Montesquieu. His was indeed the most consistent stream through which the legend infiltrated different corners of Europe. The Scottish Jacobite exile to France James Steuart, the German Cameralist Bielfeld (who wrote in French), the son of a leading Huguenot pastor living in Berlin Louis de Beausobre (1730–1783), and the Milanese professor of political economy Cesare Beccaria (whose disquisition on the subject appeared simultaneously in Italian, French, and English) did more than any others to embed the legend of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange in a progressive narrative of European commercial society inspired directly by Montesquieu. Like their muse, they were less concerned with the history of Jews than with the allegorical power of the episode.

印刷作品，包括百科全书和字典等系列出版物的增多，发生在抄袭标准薄弱的时期，为这种有时只是随意提及的特例的传播铺平了道路。总而言之，在思想的传播中，作者的可信度是最重要的，很少有作者被视为像孟德斯鸠那样的权威。他的确是传奇故事渗透到欧洲不同角落的最稳定的流向。流亡到法国的苏格兰雅各布派詹姆斯·斯蒂亚特、德国卡梅拉尔德（用法语写作）、居住在柏林的胡格诺派主要牧师的儿子路易斯·德·博索尔（1730-1783）以及米兰的政治经济学教授切萨雷·贝卡里亚（他对这个问题的论述同时出现在意大利语、法语和英语中）比其他任何人都更努力将犹太人发明汇票的传说嵌入由孟德斯鸠直接启发的欧洲商业社会的进步叙述中。和他们的缪斯一样，他们对犹太人的历史并不关心，而是关心这一事件的寓意。

Not everyone agrees with me on this point. Beausobre included the fictional narrative of the invention of bills of exchange at the hands of medieval Jews fleeing France in his treatment of the history of banking.146 Miriam Yardeni takes him literally and, ignoring the derivation of his passage, interprets it as “a factual report, devoid of ethical considerations of persecution as such.” Instead of viewing his account of Jews’ financial talent as a tale with a long past, she considers it exemplary of a growing tendency among second-generation Huguenot exiles, particularly those in Berlin, who had not experienced persecution firsthand, to be “more level-headed and perhaps more objective” with regard to Jews.147 From everything I have said thus far, it is clear that the legend relayed by Beausobre hardly warrants this literal interpretation. There is no doubt that Huguenot exiles such as Pierre Bayle (1647–1706) and Henri (1615–1710) and Jacques (1653–1723) Basnage de Beauval advanced the cause of religious toleration more than most in their time, but neither their work nor Montesquieu’s portrayal of Jews as the engines of commercial society qualify as examples of objective inquiry.

在这一点上，并非所有人都同意我的观点。博索尔在处理银行业的历史时，将中世纪逃亡法国的犹太人发明汇票的虚构叙述纳入其中。146米利亚姆·亚德尼从字面上理解他，并忽略了他这段话的引申，将其解释为 “一个事实性的报告，没有对迫害本身的伦理考虑”。她没有把他对犹太人的金融才能的描述看作是一个有着悠久历史的故事，而是认为这体现了第二代胡格诺派流亡者，特别是那些在柏林的流亡者，由于没有亲身经历过迫害，对犹太人 “更加平和，也许更加客观” 的趋势正在增长。147从我到目前为止所说的一切来看，很明显，博索布转述的传说几乎没有理由作出这种字面解释。毫无疑问，皮埃尔·贝勒（1647-1706）和亨利（1615-1710）和雅克（1653-1723）-巴斯纳吉·德·博瓦尔等胡格诺派流亡者比他们那个时代的大多数人更多地推动了宗教宽容事业，但他们的工作和孟德斯鸠把犹太人描绘成商业社会的引擎都没有资格作为客观调查的例子。

The legend’s formulations clearly did not reflect the local conditions of Jewish life mimetically, even when they adapted and incorporated local themes. Overall, I do not detect an increasingly dispassionate ethnographic style in the treatment of Jews in merchant handbooks and commercial literature, in contrast to other genres of Christian writing about Jews.148 In fact, the most serious blows to the historical account on which the legend rested came from French, German, and Italian authors writing in contexts in which Jews were less accepted and were inspired by either regional pride or antiquarian tendencies rather than by any desire to right the record regarding Jewish history. Meanwhile, the legend continued to appear in those contexts in which the place of commerce in national politics and the status of merchants in the social hierarchy remained contested. As its association with bills of exchange evolved to include other financial instruments, the view of Jews as shady manipulators of the stock market solidified even in those places where the degrees of religious toleration were highest—Amsterdam and London (although admittedly England was a distant second best to Amsterdam for Jews in the eighteenth century).

传说的表述显然没有模仿性地反映犹太人生活的当地状况，即使他们改编和吸收了当地的主题。总的来说，我没有发现商人手册和商业文学在对待犹太人方面有越来越冷静的人种学风格，这与基督教关于犹太人的其他类型的写作形成鲜明对比。148事实上，对该传说所依赖的历史叙述最严重的打击来自于法国、德国和意大利的作者，他们在犹太人不太被接受的情况下写作，并且是出于地区自豪感或古物主义倾向，而不是出于纠正犹太人历史记录的愿望。同时，在商业在国家政治中的地位和商人在社会等级制度中的地位仍有争议的情况下，这个传说继续出现。随着它与汇票的联系演变为包括其他金融工具，犹太人作为股票市场的黑幕操纵者的观点甚至在那些宗教宽容度最高的地方 —— 阿姆斯特丹和伦敦 —— 也得到了巩固（尽管在 18 世纪，英国在犹太人方面远远落后于阿姆斯特丹）。

Generations of historians, anthropologists, and literary critics have demonstrated the importance of understanding tales that once held sway over people’s imagination because they disclose forgotten cultural models and their demise. By the close of the eighteenth century, the treatment of the origins of the credit instruments that had propelled European finance to new levels of sophistication was evidence of an enduring dilemma in academic scholarship. Two competing logics—the dogma of Jewish guile and the rise of positivist historical methods—played themselves out as scholars contended with multiple accounts of Europe’s capitalist modernity and the place of Jews in those accounts. As we will see, the tale of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange became a lightning rod in rival narratives of the so-called Rise of the West in the early days of modern European academia.

一代又一代的历史学家、人类学家和文学评论家已经证明了理解那些曾经左右人们想象力的故事的重要性，因为它们披露了被遗忘的文化模式和它们的消亡。到 18 世纪末，对推动欧洲金融业发展到新水平的信贷工具的起源的处理，，证明了学术研究中一个持久的困境。两种相互竞争的逻辑 —— 犹太人狡诈的教条和实证主义历史方法的兴起 —— 在学者们争论欧洲资本主义现代性的多种说法以及犹太人在这些说法中的地位时，发挥了作用。正如我们所看到的，在现代欧洲学术界的早期，犹太人发明汇票的故事成为所谓西方崛起的敌对叙述中的一个闪电棒。

8

A Legacy that Runs Deep

源远流长的遗产

Bills—convenience to the mercantile world,
for which, I believe, we are originally indebted
to the Jews, who appear to me to have had
a devilish deal too much to do with them ever since . . .

票据 —— 给商业界带来的便利，
，我相信，我们最初是欠犹太人的
，在我看来，他们从那时起就与
，有太多的魔鬼般的关系。

—CHARLES DICKENS , DAVID COPPERFIELD (1850)1

查尔斯·狄更斯, 《大卫·科波菲尔》（1850）1

The bill of exchange is the Jew’s real god.
His only god is the illusory bill of exchange.

汇票是犹太人真正的神。
他唯一的神是虚幻的汇票。

—KARLMARX , “ON THE JEWISH QUESTION ” (1844)2

卡尔马克斯，《论犹太人问题》（1844）。2

THE HABIT OF ATTRIBUTING to Jews the invention of bills of exchange reached its zenith in the nineteenth century and percolated into an ever-broader variety of literary and scholarly genres. It left more than a trace in Victorian novels, which often portrayed Jews as usurers and callous social climbers, as the epigraph from Charles Dickens’s David Copperfield indicates.3 It was also a bone of contention for both French enemies and defenders of Jews in the 1880s and 1890s, the period leading up to the Dreyfus affair.4 The possible Jewish origin of European financial instruments was mentioned even more frequently in countless works on maritime and commercial law, bills of exchange and marine insurance, and currency and paper money—a booming literature that encompassed historical studies of the evolution of private contracts for use in long-distance trade and legal treatises designed to clarify the nature of these contracts for either pedagogical purposes or domestic and international codification projects. This nineteenth-century body of work would demand a separate investigation.5

将汇票的发明归于犹太人的习惯在 19 世纪达到顶峰，并渗入到越来越广泛的各种文学和学术流派中。它在维多利亚时代的小说中留下了更多的痕迹，这些小说经常把犹太人描绘成高利贷者和冷酷无情的社会攀比者，正如查尔斯·狄更斯的《大卫·科波菲尔》中的序言所指出的那样。3在 19 世纪 80 年代和 90 年代，即德雷福斯事件之前的那段时间，它也是法国的敌人和犹太人的捍卫者的争论焦点。4在无数关于海商法、汇票和海事保险以及货币和纸币的著作中，欧洲金融工具可能的犹太起源被更频繁地提及 —— 这些繁荣的文献包括对用于长途贸易的私人合同演变的历史研究以及旨在为教学目的或国内和国际编纂项目澄清这些合同的性质的法律论文。这一十九世纪的作品需要单独调查。5

In closing, I will depart from my penchant for lesser figures and focus instead on three giants of modern social thought: Karl Marx (1818–1883), Max Weber (1864–1920), and Werner Sombart (1863–1941). In their efforts to define what constituted modern capitalism and how it came into being, each proposed a different role for Jews. Although only Sombart transformed Jews into key actors in the genesis of Western capitalism, all three thinkers appealed to Jews to define how modern capitalism differed from earlier forms of commercialization. As part of this quest, Sombart proposed yet another version of the legend of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange, which figured front and center in his Die Juden und das Wirtschaftsleben (The Jews and Economic Life ), a text that most economic historians justly dismiss but that has exerted an enormous, troubling, and—as of late—contradictory influence on the field of Jewish history.6

最后，我将背离我对小人物的偏好，转而关注现代社会思想的三位巨头。卡尔·马克思（1818-1883）、马克斯·韦伯（1864-1920）和维尔纳·桑巴特（1863-1941）。在他们定义什么是现代资本主义以及它如何产生的努力中，每个人都为犹太人提出了不同的角色。虽然只有 桑巴特将犹太人转变为西方资本主义起源中的关键角色，但所有三位思想家都呼吁犹太人来定义现代资本主义与早期商业化形式的区别。作为这一探索的一部分，桑巴特提出了另一个版本的犹太人发明汇票的传说，这在他的《犹太人与经济生活》（Die Juden und das Wirtschaftsleben）中占据了前排和中心位置，这是一篇被大多数经济史学家公正地驳回的文本，但它对犹太历史领域产生了巨大的、令人不安的、以及最近自相矛盾的影响。6

My treatment of these complex authors bears directly on the three broad themes that I identified in the introduction and have addressed throughout the book. The first is the question of what constitutes a canonical work in the history of economic thought and how those works shaped European ideas about the birth of capitalism. The previous chapters have demonstrated that Étienne Cleirac’s Us et coustumes de la mer (1647), now almost completely forgotten, once represented a crucial point of reference that spun the legend of the Jewish invention of marine insurance and bills of exchange in myriad directions. A short piece on the economic role of Jews in medieval Europe published in 1875 by Wilhelm Roscher (1817–1894) met a similar fate: although today only a few specialists know it, the theory it advanced became canonical in the last quarter of the nineteenth century. One simply cannot understand Sombart’s views of Jews and capitalism without reference to Roscher’s.

我对这些复杂的作者的处理直接关系到我在导言中确定的并在全书中涉及的三个广泛的主题。首先是什么构成了经济思想史上的经典作品，以及这些作品如何塑造了欧洲关于资本主义诞生的思想。前面几章已经证明，艾蒂安·克莱拉克的《海洋的用途和习俗》（1647），现在几乎完全被遗忘，曾经代表了一个关键的参考点，将犹太人发明海事保险和汇票的传说推向了无数的方向。威廉·罗舍尔（Wilhelm Roscher，1817-1894）在 1875 年发表的一篇关于犹太人在中世纪欧洲的经济作用的短文也遇到了类似的命运：虽然今天只有少数专家知道它，但它提出的理论在 19 世纪最后四分之一的时间里成为了经典。如果不参考罗舍尔的理论，我们根本无法理解桑巴特对犹太人和资本主义的看法。

A deeper link than their relative obscurity connects Cleirac to Roscher. In light of the analysis of the place of Jews in the economic literature that I have conducted this far, Marx, Roscher, and Sombart appear as the heirs of, or at least as profoundly influenced by, early modern economic debates. From that previous era they inherited both their familiarity with the legend of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange and their tendency to stress the “Jewishness” of early capitalism. Weber broke with this tendency and inaugurated the process of the Christianization of capitalism that became dominant in the twentieth century. By the interwar period, leading medievalists of all persuasions— Marxists and non-Marxists, some more indebted to Weber than others, many (but not all) Catholics, and a few flirting with fascism—reacted against the then-emergent consensus that relegated the Middle Ages to a precapitalist phase of European civilization. These scholars reaffirmed the importance of late medieval economic growth in several ways, simultaneously rejecting the significance their predecessors attributed to medieval Jews in the making of modern capitalism.

比起他们的相对默默无闻，一种更深的联系将克莱拉克和罗舍尔联系在一起。根据我到目前为止对犹太人在经济文献中的地位所做的分析，马克思、罗舍尔和桑巴特似乎是早期现代经济辩论的继承者，或者至少是受其深刻影响的继承者。他们从那个时代继承了对犹太人发明汇票的传说的熟悉，以及强调早期资本主义的 “犹太性” 的倾向。韦伯打破了这种倾向，开启了资本主义基督教化的进程，这一进程在 20 世纪成为主流。到了战时，各种观点的主要中世纪学者 —— 马克思主义者和非马克思主义者，有些人比其他人更依赖韦伯，许多 （但不是全部）天主教徒，还有一些人与法西斯主义调情 —— 对当时出现的将中世纪归入欧洲文明的前资本主义阶段的共识作出了反应。这些学者以多种方式重申了中世纪晚期经济增长的重要性，同时拒绝了他们的前辈在现代资本主义形成过程中赋予中世纪犹太人的意义。

This observation feeds into my second concern, which is with periodization, and specifically with competing views of the way in which the transition from the medieval period to (early) modernity unfolded. The historical narrative of the supposed invention and dissemination of bills of exchange relayed by Cleirac implied a continuity between the medieval expulsions of French Jews and the seventeenth-century primacy of Amsterdam as a financial center. In both contexts Christian finance was seen as tainted by its Jewish origins. By contrast, Montesquieu’s refashioning of the legend presumed a sharp break between a medieval period during which the despised activities of trade and moneylending were understood as the prerogatives of Jews and a new phase in European history, located around the time of the transoceanic voyages by Columbus and Vasco da Gama, when the church retreated from the influential position it held in politics and society and commerce gained both independence from rulers’ arbitrary power and respectability.

这一观察与我的第二个关注点相吻合，那就是时代化，特别是关于从中世纪向（早期）现代性过渡的方式的竞争性观点。克莱拉克转述的所谓汇票的发明和传播的历史叙事意味着中世纪对法国犹太人的驱逐和十七世纪阿姆斯特丹作为金融中心的首要地位之间的连续性。在这两种情况下，基督教金融都被视为受到其犹太起源的玷污。相比之下，孟德斯鸠对这一传说的重新塑造假定了中世纪时期与欧洲历史上的一个新阶段之间的急剧断裂，在这一时期，贸易和放贷等被鄙视的活动被理解为犹太人的特权，该阶段位于哥伦布和瓦斯科·达伽马的越洋航行前后，当时教会从其在政治和社会中的影响力中退缩，商业从统治者的任意权力中获得独立并受到尊重。

Although the social theorists whose work I examine here never mentioned Montesquieu, they replicated his view of the Middle Ages as a time of economic autarky and of the sixteenth century as the beginning of the triumph of commerce as a superior civilizational stage. For all their differences, Marx, Sombart, and Weber agreed that the European economy during the Middle Ages did not meet their respective definitions of modern capitalism (even if Weber’s early work on medieval trade and urban society should lead us to qualify this statement). Different in temperament, political views, and scholarly approaches, all three thinkers experienced the epochal changes of rapid industrialization, mass migration to cities, and the consumerism and pauperism that accompanied these phenomena. The scale and pace of these upheavals were enormous and impressed academics, writers, and artists alike. Most scholars stressed what was new in modern capitalism—whether to praise or to demonize it—more than they dwelled on long-term continuities. The search for origins was part and parcel of this emphasis on ruptures.

尽管我在此研究的社会理论家们从未提及孟德斯鸠，但他们复制了他的观点，即中世纪是一个经济自给自足的时代，而 16 世纪是商业作为高级文明阶段的胜利的开始。尽管他们有种种分歧，但马克思、桑巴特和韦伯都认为，中世纪的欧洲经济并不符合他们各自对现代资本主义的定义（即使韦伯关于中世纪贸易和城市社会的早期工作应使我们对这一说法加以限定）。三位思想家的气质、政治观点和学术方法各不相同，但他们都经历了快速工业化、大规模向城市移民以及伴随这些现象而来的消费主义和贫穷主义的划时代变化。这些动荡的规模和速度是巨大的，给学者、作家和艺术家都留下了深刻印象。大多数学者强调了现代资本主义的新内容 —— 无论是赞美还是妖魔化 —— 而不是纠缠于长期的连续性。对起源的探索是这种强调断裂的一部分。

Sombart parted ways with the general trend among both Christian and Jewish scholars by focusing not on medieval moneylenders but on Jewish merchants of the sixteenth century, and those of Iberian descent in particular. In keeping with his focus on the Western Sephardic diaspora, he provided a new iteration and date for the supposed Jewish invention not of bills of exchange tout court , but of endorsable bills, which had come to circulate more widely because they passed from one holder to the next (chapter 1 ). Sombart turned that Jewish invention into a cornerstone of his narrative about the nexus between Jews and modern capitalism. His portrayal of the international webs of Sephardic trade and finance, however, was not a tribute to Jews’ ability to integrate into a diverse commercial society and contribute to its expansion. Instead, his account mixed an outsized celebration of Sephardic commerce with a conservative disdain for capitalism that went beyond the nostalgia of widespread antimodernist positions. Read against the turn toward ethno-nationalism and the social strife of Wilhelmine Germany, his argument about Jews and captialism contained a more menacing message.

Sombart 与基督教和犹太学者的普遍趋势分道扬镳，他不关注中世纪的放债人，而是关注 16 世纪的犹太，特别是那些伊比利亚血统的商人。为了与他对西方塞法尔人散居地的关注保持一致，他为所谓的犹太人发明的汇票提供了一个新的版本和日期，这些汇票不是在法庭上的，而是可背书的，因为它们从一个持有人传到另一个持有人，所以流通更广泛（第一章）。桑巴特把这个犹太发明变成了他关于犹太人和现代资本主义之间关系的叙述的基石。然而，他对塞法尔人贸易和金融的国际网络的描述，并不是对犹太人融入多元化商业社会并为其扩张做出贡献的能力的赞美。相反，他的叙述将对塞法尔人商业的夸张赞美与对资本主义的保守蔑视混为一谈，而这种蔑视已经超出了普遍的反现代主义立场的怀旧情绪。在向民族主义转变和威廉德国的社会纷争的背景下，他关于犹太人和资本主义的论点包含了一个更加危险的信息。

This point leads me to the last major issue with which I have been wrestling throughout this book: the relationship between the discursive representations of Jews and commerce by various authors on the one hand and the immediate historical circumstances in which those representations took shape on the other. I started by describing in detail the financial mechanisms underpinning bills of exchange and marine insurance in order to reveal the precise mixture of admiration and backlash that these instruments engendered when they were still relatively new (chapters 1 –3 ). I then situated the emergence and evolution of the tale attributing to Jews the invention of bills of exchange in relation to the social and political tensions that characterized Old Regime France, through the Revolution and beyond (chapters 4 –6 ). Similarly, in mapping the legend’s diffusion across Europe from the mid-seventeenth to late eighteenth centuries, I examined the intellectual and material environments in which that tale was received, challenged, or rejected (chapter 7 ). I cannot provide an equally granular description of the historical contexts in which the grand theories we have inherited from Marx, Sombart, and Weber came into being, but I will hint at the extent to which contemporary events, including rising nationalism and authoritarianism, the politics of antisemitism, racial theories, and Zionism, mapped onto scholarly pursuits concerning the history and definition of modern capitalism.

这一点让我想到了我在本书中一直纠结的最后一个主要问题：一方面是不同作者对犹太人和商业的话语表述，另一方面是这些表述形成的直接历史环境之间的关系。我首先详细描述了支撑汇票和海事保险的金融机制，以揭示这些工具在相对较新的时候所引起的钦佩和反感的精确混合（第 1-3章）。然后，我将把汇票的发明归功于犹太人的故事的出现和演变与法国旧制度下的社会和政治紧张局势联系起来，直到大革命及其后（第4-6章）。同样，在描绘这个传说从十七世纪中叶到十八世纪末在欧洲的传播过程中，我研究了这个传说被接受、挑战或拒绝的知识和物质环境（第七章）。我无法对我们从马克思、桑巴特和韦伯那里继承的宏大理论产生的历史背景进行同样细致的描述，但我将暗示当代事件的程度，包括不断上升的民族主义和独裁主义、反犹太主义政治、种族理论和犹太复国主义，与有关现代资本主义历史和定义的学术追求相吻合。

Emancipation is commonly recognized as the dividing line between the period we have examined up to this point and the historical backdrop to this chapter. In each European country, emancipation during the nineteenth century was a process rather than an event. During Marx’s youth, the legal equality of Jewish men in Prussia was still a matter of dispute. Between 1867 and 1871, however, most restrictions on Jews’ rights to residence, professional practice, and real estate ownership were lifted, at least on paper, across the German Empire. In other words, by the time Weber and Sombart wrote about Jews, the legal equality of male Jewish citizens had been inscribed into law. This legal revolution was a major stepping-stone toward a more equal society. Curiously, while it marked a profound break from the social and political structures of the Old Regime, emancipation also prolonged and transformed anxieties that had once been associated with a diametrically opposed measure, namely, forced baptism. The majority-Christian population feared that recent converts and newly emancipated Jews, although formally embracing the rules of their new fellowship, harbored a secret desire (as well as the power) to undermine the community that they had joined. The fear that former Jews continued to adhere to their ancient beliefs and allegiances after being baptized had been particularly acute in those regions of early modern Europe, including Iberia and southwestern France, where forced conversions were a fact of life. Under new guises, in those areas where emancipation erased most legal barriers between Jews and Christians, the view of Jewish citizens as a “fifth column” fueled new theories about the proper place that Jews should be assigned in delineating the historical trajectory of Western civilization.

解放被普遍认为是我们到目前为止所研究的时期与本章历史背景的分界线。在每个欧洲国家，19 世纪的解放，是一个过程而不是一个事件。在马克思的青年时代，普鲁士的犹太男子在法律上的平等仍然是一个争议问题。然而，在 1867 年至 1871 年期间，整个德意志帝国对犹太人的居住权、职业实践和房地产所有权的大部分限制都被取消了，至少在纸面上是这样。换句话说，在韦伯和桑巴特写下关于犹太人的文章时，男性犹太公民的法律平等已经被写入法律。这场法律革命是迈向更平等社会的一个重要步骤。奇怪的是，虽然它标志着与旧制度的社会和政治结构的深刻决裂，但解放也延长和改变了曾经与一种截然相反的措施，即强迫洗礼有关的焦虑。信奉基督教的大多数人担心，最近皈依的犹太人和新解放的犹太人，虽然在形式上接受了他们的新团契的规则，但却暗藏着破坏他们所加入的团体的愿望（以及权力）。在现代欧洲早期的那些地区，包括伊比利亚和法国西南部，对前犹太人在受洗后继续坚持其古老信仰和效忠的担心尤为严重，在那里，强迫皈依是生活中的一个事实。在新的伪装下，在那些解放消除了犹太人和基督徒之间大多数法律障碍的地区，将犹太公民视为 “第五纵队” 的观点助长了关于犹太人在划定西方文明的历史轨迹时应被赋予的适当位置的新理论。

Marx, Sombart, and Weber

马克思、桑巴特和韦伯

In the fall of 1843, at age twenty-five, Marx penned a review of two pieces on the so-called Jewish question that the atheist theologian and radical Young Hegelian Bruno Bauer had just published. In so doing, he joined a lively public debate on the subject. Bauer had challenged the Prussian Liberal Party, which demanded legal parity for Jews, by arguing that as long as Prussia remained a Christian state, Jews would always be second-class citizens, even if they were relieved of all legal disabilities. In support of his argument, Bauer had pointed to the French example: there, citizenship rights had not helped Jews improve their general conditions after 1790–1791, and in any case, religious discrimination had not been eradicated.7 Marx agreed on this point but went further. For him, the 1789 Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen equated “the rights of man” with political rights, said nothing about social rights, and merely ushered in a new property regime from which all other rights derived. “The practical application of the right of man to freedom is the right of man to private property ,” he wrote. “Therefore, not one of the so-called rights of man goes beyond the egotistic man, . . . namely an individual withdrawn into himself, his private interest and his private desires and separated from the community.”8

1843 年秋天，25 岁的马克思对无神论神学家和激进的青年黑格尔主义者布鲁诺·鲍尔刚刚发表的两篇关于所谓犹太人问题的文章撰写了评论。这样一来，他加入了一场关于这个问题的热烈的公开辩论。鲍尔对普鲁士自由党提出挑战，该党要求在法律上对犹太人一视同仁，认为只要普鲁士仍然是一个基督教国家，犹太人就永远是二等公民，即使他们被解除了所有的法律障碍。为了支持他的论点，鲍尔指出了法国的例子：在那里，公民权并没有帮助犹太人在 1790-1791 年后改善他们的总体状况，而且无论如何，宗教歧视并没有被根除。7马克思同意这一点，但更进一步。对他来说，1789 年的《人和公民的权利宣言》将 “人的权利” 等同于政治权利，对社会权利只字不提，而且只是开创了一个新的财产制度，所有其他权利都源于此。“人的自由权利的实际应用是人的私有财产权利”，他写道。“因此，没有一项所谓的人的权利超越了自我主义的人，…… 即一个人撤回到他自己、他的私人利益和他的私人欲望中，并与社会分离。8

Read alongside his “Critique of Hegel’s Doctrine of the State,” completed just a month or two earlier, “On the Jewish Question” (1844) was an early articulation of Marx’s conception of private property as the fundamental logic that animates modern civil society. By focusing on the so-called Jewish question, it elaborated a “criticism of the political state” and tackled the “relationship of political emancipation to human emancipation.”9 Even a fully secular (i.e., non-Christian) republican state, Marx reasoned, could not protect its citizens from the power of money. Even once property qualifications for voting were lifted, private property, occupation, and education would still define social relations. To counter these forces, Marx famously demanded not the political emancipation of Jews, but “the emancipation of society from Judaism,” in the sense of mankind’s emancipation “from haggling and from money.”10 Jews stood in for what Marx would later call “the cash nexus”; they represented the “anti-social element” that, he claimed, had by then reached its historical peak.11

与仅在一两个月前完成的《黑格尔国家学说批判》一起阅读，《论犹太人问题》（1844）很早就阐明了马克思关于私有财产是激励现代公民社会的基本逻辑的概念。通过关注所谓的犹太人问题，它阐述了 “对政治国家的批评”，并解决了 “政治解放与人类解放的关系”。9马克思认为，即使是一个完全世俗化（即非基督教）的共和制国家，也无法保护其公民不受金钱的影响。即使取消了投票的财产资格，私有财产、职业和教育仍将界定社会关系。为了对抗这些力量，马克思著名的要求不是犹太人的政治解放，而是 “社会从犹太教中解放出来”，在人类 “从讨价还价和金钱中解放出来” 的意义上。10犹太人代表了马克思后来所说的 “现金纽带”；他们代表了 “反社会因素”，他声称，这种因素在当时已经达到了历史的顶峰。11

In Marx’s conception, Jews worshiped the bill of exchange; they did not invent it. The difference should not go unnoticed. By making Judaism a synecdoche of humanity (a humanity incessantly occupied by buying, selling, bartering, and hustling), Marx treaded waters all too familiar, identifying Jewish usury as an attribute of both Jews and non-Jews and accusing Christian merchants of behaving like Jews in order to denounce their crookedness. But Marx also departed from this trope in a remarkable way. Rather than identifying Jewishness as a marker of certain flawed individuals, groups, or economic techniques, he presented the Judaization of (Christian) society as a process that was now completed: “The practical Jewish spirit has become the practical spirit of the Christian people,” he wrote—or, in other words, all “Christians have become Jews,” not only some of them.12

在马克思的概念中，犹太人崇拜汇票；他们并没有发明汇票。这个区别不应该被忽视。通过使犹太教成为人类的代名词（一个不断被购买、销售、易货贸易和拉客占据的人类），马克思踏上了太熟悉的水域，将犹太人的高利贷确定为犹太人和非犹太人的属性，并指责基督教商人的行为像犹太人，以谴责他们的歪曲。但马克思也以一种非凡的方式偏离了这个套路。他没有把犹太性确定为某些有缺陷的个人、团体或经济技术的标志，而是把（基督教）社会的犹太化作为一个已经完成的过程。他写道：“实用的犹太精神已经成为基督教徒的实用精神”，或者换句话说，所有 “基督徒已经成为犹太人”，而不仅仅是其中的一部分。12

A quick comparison of Marx’s notion that greed had become an inescapable social condition affecting everyone with more traditional views of Jewish usury as depicted by Honoré de Balzac in those same years brings the difference between the two into relief. One of the Jewish characters in Balzac’s La comédie humaine , Gobseck, a “banknote man” (homme-billet ), is an aged and clever usurer born in Antwerp around 1740 and living in Paris during the Restoration. Gobseck is not without qualities, but he has little regard for his fellow human beings (“If humanity, if sociability were a religion, he could be considered an atheist,” Balzac wrote). Unlike Shylock, the anachronistic pawnbroker of sixteenth-century Venice, Gobseck speculates on bills of exchange (many signed by women, another sign of the lamentable expansion of commercial society). He also belongs to a conspiratorial clique:

将马克思关于贪婪已成为影响每个人的不可避免的社会条件的观点与同年奥诺雷·德·巴尔扎克所描述的关于犹太人高利贷的更传统的观点进行简单的比较，就会发现两者之间的差异。巴尔扎克的《人类喜剧》中的一个犹太人物戈伯克（Gobseck），一个 “钞票人”（homme-billet），是一个年老而聪明的高利贷者，1740 年左右出生在安特卫普，复辟时期生活在巴黎。戈伯克并非没有品质，但他对他的同胞却不屑一顾（“如果人性，如果社交是一种宗教，他可以被认为是无神论者”，巴尔扎克写道）。与十六世纪威尼斯不合时宜的典当商夏洛克不同，高布克投机于汇票（许多汇票由妇女签署，这是商业社会可悲扩张的另一个标志）。他还属于一个阴谋家的集团。

There are a dozen of us here in Paris, all silent unknown kings, the arbiters of your destinies . . . we meet on certain days of the week at Café Thémis, by the Pont Neuf. There, we uncover the mysteries of finance. There is no fortune that can keep the truth from us; we know every family’s secrets. We keep a kind of black book where we track the most important bills issued and redeemed, drafts on the public credit system, on the bank, in trade.13

我们在巴黎有十几个人，都是默默无闻的国王，是你们命运的仲裁者…… 我们每周有几天在新桥边的泰米斯咖啡厅聚会。在那里，我们揭开金融的神秘面纱。没有什么财富能瞒得过我们；我们知道每个家庭的秘密。我们保存着一本黑皮书，在那里我们追踪最重要的票据的发行和赎回，公共信贷系统的汇票，银行的汇票，贸易的汇票。13

In short, Balzac’s Jewish moneylender and sly financier lives on the margins of Christian society, whose resources he is ready to siphon off in collusion with other Jews. Not so Marx’s Jews: they were understood to represent society in its totality. That is why there was no room in Marx’s work for the narrative of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange as we have come to know it, because in whatever version, that tale implied an initial separation between, rather than a convergence of, Jews and Christians. Jews bequeathed to non-Jews a financial innovation, and only after they adopted that innovation did Christian merchants become either potential “Judaizers” (as per Cleirac) or individuals able to use those bills to rein in the despot (according to Montesquieu). For Marx, instead, all of Christian capitalist society was “Jewish” from the start. Bills of exchange were Jews’ only real god in the sense that they were everyone’s only real god.

简而言之，巴尔扎克的犹太放债人和狡猾的金融家生活在基督教社会的边缘，他准备与其他犹太人勾结，抽走其资源。马克思的犹太人则不然：他们被理解为代表社会的整体。这就是为什么在马克思的作品中没有空间来叙述我们所知道的犹太人发明汇票的故事，因为无论什么版本，这个故事意味着犹太人和基督徒之间最初的分离，而不是融合。犹太人给非犹太人留下了一项金融创新，而只有在他们采用了这项创新之后，基督教商人才成为潜在的 “犹太化者”（按照克莱拉克的说法）或能够利用这些票据来控制暴君的个人（按照孟德斯鸠的说法）。相反，对马克思来说，所有的基督教资本主义社会从一开始就是 “犹太的”。汇票是犹太人唯一真正的神，因为它们是每个人唯一真正的神。

Marx’s identification of Jews with capitalism did not raise eyebrows then as it did later, when his antisemitic imagery (“Money is the jealous god of Israel”; “The chimerical nationality of the Jew is the nationality of the merchant”) generated no shortage of puzzlement, mistrust, and even revulsion among his readers.14 It is impossible to pinpoint a single source of influence on Marx’s choice of the injurious language of economic antisemitism as a tool of critique. That language permeated the contemporary political discourse of both the Left and the Right. His readings of Hegel and Feuerbach made Marx arguably better versed in Christian than Jewish thought. His biography, too, certainly played a part and has been used either to exculpate him or to depict him as a self-hating Jew who provided ammunition to the enemies of Jews for generations to come.

马克思将犹太人与资本主义相提并论在当时并没有像后来那样引起人们的注意，当时他的反犹太主义意象（“金钱是以色列的嫉妒之神”；“犹太人的嵌合国籍是商人的国籍”）在他的读者中产生了不小的困惑、不信任，甚至反感。14对于马克思选择经济反犹太主义的伤害性语言作为批判的工具，不可能找出一个单一的影响来源。这种语言渗透在当代左派和右派的政治话语中。他对黑格尔和费尔巴哈的阅读使马克思可以说更精通基督教思想而不是犹太教思想。他的传记也肯定起到了一定的作用，并被用来为他开脱罪责，或将他描绘成一个自我憎恨的犹太人，为犹太人的敌人提供弹药，世代如此。

Born of Jewish parents, Marx was baptized shortly after his father and not long before his mother, while both his paternal grandfather and uncle were rabbis in his native Trier. He grew up a Lutheran, a member of the reformed German Evangelical Church, the confession of Prussian rulers, in the predominantly Catholic region of the Rhineland, just after Prussia wrested it from Napoleon in 1814. Trier, on the Moselle River, was less than fifty miles from Thionville, where in 1775 Pierre-Louis Lacretelle launched the first campaign for Jewish emancipation (chapter 6 ). Ruled by France from 1795 to 1814, the left bank of the Rhine was the easternmost region to experience the Revolution’s repercussions: its largely impoverished Jewish population was emancipated, subjected to new restrictions under Napoleon, and perpetually resented by the no less disadvantaged Catholic majority that was often indebted to Jewish moneylenders. We can only speculate about the impact that these circumstances had on the young Marx.15 What is certain is that, unlike contemporary socialist antisemitic writings, chief among them Alphone Toussenel’s Les juifs, rois de l’époque (The Jews, Kings of the Time ), Marx’s work eschewed historical Jews and Judaism in favor of a metaphorical invocation of both.16

马克思的父母是犹太人，他在父亲之后不久受洗，在母亲之前不久受洗，而他的祖父和叔叔都是他家乡特里尔的拉比。他从小就是路德教派，是普鲁士统治者承认的改革派德国福音教会的成员，在以天主教为主的莱茵兰地区长大，当时普鲁士刚在 1814 年从拿破仑手中夺回莱茵兰。特里尔位于摩泽尔河上，距离蒂永维尔不到 50 英里，1775 年皮埃尔·路易·拉克雷泰尔在那里发起了第一次解放犹太人的运动（第 6 章）。从 1795 年到 1814 年被法国统治的莱茵河左岸是经历大革命影响的最东部地区：其大部分贫困的犹太人被解放，在拿破仑统治下受到新的限制，并长期受到同样处于弱势的天主教徒的不满，他们经常欠下犹太放债人的钱。我们只能猜测这些情况对年轻的马克思的影响。15可以肯定的是，与当代社会主义反犹太主义著作不同，其中最主要的是阿尔芬·图塞内尔的《犹太人，时代的国王》，马克思的作品避开了历史上的犹太人和犹太教，而对两者进行隐喻性的援引。16

For reasons that Marx never elucidated, he soon relinquished the equation of Jews and capitalism.17 In its place, he put history into the service of theory in order to outline the transition from feudalism to capitalism in Europe’s past, with a focus on England. His evolutionary conception of history was reminiscent of the Enlightenment’s stadial theory insofar as it regarded urbanization and foreign trade as the two engines of the transformation of what Adam Smith called “the age of agriculture” into the “age of commerce.” Yet Marx differed from Smith not only in his insistence on land as a source of primitive accumulation but also in his belief that “the age of commerce” was neither the pinnacle of civilization nor its endgame. Whereas for Smith, “commerce and manufactures gradually introduced order and good government, and with them, the liberty and security of individuals,” Marx believed that capitalism negates individuals’ freedom.18 Adapting the Hegelian dialectic to his theories, he transcended the thesis and antithesis of feudalism and capitalism with a new synthesis: socialism. In both Smith and Marx, the historical chronology was hazy, but the sixteenth century was identified as the definite turning point. In the first volume of Capital , Marx maintained that “trading nations,” which included the Jews, “exist[ed] in the ancient world only in its interstices,” while “the modern history of capital dates from the creation in the 16th century of a world-embracing commerce and a world-embracing market.”19

由于马克思从未阐明的原因，他很快就放弃了将犹太人和资本主义等同起来的做法。17取而代之的是，他让历史为理论服务，以概述欧洲过去从封建主义向资本主义的过渡，重点是英国。他的历史进化概念让人想起启蒙运动的阶段性理论，因为它将城市化和对外贸易视为亚当·斯密所谓的 “农业时代” 向 “商业时代” 转变的两个引擎。然而，马克思与斯密不同的是，他不仅坚持把土地作为原始积累的来源，而且认为 “商业时代” 既不是文明的顶峰，也不是文明的终结。在斯密看来，“商业和制造业逐渐引入了秩序和良好的政府，并随之引入了个人的自由和安全”，而马克思认为，资本主义否定了个人的自由。18他将黑格尔的辩证法运用到他的理论中，用一个新的综合体超越了封建主义和资本主义的理论和对立面：社会主义。在斯密和马克思那里，历史年表都是模糊的，但十六世纪被确定为明确的转折点。在《资本论》第一卷中，马克思认为，包括犹太人在内的 “贸易民族”，“在古代世界只存在于它的夹缝中”，而“资本的现代史可以追溯到 16 世纪创造的包容世界的商业和包容世界的市场。”19

Although Sombart and Weber rejected Marx’s materialist explanation for the rise of modern capitalism, they both retained his basic chronology dating the causal forces that unleashed capitalism to the sixteenth century. Weber focused on the Reformation and Sombart insisted on depicting the Middle Ages as precapitalist.20 Jewish history played a role in both authors’ conceptualizations of modern capitalism—a famously central role in Sombart’s and as an important counterexample in Weber’s. In fact, while on the surface their respective interpretations of Jews’ economic roles throughout history appear antithetical, on closer scrutiny, they can be seen to share important traits.

虽然桑巴特和韦伯拒绝了马克思对现代资本主义崛起的唯物主义解释，但他们都保留了马克思的基本年表，将释放资本主义的因果力量追溯到 16 世纪。韦伯专注于宗教改革，而桑巴特则坚持将中世纪描述为前资本主义时期。20犹太历史在两位作者对现代资本主义的概念化中都发挥了作用 —— 在桑巴特的概念中是著名的核心作用，而在韦伯的概念中则是重要的反例。事实上，虽然从表面上看，他们各自对犹太人在历史上的经济作用的解释似乎是对立的，但仔细观察，可以发现他们有共同的重要特征。

Both Weber and Sombart absorbed Roscher’s portrait of the medieval economy, and Sombart took more than a cue from Roscher’s depiction of Jews as the driving force behind the development of Western capitalism. Often referred to as the father of the German Historical School, Roscher exerted enormous influence on German academia through his writings and his students, notably Gustav von Schmoller (1838–1917). In a landmark 1875 essay, he proposed a simple thesis: “Among the Germanic peoples the Jews were better treated during the earlier than the later Middle Ages” (with the Black Death as the rough cutoff date). For Roscher, in the earlier period, Jews were the only ones “carrying on a professional trade in goods”; for several centuries, they were thus “the commercial guardians of the young nations,” that is, of medieval Christian powers. “The Jewish persecutions of the later Middle Ages,” he continued, “are in large measure a product of trade jealousy.”21

韦伯和桑巴特都吸收了罗舍尔对中世纪经济的描述，而桑巴特则更多地从罗舍尔对犹太人作为西方资本主义发展动力的描述中得到启发。罗舍尔通常被称为德国历史学派之父，他通过自己的著作和他的学生，特别是古斯塔夫·冯·施摩勒（1838-1917），对德国学术界产生了巨大影响。在 1875 年一篇具有里程碑意义的文章中，他提出了一个简单的论点：“在日耳曼民族中，犹太人在中世纪早期的待遇要好于中世纪后期”（以黑死病为大致分界线）。在罗舍尔看来，在早期，犹太人是唯一 “从事专业商品贸易” 的人；几个世纪以来，他们因此成为 “年轻国家的商业守护者”，即中世纪基督教国家的守护者。“中世纪后期对犹太人的迫害”，他继续说，“在很大程度上是贸易嫉妒的产物。”21

What made “the young nations” feel they could turn against their economic benefactors without committing suicide? Roscher explained that medieval Jews introduced three innovations, and once Christians learned to handle them, they were free to rid themselves of their teachers. These “three important steps of economic progress” devised by medieval Jews were “the introduction of interest on capital,” “the protection of the possessor of an object illegally alienated but taken into possession in good faith by the receiver” (e.g., the full negotiability of stolen cash, as long as the receiver was unaware of its illicit provenance), and “the invention of bills of exchange.”22

是什么让 “年轻的国家” 觉得他们可以反对他们的经济恩人而不至于自杀？罗舍尔解释说，中世纪的犹太人引入了三项创新，而一旦基督徒学会了处理这些创新，他们就可以自由地摆脱他们的老师了。中世纪犹太人设计的这 “经济进步的三个重要步骤” 是：“引入资本利息”，“保护非法转让但被接收者善意占有的物品的拥有者”（例如，只要接收者不知道其非法来源，被盗现金完全可以流通），以及 “发明汇票”。22

As was usual at the time, footnotes in Roscher’s article were sparse.23 It is therefore impossible to trace exactly how the legend that first appeared in the pages of Cleirac’s Us et coustumes de la mer in 1647 made its way into this text of the last quarter of the nineteenth century. To be sure, Roscher’s interpretation of the alleged invention of bills of exchange by Jews was antithetical to Montesquieu’s and closer to Friedrich Christoph Jonathan Fischer’s rendition of the legend (chapter 7 ). While in The Spirit of the Laws Christian nations were depicted as putting the Jewish invention to such good use that commerce bettered social and political relations for everyone, in Roscher’s account Christians’ appropriation of the same Jewish invention inspired “jealousy” toward those who devised it, leading to antisemitic hatred and persecution.

按照当时的惯例，罗舍尔的文章中的脚注很少。（23因此，我们不可能准确地追踪 1647 年首次出现在克莱拉克的《海洋的用途和习俗》中的传说是如何进入 19 世纪最后 25 年的这一文本的。可以肯定的是，罗舍尔对所谓犹太人发明汇票的解释与 Montesquieu 的解释相反，而更接近于弗里德里希·克里斯托夫·乔纳森·费舍尔对这个传说的演绎第 7 章）。在《法律的精神》中，基督教国家被描述为将犹太人的发明发挥得淋漓尽致，商业为每个人改善了社会和政治关系，而在罗舍尔的描述中，基督徒对同一犹太发明的占有激发了对设计者的 “嫉妒”，导致了反犹太主义的仇恨和迫害。

Sombart absorbed this lesson. As in Roscher’s essay, the association between Jews and bills of exchange figured prominently in his 1911 The Jews and Economic Life . For modern capitalism to emerge, Sombart noted in a core chapter of the book, credit had to evolve “from being a personal matter into one of an impersonal relationship,” a historical evolution that occurred once stocks and securities became tradable and payments began to be made in banknotes. In all the stages that accompanied this development, he wrote, “the Jew was ever present with his creative genius.”24 Through a series of distorted citations and ludicrous statements (often rhetorically phrased as inferences but meant as assertions), Sombart proceeded to enumerate instances in which Jews had been the protagonists of all Europe’s private and public financial innovations. His treatment of bills of exchange encapsulated the two horns of his argument: Jews brought capitalism to its mature form during the sixteenth century, but they had been merchants since antiquity and personified commerce throughout the ages. The reason for this long-term specialization in trade resided in Judaism itself, which Sombart described as having a contractual and legalistic conception of the relationship between humans and the divine, a conception that preceded Protestantism and was similarly congruent with the calculative logic of capitalism.

桑巴特吸收了这个教训。与罗舍尔的文章一样，犹太人与汇票之间的联系在他 1911 年的《犹太人与经济生活》中占据了重要地位。桑巴特在该书的一个核心章节中指出，为了使现代资本主义出现，信贷必须 “从个人事务演变为非个人关系”，一旦股票和证券变得可以交易，并开始用纸币付款，就会出现这种历史演变。他写道，在伴随着这一发展的所有阶段中，“犹太人以其创造性的天才永远存在”。24通过一系列歪曲的引文和可笑的陈述（往往是修辞上的推论，但意思是断言），桑巴特继续列举犹太人是所有欧洲私人和公共金融创新的主角的例子。他对汇票的处理概括了他论点的两个方面。犹太人在十六世纪将资本主义带到了它的成熟形式，但他们自古以来就是商人，并在整个时代将商业化。这种长期的贸易专业化的原因在于犹太教本身，Sombart 将其描述为对人与神的关系有一种契约和法律主义的概念，这种概念先于新教，同样与资本主义的计算逻辑相吻合。

By the time Sombart wrote The Jews and Economic Life , a number of scholars, including the towering German specialist of commercial law Levin Goldschmidt (1828–1897), had rejected the possibility that Jews might have invented bills of exchange and argued instead that those bills were the product of a slow evolution of the legal and financial systems.25 In a formulation typical of his reasoning, Sombart claimed that these scholars “do not render testimony strong enough for the statement that the Jews were not the inventors of bills” during the Middle Ages.26 His real subject, he added, was “the modern endorsable bill” rather than the simple four-party bill of medieval derivation. Noting that Goldschmidt had traced the origins of negotiable bills of exchange to sixteenth-century Venice and that a reference to bills in general was made in a petition addressed by Christian merchants to the Venetian Republic in 1550, when the government was discussing the possibility of expelling crypto-Jews from the city, Sombart concluded: “It is fairly certain that the use of circulating endorsable bills in Venice must have been first commenced by Jews.”27 The logic exceeded the evidence in a way that was characteristic of the entire book’s argumentative style. A reviewer at the time derided the faulty syllogism underlying this logic: banking was highly developed in Venice; sixteenth-century Venice housed a sizable Jewish community; therefore, Jews invented banking.28

当桑巴特写下《犹太人与经济生活》时，一些学者，包括德国著名的商法专家列文·戈德施密特（1828-1897），已经拒绝了犹太人可能发明了汇票的可能性，而是认为这些汇票是法律和金融体系缓慢演变的产物。25桑巴特以其典型的推理方式声称，这些学者 “没有为犹太人不是中世纪票据的发明者这一说法提供足够有力的证据”。26他补充说，他真正的主题是 “现代可背书票据”，而不是中世纪衍生的简单四方票据。注意到戈尔德施密特将可转让汇票的起源追溯到 16 世纪的威尼斯，以及 1550 年基督教商人向威尼斯共和国提交的一份请愿书中提到了一般的票据，当时政府正在讨论将隐性犹太人驱逐出城市的可能性，Sombart 总结说。“相当肯定的是，在威尼斯使用可背书票据的流通方式一定是由犹太人首先开始的”。27这种逻辑超越了证据，这也是整本书论证风格的特点。当时的一位评论家嘲笑这种逻辑背后的错误三段论：银行业在威尼斯高度发达；16 世纪的威尼斯有一个相当大的犹太社区；因此，犹太人发明了银行业。28

Sombart transplanted Roscher’s tale of the Jewish invention of bills of exchange from late medieval Europe to the sixteenth-century Adriatic, where those bills became negotiable—and thus emblems of the ultimate abstraction of modern capitalism—before migrating to Holland and across the Atlantic. Not even this inflated historical arc, however, satisfied him. Drawing on biblical and Talmudic citations that specialists immediately demonstrated to be spurious, Sombart went on to state that “modern credit instruments [derived] from Rabbinic law.”29 His argument thus came full circle, fusing the image of the sixteenth-century Jewish capitalist with that of the Jew as the eternal merchant.

桑巴特将罗舍尔关于犹太人发明汇票的故事从中世纪末的欧洲移植到了 16 世纪的亚得里亚海，在那里，这些票据成为可转让的，因此成为现代资本主义最终抽象的象征，然后迁移到荷兰并跨越大西洋。然而，即使是这种夸张的历史弧线，也不能让他满意。桑巴特以圣经和塔木德的引文为依据，专家们立即证明这些引文是虚假的，他接着说，“现代信贷工具源于拉比的法律。”29他的论点因此绕了一圈，将十六世纪犹太资本家的形象与犹太人作为永恒的商人的形象融合在一起。

More preposterous than Roscher’s essay of 1875, The Jews and Economic Life was also more heavily annotated. And more than Roscher, Sombart owed an immense debt to the then-nascent field of academic scholarship on the Jewish past, which he pillaged and distorted. Of the more than 500 bibliographical citations that appeared in its footnotes (in a book that contained 434 pages of text), 83 percent were published after 1850 and 70 percent after 1875 (appendix 7). The majority of these recent publications represented what was then a new phenomenon: the rapid increase in the number and quality of works of Jewish history written by Jewish authors. Sombart relied on Heinrich Graetz’s landmark multivolume History of the Jews more than on any other reference, citing it seventy times.30 The choice was not surprising: Graetz (1817–1891) was indisputably the most renowned Jewish historian of the nineteenth century. But it was also a curious choice, because Graetz, a religious traditionalist, had little to say about the economic life of past Jewish societies and, to the extent that he addressed the topic, emphasized Christian persecution as the cause of Jews’ specialization in moneylending and commerce. That was not Sombart’s view. The Jews and Economic Life stipulated that the expulsions from Iberia in the 1490s catalyzed Jewish capitalist potential, whereas Graetz did not see any progress in the conditions of Jewish life after 1492, and certainly did not celebrate the expansion of Jewish commerce in the sixteenth-century Atlantic. Sombart thus treated Graetz as a repository of information that he could fit into his predetermined scheme. Contrary to anything Graetz would have advocated, he even argued that the “spirit of capitalism” had belonged to the Jews from the start. Espousing the specious notion that “for some twenty centuries the Jews have kept themselves ethnically pure,” Sombart affirmed that their “characteristics were constant” and that Jews had “devoted themselves to trade” throughout their history.31

与罗舍尔 1875 年的文章相比，《犹太人与经济生活》更加荒唐，也有更多的注解。与罗舍尔相比，桑巴特对当时刚刚起步的关于犹太人历史的学术研究领域欠下了巨大的债务，他对这些学术研究进行了掠夺和歪曲。在其脚注中出现的 500 多条书目引用中（在一本包含 434 页文字的书中），83% 是在 1850 年之后出版的，70% 是在 1875 年之后出版的（附录 7）。这些最新的出版物大多代表了当时的一个新现象：由犹太作者撰写的犹太历史作品的数量和质量迅速增加。桑巴特对海因里希·格雷茨（Heinrich Graetz）具有里程碑意义的多卷本《犹太人史》的依赖程度高于其他任何参考文献，共引用了七十次。30这种选择并不令人惊讶。格雷茨（1817-1891）无疑是十九世纪最著名的犹太历史学家。但这也是一个奇怪的选择，因为格雷茨是一个宗教传统主义者，对过去犹太社会的经济生活几乎没有发言权，而且在他谈到这个话题时，强调基督教的迫害是犹太人专门从事放贷和商业的原因。这不是 Sombart 的观点。犹太人和经济生活》规定，14 世纪 90 年代从伊比利亚的驱逐行动催化了犹太人的资本主义潜力，而格雷茨却没有看到 1492 年后犹太人生活条件的任何进步，当然也没有庆祝犹太人商业在 16 世纪大西洋的扩张。因此，桑巴特将格雷茨视为一个信息库，他可以将其纳入自己预定的计划， 。与格雷茨的主张相反，他甚至认为 “资本主义精神” 从一开始就属于犹太人。桑巴特提出了一个似是而非的概念，即 “大约 20 个世纪以来，犹太人一直保持着种族上的纯洁性”，他肯定地说，他们的 “特征是不变的”，犹太人在整个历史上都 “致力于贸易”。31

The treatment of Graetz is telling of how Sombart used the sources he cited. Another of his favorite authors was Meyer Kayserling (1829–1905), a rabbi and prolific amateur historian who wrote with fervor on a great many topics, from Jewish women to Moses Mendelssohn, but turned his attention in particular to Iberian Jews. In Kayserling’s work Sombart encountered claims he subsequently made his: that the fortunes seized from Jews had financed Christopher Columbus’s Atlantic voyages and that forcibly converted Jews (“Marranos”) had flocked to the Americas, where they came to dominate trade.32 In the nineteenth century, cultivated German Jews admired the literary, aesthetic, and philosophical achievements of their ancestors in medieval Iberia, whom they regarded as antithetical to the inward-looking, uncultivated, Yiddish-speaking eastern European Jews who surrounded them. Kayserling’s work was part cause and part effect of this “allure of the Sephardic,” whose idealization of the harmonious relations among Jews, Christians, and Muslims in pre-1492 Iberia was a measure of elite German Jews’ desire to assimilate while retaining their identity.33 Sombart absorbed this cultural trend and turned it on its head: against the consensus that the Iberian “golden age” ended in 1492, he exalted sixteenth-century Sephardic Jews, a group scorned by Orthodox Jews for having converted (albeit under pressure) and thus unlikely heroes of Jewish history. His exaltation obviously was not meant to restore the greatness of Western Sephardim and in fact represented a distorting caricature of it.

对格雷茨的处理说明了桑巴特如何使用他所引用的资料来源。他最喜欢的另一位作者是迈耶·凯瑟林（Meyer Kayserling，1829-1905），他是一位拉比和多产的业余历史学家，他热衷于写许多主题，从犹太妇女到摩西·门德尔松，但他特别关注伊比利亚的犹太人。在凯瑟林的作品中，桑巴特遇到了他后来自己的主张：从犹太人手中夺取的财富为克里斯托弗·哥伦布的大西洋航行提供了资金，被迫皈依的犹太人（“Marranos”）涌向美洲，在那里他们主导了贸易。32在 19 世纪，有教养的德国犹太人钦佩他们在中世纪伊比利亚的祖先的文学、美学和哲学成就，他们认为这些祖先与他们周围那些内向、没有教养、讲意第绪语的东欧犹太人是对立的。凯瑟林的作品是这种 “塞法尔人的诱惑” 的部分原因和部分结果，塞法尔人对 1492 年前伊比利亚地区犹太人、基督徒和穆斯林之间和谐关系的理想化，是德国精英犹太人在保留身份的同时渴望同化的措施。33桑巴特吸收了这一文化趋势，并将其扭转过来：与伊比利亚 “黄金时代” 在 1492 年结束的共识相反，他推崇 16 世纪的塞法尔犹太人，这个群体因皈依（尽管是在压力下）而被正统犹太人蔑视，因此不可能是犹太历史的英雄。他的赞美显然不是为了恢复西方塞法尔迪人的伟大，实际上是对其进行了歪曲的讽刺。

No less telling of Sombart’s attitudes toward his sources is the list of those he did not credit or consult, omissions that cannot be attributed solely to the imprecise citation standards of the time. The list begins with Roscher, who was never mentioned in the book. If his theories were sufficiently known to be recognizable to contemporary readers, the same cannot be said for the Christian anti-Jewish polemicist Johann Andreas Eisenmenger (1654–1704), whom Sombart echoed without explicit acknowledgement.34 With no command of Hebrew, he can be excused for ignoring an intra-Jewish literature absorbed in debating matters of philanthropy and economic solidarity that would have clashed with his views.35 No linguistic barrier, however, separated him from credible Jewish scholarship in German and French that engaged with the economic roles of Jews but did not square with his conclusions; he either discounted this scholarship altogether or treated it as the source of minor details cited out of context.36

体现桑巴特对资料来源的态度的是他未予引用或咨询的名单，这些遗漏不能仅仅归咎于当时不精确的引用标准。这份名单从罗舍尔开始，书中从未提及他。如果说他的理论足以让当代读者认识，那么基督教反犹太论者约翰·安德烈亚斯·艾森曼格（Johann Andreas Eisenmenger，1654-1704）的情况就不一样了，桑巴特在没有明确承认的情况下呼应了他。34由于不懂希伯来语，他可以原谅自己忽略了犹太人内部的文学作品，这些文学作品专注于争论慈善事业和经济团结的问题，而这些问题可能会与他的观点相冲突。35然而，没有语言障碍，他与德文和法文中可信的犹太学术研究隔绝，这些学术研究涉及犹太人的经济角色，但与他的结论不一致；他要么完全不考虑这些学术研究，要么将其视为断章取义的小细节的来源。36

At the very same time, Sombart cherry-picked from abundant midcentury Jewish scholarly and lay publications by liberal and assimilated rabbis and writers, notably Ludwig Philippson (1811–1889), who used “a decidedly triumphalist tone” to celebrate Jews’ successes in commerce in ways that resonated positively among segments of the German bourgeoisie.37 Here and there, this apologetic literature also included proud references to the Jews’ invention of bills of exchange.38

同时，桑巴特还从自由派和被同化的拉比和作家，特别是路德维希·菲利普森（Ludwig Philippson，1811-1889）的大量中世纪犹太学术和非专业出版物中挑选了一些，他们用 “明显的胜利主义语气” 来庆祝犹太人在商业方面的成功，在德国资产阶级中产生了积极的反响。37在这里和那里，这种道歉文学也包括对犹太人发明汇票的自豪提及。38

After the 1873 stock market crash in Germany, however, antisemitism and nationalism were on the rise, and this kind of Jewish liberal triumphalism was no longer viable. The publication of The Jews and Economic Life in 1911 met with strikingly different responses among the German Jewish public, ranging from outraged hostility to enthusiastic embrace. For the most part, liberal Jews were angered by the work, while committed Zionists rejoiced at Sombart’s portrait of the brave new economic man as Jewish.39 Speaking to a large Jewish audience, Eugene Fuchs, leader of the moderate Central Union of German Citizens of Jewish Faith (Centralverein deutscher Staatsbürger jüdischen Glaubens ), which worked for the integration of Jews into German society, denounced Sombart as the most insidious type of antisemite: someone who mixed traditional elements of Jewish hatred with seemingly philosemitic praises. Not only did he fail to convince his audience, which included a group of zealous Zionists, but “the meeting, to Fuchs’ dismay, ended in near riot.”40 Exceeding the expectations of his Jewish admirers, the following year, in 1912, Sombart published a short pamphlet titled Die Zukunft der Juden (The Future of the Jews ), which denied that Jews could assimilate but conceded that they formed a nation of their own—a claim well received by Zionist separatists.41

然而，在 1873 年德国股市崩盘之后，反犹太主义和民族主义正在抬头，这种犹太自由主义的胜利不再可行了。1911 年，《犹太人与经济生活》的出版在德国犹太公众中遇到了惊人的不同反应，从愤怒的敌意到热情的拥护。在大多数情况下，自由派犹太人对该作品感到愤怒，而坚定的犹太复国主义者则对桑巴特将勇敢的新经济人描绘成犹太人而感到高兴。39致力于让犹太人融入德国社会的温和派德国公民犹太信仰中央联盟（Centralverein deutsch Staatsbürger jüdischen Glaubens）的领导人尤金·福克斯（Eugene Fuchs）在对大批犹太观众讲话时，谴责桑巴特是最阴险的反犹太主义者：他将传统的犹太仇恨元素与看似哲学的赞美混为一谈。他不仅没有说服他的听众，其中包括一群狂热的犹太复国主义者，而且 “令富克斯失望的是，会议在近乎骚乱中结束”。40超出他的犹太崇拜者的期望，第二年，即 1912 年，桑巴特出版了一本名为《犹太人的未来》（Die Zukunft der Juden）的简短小册子，其中否认犹太人可以同化，但承认他们形成了一个自己的国家 —— 这一主张受到了犹太复国主义分离主义者的欢迎。41

The reception among Jewish historians was more sober and more sobering. By and large, they were closer to Roscher than to Sombart in their emphasis on persecution as the chief explanation for Jews’ commercial specialization, but their framework could accommodate elements of Sombart’s thesis. Georg Caro (1867–1912) and Ignaz Schipper (1884–1943), the authors of two recent and authoritative large-scale histories of the Jews, paid more attention to the economy than did Graetz. Sombart, however, lifted from these surveys a mere couple of anecdotes to back up his claims and failed to engage with their arguments.42 It fell upon Jewish textual scholars, who were philologists more than historians, to tear apart the building blocks of Sombart’s account by demonstrating the inaccuracy of his biblical and Talmudic citations, beginning with those related to the alleged Jewish invention of bills of exchange, stocks, obligations, and banknotes.43 These damaging criticisms by Jewish textual scholars, however, did not forge a coherent alternative to the narratives offered by either Graetz or Sombart.

犹太历史学家们的看法更加冷静，更加清醒。总的来说，他们在强调迫害是犹太人商业专业化的主要解释方面，更接近于罗舍尔，而不是桑巴特，但他们的框架可以容纳桑巴特理论的内容。乔治·卡罗（Georg Caro，1867-1912）和伊格纳茨·希佩尔（Ignaz Schipper，1884-1943）是最近两部权威的大规模犹太人历史的作者，他们比格雷茨更关注经济问题。然而，桑巴特仅仅从这些调查中提取了几个轶事来支持他的主张，而没有参与他们的论证。42与其说是历史学家，不如说是文字学家的犹太文字学者们，通过证明宋巴特的圣经和塔木德引文的不准确性，将宋巴特的叙述拆开，，首先是那些与所谓犹太人发明汇票、股票、债务和钞票有关的内容。43然而，犹太文本学者的这些破坏性批评并没有为格雷茨或桑巴特的叙述提供一个连贯的替代方案。

That kind of work only appeared later, inspired at least in part by Weber’s very different treatment of Jewish economic history. In his college thesis, completed under Goldschmidt’s supervision, Weber identified legal innovations that had promoted capitalism in the late medieval Italian communes.44 But he never focused on bills of exchange, whose Jewish origin Goldschmidt had contested.45 Weber also soon abandoned the study of Italian communes and is better remembered for the work that he produced in dialogue with Sombart.

这种工作后来才出现，至少部分是受到韦伯对犹太经济史非常不同的处理的启发。在戈尔德施密特指导下完成的大学论文中，韦伯确定了在中世纪后期意大利公社中促进资本主义的法律创新。44但他从未关注过汇票，因为戈德施密特对汇票的犹太起源提出过异议。45韦伯也很快放弃了对意大利公社的研究，人们对他与桑巴特对话的作品印象更深。

It is well known that Sombart’s The Jews and Economic Life was a response to Weber’s The Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism (1904–1905).46 Weber’s Ancient Judaism (1915–1919), in turn, was a response to Sombart’s The Jews and Economic Life . In that work, as well as in the university lectures that he delivered the semester before his death in June 1920 and in the pages later collected in Economy and Society , Weber singled out Jews and Judaism as the opposites of modern capitalism and its spirit (as he defined it). He repeated Roscher’s thesis when he stated that “the first wave of anti-Semitism” at the time of the Crusades was “a symptom of the development of a national commercial class.”47 But he thoroughly rejected the way in which Sombart had spun Roscher’s thesis and specifically the identification of Judaism with the ethics of capitalism. For Weber, Jews possessed loyalty only to other Jews and were thus unable to participate in impersonal market transactions. Introducing the notion of Jews as pariahs and their dual in-group/out-group morality, Weber spoke of Jews’ “voluntary ghetto” as predating “compulsory internment.”48 He then concluded that “since antiquity, Jewish pariah capitalism . . . felt at home in the very forms of state-and booty-capitalism along with pure money usury and trade, precisely what Puritanism abhorred.”49

众所周知，桑巴特的《犹太人与经济生活》是对韦伯《新教伦理与资本主义精神》（1904-1905）的回应。46而韦伯的《古代犹太教》（1915-1919）则是对桑巴特的《犹太人与经济生活》的回应。在那部作品中，以及在他 1920 年 6 月去世前一学期发表的大学演讲中，以及在后来收集的《经济与社会》中，韦伯把犹太人和犹太教作为现代资本主义及其精神（按照他的定义）的对立面。他重复了罗舍尔的论点，他说十字军东征时的 “第一波反犹太主义” 是 “一个民族商业阶级发展的症状”。47但他彻底拒绝了桑巴特对罗舍尔的论述的理解，特别是将犹太教与资本主义伦理相提并论的做法。对韦伯来说，犹太人只对其他犹太人拥有忠诚，因此无法参与非个人化的市场交易。在介绍犹太人作为贱民的概念和他们的群体内/群体外双重道德时，韦伯谈到犹太人的 “自愿犹太区” 早于 “强制拘禁”。48然后他得出结论，“自古以来，犹太人的贱民资本主义…… 在国家和战利品资本主义以及纯粹的货币高利贷和贸易形式中感到自在，这正是清教主义所憎恶的。”49

Weber disagreed with Sombart on several other issues concerning the origins and achievements of Western capitalism. Given his greater textual meticulousness and his rejection of any affinity between Judaism and the spirit of modern capitalism, he made no reference to the alleged Jewish invention of bills of exchange, which both Roscher and Sombart had highlighted. That said, in spite of all the important differences between Weber’s and Sombart’s characterizations of past Jewish economic contributions, the two shared a conception of Judaism as a religion that favored self-segregation—a belief that allowed both of them to downplay persecution and to portray Judaism as exogenous to the arc of Western history. For Weber, modern capitalism was “uniquely Occidental ” and Judaism an “Oriental” religion.50

在有关西方资本主义的起源和成就的其他几个问题上，韦伯与桑巴特意见相左。鉴于他在文本上更加细致，并且拒绝接受犹太教和现代资本主义精神之间的任何亲和力，他没有提到所谓的犹太人发明的汇票，而罗舍尔和桑巴特都强调过这一点。也就是说，尽管韦伯和桑巴特对过去犹太人的经济贡献的描述存在所有重要的差异，但两人对犹太教的概念是相同的，认为它是一种赞成自我隔离的宗教 —— 这种信念使，他们两人都能淡化迫害，并将犹太教描绘成西方历史弧线中的外生事物。对韦伯来说，现代资本主义是 “独特的西方”，而犹太教是 “东方” 宗教。50

The Revolt of the Medievalists

中世纪主义者的反叛

One of the unintended consequences of the heated debates spurred by Weber’s and Sombart’s rival interpretations of the causes of Europe’s economic ascent beginning in the sixteenth century was a call to arms by economic historians of the Middle Ages. The expression “the revolt of the medievalists” was coined by Wallace Ferguson in 1948 to describe the contributions of those scholars who, during the interwar period, had subverted Jacob Burckhardt’s legacy in the study of the Renaissance and proclaimed the twelfth century to be the foundational moment of European civilization.51 In fact, a parallel revolt of other medievalists, different from but not unrelated to the one Ferguson identified, had been underway since 1914, when the Belgian historian Henri Pirenne (1862–1935), objecting to both Sombart and Weber, wrote: “All the essential features of capitalism—individual enterprise, advances on credit, commercial profit, speculation, etc.—are to be found from the twelfth century on, in the city republics of Italy—Venice, Genoa, or Florence.”52 Around the same time, the German Catholic liberal historian Lujo Brentano (1844–1931) not only belittled Sombart’s account but also maintained that the warlike mentality of feudalism and the church during the High Middle Ages were responsible for transforming commerce (which had not disappeared after the fall of Rome) into modern capitalism. In his words, “The beginning of modern capitalism does not date from the Fourth Crusade [1204]; had it not already developed long before, the Fourth Crusade would not have been thinkable.”53

韦伯和桑巴特对 16 世纪开始的欧洲经济崛起原因的对立解释所引发的激烈争论的一个意外后果是，中世纪的经济史学家们发出了武装呼吁。华莱士·弗格森（Wallace Ferguson）在 1948 年创造了 “中世纪主义者的反叛” 这一说法，以描述那些在战时颠覆雅各布·布克哈特在文艺复兴研究中的遗产并宣称 12 世纪是欧洲文明的基础时刻的学者的贡献。51事实上，自 1914 年以来，其他中世纪主义者的平行反叛，与弗格森确定的反叛不同，但并非没有关系，当时比利时历史学家亨利·皮伦（1862-1935）反对桑巴特和韦伯，他写道：“资本主义的所有基本特征 —— 个人企业、信贷垫款、商业利润、投机等 —— 从十二世纪开始，在意大利的城市共和国 —— 威尼斯、热那亚或佛罗伦萨都可以看到。”52大约在同一时期，德国天主教自由主义历史学家卢乔·布伦塔诺（1844-1931）不仅贬低了桑巴特的说法，而且还坚持认为，中世纪高潮时期封建主义和教会的好战心态是将商业（罗马灭亡后并没有消失）转变为现代资本主义的原因。用他的话说，“现代资本主义的开始并不是从第四次十字军东征 1204 开始的；如果它不是在很早以前就已经发展起来，第四次十字军东征就无法想象”。53

Far from being a mere quibble over periodization, the revolt of these medievalists had far-reaching consequences for twentieth-century scholarly debates about the so-called Rise of the West. Until the 1970s, the alternative chronology it proposed for Europe’s economic takeoff had mainstream purchase. Moreover, the Middle Ages that the opponents of Weber and Sombart portrayed as the incubators of Western capitalism were thoroughly Christian; Catholic historians in particular detected in these societies a positive alliance between moral theologians and political elites, between Scholasticism and the ethics of merchant-bankers who were also civic leaders.

这些中世纪学者的反叛远非仅仅是对年代划分的争论，而是对二十世纪学术界关于所谓西方崛起的辩论产生了深远的影响。直到 20 世纪 70 年代，它为欧洲的经济腾飞提出的替代年表一直被主流所接受。此外，被韦伯和桑巴特的反对者描绘为西方资本主义孵化器的中世纪是彻底的基督教；特别是天主教历史学家在这些社会中发现了道德神学家和政治精英之间的积极联盟，以及学术主义和同时也是公民领袖的商人银行家的伦理。

The economic historians of the interwar period who saw capitalism taking shape in the Middle Ages came from a wide political spectrum, but all relegated Jews to the margins of their inquiries, if they discussed them at all. In France, they included anti-Marxists like Henri Sée (1864–1936) and André-E. Sayous (1873–1940), as well as Marxists like Henri Hauser (1866–1946).54 In Italy, a legal-economic school anticipated the early revolt of the medievalists with pioneering studies of medieval commercial law, including several focusing on marine insurance and bills of exchange. Predictably, once they scrutinized archival records in Genoa, Venice, and other Italian medieval cities, these scholars, some of whom, notably Alessandro Lattes (1858–1940) and Arturo Segre (1873–1928), were Jewish, found no trace of a supposed Jewish invention of bills of exchange. More generally, they repudiated the idea that Jews had been key players in medieval international trade and finance.55
